Speaker: NA
Text: Thursday, 27th August, 1959.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Hon. John MCLeay)

Speaker: NA
Text: took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read

Speaker: NA
Text: prayers.

Speaker: Dr EVATT
Text: I wish again to ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister acting for the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: External Affairs a question which he

Speaker: NA
Text: answered in part recently. This matter has

Speaker: NA
Text: been referred to a few times in the last four

Speaker: NA
Text: or five weeks. It concerns the situation

Speaker: NA
Text: in Laos, which seems to have worsened.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for External Affairs, some

Speaker: NA
Text: little time ago, advised the House, in effect,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the best course was for Australia to

Speaker: NA
Text: do nothing. I am not suggesting armed

Speaker: NA
Text: intervention in Laos, but I do suggest that

Speaker: NA
Text: we should use the conciliation processes of

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Nations, particularly the

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Council. If the situation in Laos

Speaker: NA
Text: were to worsen it could cause a very

Speaker: NA
Text: serious disturbance in Indo-China generally

Speaker: NA
Text: and perhaps further afield. Will the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister look at this matter again in the

Speaker: NA
Text: light of developments in the last few days?

Speaker: NA
Text: This is an important matter and Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: -indeed , any nation-ha s the right to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring such matters before either the

Speaker: NA
Text: Security Council or the General Assembly

Speaker: NA
Text: of the United Nations, as the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman knows.

Speaker: Sir GARFIELD BARWICK
Text: A few

Speaker: NA
Text: days ago, in answer to a question, I told

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable gentleman that, having

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to the need to respect the sovereignty

Speaker: NA
Text: and independence of Laos, it was not

Speaker: NA
Text: thought advisable at this stage for Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia to attempt, on its own initiative, to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring the matter before the United Nations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although I did not mention his name, I

Speaker: NA
Text: inferred that Mr Ngon Sananikone had

Speaker: NA
Text: arrived in New York and as I understood-

Speaker: NA
Text: I now know this to be so-wa s having

Speaker: NA
Text: discussions with Mr Hammarskjold, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary-General of the United Nations.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are a number of courses that may

Speaker: NA
Text: be taken in relation to the United Nations,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I know that they are currently being

Speaker: NA
Text: explored by the Secretary-General and Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sananikone. I also know that Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: representative in New York is keeping: in

Speaker: NA
Text: close touch with the situation and, indeed,

Speaker: NA
Text: is having conversations with Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sananikone. The Government feels that

Speaker: NA
Text: this small but important nation of Laos

Speaker: NA
Text: desires to determine as far as possible its

Speaker: NA
Text: own course of action. We would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: respect that desire so long as there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: flare up of activities beyond the borders

Speaker: NA
Text: LAOS. of Laos.

Speaker: NA
Text: DEVELOPMENT OF NORTHERN

Speaker: NA
Text: AUSTRALIA.

Speaker: Mr BROWNE
Text: I should like to ask a

Speaker: NA
Text: question of the Minister representing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for National Development. Can

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister inform the House whether

Speaker: NA
Text: there is in existence a government blue-

Speaker: NA
Text: print for the agricultural and mineral

Speaker: NA
Text: development of the north of Australia or

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the Government envisages any

Speaker: NA
Text: desirable line of progress in this matter? If

Speaker: NA
Text: such a blueprint is in existence, or if the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government envisages any desirable line of

Speaker: NA
Text: progress, will the Minister acknowledge the

Speaker: NA
Text: due importance of the matter by making

Speaker: NA
Text: this information public?

Speaker: Sir GARFIELD BARWICK
Text: Th e Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth, of course, has a great interest

Speaker: NA
Text: in the development of the north of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, but, primarily, the responsibility for

Speaker: NA
Text: this rests on Western Australia in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: the north of that State and on Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of the north of Queensland.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth has evidenced its

Speaker: NA
Text: interest in the matter by its offer of

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£5,000,000 to the Western Australian Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment not so long ago. The develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the Northern Territory is a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: for my colleague, the Minister for Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tories, and I shall refer the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber's question to him. I shall refer the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter generally also to the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: National Development, whom I represent

Speaker: NA
Text: in this House.

Speaker: NA
Text: OVERSEAS' INVESTMENTS IN

Speaker: NA
Text: AUSTRALIA.

Speaker: Mr CAIRNS
Text: I ask the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: a question arising from a question asked

Speaker: NA
Text: fast Tuesday by the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Scullin, the essential part of which was an

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry whether it was this Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: policy to give: preference to companies with

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas shareholdings. The right honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentleman will know, from reference

Speaker: NA
Text: to " Hansard ", that he did not deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: that aspect of the question. I now ask

Speaker: NA
Text: him: Does the federal trade and import

Speaker: NA
Text: policy ensure preference to companies with

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas shareholdings?

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: Th e answer to that

Speaker: NA
Text: question is, " No ".

Speaker: NA
Text: BROADCASTING.

Speaker: Mr HALBERT
Text: I wish to ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: Postmaster-General a question. Is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister aware that a large area in the

Speaker: NA
Text: agricultural districts of Western Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: does not get reasonable radio broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: services; that there are populated areas

Speaker: NA
Text: within 100 miles of Perth where it is not

Speaker: NA
Text: worth while owning a radio set; that only

Speaker: NA
Text: a small proportion of the population can

Speaker: NA
Text: receive an alternative programme from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Broadcasting Commission; and

Speaker: NA
Text: that the residents of not more than 10 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, of my electorate can have the enjoy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of hearing the parliamentary broad-

Speaker: NA
Text: casts or good alternative musical pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: grammes? Does the Minister consider it

Speaker: NA
Text: only reasonable that the country districts

Speaker: NA
Text: of Western Australia should have proper

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasting services before further money

Speaker: NA
Text: is spent on television in the eastern States,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly as broadcasting has been

Speaker: NA
Text: operating in Australia for nearly 36 years?

Speaker: Mr DAVIDSON
Text: I am aware that

Speaker: NA
Text: there are areas in Western Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: ing parts of the honorable member's elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate, in which broadcast reception is not

Speaker: NA
Text: good. Similar conditions prevail in other

Speaker: NA
Text: parts of Australia also. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadcasting Commission and particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Broadcasting Control Board

Speaker: NA
Text: have been investigating this problem for

Speaker: NA
Text: some time, and, over a considerable period,

Speaker: NA
Text: have been doing their best to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcast reception in country areas is im-

Speaker: NA
Text: proved. Last year, an engineer was sent

Speaker: NA
Text: to Western Australia to make a thorough

Speaker: NA
Text: survey of broadcast reception in that State.

Speaker: NA
Text: He returned and made a comprehensive

Speaker: NA
Text: report, which is still under study by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadcasting Control Board for the pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose of determining what further action

Speaker: NA
Text: can be taken to improve reception in the

Speaker: NA
Text: area.

Speaker: NA
Text: In reply to one of the points made by

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member, I point out that

Speaker: NA
Text: improvements are not being delayed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure of money on the extension of

Speaker: NA
Text: television services. The funds available to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Post Office, the Broadcasting Control

Speaker: NA
Text: Board and the Australian Broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission for the extension and improve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of radio broadcast services have not

Speaker: NA
Text: been varied as a result of the development

Speaker: NA
Text: of television.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I have already pointed out, reception

Speaker: NA
Text: in other parts of Australia also needs atten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion from time to time, and we have

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted, as our main policy, one of

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing the power of stations which can

Speaker: NA
Text: provide alternative programmes in country

Speaker: NA
Text: areas. An example of what has already

Speaker: NA
Text: been done in this regard is available at

Speaker: NA
Text: Wagin in Western Australia, where the

Speaker: NA
Text: power of the station was built up about

Speaker: NA
Text: twelve months ago to 50,000 watts.

Speaker: NA
Text: Similar action has been taken at station

Speaker: NA
Text: 4QN, Townsville, and at the station at

Speaker: NA
Text: Grafton in New South Wales. These sta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions are serving large country areas which

Speaker: NA
Text: previously had not enjoyed very good

Speaker: NA
Text: reception. As a result of the building up

Speaker: NA
Text: of their power to 50,000 watts, they are

Speaker: NA
Text: providing a vastly improved service for

Speaker: NA
Text: those areas. This policy will be extended

Speaker: NA
Text: further in Western Australia. I repeat

Speaker: NA
Text: that the power has already been built up at

Speaker: NA
Text: Wagin, and it is intended as a part of our

Speaker: NA
Text: forthcoming programme, but at a date that

Speaker: NA
Text: I cannot specify at present, to increase the

Speaker: NA
Text: includpower of station 6WF to 50,000 watts.

Speaker: NA
Text: EDUCATION.

Speaker: Mr WHTTLAM
Text: I address a question

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Prime Minister. Last March the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable gentleman promised the

Speaker: NA
Text: Premiers that he would set out quite fully

Speaker: NA
Text: and categorically in a letter to each of them

Speaker: NA
Text: his reasons for refusing to set up a joint

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth-State commission into

Speaker: NA
Text: primary, secondary and technical educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I believe that last month he sent

Speaker: NA
Text: letters to them. Meantime, on 21st April,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the House told the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Newcastle that he would

Speaker: NA
Text: inquire whether copies of the letters could

Speaker: NA
Text: be distributed among honorable members.

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 now ask the Prime Minister whether

Speaker: NA
Text: he will table the letters or otherwise make

Speaker: NA
Text: their text available, and in particular

Speaker: NA
Text: whether he will do so before the debate on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Estimates for his department.

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: Th e answer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: question is: " Yes, I will ".

Speaker: NA
Text: TRADE WITH RUSSIA.

Speaker: Mr LUCOCK
Text: Ca n the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade advise the House whether, in view

Speaker: NA
Text: of the re-establishment of diplomatic mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions between Austraha and the Soviet

Speaker: NA
Text: Union, there is any likelihood of increased

Speaker: NA
Text: sales of Australian products to that country?

Speaker: NA
Text: Further, can the Minister comment on

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper speculations that Russian wool-

Speaker: NA
Text: buyers will participate direcdy in the

Speaker: NA
Text: present series of wool auctions?

Speaker: Mr MCEWEN
Text: I am not in a position

Speaker: NA
Text: to answer the question with any precision.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me make it clear that in whatever dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussions took place prior to the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: establishment of diplomatic missions

Speaker: NA
Text: between Australia and the Soviet Union,

Speaker: NA
Text: there was no mention, except perhaps by

Speaker: NA
Text: way of passing reference, to trade. There

Speaker: NA
Text: was certainly none of sufficient significance

Speaker: NA
Text: to bring me into the discussions. The

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of trade, therefore, was not basic to

Speaker: NA
Text: the re-establishment of diplomatic missions.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, the Russians themselves have

Speaker: NA
Text: announced that they are going to re-enter

Speaker: NA
Text: the wool auction room. We have reason

Speaker: NA
Text: to believe that they wish to procure our

Speaker: NA
Text: wool, and it might be reasonable to expect

Speaker: NA
Text: their re-entry into the auction room. I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand also that the Soviet Union will

Speaker: NA
Text: station in Canberra a commercial coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: sellor. If and when that occurs, I have

Speaker: NA
Text: no doubt that we shall achieve a better

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding of the desired commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: relationship between Australia and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet Union. As regards Australia's atti-

Speaker: NA
Text: tude, we have never placed any obstruction

Speaker: NA
Text: in the way of the sale to the Soviet of our

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinary, normal export products, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: foodstuffs and wool.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMONWEALTH PROFESSIONAL

Speaker: NA
Text: OFFICERS.

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: I s the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: aware that the Commissioner for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Snowy Mountains Authority stated recently

Speaker: NA
Text: that difficulty was experienced in obtaining

Speaker: NA
Text: adequate numbers of trained technical

Speaker: NA
Text: people for government projects? Is this

Speaker: NA
Text: the case with other government instrumen-

Speaker: NA
Text: talities and departments, and is it due to

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that higher salaries are paid by

Speaker: NA
Text: private concerns? Does he approve of a

Speaker: NA
Text: statement by the Minister for National

Speaker: NA
Text: Development that it is desirable that

Speaker: NA
Text: private companies should attract govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment-trained personnel from the Bureau of

Speaker: NA
Text: Mineral Resources? Will the right honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentleman examine the matter of the

Speaker: NA
Text: salaries of the qualified professional men

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged in such work, in order to place

Speaker: NA
Text: government departments in a better com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petitive position?

Speaker: Mr MENZIES
Text: 1 did not hear either

Speaker: NA
Text: of the statements that have been referred

Speaker: NA
Text: to by the honorable member. I would be

Speaker: NA
Text: very pleased to find out what was said.

Speaker: NA
Text: PHARMACEUTICAL BENEFITS.

Speaker: Mr KILLEN
Text: M y question is

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed to the Minister for Health. Are

Speaker: NA
Text: there many drugs available only on a

Speaker: NA
Text: doctor's prescription, the dispensing of

Speaker: NA
Text: which would attract charges of less than

Speaker: NA
Text: 5s.? Will the Minister describe the posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of drugs on those prescriptions in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to the Government's current

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals?

Speaker: Dr DONALD CAMERON
Text: I give this

Speaker: NA
Text: as my own impression, because I cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: answer with complete precision: I should

Speaker: NA
Text: think that, of the total number of doctors'

Speaker: NA
Text: prescriptions presented by patients, only a

Speaker: NA
Text: relatively small number could be dispensed

Speaker: NA
Text: by chemists for less than 5s. That does not

Speaker: NA
Text: cover merely single drugs; it covers com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pounded medicines as well. The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman also asks about the effect of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's proposals on prescribing.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is proposed is that the range of drugs

Speaker: NA
Text: at present regarded as pharmaceutical

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits will be greatly increased and will

Speaker: NA
Text: not, in fact, be limited to single drugs, so

Speaker: NA
Text: that a great many prescriptions for which

Speaker: NA
Text: the patient now pays will be brought

Speaker: NA
Text: within the range of pharmaceutical benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: NATURALIZATION.

Speaker: Mr LUCHETTI
Text: I ask the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Territories whether he has given further

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration to granting Australian citizen-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship to people of European-Melanesian

Speaker: NA
Text: mixed blood in the Territory of Papua and

Speaker: NA
Text: New Guinea. If he has done so, what

Speaker: NA
Text: action does he intend to take? Will the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister tell the House what percentage

Speaker: NA
Text: of people of Asian origin, including

Speaker: NA
Text: Chinese, have accepted the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: take out Australian citizenship in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory?

Speaker: Mr HASLUCK
Text: A s a result of the

Speaker: NA
Text: decision of this Government, an oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity was given to certain persons of

Speaker: NA
Text: Asian origin who were born in the Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory or who had lived there for a long time

Speaker: NA
Text: to become Australian citizens. Although I

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot give the exact percentage, I would

Speaker: NA
Text: be correct in saying that the big majority

Speaker: NA
Text: of those eligible under the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: decision have become or are in process of

Speaker: NA
Text: becoming naturalized Australian citizens.

Speaker: NA
Text: This has left us with the problem of a

Speaker: NA
Text: small number of Asians who were not

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible under the previous decision and a

Speaker: NA
Text: comparatively small number of persons of

Speaker: NA
Text: mixed blood who have an indefinite status.

Speaker: NA
Text: Considerable work has been done both in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Territory and in the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Territories in Canberra in examining the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem and in preparing proposals. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that the honorable member will

Speaker: NA
Text: realize that this is a matter for decision

Speaker: NA
Text: by Cabinet, and I shall shortly make

Speaker: NA
Text: mendations to Cabinet on the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: PHARMACEUTICAL BENEFITS.

Speaker: Mr BUCHANAN
Text: M y question is

Speaker: NA
Text: directed to the Minister for Health. Will

Speaker: NA
Text: the increased range of drugs available as

Speaker: NA
Text: pharmaceutical benefits allow the prescripcated

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of cortisone for the treatment of

Speaker: NA
Text: arthritic conditions?

Speaker: Dr DONALD CAMERON
Text: Cortison e

Speaker: NA
Text: is, in fact, available for the treatment

Speaker: NA
Text: arthritic conditions at present, subject to

Speaker: NA
Text: certain restrictions. That is to say,

Speaker: NA
Text: one of a class of what are known as second

Speaker: NA
Text: schedule or restricted drugs. Although

Speaker: NA
Text: those drugs are pharmaceutical benefits,

Speaker: NA
Text: their use as pharmaceutical benefits is

Speaker: NA
Text: restricted to a certain range of diseases.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposals announced by the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: in his Budget speech will not affect that

Speaker: NA
Text: position one way or the other. There will

Speaker: NA
Text: still be two schedules- a general schedule

Speaker: NA
Text: of drugs which may be prescribed as phar-

Speaker: NA
Text: maceutical benefits for any disease, and a

Speaker: NA
Text: restricted schedule of drugs which may be

Speaker: NA
Text: prescribed as pharmaceutical benefits only

Speaker: NA
Text: for a limited range of diseases.

Speaker: NA
Text: POSTAL DEPARTMENT.

Speaker: Mr COSTA
Text: Las t week I asked the

Speaker: NA
Text: Postmaster-General whether it was true

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Postal Department was placing the

Speaker: NA
Text: collection of outstanding telephone debts

Speaker: NA
Text: in the hands of outside debt collecting

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies for a 10 per cent, payment of

Speaker: NA
Text: the amount collected. Has he yet obtained

Speaker: NA
Text: this information? If so, will he let me

Speaker: NA
Text: have it?

Speaker: Mr DAVIDSON
Text: I am sorry that I

Speaker: NA
Text: have not yet obtained the information for

Speaker: NA
Text: which the honorable member asked last

Speaker: NA
Text: week. I did start inquiries, and I expect to

Speaker: NA
Text: receive the information very shortly. As

Speaker: NA
Text: soon as I do I will give it to the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMONWEALTH DEVELOPMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: BANK.

Speaker: Mr BRIMBLECOMBE
Text: I ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer: Is the Commonwealth Develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment Bank now established and ready for

Speaker: NA
Text: business? If not, as there are many young

Speaker: NA
Text: men in this country who are eager to go

Speaker: NA
Text: recomon the land and who desire to use this

Speaker: NA
Text: bank's services, can the Minister say when

Speaker: NA
Text: this organization will be ready for wide-

Speaker: NA
Text: spread operation?

Speaker: Mr HAROLD HOLT
Text: Th e Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Development Bank has not yet been

Speaker: NA
Text: officially constituted for the purposes indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: by the honorable member. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that earlier in the year I mentioned that it

Speaker: NA
Text: was probable that it would come into full

Speaker: NA
Text: operation at the beginning of the next

Speaker: NA
Text: calendar year. Arrangements have been

Speaker: NA
Text: of in train for the appointment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: various elements of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: it is Banking Corporation and announcements

Speaker: NA
Text: should have been made this morning-the y

Speaker: NA
Text: were authorized by me-o f the appoint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments of the general managers of the three

Speaker: NA
Text: banks making up the corporation. But

Speaker: NA
Text: until such time as the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Development Bank functions as such, there

Speaker: NA
Text: remain, of course, the industrial finance

Speaker: NA
Text: section of the Commonwealth Bank and

Speaker: NA
Text: the mortgage bank section, either of which

Speaker: NA
Text: would be capable, perhaps, of dealing with

Speaker: NA
Text: the kind of problem which the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member has in mind, at least until the

Speaker: NA
Text: other bank comes into full operation.

Speaker: NA
Text: TAXATION IN PAPUA AND NEW

Speaker: NA
Text: GUINEA.

Speaker: Mr DUTHIE
Text: I ask the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Territories whether one reason for the bit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter opposition to taxation in New Guinea,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially from the planters, is that they

Speaker: NA
Text: regard payment of tax as a lowering of

Speaker: NA
Text: their status in the eyes of the native people

Speaker: NA
Text: who, themselves, pay tax. What level of

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation has been imposed in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation in Australia?

Speaker: Mr HASLUCK
Text: I would not attempt

Speaker: NA
Text: to analyse the motives of any one who may

Speaker: NA
Text: be opposing the introduction of taxation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I imagine that the motives vary from place

Speaker: NA
Text: to place. I think the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: is perhaps in error in saying that the

Speaker: NA
Text: planters, as a class, are against taxation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some planters are opposing it as indivi-

Speaker: NA
Text: duals, but we know that there are quite a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of people engaged in planting who

Speaker: NA
Text: are not opposing it and who recognize that

Speaker: NA
Text: the abolition of export duties, which were

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the whole reform carried out allied

Speaker: NA
Text: with the introduction of income tax, will

Speaker: NA
Text: be more to their advantage and a greater

Speaker: NA
Text: encouragement to development than the

Speaker: NA
Text: old system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Regarding the level of taxation, the rate

Speaker: NA
Text: of taxation both on private individuals

Speaker: NA
Text: and on companies is approximately half

Speaker: NA
Text: the rate imposed on equivalent incomes in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, but in consequence of the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that the concessional deductions in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory are much more liberal than on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian mainland and in view of

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that some concessions are given

Speaker: NA
Text: which are not allowed in Australia at all,

Speaker: NA
Text: the actual payment of tax by a person on

Speaker: NA
Text: an income will be considerably less than

Speaker: NA
Text: half of what would be paid by an Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian on an equivalent income.

Speaker: NA
Text: R.A.A.F. CAMP, URANQUINTY.

Speaker: Mr FAIRBAIRN
Text: I ask the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Interior whether the installations at

Speaker: NA
Text: the Royal Australian Air Force camp at

Speaker: NA
Text: Uranquinty have been handed over to his

Speaker: NA
Text: department for disposal. I f so, can

Speaker: NA
Text: inform the House whether the camp will

Speaker: NA
Text: be offered for sale as a whole to some

Speaker: NA
Text: organization, or whether the various

Speaker: NA
Text: stallations will be sold separately for

Speaker: NA
Text: dismantling and re-erection elsewhere?

Speaker: NA
Text: Will the unused land be offered first to

Speaker: NA
Text: relatives of those people from whom it

Speaker: NA
Text: was compulsorily resumed during the war?

Speaker: Mr FREETH
Text: Th e honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: has taken a great interest in the Uranquinty

Speaker: NA
Text: station ever since it became known that it

Speaker: NA
Text: was no longer required by the Royal

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Air Force. However, the sta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion was handed to my department for

Speaker: NA
Text: disposal only a week or ten days ago. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have received numerous inquiries from

Speaker: NA
Text: people wishing to purchase some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: land or some of the buildings on the land,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we do not expect any difficulty in

Speaker: NA
Text: disposing of the installations separately.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, I know that the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber is interested in maintaining, as far as

Speaker: NA
Text: possible, the value of the aerodrome as an

Speaker: NA
Text: intact unit, and the department at present

Speaker: NA
Text: is negotiating with the New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, which is interested in acquir-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing approximately 400 acres of the land

Speaker: NA
Text: for its own purposes. I am unable to

Speaker: NA
Text: state the stage that has been reached in the

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiations, but I shall keep the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member informed of the position.

Speaker: NA
Text: DENTAL SERVICES.

Speaker: Mr STEWART
Text: Yesterday , I directed

Speaker: NA
Text: a question to the Minister for Health con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerning negotiations between the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Dental Association and the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Health for the establishment of a dental

Text: health scheme. If, as stated yesterday, no

Text: action has been or is being taken to raise

Text: the standard of dental health in Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: and to make dental treatment less costly?

Text: Standard s

Speaker: NA
Text: of professional practice in Australia are not

Speaker: NA
Text: matters for determination by the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Department of Health.

Speaker: NA
Text: POSTAL DEPARTMENT.

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Text: Ca n the Postmaster-

Speaker: NA
Text: General say when it is expected that the

Speaker: NA
Text: he extensive work on the Toowoomba auto-

Speaker: NA
Text: matic telephone exchange system will be

Speaker: NA
Text: completed? Is the system that is being

Speaker: NA
Text: ininstalled at the main automatic exchange,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the two supplementary exchanges, of

Speaker: NA
Text: a type that incorporates new developments

Speaker: NA
Text: the known as the cross-bar system? If so, will

Speaker: NA
Text: this project be used as a pilot system with

Speaker: NA
Text: a view to the provision of this kind of

Speaker: NA
Text: exchange in other centres of Australia?

Speaker: NA
Text: Has the Minister a firm estimate of the

Speaker: NA
Text: total cost of the project in Toowoomba?

Speaker: Mr DAVIDSON
Text: Th e exchange equip-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that is being installed in the post

Speaker: NA
Text: office at Toowoomba is known as the

Speaker: NA
Text: cross-bar system. Although this is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: new system, it has been considerably

Speaker: NA
Text: developed in recent years. Previously, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have used what is known as the step-by-

Speaker: NA
Text: step system. We believe that the develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the cross-bar system will offer

Speaker: NA
Text: considerable opportunities to reduce the

Speaker: NA
Text: space required for installation, that it will

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce maintenance and that it will permit

Speaker: NA
Text: of more effective operation. Our engineers

Speaker: NA
Text: who have been investigating the develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of this system in both France and

Speaker: NA
Text: Sweden have obtained information which

Speaker: NA
Text: has led them to believe that the advantages

Speaker: NA
Text: that I have mentioned will be obtained.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have decided, therefore, to pursue the

Speaker: NA
Text: possibility of introducing steadily this kind

Speaker: NA
Text: of equipment throughout Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Already the two small installations that

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made in Melbourne have proved

Speaker: NA
Text: successful and, in the circumstances, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have decided to install the system in

Speaker: NA
Text: Toowoomba, a rural city which, as honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members will realize, is eminently

Speaker: NA
Text: suited, by reason of its wide coverage, for

Speaker: NA
Text: this kind* of installation. The results

Speaker: NA
Text: obtained in Toowoomba will be a guide

Speaker: NA
Text: to the department as to the desirability of

Speaker: NA
Text: proceeding with further installations. To

Speaker: NA
Text: install this equipment will cost in the

Speaker: NA
Text: vicinity of Â£383,000, and I believe that it

Speaker: NA
Text: will come into operation about the middle

Speaker: NA
Text: of next year. The department is not only

Speaker: NA
Text: pursuing the possibility of introducing this

Speaker: NA
Text: improved system, but is also investigating

Speaker: NA
Text: the possibility of the equipment being

Speaker: NA
Text: manufactured in Australia if it is successful.

Speaker: NA
Text: POSTAL CHARGES.

Speaker: Mr WARD
Text: I s it a fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer, in endeavouring to justify the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed increases in charges imposed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Postmaster-General's Department, ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pressed the view that in assessing the

Speaker: NA
Text: financial position of the department, allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance should be made for an interest charge

Speaker: NA
Text: on invested capital? Is it a fact that capital

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure which he stated had been pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided from revenue since the termination

Speaker: NA
Text: of World War II . , was met from taxa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion imposed on the general public? If so,

Speaker: NA
Text: does the Treasurer agree that to increase

Speaker: NA
Text: charges now to meet the payment of

Speaker: NA
Text: interest upon invested capital is, in fact,

Speaker: NA
Text: compelling the taxpayer to pay interest

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Government upon capital which he

Speaker: NA
Text: himself has supplied to the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: free of cost?

Speaker: Mr HAROLD HOLT
Text: Thes e matters

Speaker: NA
Text: can be looked at in rather different ways.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a fact that the very substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: amounts of capital invested in the Post

Speaker: NA
Text: Office since World War II . have been

Speaker: NA
Text: obtained, not from loans, but from revenue.

Speaker: NA
Text: In that sense, the taxpayer has contributed,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the form of revenue, to works which

Speaker: NA
Text: normally a government would prefer to

Speaker: NA
Text: finance by way of loan if that were prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticable. 1 think that all members know

Speaker: NA
Text: the reasons why it has not been practicable

Speaker: NA
Text: for us to provide loan moneys for this pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose. All the loan raisings of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Government, over these years,

Speaker: NA
Text: have been devoted to the needs of the

Speaker: NA
Text: State Governments. If we were not to have

Speaker: NA
Text: a component in postal charges representing

Speaker: NA
Text: some return on capital invested, then the

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayer who has already contributed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the capital cost of the Post Office in this

Speaker: NA
Text: substantial degree, would have to contribute

Speaker: NA
Text: further amounts in the years ahead. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is obvious enough to any one who bothers

Speaker: NA
Text: to think about it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Roughly Â£50,000,000 has to be found

Speaker: NA
Text: this year from the Budget for the capital

Speaker: NA
Text: needs of the Post Office. The correspond-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing sum in subsequent budgets is likely to

Speaker: NA
Text: grow appreciably larger in the years ahead,

Speaker: NA
Text: as Australia grows. If those who use the

Speaker: NA
Text: services of the Postal Department do not,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the aggregate, provide a commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: return to the department, quite clearly the

Speaker: NA
Text: taxpayer of the future instead of those who

Speaker: NA
Text: use the services, will have to go on pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: viding money for the needs of the Post

Speaker: NA
Text: Office. So while, in a sense, it is true

Speaker: NA
Text: that the taxpayer has provided these capital

Speaker: NA
Text: moneys and that the increased charges will

Speaker: NA
Text: affect some taxpayers-no t all of them to

Speaker: NA
Text: the same degree-i n future, a more just

Speaker: NA
Text: distribution of Postal Department expenses

Speaker: NA
Text: and charges will be made, bearing on those

Speaker: NA
Text: who use the services rather than on the

Speaker: NA
Text: general body of taxpayers.

Text: ballot to try to finalize this very important

Speaker: NA
Text: of a rather more technical character than

Text: problems of this country than the arrange-

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: to to him any great hope that I will be able

Text: ABORIGINES.

Speaker: Mr COPE
Text: Wil l the Minister for Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: that tories inform the House of the latest

Speaker: NA
Text: development between Daly, Arthur and

Speaker: Mr HASLUCK
Text: Mr Speaker, in

Speaker: NA
Text: answer to a telegram that was sent to me

Speaker: NA
Text: by the suitor, Mr Daly, I informed him

Speaker: NA
Text: that there should be no reasonable objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to his interviewing Gladys and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinuing to talk with her. But I suggested

Speaker: NA
Text: he should discuss with the Administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor of the Northern Territory an arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment under which the question might be

Speaker: NA
Text: deferred for, say, six months so as to make

Speaker: NA
Text: to sure that the woman herself was clear

Speaker: NA
Text: about her own wishes, because she had

Speaker: NA
Text: made avowals of preference for Arthur

Speaker: NA
Text: of, and avowals of preference for Daly. I

Speaker: NA
Text: also suggested that a period of six months

Speaker: NA
Text: be would allow us time to sort out the exact

Speaker: NA
Text: significance of the tribal relationship

Speaker: NA
Text: is between the woman and Arthur. Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sequent on that suggestion-and , of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: six months is very much less than the seven

Speaker: NA
Text: years that Jacob was prepared to serve

Speaker: NA
Text: for Leah and another seven years for

Speaker: NA
Text: I Rachel-counse l for Daly wrote to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Administrator, in terms which generally

Speaker: NA
Text: were rather demanding, and sought an

Speaker: NA
Text: immediate solution. The Administrator

Speaker: NA
Text: has again invited counsel for Daly and

Speaker: NA
Text: Daly himself to discuss with him this

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangement for what might be termed a

Speaker: NA
Text: cooling-off period.

Speaker: Mr CLYDE CAMERON
Text: I should

Speaker: NA
Text: to ask the Minister for Territories a

Speaker: NA
Text: Is it a fact that the person who

Speaker: NA
Text: to is making the inquiries into this affair

Speaker: NA
Text: rate between Arthur and Gladys, which was

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned in the House last week, is a

Speaker: NA
Text: man by the name of Ward? Is it also a

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that people bearing this name are

Text: notorious for their inquisitiveness about

Text: other people's affairs?

Speaker: Mr HASLUCK
Text: I t is true that Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: has Daly's counsel, who represented him in the

Text: court proceedings and is acting for him

Speaker: NA
Text: at present, is a Mr Ward. Mr Ward also

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Legislative Council for the Northern

Text: Territory. So, in both his capacity as a

Text: local member and as counsel for one of

Text: the parties concerned, he has been very

Text: at all of the characteristics of the Ward

Speaker: NA
Text: SMALLPOX.

Speaker: Mr CLEAVER
Text: Ha s the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Health received a resolution from the

Speaker: NA
Text: annual conference of the Parents and

Speaker: NA
Text: Citizens Federation of Western Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: asking for a national immunization plan

Speaker: NA
Text: against smallpox? Does the Minister con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider that, due to the shorter travelling

Speaker: NA
Text: between Asia and Australia, there is any

Speaker: NA
Text: danger of smallpox becoming epidemic?

Speaker: NA
Text: If so, will he earnestly consider the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: munization proposal to which I have

Speaker: NA
Text: referred?

Speaker: Dr DONALD CAMERON
Text: No , Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, I have not received such a

Speaker: NA
Text: request. The question of immunization

Speaker: NA
Text: against smallpox is constantly in the mind

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Department of Health. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: think it is necessary to institute a national

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign, but I think it is a good thing

Speaker: NA
Text: that people should be aware that although

Speaker: NA
Text: we have excellent quarantine arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: which, so far, have been highly successful

Speaker: NA
Text: in preventing smallpox from either gain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing access to, or spreading in, this country,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is always a possibility that even with

Speaker: NA
Text: the best arrangements smallpox will enter

Speaker: NA
Text: the country, so I think it is probably highly

Speaker: NA
Text: desirable that people should voluntarily

Speaker: NA
Text: undergo vaccination.

Speaker: NA
Text: POSTAL DEPARTMENT.

Speaker: Mr DRUMMOND
Text: I desire to ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: Postmaster-General a question without

Speaker: NA
Text: notice, which I would preface, Sir, by

Speaker: NA
Text: referring very briefly to an answer given

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Treasurer to a question concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Bank. Apparently,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government, in its wisdom, has decided

Speaker: NA
Text: to give semi-autonomy to certain branches

Speaker: NA
Text: of the bank under a general policy, in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to enable the bank to expand more

Speaker: NA
Text: healthfully on the lines of big business

Speaker: NA
Text: wherever it develops. Having regard to

Speaker: NA
Text: those facts, I ask the Postmaster-General

Speaker: NA
Text: whether he, or the Government, has con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered a similar proposal to apply to what

Speaker: NA
Text: is now a very big enterprise which must,

Speaker: NA
Text: with the growth of our population, become

Speaker: NA
Text: much bigger-tha t is, the Postal Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and all its associated activities. Has

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration been given to proposals for

Speaker: NA
Text: creating semi-autonomous branches under

Speaker: NA
Text: a central general policy control?

Speaker: Mr DAVIDSON
Text: No , I do not know

Speaker: NA
Text: of any such proposal having been con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered. Certainly it has not come before

Speaker: NA
Text: me and I have not heard that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has considered the proposal of the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for New England that

Speaker: NA
Text: we establish, if I understand him correctly,

Speaker: NA
Text: a series of semi-autonomous branches of

Speaker: NA
Text: time the Postal Department which would operate

Speaker: NA
Text: more or less autonomously, with some

Speaker: NA
Text: general direction, in country areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Drummond -No , no-throughou t

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth.

Speaker: Mr DAVIDSON
Text: Well , throughout the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth. Therefore, the reply is

Speaker: NA
Text: that no consideration has yet been given

Speaker: NA
Text: to such a proposal, but I shall be happy

Speaker: NA
Text: to make some inquiries as to its feasibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: TRADE WITH CHINA.

Speaker: Mr JONES
Text: M y question without

Speaker: NA
Text: notice is to the Minister for Trade. In

Speaker: NA
Text: asking it I make reference to a question

Speaker: NA
Text: that I asked the right honorable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: yesterday, relative to the export of wool,

Speaker: NA
Text: steel and other materials to mainland

Speaker: NA
Text: China. In reply he indicated to me that

Speaker: NA
Text: goods for export to mainland China were in

Speaker: NA
Text: three categories. The first category consisted

Speaker: NA
Text: of goods the export of which was absolutely

Speaker: NA
Text: forbidden, and that category has never been

Speaker: NA
Text: modified. The second category consisted of

Speaker: NA
Text: goods on an intermediate list. Those goods

Speaker: NA
Text: could be exported subject to the approval

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Department of External Affairs. The

Speaker: NA
Text: third category comprised foodstuffs, wool

Speaker: NA
Text: and other goods on which there has never

Speaker: NA
Text: been an export ban.

Speaker: NA
Text: I ask the Minister whether I and other

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members may have a copy of

Speaker: NA
Text: those lists. Further, how long has steel

Speaker: NA
Text: been considered a non-defence material?

Speaker: NA
Text: In the light of his reply to my question

Speaker: NA
Text: yesterday, does the Minister not consider

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's declared policy of non-

Speaker: NA
Text: recognition of mainland China to be sheer

Speaker: NA
Text: humbug?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mir. MCEWEN -List s are not available.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that yesterday I did say that the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: port of goods in one category was abso-

Speaker: NA
Text: lutely forbidden. I think I also added that

Speaker: NA
Text: that category had never been modified. In

Speaker: NA
Text: using those terms I was perhaps not com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely correct, for which I express regret,

Speaker: NA
Text: because I think there is some scope for

Speaker: NA
Text: modification between the forbidden list and

Speaker: NA
Text: the list of goods that are available for

Speaker: NA
Text: export subject to permission from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of External Affairs. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: it is obvious that if the export of certain

Speaker: NA
Text: goods is to be forbidden due to strategic

Speaker: NA
Text: considerations, the current appraisal of

Speaker: NA
Text: strategic circumstances could lead to some

Speaker: NA
Text: modification in that list. In fact, my state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that certain goods may be exported

Speaker: NA
Text: subject to approval by the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: External Affairs, indicates some fluidity of

Speaker: NA
Text: judgment from time to time in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: that category. The conclusion to be drawn

Speaker: NA
Text: is that there is no hard and fast rule that

Speaker: NA
Text: certain goods shall be placed in a particular

Speaker: NA
Text: category.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: Bass) [11.18] - Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman, the Budget presented by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer ( Mr Harold Holt)-hi s first

Speaker: NA
Text: that capacity-ca n only be described

Speaker: NA
Text: disappointing. I believe that opinion

Speaker: NA
Text: widely shared throughout the community. occasion.

Speaker: NA
Text: In what is normally a profoundly important

Speaker: NA
Text: financial document, the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: placency in the face of its failure to

Speaker: NA
Text: with the real problems affecting Australia concerned?

Speaker: NA
Text: can only be described as alarming. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, the Treasurer dismissed the

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment situation with a brief reference

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that employment rose on the one

Speaker: NA
Text: hand and unemployment fell on the other.

Speaker: NA
Text: That statement is only partially correct

Speaker: NA
Text: will not stand up to careful analysis. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget completely ignores the alarming

Speaker: NA
Text: situation into which farm income has been

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed to decline. Although farm income

Speaker: NA
Text: during 1958-59 rose to Â£399,000,000, which

Speaker: NA
Text: was a slight improvement on the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: year, it was substantially less than the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of Â£514,000,000 earned during

Speaker: NA
Text: 1956-57. The purchasing power of far-

Speaker: NA
Text: mers' incomes therefore is considerably less

Speaker: NA
Text: than it was two years ago. But still there

Speaker: NA
Text: is no indication from this Government that

Speaker: NA
Text: it intends to do anything about checking

Speaker: NA
Text: that drift except, of course, to abdicate

Speaker: NA
Text: from the field of land settlement and leave

Speaker: NA
Text: the States to their own devices in that

Speaker: NA
Text: respect. The Budget refuses anything but

Speaker: NA
Text: a mere token handout to the pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: and it completely ignores the problems of

Speaker: NA
Text: large families, many of which are desper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ately in need of help and a substantia]

Speaker: NA
Text: number of which are to-day expected to

Speaker: NA
Text: exist on a benefit commonly known as the

Speaker: NA
Text: dole.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Budget ignores the opportunity that

Speaker: NA
Text: now exists to end the housing crisis and at

Speaker: NA
Text: the same time enable a large percentage of

Speaker: NA
Text: those people who are to-day without useful

Speaker: NA
Text: employment to return to work. On the

Speaker: NA
Text: contrary, the Treasurer merely made a

Speaker: NA
Text: general reference to the worth of the indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: vidual citizen and his value to the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian community generally. He then

Speaker: NA
Text: proceeded to ignore all of the matters to

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have referred and with which the

Speaker: NA
Text: individual citizen is so vitally concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: That, I believe, is the general context

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Budget that was presented only a

Speaker: NA
Text: few days ago by the Treasurer. I concede

Speaker: NA
Text: . that Australians generally are a very

Speaker: NA
Text: patient, industrious and co-operative race

Speaker: NA
Text: in of people but it would be understandable

Speaker: NA
Text: as if they were somewhat concerned at the

Speaker: NA
Text: is Budget that has been presented on this

Speaker: NA
Text: May I refer to some of the things

Speaker: NA
Text: comwith which the great majority of

Speaker: NA
Text: deal people in this country are vitally

Speaker: NA
Text: They are affected by

Speaker: NA
Text: housing, education and health facilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: emWhilst it may be said that opportunities

Speaker: NA
Text: to exist in this country for decent housing,

Speaker: NA
Text: that health facilities are available and that

Speaker: NA
Text: there are employment opportunities for

Speaker: NA
Text: and those people in the community who are

Speaker: NA
Text: fortunately placed, it must be admitted at

Speaker: NA
Text: the same time that for the great majority

Speaker: NA
Text: of people, education and health facilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: which are increasingly becoming the

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility of the Commonwealth Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment, are no longer available to the

Speaker: NA
Text: extent that they should be.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me refer again to the problem of

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment. I remember that we com-

Speaker: NA
Text: menced the year 1958 with a most signi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ficant statement from the then Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour and National Service, who is now

Speaker: NA
Text: our Treasurer. In a news release at that

Speaker: NA
Text: time issued by the Department of Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: and National Service he said that the year

Speaker: NA
Text: was a most significant one so far as employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment was concerned. But what was the

Speaker: NA
Text: real position then? According to the

Speaker: NA
Text: figures that had been released by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister himself, the number of persons

Speaker: NA
Text: registered with the various offices of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Labour and National

Speaker: NA
Text: Service throughout Australia had increased

Speaker: NA
Text: by almost 6,000 compared with the number

Speaker: NA
Text: in the previous year. The number of per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons in receipt of unemployment benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: had risen by almost 1,600. Yet the

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible Minister, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: spokesman in these matters, suggested that

Speaker: NA
Text: 1958 saw an improvement in the

Speaker: NA
Text: employment position!

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me put the position in another way.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the end of January, 1955, the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of persons registered for employment with

Speaker: NA
Text: the various offices of the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour and National Service was 16,266.

Speaker: NA
Text: By 1956-tha t is, the year of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's little Budget, which secured from

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of this country additional

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue of Â£115,000,000-th e number of

Speaker: NA
Text: persons registered for employment had

Speaker: NA
Text: risen to 31,000. In 1957, the figure was

Speaker: NA
Text: never less than 46,000. During 1958, the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of persons registered for work

Speaker: NA
Text: rose first to 56,000 and, at the end of the

Speaker: NA
Text: year, stood at 64,000. The latest figures

Speaker: NA
Text: given in a news release made only a few

Speaker: NA
Text: days ago by the present Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour and National Service ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: MCMahon) indicate that the number regis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tered now stands at 63,623. I suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that, in the circumstances, there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: cause for complacency about unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment on the part of this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: because, in only two years, the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: persons registered for work has risen by

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 30,000. It is remarkable that

Speaker: NA
Text: the responsible Minister should talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: increased employment opportunities, when,

Speaker: NA
Text: on his own admittedfigures,this significant

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in the number of persons seeking,

Speaker: NA
Text: useful employment has occurred.

Speaker: NA
Text: In respect of the unemployment benefit,.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Chairman, the same unhappy position

Speaker: NA
Text: exists. In March, 1957, 13,077 persons

Speaker: NA
Text: were receiving the unemployment benefit,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is commonly known as the dole.

Speaker: NA
Text: By March of 1958, the number had risen

Speaker: NA
Text: to 24,485. In July of this year, the num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber stood at 27,410. According to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's recent news release, the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of persons receiving unemployment benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Commonwealth had fallen by

Speaker: NA
Text: 118 since 27th June, but I believe that a

Speaker: NA
Text: careful analysis of that news release will

Speaker: NA
Text: show that the fact remains that, because

Speaker: NA
Text: there was a reduction of 1,462 in Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land, there must have been increases in

Speaker: NA
Text: all the other States. That seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate quite conclusively that the unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment situation continues to deteriorate,

Speaker: NA
Text: in spite of what is said by Government

Speaker: NA
Text: spokesmen.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is normally a great similarity

Speaker: NA
Text: between the news releases made by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Labour and National

Speaker: NA
Text: Service every month through the Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Almost without exception, they refer to

Speaker: NA
Text: seasonal factors, young people leaving

Speaker: NA
Text: school and other things affecting the

Speaker: NA
Text: employment situation. But I suggest at

Speaker: NA
Text: once that the responsible Minister is bound

Speaker: NA
Text: to concede that we cannot consider the

Speaker: NA
Text: number of young people leaving school or

Speaker: NA
Text: seasonal factors as being responsible for

Speaker: NA
Text: the serious growth in unemployment in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country in recent years. The problem

Speaker: NA
Text: goes much deeper than that. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that the important factor is the availability

Speaker: NA
Text: of job opportunities. The figures can be

Speaker: NA
Text: substantiated by reference to the various

Speaker: NA
Text: documents made available from time to

Speaker: NA
Text: time by the department.

Speaker: NA
Text: In February of 1958 the present

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer, who, as I have said, was then

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Labour and National Service,

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated that in that month the Cabinet

Speaker: NA
Text: would consider a plan for reducing unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment. If in point of fact such a plan

Speaker: NA
Text: was to be put before the Cabinet,

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously the Cabinet had no intention of

Speaker: NA
Text: considering it seriously, even if the Cabinet

Speaker: NA
Text: intended to consider it at all, because the

Speaker: NA
Text: -number of persons registered for employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is certainly far higher now than it

Speaker: NA
Text: was at that stage. As the level of unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment has risen, the present Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Labour and National Service has been

Speaker: NA
Text: intent, not on curbing the movement, but

Speaker: NA
Text: rather on finding a basis for a false com-

Speaker: NA
Text: parison of the unemployment figures.

Speaker: NA
Text: Again, I refer to the news release made by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Labour and National

Speaker: NA
Text: Service for the Minister's interpretation

Speaker: NA
Text: of what is meant by the term "Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: work force ". On this point, I completely

Speaker: NA
Text: disagree with the Minister. In the news

Speaker: NA
Text: release, he stated-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian work force, as defined by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Statistician . . . includes em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployers, self-employed, wage and salary earners,

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed persons, and all helping in any

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, business, trade or service . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister states that the work force

Speaker: NA
Text: totals 4,000,000 persons, but I suggest that

Speaker: NA
Text: this figure is completely contradicted by

Speaker: NA
Text: that supplied by the Commonwealth Statis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tician, and that the Minister's definition

Speaker: NA
Text: of " Australian work force" has been

Speaker: NA
Text: invented by him in comparatively recent

Speaker: NA
Text: times in order to suggest a much lower

Speaker: NA
Text: percentage of unemployment than pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: viously existed. The latest monthly survey

Speaker: NA
Text: of employment statistics by the Bureau of

Speaker: NA
Text: Census and Statistics indicates that the

Speaker: NA
Text: total number of persons employed in

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, including members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Forces, is 2,984,700.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Crean -Tha t does not include rural

Speaker: NA
Text: workers, either.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: Tha t figure excludes

Speaker: NA
Text: those engaged in rural production. I sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gest that if the number of persons engaged

Speaker: NA
Text: in rural production is included the figure

Speaker: NA
Text: would certainly not exceed 3,000,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Surely even the Minister and other mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the Government, who, I know, take

Speaker: NA
Text: a great deal of convincing in these matters

Speaker: NA
Text: if it does not suit their purposes to be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: vinced, are bound to concede that the per-

Speaker: NA
Text: centage of workers unemployed, when

Speaker: NA
Text: measured against the figure of 4,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: for the work force-th e fictitious figure

Speaker: NA
Text: supplied by the head of the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of Labour and National Service-i s very

Speaker: NA
Text: different from that obtained when it is

Speaker: NA
Text: measured against the figure of 3,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: supplied by the Commonwealth Statistician

Speaker: NA
Text: If this clumsy attempt at concealing the

Speaker: NA
Text: real percentage of unemployment were not

Speaker: NA
Text: so serious, it could almost be described as

Speaker: NA
Text: humorous.

Speaker: NA
Text: For seventeen consecutive months, Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman, the number of persons receiving

Speaker: NA
Text: the unemployment benefit has exceeded

Speaker: NA
Text: 24,000. Generally, it has remained close

Speaker: NA
Text: to the 30,000 mark. As I indicated a few

Speaker: NA
Text: moments ago, it now stands at 27,410.

Speaker: NA
Text: Obviously, therefore, full employment is

Speaker: NA
Text: no longer, as it should be, a fundamental

Speaker: NA
Text: aim of this Government, which completely

Speaker: NA
Text: ignores the fact that the people of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia demand, and indeed, are entitled to

Speaker: NA
Text: expect, full employment. In my opinion,

Speaker: NA
Text: the present level of unemployment repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sents, from the national viewpoint, a sense-

Speaker: NA
Text: less waste of productive power. From the

Speaker: NA
Text: point of view of the individual, it means

Speaker: NA
Text: a loss of self-respect and of his ability to

Speaker: NA
Text: compete on anything approaching equal

Speaker: NA
Text: terms in the economic life of this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the past two years, the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: has repeatedly directed the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: attention to the rise in the unemployment

Speaker: NA
Text: figures and to the continuing trend towards

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment, but the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: refused to move in the matter. Obviously,

Speaker: NA
Text: it accepts a situation in which, on its own

Speaker: NA
Text: admitted figures, more than 60,000 persons

Speaker: NA
Text: are denied useful employment. I suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Treasurer should have devoted

Speaker: NA
Text: more than the few lines that he did devote

Speaker: NA
Text: in his Budget speech to the problem of

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployment. He contented himself with

Speaker: NA
Text: a brief statement that employment had

Speaker: NA
Text: risen, on the one hand, and that unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment had declined, on the other. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe. Sir, that I have been able to sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantiate the claim that unemployment has

Speaker: NA
Text: not declined and that, on the contrary, it

Speaker: NA
Text: has substantially increased.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me turn now, Mr Chairman, to

Speaker: NA
Text: social services. I believe that, in this

Speaker: NA
Text: respect, the Budget is noteworthy more for

Speaker: NA
Text: what it does not do for the pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: than for what it proposes to do for them.

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, it proposes an increase of

Speaker: NA
Text: 7s. 6d. a week in age, invalid and other

Speaker: NA
Text: classes of pensions. Surely that can be

Speaker: NA
Text: described, in the circumstances, only as

Speaker: NA
Text: niggaTdly. Child endowment, for example,

Speaker: NA
Text: remains unchanged, as it has done through-

Speaker: NA
Text: out the term of office of this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: -wit h the exception, of course, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: introduction, in 1950, of the endowment of

Speaker: NA
Text: 5s. a week for the first child. But what

Speaker: NA
Text: is that 5s. really worth to-day? I doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: very much whether it would be worth even

Speaker: NA
Text: half of its value in 1950. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour Party, in its programme for the

Speaker: NA
Text: general elections in 1958, told the people

Speaker: NA
Text: that it would double child endowment for

Speaker: NA
Text: the first child.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Mackinnon -Afte r having said on

Speaker: NA
Text: a previous occasion that you would never

Speaker: NA
Text: pay it.

Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Text: Ou r policy for the

Speaker: NA
Text: last general elections was that the endowtotally

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for the second child would be

Speaker: NA
Text: creased from 10s. to 17s. 6d. a week and

Speaker: NA
Text: that the endowment for subsequent mented

Speaker: NA
Text: children would be increased to Â£1 a week.

Speaker: NA
Text: In view of the interjection just made

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Corangamite, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is interesting to note, on the figures

Speaker: NA
Text: plied by the Government in its Budget for

Speaker: NA
Text: the financial year 1958-59, that these

Speaker: NA
Text: posals could have been financed satisfacthe

Speaker: NA
Text: torily. Labour's proposals were to

Speaker: NA
Text: no more than Â£58,000,000. Although the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government budgeted originally for

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit in 1958-59, the actual deficit

Speaker: NA
Text: not nearly so great as that budgeted for.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a clear indication to the people,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Chairman, that our proposals in of

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of child endowment could have in

Speaker: NA
Text: been financed, as the Government's own

Speaker: NA
Text: figures in that Budget indicated.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to turn now to repatriation

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits, Sir. The Government proposes

Speaker: NA
Text: increase the pensions payable to totally

Speaker: NA
Text: and permanently incapacitated ex-servicecountry

Speaker: NA
Text: men by 15s. a week. In view of the sion.

Speaker: NA
Text: situation in which these unfortunate people

Speaker: NA
Text: find themselves to-day, we must regard

Speaker: NA
Text: that increase as being completely inadequate

Speaker: NA
Text: and insignificant. There are now no more

Speaker: NA
Text: than 12,000 totally and permanently indo

Speaker: NA
Text: capacitated ex-servicemen in Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they certainly deserve from this rate

Speaker: NA
Text: Government far greater generosity than

Speaker: NA
Text: they have been accorded in this Budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: Their pension will be increased to Â£12 5s.

Speaker: NA
Text: a week. It may be said in favour of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government that this is the first time

Speaker: NA
Text: the last three years that totally and

Speaker: NA
Text: manently incapacitated ex-servicemen will

Speaker: NA
Text: have received the benefit of the whole of

Speaker: NA
Text: the increase in their pension. When

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, in its Budget for the finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial year 1957-58, increased the rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: this pension by 25s. a week, it did not

Speaker: NA
Text: alter the ceiling limit, and this meant that

Speaker: NA
Text: the service pensions payable to totally and

Speaker: NA
Text: permanently incapacitated ex-servicemen

Speaker: NA
Text: and their wives were correspondingly

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced. In 1958-59, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: increased the rate of this pension by 15s.

Speaker: NA
Text: a week, but, again, the ceiling limit was

Speaker: NA
Text: not altered and the benefit of the full

Speaker: NA
Text: increase was not received.

Speaker: NA
Text: This has been the experience of those

Speaker: NA
Text: and permanently incapacitated ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: inservicemen who are married and whose

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions are to a certain extent supple-

Speaker: NA
Text: by service pensions. It is perfectly

Speaker: NA
Text: true that single totally and permanently

Speaker: NA
Text: by incapacitated ex-servicemen benefited by

Speaker: NA
Text: the full increase in the pension rate, but

Speaker: NA
Text: supthe pensions of most totally and per-

Speaker: NA
Text: manently incapacitated ex-servicemen are

Speaker: NA
Text: prosupplemented by service pensions. So, for

Speaker: NA
Text: past two years, the most deserving

Speaker: NA
Text: cost members of the community have been

Speaker: NA
Text: denied the full benefit of the increased

Speaker: NA
Text: a pensions granted by the Government. On

Speaker: NA
Text: was this occasion, as I said a few moments

Speaker: NA
Text: ago, the Government has decided to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease the ceiling limit amount to the extent

Speaker: NA
Text: 15s. a week, and this is the first year

Speaker: NA
Text: the last three in which they will be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to enjoy the full benefit of the increase.

Speaker: NA
Text: The genera] rate pension, commonly

Speaker: NA
Text: known as the 100 per cent, pension, has

Speaker: NA
Text: to been increased by 7s. 6d. a week, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: great majority of service pensioners in this

Speaker: NA
Text: are being paid the general rate pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: What does this increase in the general

Speaker: NA
Text: rate pension really mean? The pensioner

Speaker: NA
Text: receiving the 100 per cent, pension will

Speaker: NA
Text: get the increase of 7s. 6d. a week, but

Speaker: NA
Text: let us see what it will mean to those who

Speaker: NA
Text: not receive the full 100 per cent, pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion. The pensioners on the 80 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: will get an increase of 6s. a week. The

Speaker: NA
Text: 40 per cent, pension will be increased by

Speaker: NA
Text: 3s. a week, and the 20 per cent, pensioner

Speaker: NA
Text: will get the magnificent increase of ls. 6d.

Speaker: NA
Text: a week. I suggest that those general rate

Speaker: NA
Text: in pensioners in the categories to which I

Speaker: NA
Text: perhave referred-an d I think they comprise

Speaker: NA
Text: the great majority of service pensioners in

Speaker: NA
Text: this country - will be extremely dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed at the consideration they have

Speaker: NA
Text: the received from a Government which made

Speaker: NA
Text: certain promises with regard to pension

Speaker: NA
Text: creases in 1949.

Speaker: NA
Text: While the service pension is to be

Speaker: NA
Text: creased to Â£4 15s. a week, the wife's allowtarget

Speaker: NA
Text: ance will remain at Â£3 10s. a fortnight-

Speaker: NA
Text: the magnificent sum of Â£1 15s. a week.

Speaker: NA
Text: refer again to this matter because I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that those receiving these allowances repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent possibly the most deserving section

Speaker: NA
Text: our community. A service pensioner may

Speaker: NA
Text: have a war disability which is not

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered by the Repatriation Department

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficientiy grave to render him completely

Speaker: NA
Text: incapacitated, but it may render him inthis

Speaker: NA
Text: capable of engaging in useful employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: If his wife is under 60 years of age she

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to exist on Â£3 10s. a fortnight.

Speaker: NA
Text: I agree with the comments made last night

Speaker: NA
Text: by the honorable member for Port Ademitted.

Speaker: NA
Text: laide ( Mr Thompson), who suggested

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Social Services ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Roberton), who is now sitting at the table,

Speaker: NA
Text: that he might, even at this late stage,

Speaker: NA
Text: consider the plight in which these pepole

Speaker: NA
Text: to whom I have referred now find themHomes Division.

Speaker: NA
Text: selves.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is one other theme that I

Speaker: NA
Text: like to develop in the few minutes that

Speaker: NA
Text: main to me. I refer to the question

Speaker: NA
Text: housing. I know that the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has great difficulty in some

Speaker: NA
Text: respects in legislating to deal with recesIn

Speaker: NA
Text: sions that occur, both internally and

Speaker: NA
Text: ternally, because of constitutional limitahas

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of power. But there is one power

Speaker: NA
Text: that is certainly available to this Governwe

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. There is no restriction on its power

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of the provision of homes for

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of this country. I remember

Speaker: NA
Text: that in 1956 the Minister for National Deincreasing,

Speaker: NA
Text: velopment (Senator Spooner) presented to

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of this country a document

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled "The Housing Situation". The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister pointed out in that document that, a home.

Speaker: NA
Text: as a result of the natural increase in popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation and the increase resulting from the

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration programme, the demand for

Speaker: NA
Text: houses would rise from 60,000 in 1961 to expired.

Speaker: NA
Text: 86,000 in 1975. He said also that a steady

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of 77,000 homes completed each year

Speaker: NA
Text: would be needed if we were to reach the

Speaker: NA
Text: target. What has happened? In 1956, the

Speaker: NA
Text: year that the Minister made this document

Speaker: NA
Text: available and suggested that the minimum

Speaker: NA
Text: annual requirement would be 77,000 shall

Speaker: NA
Text: inhomes, only 73,000 homes were built. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the following year, only 70,000 homes were

Speaker: NA
Text: built, but it is true that in the next year,

Speaker: NA
Text: in1958, home construction exceeded the

Speaker: NA
Text: of 77,000 by approximately 2,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, we are falling further behind

Speaker: NA
Text: I each year in the race to provide homes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me refer to the fields in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: of Commonwealth Government has some

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for housing. I refer first to

Speaker: NA
Text: conwar service homes, for which the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth accepted full responsibility.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amount of money to be made available

Speaker: NA
Text: year for the construcion of war service

Speaker: NA
Text: homes is Â£35,000,000; it has remained at

Speaker: NA
Text: is this figure since 1957-58. In 1957-58,

Speaker: NA
Text: 22,399 applications for assistance through

Speaker: NA
Text: the War Service Homes Division were sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: At the end of that year, 19,257

Speaker: NA
Text: to outstanding applications remained. In

Speaker: NA
Text: other words, the War Service Homes Divi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion was able to make up the leeway only

Speaker: NA
Text: to the extent of about 3,000 homes. I

Speaker: NA
Text: rerefer, of course, to those who want to

Speaker: NA
Text: build their homes through the War Service

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me refer to the difficulties that face

Speaker: NA
Text: would these people. In 1955, the maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: readvance fixed by the responsible Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: of was Â£2,750. In those days, the maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: advance exceeded the cost of the home,

Speaker: NA
Text: but to-day it is far below the average cost.

Speaker: NA
Text: one State alone, New South Wales, the

Speaker: NA
Text: exaverage cost of a dwelling-house and land

Speaker: NA
Text: increased each year until it is now

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£3,763, requiring a deposit of Â£1,013. If

Speaker: NA
Text: want to give the people the assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: to which they are entitled through the

Speaker: NA
Text: War Service Homes Division, obviously the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government must consider immediately

Speaker: NA
Text: first, the amount it makes avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able each year for the construction of war

Speaker: NA
Text: service homes and, secondly, the maximum

Speaker: NA
Text: advance to enable these people to purchase

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Mr Bowden) -

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The honorable member's time has

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Text: Sturt) [11.48] -A s I pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose to praise certain items in the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: and to criticize others, I want to define

Speaker: NA
Text: my position clearly at the outset. I am,

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir, a member of the Liberal Party, the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: stitution of which provides that members

Speaker: NA
Text: be free in all things to act and vote

Speaker: NA
Text: according to the dictates of their con-

Speaker: NA
Text: science. I would not be a member of a

Speaker: NA
Text: party that prevented me at any time from

Speaker: NA
Text: freely expressing my views. It is most

Speaker: NA
Text: regrettable that the Australian Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Party does not similarly leave its members

Speaker: NA
Text: free. These constant expulsions from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Labour Party because members

Speaker: NA
Text: conscientiously express their views are

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely bad for democracy. The ability

Speaker: NA
Text: of members freely to express their views

Speaker: NA
Text: shows a healthy party and a healthy

Speaker: NA
Text: democracy.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the same time I am a team man.

Speaker: NA
Text: If, having freely expressed my views, I

Speaker: NA
Text: am unable to convince the majority of my

Speaker: NA
Text: party that my views are right, as a team

Speaker: NA
Text: man I normally accept the decision of the

Speaker: NA
Text: team. I am not always right and I am

Speaker: NA
Text: not always wrong. When to-day I criticize

Speaker: NA
Text: certain items in the Budget, that does not

Speaker: NA
Text: mean that I will vote against it, because

Speaker: NA
Text: I recognize that it is the combined thinking

Speaker: NA
Text: of members of the Cabinet who have the

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility to present it. I do not believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that any member of the Cabinet agrees with

Speaker: NA
Text: every item in the Budget. It would be

Speaker: NA
Text: unreal to think that that were so. But

Speaker: NA
Text: the Budget is the combined decision of the

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Cabinet, in whom I have

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence and for whom I have respect.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the outset, I say that I cannot agree

Speaker: NA
Text: with the general approach of Cabinet that

Speaker: NA
Text: this is a deficit budget. On the contrary,

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe it shows that thefinancialposition

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia is stronger to-day than at any

Speaker: NA
Text: time in our history. The figures on pages

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 and 11 of the current report of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General, which deals with the

Speaker: NA
Text: financial position for the year ended 30th

Speaker: NA
Text: June, 1959, show that, despite low wool

Speaker: NA
Text: prices and a year following a drought, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth reduced its public debt by

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£86,000,000 and that treasury-bills

Speaker: NA
Text: increased by Â£36,000,000. This gives a net

Speaker: NA
Text: improvement in our balance-sheet of

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£50,000,000 for one year. In addition to

Speaker: NA
Text: that, we paid out of revenue for public

Speaker: NA
Text: works, for which there are corresponding
