Speaker: NA
Text: assets, Â£132,000,000. The real position,

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore, is that the Commonwealth's

Speaker: NA
Text: assets over liabilities in one year improved

Speaker: NA
Text: by Â£182,000,000. I fail to understand

Speaker: NA
Text: why Treasury officials are continually

Speaker: NA
Text: altering the manner in which these figures

Speaker: NA
Text: are presented. This is apparently done in

Speaker: NA
Text: an effort to create a situation that is suitable

Speaker: NA
Text: to themselves. I would say that the figures

Speaker: NA
Text: for the financial year ended 30th June last

Speaker: NA
Text: are probably the most satisfactory that have

Speaker: NA
Text: ever been presented, and I do not see any

Speaker: NA
Text: reason to tell the world that Australia has

Speaker: NA
Text: a deficit when last year Australia showed

Speaker: NA
Text: that it was able to reduce its liabilities or

Speaker: NA
Text: add to its assets by an amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: Although the approach has been changed

Speaker: NA
Text: and a new item added, a critical examina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the Budget for this year shows that

Speaker: NA
Text: the revenue of the Commonwealth for the

Speaker: NA
Text: year will be Â£1,385,000,000 and that

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure will be a like amount. But on

Speaker: NA
Text: the expenditure side we find an item of

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£142,000,000 which will be spent on capital

Speaker: NA
Text: works. Once again, Australia's balance-

Speaker: NA
Text: sheet in this year is shown to improve to

Speaker: NA
Text: the extent of Â£142,000,000 in assets over

Speaker: NA
Text: liabilities. The loan account shows that

Speaker: NA
Text: we expect to spend on works and housing

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£220,000,000 and on war service land

Speaker: NA
Text: settlement Â£7,000,000, making a total for

Speaker: NA
Text: these two items of Â£227,000,000. We

Speaker: NA
Text: expect to raise from loan funds

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£190,000,000 and from sinking fund

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£46,000,000, so that the loan account also

Speaker: NA
Text: shows a surplus of Â£9,000,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some one may then ask, " How is it that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer comes forward and says that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have a deficit of Â£61,000,000?" This is

Speaker: NA
Text: how he arrived at it: I pointed out that

Speaker: NA
Text: our revenue and expenditure account

Speaker: NA
Text: balances, that we have a Â£9,000,000 esti-

Speaker: NA
Text: mated surplus over the Loan Account but

Speaker: NA
Text: we expect we will have to pay off maturing

Speaker: NA
Text: securities amounting to Â£70,000,000. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasury officials say that if we deduct the

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£9,000,000 surplus in the Loan Account

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Â£70,000,000 we have to pay off

Speaker: NA
Text: our liabilities, the result is a cash deficit of

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£61,000,000. Of course, it is a cash deficit

Speaker: NA
Text: and it reminds me of the man who has an

Speaker: NA
Text: income of Â£2,000 a year and whose expen-

Speaker: NA
Text: diture is Â£1,000 a year, in addition to

Speaker: NA
Text: which he pays off Â£1,500 of the mortgage

Speaker: NA
Text: on his house and then says, " I have had a

Speaker: NA
Text: terrible year; I have a cash deficit of Â£500 ".

Speaker: NA
Text: If we are going to pay off our past liabilities

Speaker: NA
Text: at the rate that we have been and are paying

Speaker: NA
Text: them off, of course we will go on having a

Speaker: NA
Text: cash deficit.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am not questioning the decision which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasury has made. I realize that there

Speaker: NA
Text: is a distinct danger of inflation and that if

Speaker: NA
Text: a considerable amount of cash is placed in

Speaker: NA
Text: the hands of the people this would create

Speaker: NA
Text: new purchasing power and, in turn, could

Speaker: NA
Text: stimulate inflation. I think the proper ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proach to this Budget is to regard its real

Speaker: NA
Text: objective as anti-inflationary. It is a sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: plus budget and not a deficient budget, but

Speaker: NA
Text: it is one by which we are paying off our

Speaker: NA
Text: past liabilities because we realize that under

Speaker: NA
Text: present conditions our main and prime ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: jective is to keep down costs. Therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: we must not inject more money than is

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary into the community. If that is

Speaker: NA
Text: the true approach behind the Treasury

Speaker: NA
Text: thinking, as I believe it must be, I feel

Speaker: NA
Text: such concessions as were to be given in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget should have been given with that

Speaker: NA
Text: in mind, namely, the reduction of costs

Speaker: NA
Text: and the checking of inflation. Inflation is

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe most deadly thing in the country. It

Speaker: NA
Text: robs the worker of his wages and the

Speaker: NA
Text: thrifty of their savings. We have seen far

Speaker: NA
Text: too much inflation in the past. Under the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous Labour Government prices were

Speaker: NA
Text: going up at the rate of 10 per cent, per

Speaker: NA
Text: annum. In the early days of this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment they continued to go up at the rate

Speaker: NA
Text: of 10 per cent, per annum until finally the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government took stern action to steady

Speaker: NA
Text: costs. But we find that they are still rising

Speaker: NA
Text: at the rate of about 2 i per cent, per annum.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that this Budget should have been

Speaker: NA
Text: designed to reduce costs. Therefore, I

Speaker: NA
Text: would have liked to see reductions made in

Speaker: NA
Text: sales tax, because this directly affects the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of production. I think particularly of

Speaker: NA
Text: sales tax on foodstuffs and furniture and

Speaker: NA
Text: other items which are necessary to the

Speaker: NA
Text: well-being of the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: I now turn to the social service pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visions. Every honorable member will

Speaker: NA
Text: support the 7s. 6d. a week increase in pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions because every one realizes that some

Speaker: NA
Text: increase is absolutely essential. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: people have quibbled at the amount of the

Speaker: NA
Text: increase. My main objection is that it has

Speaker: NA
Text: been unscientific. I do not think it is good

Speaker: NA
Text: enough to pick a figure out of a hat and

Speaker: NA
Text: say " We will give them 7s. 6d. more ". I

Speaker: NA
Text: have said repeatedly in this chamber that

Speaker: NA
Text: the time is long overdue when there should

Speaker: NA
Text: be age security for all, provided on a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tributory basis and free of the means test.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not withdraw one word of that, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: will continue to advocate it so long as I

Speaker: NA
Text: am a member of this Parliament. The last

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour Government was in office for eight

Speaker: NA
Text: years but it did nothing about abolishing

Speaker: NA
Text: the means test. The present Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has been in office now for nearly ten years

Speaker: NA
Text: and although it has liberalized the means

Speaker: NA
Text: test from time to time it has not yet brought

Speaker: NA
Text: in a contributory plan in accordance with

Speaker: NA
Text: its policy. If the Government intends to

Speaker: NA
Text: retain this cruel and unjust means test, I

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that if the pension is to be based on

Speaker: NA
Text: needs the needs should be accurately

Speaker: NA
Text: measured.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the present legislation, a married

Speaker: NA
Text: couple receiving Â£7 a week in wages or

Speaker: NA
Text: that superannuation and also Â£8 15s. a week in

Speaker: NA
Text: pension- a total income of Â£15 15s. a week,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is Â£2 odd in excess of the basic

Speaker: NA
Text: wage-i s now to have that amount

Speaker: NA
Text: increased to Â£16 10s. a week, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately Â£3 in excess of the basic

Speaker: NA
Text: wage. Can any honorable member say

Speaker: NA
Text: that the needs of that couple are as great

Speaker: NA
Text: as the needs of the widow in receipt of

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£4 7s. 6d. now to be increased to Â£4 15s.

Speaker: NA
Text: a week? If we are going to measure pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions according to need, let us measure

Speaker: NA
Text: needs truly and properly and scientifically,

Speaker: NA
Text: not giving some people Â£3 a week more

Speaker: NA
Text: than the basic wage and keeping others,

Speaker: NA
Text: such as widows, single aged and invalids,

Speaker: NA
Text: down to Â£4 15s. a week. In addition, we

Speaker: NA
Text: find that the thrifty, in many cases, are

Speaker: NA
Text: worse off than they were before. A widow

Speaker: NA
Text: who has saved and invested Â£2,300, which

Speaker: NA
Text: brings in an income of Â£115 a year, has

Speaker: NA
Text: to try to live on that income or eat into her

Speaker: NA
Text: capital. She receives no pension at all,

Speaker: NA
Text: but a person who has saved nothing receives

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£4 15s. a week. I believe that our present

Speaker: NA
Text: social service legislation. imposes cruel

Speaker: NA
Text: injustices upon the thrifty. How can we

Speaker: NA
Text: expect people to save when they are

Speaker: NA
Text: penalized to such an extent by the means

Speaker: NA
Text: test?

Speaker: NA
Text: There are two ways of removing this

Speaker: NA
Text: injustice. One is to abolish the means test

Speaker: NA
Text: altogether and have a contributory plan of

Speaker: NA
Text: age security under which every aged

Speaker: NA
Text: person, regardless of means, will receive

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation because he or she has paid

Speaker: NA
Text: for it. Need will not be relevant. The

Speaker: NA
Text: sum received will be similar to the super-

Speaker: NA
Text: annuation of the public servant or the

Speaker: NA
Text: member of Parliament. They paid for their

Speaker: NA
Text: superannuation and they receive it as of

Speaker: NA
Text: right. The other way is to liberalize the

Speaker: NA
Text: means test so that justice is done to the

Speaker: NA
Text: thrifty as well as to the thriftless. At

Speaker: NA
Text: present, an aged person loses Â£1 a year of

Speaker: NA
Text: pension for every Â£10 of capital that he

Speaker: NA
Text: possesses in excess of Â£200. No person,

Speaker: NA
Text: whether aged or young, can safely invest

Speaker: NA
Text: his money at 10 per .cent, interest. The

Speaker: NA
Text: aged person who has saved during his

Speaker: NA
Text: working life is worse off than the aged

Speaker: NA
Text: person who has not saved at all. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: capital means test were so liberalized as to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide for a reduction of Â£1 a year in

Speaker: NA
Text: pension for every Â£20 of capital in excess

Speaker: NA
Text: of Â£200-i n other words, 5 per cent -th e

Speaker: NA
Text: thrifty man would be in no worse position

Speaker: NA
Text: than he who had not saved during his

Speaker: NA
Text: working life. Every one knows that 5 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, interest may be obtained on govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment loans, so people with a little capital

Speaker: NA
Text: would have no hesitation in supporting go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment loans in the knowledge that by

Speaker: NA
Text: doing so they would not be affecting their

Speaker: NA
Text: pension rights.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that it is too late now for my

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestion to be incorporated in the Bud-

Speaker: NA
Text: get, but I ask the Treasurer and the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment to liberalize the means test, if not

Speaker: NA
Text: to abolish it altogether, so that the thrifty

Speaker: NA
Text: will have an income at least equal to that

Speaker: NA
Text: of the spendthrifts. My suggestion also

Speaker: NA
Text: envisages the removal of the present ceiling

Speaker: NA
Text: of Â£2,250 worth of assets that may be

Speaker: NA
Text: owned by a person seeking a pension. If

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government saw fit to do so, it could

Speaker: NA
Text: implement these reforms at a cost of only

Speaker: NA
Text: a few millions of pounds, much less than

Speaker: NA
Text: the amount involved in its present pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posals.

Speaker: NA
Text: I congratulate the Government on Its

Speaker: NA
Text: decision to make hospital benefits available

Speaker: NA
Text: to all aged and chronically ill persons

Speaker: NA
Text: whether or not they are in recognized hos-

Speaker: NA
Text: pitals. It is the illness that justifies the

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance, not the bed in the hospital in

Speaker: NA
Text: which the sick person lies. I appreciate

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's action in concurring in

Speaker: NA
Text: the views that have been expressed by some

Speaker: NA
Text: of us in this Parliament who have felt so

Speaker: NA
Text: strongly about certain aged and chronically

Speaker: NA
Text: ill persons being denied hospital benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: simply because they have been in hospitals

Speaker: NA
Text: which, for purposes of the legislation, were

Speaker: NA
Text: not recognized by the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government is to be congratulated

Speaker: NA
Text: <dso on its decision to allow additional

Speaker: NA
Text: tention allowances to private companies

Speaker: NA
Text: without incurring penalty tax. In this coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try we need most of all capital-i n other

Speaker: NA
Text: words, savings-an d anything that can be

Speaker: NA
Text: done to encourage savings adds to employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and the development of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Obviously, it is difficult to induce people

Speaker: NA
Text: to save when we penalize them by the

Speaker: NA
Text: application of the means test. We must

Speaker: NA
Text: -realize that we cannot develop our country

Speaker: NA
Text: unless we have adequate capital to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: the new equipment that is necessary to

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain employment in our industries. I

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate the Government on increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: the amount of tax deduction for super-

Speaker: NA
Text: annuation and insurance payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: I support also the proposals regarding

Speaker: NA
Text: pharmaceutical benefits under which sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantially all prescriptions written by a

Speaker: NA
Text: doctor will be dispensed at a cost of 5s.

Speaker: NA
Text: each. I am sure that the community will

Speaker: NA
Text: accept that charge as a necessary check

Speaker: NA
Text: on those people who have been inclined

Speaker: NA
Text: to spend the taxpayers' money unneces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sarily on drugs that were not really re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired to deal with the particular com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plaint under treatment.

Speaker: NA
Text: My main criticism of the Budget is that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is too conservative. In a progressive

Speaker: NA
Text: country such as ours we could have taken,

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps, a few more risks. I have such

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence in the future of Australia, with

Speaker: NA
Text: its expanding production, that I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have been somewhat over-cautious.

Speaker: NA
Text: My great disappointment is that nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: has been done to liberalize the means test

Speaker: NA
Text: so as to help the thrifty members of our

Speaker: NA
Text: community. In fact, this Budget places

Speaker: NA
Text: the thrifty at an even greater disadvantage

Speaker: NA
Text: than they were before.

Speaker: Mr DAVIES
Text: Braddon) [12.11] -A s a

Speaker: NA
Text: relative newcomer to this Parliament I

Speaker: NA
Text: should like to congratulate the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Griffith ( Mr Chresby) on the

Speaker: NA
Text: maiden speech that he delivered last week.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Labour Party is opposed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Budget because it favours the large

Speaker: NA
Text: undertakings and gives no relief to the

Speaker: NA
Text: family man, the primary producer or indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try generally. We have been told so often

Speaker: NA
Text: of the so-called prosperity of Australia, but

Speaker: NA
Text: this is a myth to the pensioners and those

Speaker: NA
Text: on fixed and low incomes. If Australia is

Speaker: NA
Text: reas financially buoyant as we have been

Speaker: NA
Text: told by the Government, why have not

Speaker: NA
Text: greater concessions been made to the little

Speaker: NA
Text: people? The honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bowman ( Mr MCColm) was right in his

Speaker: NA
Text: description of the Budget as a thimble and

Speaker: NA
Text: pea Budget. Many people have looked for

Speaker: NA
Text: the pea-som e real concession-bu t have

Speaker: NA
Text: failed to find it. The concessions that

Speaker: NA
Text: have been granted, amounting to

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£25,000,000 in a full year, will be offset

Speaker: NA
Text: by more than Â£20,000,000 representing in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased charges imposed on the people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Increased telephone charges will cost the

Speaker: NA
Text: people Â£13,000,000 a year. That amount

Speaker: NA
Text: will increase greatly the huge profits that

Speaker: NA
Text: are being made already in the telephone

Speaker: NA
Text: section of the Postmaster-General's Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. In 1957-58, the last year for which

Speaker: NA
Text: figures are available, the telephone section

Speaker: NA
Text: showed a profit of Â£6,294,000 on a total

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue of Â£56,504,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reconstituted scheme of pharmaceuti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal benefits, by which people will be charged

Speaker: NA
Text: 5s. for each prescription written for them

Speaker: NA
Text: by a doctor, will cost the people about

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£4,000,000 and will place a heavy burden

Speaker: NA
Text: on the family man who is now trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: exist on the basic wage. It is a scathing

Speaker: NA
Text: indictment of this Government that in an

Speaker: NA
Text: era of so-called prosperity the sick should

Speaker: NA
Text: be taxed to provide revenue to bolster the

Speaker: NA
Text: finances of the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: The new postage rates are expected to

Speaker: NA
Text: yield about Â£5,000,000. The Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter ( Mr Menzies) last week announced

Speaker: NA
Text: certain modifications to the proposals out-

Speaker: NA
Text: lined by the Treasurer ( Mr Harold Holt),

Speaker: NA
Text: but the bulk postage rate will remain at

Speaker: NA
Text: double the previous rate.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my electorate the country newspapers

Speaker: NA
Text: - I call to mind the " King Island News ",

Speaker: NA
Text: the " Circular Head Chronicle", the

Speaker: NA
Text: " Tasmanian Farmer" and the leading

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper in northern and western Tas-

Speaker: NA
Text: mania, " The Advocate "-ar e doing an

Speaker: NA
Text: excellent job, but they will be hard hit by

Speaker: NA
Text: these impositions. The newspaper is a vital

Speaker: NA
Text: means of information and communication,

Speaker: NA
Text: not only for city dwellers but also, and

Speaker: NA
Text: more particularly, for people in country

Speaker: NA
Text: areas. All honorable members will remem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber the effect of the economy drive intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced by the Postmaster-General ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Davidson) earlier this year, which meant

Speaker: NA
Text: that certain mail deliveries were curtailed

Speaker: NA
Text: on public holidays. Country people

Speaker: NA
Text: suffered because they were denied their

Speaker: NA
Text: newspapers. I hope that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: will reconsider its proposals before bring-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing down enacting legislation. One news-

Speaker: NA
Text: paper in my electorate pays Â£6,000 a year

Speaker: NA
Text: in postage, half of which amount is met by

Speaker: NA
Text: the subscribers and the other half by the-

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper itself. The increased postage

Speaker: NA
Text: will double the amount previously paid:

Speaker: NA
Text: and under the policy of the newspaper,

Speaker: NA
Text: half of the additional charge of Â£12,000-

Speaker: NA
Text: will be met by the subscribers and the other

Speaker: NA
Text: half by the newspaper. Advertising rates

Speaker: NA
Text: must rise because, when we take into con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration the recent increase of 15s. in the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic wage, the pending margins claim and

Speaker: NA
Text: these increased postage rates, the newspaper

Speaker: NA
Text: will have no other course open to it. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, the average people will be the ones

Speaker: NA
Text: who suffer.

Speaker: NA
Text: The increased postage and telephone

Speaker: NA
Text: charges are estimated to cost Tasmanians

Speaker: NA
Text: alone Â£1,000,000 a year. This will be hard

Speaker: NA
Text: for Tasmanian industry, because of its

Speaker: NA
Text: distance from established markets. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: not fair to the people who manufacture in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania and who have to compete with

Speaker: NA
Text: those on the mainland who are not worried

Speaker: NA
Text: by high freights. The president of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hobart Chamber of Commerce this week

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed the concern being felt by indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try all over the State. He has been

Speaker: NA
Text: reported as follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: The sharp and unexpected rise in both the

Speaker: NA
Text: postal and telephone charges appeared to be an

Speaker: NA
Text: unaccountable action on the part of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that should be aware of the increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: necessity to reduce working costs. The increased

Speaker: NA
Text: charges would wipe out the benefits of reduced

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax and would increase the direct cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: all manufactured and commercial articles.

Speaker: NA
Text: Again, tiie consumer will be the loser,

Speaker: NA
Text: From calculations that have been made,

Speaker: NA
Text: private telephone subscribers in towns in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate are expected to pay from Â£5

Speaker: NA
Text: to Â£6 more a year for calls and about Â£2

Speaker: NA
Text: more in rentals. The family man will

Speaker: NA
Text: carry a double burden-increase s in his

Speaker: NA
Text: own telephone and postage rates and those

Speaker: NA
Text: passed on in the cost of the articles which

Speaker: NA
Text: he purchases. The effects will be Australia-

Speaker: NA
Text: wide. The " Mercury", which is printed

Speaker: NA
Text: in Hobart, quotes some alarming possible

Speaker: NA
Text: effects of the rises. It says-

Speaker: NA
Text: One large mail order firm in Australia has

Speaker: NA
Text: already negotiated a contract with a Dutch print-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Arm to produce its catalogue to be posted

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australians from Holland.

Speaker: NA
Text: Two large Australian retail firms are planning

Speaker: NA
Text: to have catalogues and mail order material printed

Speaker: NA
Text: in New Zealand and posted from Auckland to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian addresses because the cost of postage

Speaker: NA
Text: would be much lower.

Speaker: NA
Text: One world-famous monthly magazine which

Speaker: NA
Text: reprints in Australia will be involved in more

Speaker: NA
Text: that Â£100,000 extra a year in postage and may

Speaker: NA
Text: be obliged to make its distribution arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: for Australians outside Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Christmas card trade will be heavily hit.

Speaker: NA
Text: It' is claimed that as the average cost of a

Speaker: NA
Text: Christmas card is 4d., the postage will be higher

Speaker: NA
Text: than the cost of a card.

Speaker: NA
Text: After analysis of this Budget, it will be

Speaker: NA
Text: seen that the concessions which have been

Speaker: NA
Text: given by the Treasurer with one hand have

Speaker: NA
Text: been taken away with the other. With

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to industry, there has been no

Speaker: NA
Text: alleviation of company, pay-roll, or sales

Speaker: NA
Text: tax, and no relief through depreciation

Speaker: NA
Text: allowances. Instead, industry is now faced

Speaker: NA
Text: with considerable increases in expenses

Speaker: NA
Text: through extra telephone and postage

Speaker: NA
Text: charges. These will inevitably be added

Speaker: NA
Text: on to the cost structure although higher

Speaker: NA
Text: costs are already gradually pricing our pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducts out of world markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: The pension increase of 7s. 6d. a week

Speaker: NA
Text: considerably less than should have been

Speaker: NA
Text: awarded and is resented by all sections

Speaker: NA
Text: the community. The most disappointing

Speaker: NA
Text: and disconcerting feature of this social

Speaker: NA
Text: services programme is the failure to

Speaker: NA
Text: crease child endowment and so extend

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the so-called " social justice"

Speaker: NA
Text: the family unit. Allowance for the

Speaker: NA
Text: child has not changed for nine years and,

Speaker: NA
Text: for the second and the subsequent children,

Speaker: NA
Text: it has not changed for ten years. Yet costs

Speaker: NA
Text: have risen at least 100 per cent, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: time!

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition condemns, also, the

Speaker: NA
Text: failure of the Government to grant a rise

Speaker: NA
Text: the wives of invalid pensioners. They still

Speaker: NA
Text: receive a miserable 35s. a week for caring

Speaker: NA
Text: for the sick. I had hoped, too, that

Speaker: NA
Text: common justice to men who are still sufferto

Speaker: NA
Text: ing from war sacrifices involving injury

Speaker: NA
Text: or illness, they would be given a pension

Speaker: NA
Text: equal at least to the basic wage. Howtion

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, we find that these totally and permarkets,

Speaker: NA
Text: manently incapacitated pensioners will

Speaker: NA
Text: ceive only an extra 15s. per week, leaving

Speaker: NA
Text: them 31s. per week less than the basic

Speaker: NA
Text: wage. This is typical of the approach

Speaker: NA
Text: made by this Government to repatriation

Speaker: NA
Text: (benefits and to the whole question of

Speaker: NA
Text: service benefits as well.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable members on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber have dealt at length with the effect

Speaker: NA
Text: of the 5 per cent, reduction in income

Speaker: NA
Text: tax rates and have shown what little effect

Speaker: NA
Text: it will have on family income in a period

Speaker: NA
Text: of rising prices. I had hoped that workers'

Speaker: NA
Text: fares to and from work would be an allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: able tax deduction. I listened with great

Speaker: NA
Text: interest to the very able speech by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Parkes ( Mr Haylen)

Speaker: NA
Text: on Tuesday evening on the subject of taxa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion deductions. I am concerned about the

Speaker: NA
Text: workers in places such as Devonport,

Speaker: NA
Text: Ulverstone, and Wynyard who pay as

Speaker: NA
Text: much as Â£1 a week out of their wages in

Speaker: NA
Text: travelling expenses to and from the Asso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciated Pulp and Paper Mills in Burnie.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a considerable amount when we

Speaker: NA
Text: realize how other costs of living, borne by

Speaker: NA
Text: the workers in this country, have risen. At

Speaker: NA
Text: the same time, business executives run cars

Speaker: NA
Text: and charge them up to company expenses

Speaker: NA
Text: as tax deductions.

Speaker: NA
Text: I desire merely to add, regarding taxa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, that the tax structure is changing

Speaker: NA
Text: rapidly from one of direct taxation to one

Speaker: NA
Text: is of indirect taxation and that the consumer

Speaker: NA
Text: -th e wage-earner-i s bearing too great a

Speaker: NA
Text: of burden because of the imposition of sales

Speaker: NA
Text: tax on practically all items-includin g

Speaker: NA
Text: even school requisites-an d because of

Speaker: NA
Text: inexcise and customs duties. These latter

Speaker: NA
Text: imposts raised Â£208,000,000 last year and

Speaker: NA
Text: to the average payment per person was Â£29,

Speaker: NA
Text: first or more than l i s . a week.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn now to the position of primary

Speaker: NA
Text: producers in this country. The Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: same has glossed over the reduced income posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of primary producers with a passing

Speaker: NA
Text: reference to increased rural production.

Speaker: NA
Text: In reviewing the progress of the economy,

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Treasurer said that 1958-59 had been a

Speaker: NA
Text: notable year for rural production, and later

Speaker: NA
Text: he referred to the higher rural output and

Speaker: NA
Text: in the large volume of commodities that had

Speaker: NA
Text: be sold. The stark fact is that although

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian farmers have proved that they

Speaker: NA
Text: can produce the goods, the costs of produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: are pricing these goods out of world

Speaker: NA
Text: with a consequent drop in income

Speaker: NA
Text: reto the farmers. Actually, farm income, at

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£399,000,000, was the second lowest that

Speaker: NA
Text: has been recorded in the past ten years.

Speaker: NA
Text: A study of the graph on page 6 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: social paper, " National Income and Expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture", reveals very plainly that over the

Speaker: NA
Text: past ten years wages and salaries have

Speaker: NA
Text: shown a gradual upward trend, in keeping

Speaker: NA
Text: with company and other business income,

Speaker: NA
Text: but that farm income, apart from two

Speaker: NA
Text: seasons, has shown several depressions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The latest figures that are available from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bureau of Agricultural Economics show

Speaker: NA
Text: that in Tasmania 20 per cent, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: primary producers earn incomes below

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£500 per annum and 61 per cent, earn

Speaker: NA
Text: below Â£1,000 per annum. For the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia, IS per cent, of primary pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers earn incomes below Â£500 per

Speaker: NA
Text: annum and 55 per cent, earn below Â£1,000

Speaker: NA
Text: per annum.

Speaker: NA
Text: We heard talk of expansion in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer's speech, but what encourage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is given to people to develop the food

Speaker: NA
Text: bowl of the north of Australia through

Speaker: NA
Text: increased tax concessions to people who go

Speaker: NA
Text: into those areas and develop them? What

Speaker: NA
Text: incentive is given to young people to

Speaker: NA
Text: develop farms in marginal areas? It is not

Speaker: NA
Text: uncommon in my electorate and, I believe,

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout Australia, for a young farmer

Speaker: NA
Text: on a property of 400 acres to have to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: yearly commitments of approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£2,000, made up of capital repayments

Speaker: NA
Text: and bank interest, before making a penny

Speaker: NA
Text: for ordinary living expenses or for develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. I had great hopes of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank and the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Development Bank introducing for civilians

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes of land development similar to the

Speaker: NA
Text: war service land settlement scheme, but

Speaker: NA
Text: money is just as hard to get now. No

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt, it is still being channelled by the

Speaker: NA
Text: private trading banks into the more lucra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive fields of hire purchase.

Speaker: NA
Text: Farmers, to-day, look upon the Post-

Speaker: NA
Text: master-General's Department as a taxing

Speaker: NA
Text: medium. They are obliged to use tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: phones a great deal owing to their distance

Speaker: NA
Text: from merchants and other suppliers. Now

Speaker: NA
Text: they will be forced to pay more for

Speaker: NA
Text: telephone calls and postage. The news-

Speaker: NA
Text: papers and periodicals used by these people

Speaker: NA
Text: invariably go through the post, so, by

Speaker: NA
Text: having to pay additional postage, these

Speaker: NA
Text: pioneers of the outback are to be penalized

Speaker: NA
Text: further by this Liberal-Country Party

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. Increases incurred by busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness houses, too, will inevitably be passed

Speaker: NA
Text: on to farmers and consumers and, to-day,

Speaker: NA
Text: this is a serious matter. A great proportion

Speaker: NA
Text: of farmers, as I have shown, are not making

Speaker: NA
Text: the basic wage although their wives and

Speaker: NA
Text: children may assist them with production.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet we find no relief for them in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget!

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Primary Industry ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Adermann) in his speech on the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: said-

Speaker: NA
Text: Our undisputed objective is to raise Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: economy to the level of the economy of a great

Speaker: NA
Text: nation. The policies enunciated in the Budget are

Speaker: NA
Text: aimed at the achievement of this objective . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: The important factors necessary to the attainment

Speaker: NA
Text: of our objective are, first, vitality and, secondly,

Speaker: NA
Text: a generally sound structure of rural industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Neither of these objectives receives any sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: port or stimulus in this Budget. Nothing is

Speaker: NA
Text: done to give relief, halt rising costs, or pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vent this creeping inflation. Serious con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cern is felt for the Tasmanian apple

Speaker: NA
Text: industry in this regard. I feel that it will

Speaker: NA
Text: do no harm to acquaint honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers with a few facts showing how rising

Speaker: NA
Text: costs in recent years are pricing us out of

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas markets. It costs 8s. 6d. to pack

Speaker: NA
Text: a case of apples. This covers the case,

Speaker: NA
Text: straw boards, wrapping paper, grading and

Speaker: NA
Text: nailing. Freight on a case of apples from

Speaker: NA
Text: the packing shed to England is 15s. lOd.

Speaker: NA
Text: and an average of 5s. commission for sales

Speaker: NA
Text: in that country is charged. The costs on a

Speaker: NA
Text: case of apples, therefore, total Â£1 9s. 4d.

Speaker: NA
Text: before the grower gets a penny for his

Speaker: NA
Text: fruit or any return toward the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: manures, sprays and general cultivation.

Speaker: NA
Text: These costs have been averaged out by a

Speaker: NA
Text: group of orchardists in the Huon Valley.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know of some growers who are receiving

Speaker: NA
Text: 12s. in the shed. If we subtract the 8s. 6d.

Speaker: NA
Text: costs for presentation of a case of apples,

Speaker: NA
Text: the grower is left with 3s. 6d. a case for his

Speaker: NA
Text: fruit and to cover production costs. The

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of this industry to our overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: balance of trade is seen from the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1958 crop was worth Â£7,164,000 and

Speaker: NA
Text: that 4,388,000 cases were exported over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas of a total crop of 6,641,000 cases.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recently, an honorable senator who sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports the Government, when speaking in

Speaker: NA
Text: another place, stated that the price received

Speaker: NA
Text: for Australian apples in England and

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe had collapsed at the end of last

Speaker: NA
Text: season. He said that many of the

Speaker: NA
Text: recognized buyers had stated that they were

Speaker: NA
Text: not anxious to buy Australian apples in the.

Speaker: NA
Text: future and were recommending Australian,

Speaker: NA
Text: growers to send their fruit on consignment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I only hope that this will never mean a

Speaker: NA
Text: return to pre-war conditions when growers

Speaker: NA
Text: often received a debit return instead of a

Speaker: NA
Text: credit for their exports. I know one classic

Speaker: NA
Text: case of a grower who consigned 200 cases

Speaker: NA
Text: and received a bill for 2s. 6d. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of this industry, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: should do -everything possible to reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: costs. The Department of Trade should

Speaker: NA
Text: investigate overseas freight rates with a

Speaker: NA
Text: view to their reduction, and should explore

Speaker: NA
Text: every possible avenue for new markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is very pleasing to note that, at

Speaker: NA
Text: opening wool sales on Monday, prices were

Speaker: NA
Text: from 12i per cent, to 15 per cent, up on

Speaker: NA
Text: last season's closing levels. It is to

Speaker: NA
Text: hoped that the market will remain buoyant.

Speaker: NA
Text: The opening prices were higher than those

Speaker: NA
Text: expected but are still below those that

Speaker: NA
Text: obtained in 1957. According to informaTreasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: tion published in " Wool Facts ", a publicaunder

Speaker: NA
Text: tion compiled by the Australian Woolduced

Speaker: NA
Text: growers' Council, the value of wool the

Speaker: NA
Text: exported in the twelve months ended 30th

Speaker: NA
Text: June, 1959, was Â£302,000,000 compared congenial

Speaker: NA
Text: with Â£373,000,000 for 1957-58, a drop of

Speaker: NA
Text: 19 per cent. The value of wool exports,

Speaker: NA
Text: a proportion of our total export income,

Speaker: NA
Text: fell from 46 per cent, in 1957-58 to

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent, in 1958-59.

Speaker: NA
Text: Beef exports to the United Kingdom and

Speaker: NA
Text: to the United States of America have

Speaker: NA
Text: reached an all time record, but experts are

Speaker: NA
Text: now warning exporters that they should

Speaker: NA
Text: regard the American market with caution.

Speaker: NA
Text: Prices American buyers are prepared to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: are now falling, and sales are becoming

Speaker: NA
Text: more difficult to effect. One research

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee in the United States of America

Speaker: NA
Text: recently predicted that if the herd increase

Speaker: NA
Text: continued at the present rate, prices for

Speaker: NA
Text: meat could fall by 50 per cent. This

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment must do all in its power to bring

Speaker: NA
Text: stability to our rural industries because

Speaker: NA
Text: must export to live and these rural exports

Speaker: NA
Text: form the bulk of our overseas balance of

Speaker: NA
Text: payments. The fat lamb industry is faced

Speaker: NA
Text: this season with depressed prices. Lambs,

Speaker: NA
Text: at an average of Â£2 each, are a losing

Speaker: NA
Text: position. Many other crops such as pinebring

Speaker: NA
Text: apples, potatoes, and bananas are in

Speaker: NA
Text: same category and yet this Budget which

Speaker: NA
Text: said to be " directed to the twin purposes of

Speaker: NA
Text: expansion and stability", allows for no

Speaker: NA
Text: concession for primary producers. Potaof

Speaker: NA
Text: toes were once the staple crop of the northcession.

Speaker: NA
Text: west coast of Tasmania, but the area

Speaker: NA
Text: planted with potatoes in that district in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1958-59 was down to 16,186 acres. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: a decrease of 5,510 acres on the figure for

Speaker: NA
Text: 1957-58 and is the smallest area sown since

Speaker: NA
Text: In connexion with the concept of expan-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion, I am sorry that the Government does

Speaker: NA
Text: not encourage people, by tax remissions and

Speaker: NA
Text: other concessions, to go into isolated areas

Speaker: NA
Text: of this great country and by clearing the

Speaker: NA
Text: land and cultivation bring additional land

Speaker: NA
Text: the into production. I refer now particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: to King Island. This island, roughly 40

Speaker: NA
Text: miles long and 20 miles wide, is situated

Speaker: NA
Text: be mid-way between Tasmania and Victoria.

Speaker: NA
Text: Residents there have tried repeatedly to

Speaker: NA
Text: obtain a zonal income tax concession, and

Speaker: NA
Text: were as early as November, 1951, the former

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out that concessions

Speaker: NA
Text: section 79A of the act were intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: as a form of practical recognition of

Speaker: NA
Text: disabilities to which residents of the

Speaker: NA
Text: areas concerned are subject because of un-

Speaker: NA
Text: climatic conditions, isolation and

Speaker: NA
Text: the high cost of living in comparison with

Speaker: NA
Text: as other parts of Australia. These require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments are all to be found on King Island,

Speaker: NA
Text: 37 yet the Treasurer has again turned down

Speaker: NA
Text: the request.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Department of Primary Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: which administers the war service land

Speaker: NA
Text: settlement scheme, recognizes the difficul-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties of more than 160 Second World War

Speaker: NA
Text: soldier settlers on King Island from the

Speaker: NA
Text: viewpoint of their isolation from markets,

Speaker: NA
Text: high freight costs, the high cost of living

Speaker: NA
Text: comand the need for re-development of most

Speaker: NA
Text: properties. It has set up a committee of

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry to investigate the financial position

Speaker: NA
Text: of each settler on the island. I regret that

Speaker: NA
Text: Gothe Minister for Primary Industry ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Adermann) would not agree to the request

Speaker: NA
Text: we from the islanders to set up a joint parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary committee to inquire into all

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects of war service land settlement, but

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend him for setting up this commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee of inquiry. I assure him of the full

Speaker: NA
Text: prosupport of the settlers in any attempt to

Speaker: NA
Text: stability to the various settle-

Speaker: NA
Text: the ments not only on King Island but

Speaker: NA
Text: is also at Mawbanna, Montagu and Preolenna.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is to be hoped that one day, some

Speaker: NA
Text: federal Treasurer will recognize the claims

Speaker: NA
Text: the King Islanders for a zonal tax con-

Speaker: NA
Text: These people are battling against

Speaker: NA
Text: high costs brought about by their isolation

Speaker: NA
Text: and the great depreciation of plant and

Speaker: NA
Text: machinery that occurs there. One has only

Speaker: NA
Text: to see the effect of the salt air on motor

Speaker: NA
Text: cars, tractors and other farm machinery to

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciate the difficulties of their position,

Speaker: NA
Text: the fairness of their claims for zonal tax

Speaker: NA
Text: concessions and for further depreciation

Speaker: NA
Text: allowances on farm machinery. However

Speaker: NA
Text: we expand the economy of this country-

Speaker: NA
Text: and we must expand to hold it-i t is vitally

Speaker: NA
Text: important that our natural resources and

Speaker: NA
Text: assets are used to the fullest extent. Full

Speaker: NA
Text: use must be made of the funds and re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sources of the Commonwealth Bank.

Speaker: NA
Text: Here, I wish to make a plea for the

Speaker: NA
Text: timber industry not only in Tasmania but

Speaker: NA
Text: also in Australia as a whole. Importations

Speaker: NA
Text: of cheap Malayan timber have risen by

Speaker: NA
Text: 25,000,000 super, feet in recent years.

Speaker: NA
Text: The production of Tasmanian timber has

Speaker: NA
Text: dropped from 151,000,000 super, feet

Speaker: NA
Text: to 141,000,000 super, feet in four years.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is mainly due to lack of li-in. and

Speaker: NA
Text: 2-in. hardwood. In a fiercely competitive

Speaker: NA
Text: trade, millers find they have not the finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial resources to cut these lines of timber

Speaker: NA
Text: because it takes approximately eighteen

Speaker: NA
Text: months for li-in. timber and two years

Speaker: NA
Text: for 2-in. timber to air-dry before being

Speaker: NA
Text: kiln-dried. Approximately 4,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: super, feet is available now, but Tas-

Speaker: NA
Text: mania could build this total to 10,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: super, feet a year and compete success-

Speaker: NA
Text: fully with Malayan imports if some finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial backing were given. Millers simply

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot afford to wait while these stocks

Speaker: NA
Text: drying before making sales.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth should investigate

Speaker: NA
Text: the possibility of making an advance to

Speaker: NA
Text: millers of, for example, 80s. for 100 green

Speaker: NA
Text: super, feet. An amount of Â£400,000

Speaker: NA
Text: to cover 10,000,000 super, feet could

Speaker: NA
Text: easily come from the Commonwealth Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: and be repaid by the millers when they

Speaker: NA
Text: had disposed of their stocks of the finished

Speaker: NA
Text: product. I make this plea because the

Speaker: NA
Text: timber industry is of great importance

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania. This Government has refused

Speaker: NA
Text: to restrict the rapidly increasing imports

Speaker: NA
Text: from Malaya and has over-ridden the

Speaker: NA
Text: commendation of the Tariff Board for

Speaker: NA
Text: freight subsidy for the Tasmanian product.

Speaker: NA
Text: Perhaps the Government will give some

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration to providing financial assisttelevision

Speaker: NA
Text: ance to millers in their attempt to build

Speaker: NA
Text: up stocks of l i and 2 inch timber which

Speaker: NA
Text: could successfully compete with imported

Speaker: NA
Text: timber in the joinery trade. I have stated

Speaker: NA
Text: before in this chamber that any assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: to the timber trade would be a good

Speaker: NA
Text: national investment. A cycle of employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is created starting with the loggers

Speaker: NA
Text: and the millers in the bush. The mills go

Speaker: NA
Text: into increased production and that provides

Speaker: NA
Text: employment for bricklayers, tilers, plumbers,

Speaker: NA
Text: electricians and home furnishers. That

Speaker: NA
Text: cycle influences and affects whole sections

Speaker: NA
Text: of the community, and any move to create

Speaker: NA
Text: employment in this country should be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered carefully by the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unemployment figures have risen from a

Speaker: NA
Text: minima of 31,000 in 1956, 46,000 in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1957, and 56,000 in 1958, to a minimum

Speaker: NA
Text: of 63,000 in any month of this year. The

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunate unemployed and their depen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dants are the people for whom the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: should have provided a greater measure

Speaker: NA
Text: of social justice. But they are simply

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to by the Government as a per-

Speaker: NA
Text: centage of the work force, and the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: contains no mention of any attempt to

Speaker: NA
Text: solve this problem of growing unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. This Government has succeeded in

Speaker: NA
Text: its objective of creating a pool of unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment and, by denying those out of

Speaker: NA
Text: work any increase in the unemployment

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit, shows itself to be quite indifferent

Speaker: NA
Text: to this great social problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: In conclusion, I wish to support the

Speaker: NA
Text: claims made by my colleague, the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: are able member for Wilmot ( Mr Duthie), for

Speaker: NA
Text: the provision of television services to the

Speaker: NA
Text: north-west coast of Tasmania as soon as

Speaker: NA
Text: practicable. In this area we are averaging

Speaker: NA
Text: 40 per cent, reception from Melbourne tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision stations and, since television is here

Speaker: NA
Text: to stay, people there are keen to avail

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves of this medium of entertain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. The Government should investigate

Speaker: NA
Text: the possibility of relaying programmes to

Speaker: NA
Text: the coast, from Melbourne, by means of a

Speaker: NA
Text: booster station on King Island, or from

Speaker: NA
Text: to Hobart by a booster station on Mount

Speaker: NA
Text: Roland, and should make television recep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion available to the isolated mining com-

Speaker: NA
Text: remunities on the west coast by a booster

Speaker: NA
Text: a station on Mount Sedgewick or some

Speaker: NA
Text: other suitable west coast peak.

Speaker: NA
Text: Retailers are reaping a harvest by selling

Speaker: NA
Text: receivers which will be out of

Speaker: NA
Text: date by the time television comes to the

Speaker: NA
Text: north-west coast in its right and proper

Speaker: NA
Text: fashion. If a station can be set up for

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£300,000 to Â£400,000, as mentioned in

Speaker: NA
Text: <ne recent debate on the extension of tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision to country areas, I hope it will not

Speaker: NA
Text: be long before the Postmaster-General

Speaker: NA
Text: approves of the extension of television to

Speaker: NA
Text: the areas I have mentioned.

Speaker: Mr ASTON
Text: Phillip) [12.37] - I have

Speaker: NA
Text: listened with interest to the first speech

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Braddon ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Davies) on a budget, and I must confess

Speaker: NA
Text: that I was rather disappointed, because he

Speaker: NA
Text: followed the humdrum line that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: had from the Labour Opposition right

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout this debate. We have heard

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members opposite trying to whip

Speaker: NA
Text: into life the old, dead story of unem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment. Surely, Mr Temporary Chair-

Speaker: NA
Text: man, any political party with any political

Speaker: NA
Text: nous knows that unemployment in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country is a dead issue-know s that, far

Speaker: NA
Text: from rising, unemployment has fallen.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, I have very high hopes that it will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to fall.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Braddon

Speaker: NA
Text: talked about this Government having

Speaker: NA
Text: succeeded in creating a pool of unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. To rebut that statement I simply

Speaker: NA
Text: refer the honorable gentleman to the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment's history over the ten years in

Speaker: NA
Text: which it has been in office, when, at many

Speaker: NA
Text: times, we have had full employment in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Like many other members of the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Party, the honorable gentleman looks on

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget-time as a time for gathering round

Speaker: NA
Text: the Christmas tree, with handouts for

Speaker: NA
Text: everybody, irrespective of where the

Speaker: NA
Text: finance is to come from. We never hear

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Opposition at Budget-time any

Speaker: NA
Text: constructive suggestion for improving the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy or increasing our expansion and

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity. All we have from it this

Speaker: NA
Text: time is criticism about the level of social

Speaker: NA
Text: service benents, tax rates and postal

Speaker: NA
Text: charges. At the same time, honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite talk about the " colossal

Speaker: NA
Text: profits " made by large manufacturers and

Speaker: NA
Text: retailers. Surely a little simple arithmetic

Speaker: NA
Text: would tell any one that the creation of a

Speaker: NA
Text: condition of full employment relies on the

Speaker: NA
Text: expansion of the activities of our manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facturers, so that the working people of

Speaker: NA
Text: this country, whom the Opposition claims

Speaker: NA
Text: to represent here, can have the high

Speaker: NA
Text: standards of living that Australians con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider necessary. I believe that before the

Speaker: NA
Text: public will ever return the Labour Party

Speaker: NA
Text: to the treasury bench, that party will have

Speaker: NA
Text: to develop a more national outlook-

Speaker: NA
Text: losing its sectional outlook and abandon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing its attempt to whip up ill-feeling in

Speaker: NA
Text: the community about class distinctions.

Speaker: NA
Text: The days when that kind of thing meant

Speaker: NA
Text: anything have gone. The people are sick

Speaker: NA
Text: by of it. They have had good government

Speaker: NA
Text: over the last ten years, and I suggest to

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentlemen opposite that at least

Speaker: NA
Text: they should develop a more national out-

Speaker: NA
Text: look for the benefit of this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: With those few remarks, Mr Temporary

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman, I turn now to matters which

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe are important in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget. During the Budget speech the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer ( Mr Harold Holt) quite properly

Speaker: NA
Text: referred in commendatory terms to the

Speaker: NA
Text: expansion and increased productivity that

Speaker: NA
Text: had taken place in Australia over the last

Speaker: NA
Text: ten years. He rightly took pride in the

Speaker: NA
Text: record of the Government which, as a result

Speaker: NA
Text: of its sound, progressive policy, has main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained the Australian economy in a most

Speaker: NA
Text: sound and extremely stable position.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was particularly pleased to learn that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Budget provides for increases of age

Speaker: NA
Text: and invalid pensions and repatriation bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fits. I point out, however, that these in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creases, at this particular time, are no

Speaker: NA
Text: more than could reasonably be given by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government. Particularly do I say so

Speaker: NA
Text: because I feel that there are real prospects

Speaker: NA
Text: of further increases in the prices of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer goods in the ensuing year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst the proposed increases of pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions and repatriation benefits are accept-

Speaker: NA
Text: able, I should prefer to see them coupled

Speaker: NA
Text: with a relaxation of the means test. I

Speaker: NA
Text: share the views of the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Sturt ( Mr Wilson) on this matter. The

Speaker: NA
Text: means test does not encourage thrift. In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, it penalizes those who have taken

Speaker: NA
Text: pains in their early life to save up for their

Speaker: NA
Text: old age. With the proposed increases in

Speaker: NA
Text: the rates of pensions people on super-

Speaker: NA
Text: annuation, or who come within the ambit

Speaker: NA
Text: of the means test, will be further pena-

Speaker: NA
Text: lized. Many of them have put their

Speaker: NA
Text: savings into bonds and superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes, and have made a contribution to

Speaker: NA
Text: the comforts that they will enjoy-o r hope

Speaker: NA
Text: to enjoy-i n the later stages of their lives.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the Budget proposals a married

Speaker: NA
Text: couple will be able to receive an income

Speaker: NA
Text: of Â£16 10s. a week, made up of their pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions and any outside income they may

Speaker: NA
Text: gain, without affecting their pensions. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is more than Â£3 above the basic wage.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are many people who, because of

Speaker: NA
Text: their thrift, are not receiving this amount

Speaker: NA
Text: into their homes to-day. The return from

Speaker: NA
Text: their investments and the superannuation

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits for which they have contributed,

Speaker: NA
Text: together do not give them such an income.

Speaker: NA
Text: Consequently, those people are becoming

Speaker: NA
Text: the new poor of Australia. I urgently sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gest to the Government that it give con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration to a further alleviation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: means test so as to embrace these people,

Speaker: NA
Text: who at present are being penalized because

Speaker: NA
Text: of their past thrift.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thrift, of course, should be encouraged,

Speaker: NA
Text: not discouraged. As a result of the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinued application of the means test people

Speaker: NA
Text: who might otherwise save to support, or

Speaker: NA
Text: help to support, themselves in their old

Speaker: NA
Text: age, will squander their savings so that

Speaker: NA
Text: they will be eligible to receive pensions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Most honorable members have experiences

Speaker: NA
Text: of people telling them of their financial

Speaker: NA
Text: position and wanting to know how far they

Speaker: NA
Text: must bring their assets down in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: receive a pension without being affected

Speaker: NA
Text: by the means test. I believe, Sir, that this

Speaker: NA
Text: position should be avoided. I realize that

Speaker: NA
Text: wherever we draw the line in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: the means test there will always be some-

Speaker: NA
Text: body above it and somebody else below it.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the same time, however, when we con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider that a pensioner couple may have an

Speaker: NA
Text: income of Â£16 10s. a week, without their

Speaker: NA
Text: pensions being affected, and without their

Speaker: NA
Text: having had to save a penny towards it, we

Speaker: NA
Text: can see that people who did save for the

Speaker: NA
Text: future are being penalized.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another matter touching social services

Speaker: NA
Text: to which I wish to refer is the funeral

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit. I believe that the funeral benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: has not been increased since 1943. It still

Speaker: NA
Text: stands at the princely sum of Â£10. Every-

Speaker: NA
Text: body knows of the increases in costs that

Speaker: NA
Text: have occurred since 1943, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: funeral costs, which seem to have risen

Speaker: NA
Text: to an exorbitant degree. In most cases it

Speaker: NA
Text: is the relatives of a deceased age pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner who have either to pay for the

Speaker: NA
Text: funeral in full or contribute to its cost,

Speaker: NA
Text: although many aged pensioners do manage

Speaker: NA
Text: to scrape from their pensions a few shillings

Speaker: NA
Text: each week, which are put aside to help

Speaker: NA
Text: them to keep their pride by knowing that

Speaker: NA
Text: they will have a decent burial. I submit

Speaker: NA
Text: that Â£10 as a funeral benefit is grossly in-

Speaker: NA
Text: adequate at this time, and the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: should look at this with a view to increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing it to an amount more in keeping with

Speaker: NA
Text: actual funeral costs to-day.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sitting suspended from 12.45-to 2.35 p.m.

Speaker: Mr ASTON
Text: Prio r to the suspension

Speaker: NA
Text: of the sitting I made a plea to the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to make some modification in the

Speaker: NA
Text: means test and also to increase funeral

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits. The cost to the community of

Speaker: NA
Text: social services must inevitably increase,

Speaker: NA
Text: but at the same time I believe that the

Speaker: NA
Text: majority of Australians will accept that

Speaker: NA
Text: cost if it means that the aged and the

Speaker: NA
Text: sick in the community will enjoy a better

Speaker: NA
Text: standard of living, provided, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: that social services are based on needs.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was extremely disappointed that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget, except for a liberalization of the

Speaker: NA
Text: retention allowance for private companies,

Speaker: NA
Text: did not give any incentives for the expan-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of the private sector of the economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: It may be argued that public works in

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves add to the expansion and are an

Speaker: NA
Text: encouragement to the private sector, but

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that the private sector of the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy deserves some other incentives.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasurer in his Budget speech re-

Speaker: NA
Text: peatedly acknowledged the part played by

Speaker: NA
Text: industry and on several other occasions he

Speaker: NA
Text: has emphasized the role of industry in the

Speaker: NA
Text: past ten years. He posed the question:

Speaker: NA
Text: Can this development be equalled or sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: passed in the next decade? I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: the answer is " Yes"; but I also believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that encouragement for industry to achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: still higher production and efficiency and

Speaker: NA
Text: to reduce costs of production must be

Speaker: NA
Text: given, and not given too late.

Speaker: NA
Text: In recent years our work force has in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased considerably. In the last four

Speaker: NA
Text: years it has increased by approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: 60,000 persons a year and now numbers

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately 4,000,000 people. By 1970

Speaker: NA
Text: it is anticipated that the work force will

Speaker: NA
Text: total 5,300,000 people, or an increase of

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,300,000 people in ten years. This is a

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of 2.6 per cent, per annuni compared

Speaker: NA
Text: with 1.6 per cent, in recent years. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated that in 1960 104,000 additional

Speaker: NA
Text: workers will be available for employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opportunities for employment must be

Speaker: NA
Text: available immediately if we are to main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain or improve our low unemployment

Speaker: NA
Text: percentage and our standard of living, and

Speaker: NA
Text: to increase our productivity level. The

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing industries will be called

Speaker: NA
Text: upon to absorb approximately 40,000 of

Speaker: NA
Text: the additional work force. It is well to

Speaker: NA
Text: note that the yearly absorption rate over

Speaker: NA
Text: the last two years has been approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: 16,000 people. It is obvious therefore that

Speaker: NA
Text: employment will have to be found for

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately two and one half times the

Speaker: NA
Text: number now absorbed yearly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those figures show quite starkly the

Speaker: NA
Text: magnitude of the problem ahead and repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent a challenge that must be faced by

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. One cannot fail to conclude that

Speaker: NA
Text: unless these additional persons are readily

Speaker: NA
Text: absorbed into employment, our internal

Speaker: NA
Text: economy may require some unpleasant

Speaker: NA
Text: adjustments.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition to these responsibilities, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry and commerce must play a leading

Speaker: NA
Text: role in fulfilling our much needed export

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements. The Export Development

Speaker: NA
Text: Council has reached tbe conclusion that if

Speaker: NA
Text: we are to avoid continual balance of pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments problems we must extend our income

Speaker: NA
Text: from trading overseas by Â£250,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: within the next five years, or at the rate

Speaker: NA
Text: of Â£50,000,000 a year. The report of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Export Development Council states-

Speaker: NA
Text: Prospects in traditional markets, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: for agricultural foodstuffs, were not encouraging

Speaker: NA
Text: although exports of basic raw materials would

Speaker: NA
Text: improve if economic growth was maintained

Speaker: NA
Text: abroad. . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: To earn the export income needed to support

Speaker: NA
Text: economic development, ever increasing attention

Speaker: NA
Text: must be devoted to manufactured and semi-

Speaker: NA
Text: manufactured products.

Speaker: NA
Text: The council points out that although

Speaker: NA
Text: spects for wool exports are somewhat enit

Speaker: NA
Text: couraging-thi s has proved to be correct-

Speaker: NA
Text: there is less optimism for wheat exports

Speaker: NA
Text: the next five years.

Speaker: NA
Text: The council believes that the chief possioverall

Speaker: NA
Text: bilities for growth in overseas sales lie

Speaker: NA
Text: iron and steel products, motor vehicles,

Speaker: NA
Text: agricultural machinery and parts, engineertaxes

Speaker: NA
Text: ing products, tools, hardware and

Speaker: NA
Text: products. Those articles at present are

Speaker: NA
Text: supplied and manufactured by secondary

Speaker: NA
Text: industries. It can be seen clearly then that

Speaker: NA
Text: industry is urgently in need of encourage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment if it is to gear itself to the task ahead.

Speaker: NA
Text: The building of great factories, the carrying

Speaker: NA
Text: out of more scientific experiments, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: improving of efficiency depend very greatly

Speaker: NA
Text: on the ability of industry to meet the chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenge of absorption, productivity and in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased sales abroad, all of which are vital

Speaker: NA
Text: to our economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: A great deal has been done to advertise

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian goods in overseas markets. But

Speaker: NA
Text: much more must be done in this field to

Speaker: NA
Text: secure the necessary expansion and provide

Speaker: NA
Text: the incentive to sell or market overseas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our commercial undertakings and manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facturing industries must become conscious

Speaker: NA
Text: of the advantages of trading with Asian and

Speaker: NA
Text: other countries. Australia is a young, pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gressive and expanding country. We enjoy

Speaker: NA
Text: the confidence of the free world. We

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be afraid of incipient inflation,

Speaker: NA
Text: however much we may dislike the idea of

Speaker: NA
Text: inflation, because a young country expand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing as rapidly as Australia has been expand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in the past can hardly avoid some

Speaker: NA
Text: measure of inflation if it is to go forward.

Speaker: NA
Text: A too cautious attitude could have severe

Speaker: NA
Text: limiting effects on the rate of our expansion

Speaker: NA
Text: and development. If we are to avoid being

Speaker: NA
Text: priced out of overseas markets and if we

Speaker: NA
Text: are to reduce the cost of living on the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer market in Australia, costs of manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facture must be kept to a minimum.

Speaker: NA
Text: It may be pointed out that undoubtedly

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposed increase in telephone and

Speaker: NA
Text: postal charges will be borne in the main by

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. Those increases, together with

Speaker: NA
Text: the recent basic wage increase, must have a

Speaker: NA
Text: substantial and unavoidable effect on costs

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia. Industry generally will not

Speaker: NA
Text: be content to bear those costs and, as a

Speaker: NA
Text: consequence, will pass them on to the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: prosumer. I suggest to the Government that

Speaker: NA
Text: may see fit to examine the range of taxes

Speaker: NA
Text: that add to inflation-taxe s which, when

Speaker: NA
Text: in trade and industry are playing and will

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to play an increasing part in our

Speaker: NA
Text: economy, inflate the prices at which

Speaker: NA
Text: in we are required to sell overseas or on the

Speaker: NA
Text: consumer market. Such taxes are retarding

Speaker: NA
Text: and should be either progressively

Speaker: NA
Text: similar reduced or abolished altogether.

Speaker: NA
Text: This brings me to the point that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government should have considered some

Speaker: NA
Text: measure of relief in pay-roll tax, either in

Speaker: NA
Text: the form of reduction in the rate of the tax,

Speaker: NA
Text: an increase in the deductible allowance, or,

Speaker: NA
Text: less probable, its total abolition. To my

Speaker: NA
Text: mind that would have had the effect of

Speaker: NA
Text: reminding industry that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: had not entirely forgotten it and was con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned with the magnitude of the task that

Speaker: NA
Text: lies ahead. I do not want it to be thought

Speaker: NA
Text: that I believe that industry is not doing

Speaker: NA
Text: well at present. In fact, industry and com-

Speaker: NA
Text: merce have improved their positions in

Speaker: NA
Text: recent years and have made good profits

Speaker: NA
Text: and achieved good trading results. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: any fair-minded person will agree that had

Speaker: NA
Text: it not been for the fact that industry and

Speaker: NA
Text: commerce have been able to progress and

Speaker: NA
Text: make profits, our economy would not be in

Speaker: NA
Text: its present healthy state.

Speaker: NA
Text: Relief from the pay-roll tax would

Speaker: NA
Text: stimulate the development, expansion and

Speaker: NA
Text: progress of industry, and it would encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: the inflow of capital investment which is

Speaker: NA
Text: imperative if we are to get the new build-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings and capital equipment which are so

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary for the expansion of our eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomy. If the Government had taken any

Speaker: NA
Text: of the courses that I have suggested, it

Speaker: NA
Text: would have added to the capacity to reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: the prime cost of goods to the manufacturer

Speaker: NA
Text: and to reduce the sale price to the distri-

Speaker: NA
Text: butor or retailer, whose profits would be

Speaker: NA
Text: struck at the lower cost level. This, in

Speaker: NA
Text: turn, would result in the capacity to sell

Speaker: NA
Text: our commodities to the community at

Speaker: NA
Text: generally lower prices and, at the same

Speaker: NA
Text: time, would strengthen our trade with other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries by making our prices more com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petitive in the world's markets.

Speaker: NA
Text: The pay-roll tax, Sir, was introduced in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1941, and it is estimated that, in the current cluding

Speaker: NA
Text: financial year, it will return some

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£53,000,000 to revenue. As I shall show,

Speaker: NA
Text: the burden of this tax is placed mainly on

Speaker: NA
Text: industry and the manufacturer. The pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: roll tax has quite frequently been related to

Speaker: NA
Text: the financing of child endowment. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: been said that child endowment is part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the wage structure and, therefore, a logical

Speaker: NA
Text: addition to the costs of the employer. The

Speaker: NA
Text: basic wage, however, is now fixed on the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis of the capacity of industry to pay and

Speaker: NA
Text: on the needs of the family wage-earner.

Speaker: NA
Text: and therefore the employer virtually con^

Speaker: NA
Text: tributes twice, owing to the increased wages

Speaker: NA
Text: resulting from the method of fixing the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic wage, and owing to the imposition

Speaker: NA
Text: of this iniquitous tax. As the basic wage

Speaker: NA
Text: takes into consideration the needs of the

Speaker: NA
Text: family man, child endowment becomes a

Speaker: NA
Text: straight-out social service obligation. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not support the contention that any parti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cular section of the community should be

Speaker: NA
Text: called upon to finance any particular part

Speaker: NA
Text: of social service benefits. Social services

Speaker: NA
Text: should be the responsibility of the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: community, and child endowment should

Speaker: NA
Text: not be regarded differently from any other

Speaker: NA
Text: social service benefit such as age pensions

Speaker: NA
Text: or medical benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: All State governments and local

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities pay this tax, which, in turn,

Speaker: NA
Text: increases the costs of State railways and

Speaker: NA
Text: public transport, with consequent increases

Speaker: NA
Text: in fares and freight rates. This further adds

Speaker: NA
Text: to the costs of industry and consumers. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: interesting to analyse the break-up of the

Speaker: NA
Text: sources of pay-roll tax. State government

Speaker: NA
Text: instrumentalities and State government de-

Speaker: NA
Text: partments and local government authorities

Speaker: NA
Text: contribute between them Â£15,000,000 a

Speaker: NA
Text: year. Manufacturing, building and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: struction industries contribute Â£25,000,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Distributing wholesalers and retailers con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tribute Â£4,000,000 each. Primary produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, including mining, contributes

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£3,000,000, and all others not shown in

Speaker: NA
Text: the preceding categories contribute

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£2,000,000. This gives a total pay-roll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: yield of Â£53,000,000. It can readily be

Speaker: NA
Text: seen that the manufacturing, building and

Speaker: NA
Text: construction employers pay almost one-half

Speaker: NA
Text: of the tax, and that commerce, in the form

Speaker: NA
Text: of wholesalers and retailers, pays

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£8,000,000, whereas primary industry, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: mining, contributes only

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£3,000,000. The burdensome tax has an

Speaker: NA
Text: undoubted inflationary effect, and its sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional application can readily be seen by

Speaker: NA
Text: reference to the figures which I have just

Speaker: NA
Text: given.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the pay-roll tax were to be abolished,

Speaker: NA
Text: the net loss to revenue would not necessarily -

Speaker: NA
Text: total Â£53,000,000, for the loss could be

Speaker: NA
Text: offset in a number of ways. Grants to the

Speaker: NA
Text: States could be reduced by the amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: pay-roll tax that the State governments are

Speaker: NA
Text: now called upon to pay-Â£15,000,00 0 a

Speaker: NA
Text: year. The yield of company tax and tax

Speaker: NA
Text: on income derived from companies would

Speaker: NA
Text: be increased. As pay-roll tax payments

Speaker: NA
Text: are deductible from gross figures before the

Speaker: NA
Text: profit or loss is struck, it is estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: the abolition of the tax would result in

Speaker: NA
Text: additional revenue of Â£13,000,000 from

Speaker: NA
Text: this source. It can be seen that these two

Speaker: NA
Text: factors alone would increase the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's revenue by Â£28,000,000. If we

Speaker: NA
Text: add to this the savings that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment would make in lower costs for goods

Speaker: NA
Text: and services, together with the saving of

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure resulting from the necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: readjustment of the staff policing the tax,

Speaker: NA
Text: we could conservatively take the total gain

Speaker: NA
Text: to Â£30,000,000. This would leave a loss

Speaker: NA
Text: to revenue of only Â£23,000,000 from the

Speaker: NA
Text: total abolition of the pay-roll tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: As it is estimated that the returns from

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax will be reduced by more than

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£22,000,000 as a result of the tax con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessions in this Budget, the pay-roll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: could well have been abolished and the

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit spread over the whole community.

Speaker: NA
Text: This would have made a real contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: towards stability by removing an inflation-

Speaker: NA
Text: ary medium from our economic structure.

Speaker: NA
Text: The abolition of this tax would have made

Speaker: NA
Text: the prices of our exports more highly com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petitive with those of overseas products,

Speaker: NA
Text: and home-consumption prices would have

Speaker: NA
Text: been reduced. The private investment of

Speaker: NA
Text: capital would have been given a fillip which

Speaker: NA
Text: industry will most certainly need if it is to

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake the task of expansion ahead.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, I ask the Government to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider the abolition, or, alternatively, the

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction, of this iniquitous tax. It is dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: criminatory and sectional, and it is imposed

Speaker: NA
Text: only on the employer of labour. It does

Speaker: NA
Text: not apply to other kinds of business people

Speaker: NA
Text: whose businesses may be equally as profit-

Speaker: NA
Text: able, or even more profitable-fo r example,

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers and graziers, who qualify for

Speaker: NA
Text: exemption.

Speaker: NA
Text: This tax penalizes the employer for effi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciency and for increasing his staff. The

Speaker: NA
Text: more workers he employs, the more tax

Speaker: NA
Text: he is called upon to pay. In fact, he is

Speaker: NA
Text: penalized for increasing the work force-

Speaker: NA
Text: the very thing for which incentive should

Speaker: NA
