Text: be given. Pay-roll tax must be paid by the

Speaker: NA
Text: the employer regardless of whether his

Speaker: NA
Text: operations show a profit or a loss. In

Speaker: NA
Text: respect, to my mind, this tax disregards

Speaker: NA
Text: basic principle of taxation-tha t a tax must

Speaker: NA
Text: be based on the amount of income earned

Speaker: NA
Text: and the ability to pay. As I have shown,

Speaker: NA
Text: this tax is inflationary. It is a cumulative

Speaker: NA
Text: that tax, and the greater the number of pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cesses in the manufacture of an article, the

Speaker: NA
Text: greater is the proportion of cost added by

Speaker: NA
Text: the pay-roll tax. The result, Sir, is that,

Speaker: NA
Text: ultimately, the additional cost to the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer is more than the revenue derived

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Government. Industry needs in-

Speaker: NA
Text: centive to expand, and I have endeavoured

Speaker: NA
Text: to show that unless it is encouraged and

Speaker: NA
Text: assisted to absorb the increasing work force

Speaker: NA
Text: we shall be in for some unpleasant adjust-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in our economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The pay-roll tax is not the only tax to

Speaker: NA
Text: which I think the Government should turn

Speaker: NA
Text: its attention. The sales tax, also, should

Speaker: NA
Text: be given close attention by the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. The family man with the larger

Speaker: NA
Text: family is the one who is called upon to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: most, and the larger the family, the more

Speaker: NA
Text: he pays, particularly in sales tax on food-

Speaker: NA
Text: stuffs and necessities such as pepper,

Speaker: NA
Text: essences, soap and soap powders and other

Speaker: NA
Text: essential requirements such as toothpaste,

Speaker: NA
Text: boot polish and, of course, household fur-

Speaker: NA
Text: niture, which is so necessary to newly-

Speaker: NA
Text: married couples. These are things to which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government should look if it is so

Speaker: NA
Text: much concerned about keeping down the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of living. It should reduce direcdy

Speaker: NA
Text: the costs of those who use these things

Speaker: NA
Text: most and who are now called upon to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: most in sales tax- a tax which further adds

Speaker: NA
Text: to consumer costs.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are many anomalies in the sales

Speaker: NA
Text: tax legislation, and I should like to direct

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's attention to one or two

Speaker: NA
Text: which I think should be rectified. We find,

Speaker: NA
Text: for instance, that biscuits for human con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption are taxed at the rate of 12i per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. Yet dog biscuits are entirely exempt.

Speaker: NA
Text: We find also that meat pies are exempt,

Speaker: NA
Text: although fish or fruit pies attract a rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: \ 2 i per cent. The Government should

Speaker: NA
Text: give consideration to the numerous

Speaker: NA
Text: anomalies that exist. I have mentioned

Speaker: NA
Text: those few only, because my time is limited.

Speaker: NA
Text: I now wish to turn to a discussion of

Speaker: NA
Text: Postmaster-General's Department.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although the charges that it is proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: this to increase have not been increased since

Speaker: NA
Text: a 1951, it is agreed on all sides that wages

Speaker: NA
Text: and other costs have increased enormously.

Speaker: NA
Text: The question that is exercising my mind is

Speaker: NA
Text: this: If these costs have been increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: since 1951, why were the increases in

Speaker: NA
Text: charges delayed for so long? If they had

Speaker: NA
Text: been made earlier, or if the charges had

Speaker: NA
Text: been increased progressively, they would

Speaker: NA
Text: not then have made such an impact upon

Speaker: NA
Text: the community or have been so unpopular.

Speaker: NA
Text: The process of increasing these charges

Speaker: NA
Text: should have been a more gradual one. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do suggest, however, that no Government

Speaker: NA
Text: worth its salt would hesitate to introduce

Speaker: NA
Text: unpopular measures such as this one if it

Speaker: NA
Text: were found necessary to do so in order

Speaker: NA
Text: to put this great organization on a business-

Speaker: NA
Text: like footing, as I believe it should be.

Speaker: NA
Text: A committee has been set up to inquire

Speaker: NA
Text: into tbe capital employed in the Postmaster-

Speaker: NA
Text: General's Department. This is a formid-

Speaker: NA
Text: able task, and I believe the committee's

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of reference should be widened, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that a full and searching inquiry should be

Speaker: NA
Text: made into the methods and the efficiency

Speaker: NA
Text: of the department, and into any wastage

Speaker: NA
Text: that occurs. We have magnificent

Speaker: NA
Text: organizations such as Qantas Empire Air-

Speaker: NA
Text: ways Limited, Trans-Australia Airlines,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the national shipping line, which

Speaker: NA
Text: operate at a profit, are efficient and com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pete with private interests on a competi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive basis. We know that the Post Office

Speaker: NA
Text: is on a different footing from those organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: zations, but I think the committee I have

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned should inquire into the question

Speaker: NA
Text: whether all or part of the Post Office

Speaker: NA
Text: organization should be placed under the

Speaker: NA
Text: control of a commission. We know that

Speaker: NA
Text: in time of war, and also, of course, in

Speaker: NA
Text: peace-time, lines of communication have

Speaker: NA
Text: to be kept open. We know that capital

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment is essential and that probably

Speaker: NA
Text: the running of the Postmaster-General's

Speaker: NA
Text: Department is beyond the scope of private

Speaker: NA
Text: interests. But as matters stand to-day, we

Speaker: NA
Text: find that the general taxpayer is contribut-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing towards the maintenance of the postal

Speaker: NA
Text: services through general revenue.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Order ! The honorParliament

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentleman's time has expired.

Speaker: Mr MINOGUE
Text: West Sydney) [2.57] -

Speaker: NA
Text: We are discussing to-day a budget proCommonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: viding for revenue and expenditure of

Speaker: NA
Text: than Â£1,600,000,000. Although we have

Speaker: NA
Text: listened to many members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: and Country Parties telling us of the good

Speaker: NA
Text: things the Budget contains, the amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Evatt)

Speaker: NA
Text: will be put to the vote to-night before half

Speaker: NA
Text: of the 123 members of this House have

Speaker: NA
Text: bothered to speak in tlie debate. The

Speaker: NA
Text: reason why they have not spoken is simply

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are ashamed of the things that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Budget contains. There is no other

Speaker: NA
Text: reason.

Speaker: NA
Text: The previous speaker, the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Phillip ( Mr Aston), opened

Speaker: NA
Text: his speech by saying that there are not many

Speaker: NA
Text: unemployed in this country. He said there

Speaker: NA
Text: are only a few thousand of them and that,

Speaker: NA
Text: after all, the proportion is less than in any

Speaker: NA
Text: other country. The first part of my speech

Speaker: NA
Text: to-day will be devoted to the unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment problem. The Minister for Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: and National Service ( Mr MCMahon) has

Speaker: NA
Text: told us that there are up to 70,000 people

Speaker: NA
Text: out of work. I venture to suggest that the

Speaker: NA
Text: incidence of unemployment is greater in my

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate in Sydney than anywhere else in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. Yet we find that a member of

Speaker: NA
Text: this Parliament whose electorate is only a

Speaker: NA
Text: few miles from mine and includes within

Speaker: NA
Text: its boundaries not one factory or industry, a

Speaker: NA
Text: member who won his seat from a Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: man by taking advantage of the publicity

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with the Petrov case, gets up in

Speaker: NA
Text: this committee and tells us that it does not

Speaker: NA
Text: matter very much about these people who

Speaker: NA
Text: are out of work.

Speaker: NA
Text: I challenge that honorable member, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I challenge the Minister for Labour and

Speaker: NA
Text: National Service, to find jobs for the hun-

Speaker: NA
Text: dreds of people who are out of work in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate. Every day they come to

Speaker: NA
Text: me and I send them to the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Employment Service in the Grace Building,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they are all told the same thing. In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact it seems to be a crime for a man or

Speaker: NA
Text: woman to be over 50 years of age, because

Speaker: NA
Text: they then have no earthly chance of getting

Speaker: NA
Text: jobs. Yet we hear the Minister for Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Services ( Mr Roberton) telling us in this

Speaker: NA
Text: that besides the Â£4 7s. 6d. age

Speaker: NA
Text: pension, a person is also allowed to earn

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£3 10s. a week. Let me tell the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: that 86 per cent, of pensioners in the

Speaker: NA
Text: do not earn anything at all.

Speaker: NA
Text: more Nevertheless, he continues to tell the

Speaker: NA
Text: people that a pensioner's income can be as

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal high as Â£8 5s. a week.

Speaker: NA
Text: Everything that this Government gives

Speaker: NA
Text: to pensioners has a string tied to it. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 1955 it gave them a small increase, and

Speaker: NA
Text: what did we find? We found that a pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner who earned more than Â£2 a week

Speaker: NA
Text: was deprived of the benefits of the pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner medical service. Is that not a trick?

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course it is a trick to say to these people,

Speaker: NA
Text: " You may earn a couple of pounds a week,

Speaker: NA
Text: but you will then lose your entitlement to

Speaker: NA
Text: the pensioner medical service, your right to

Speaker: NA
Text: concession travel in trains, and various

Speaker: NA
Text: other concessions". This Government

Speaker: NA
Text: always makes sure that it can pull a string

Speaker: NA
Text: and take back some of the increase that

Speaker: NA
Text: it gives.

Speaker: NA
Text: In Sydney, there are men and women

Speaker: NA
Text: trudging the streets looking for jobs.

Speaker: NA
Text: they register for employment they are

Speaker: NA
Text: asked how old they are, and if a male

Speaker: NA
Text: applicant is more than 65 and a woman

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 60, they are told that the best

Speaker: NA
Text: thing they can do is to collect the pension.

Speaker: NA
Text: But the pension is not so easily collected.

Speaker: NA
Text: When a person makes application for the

Speaker: NA
Text: pension he is very lucky if he starts to

Speaker: NA
Text: receive it within eight or nine weeks.

Speaker: NA
Text: Is it not degrading for a man who

Speaker: NA
Text: been used to work, who has regularly Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: earned his Â£15 or Â£20 a week, to be

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced to an income of Â£3 or Â£3 5s. a

Speaker: NA
Text: week, with no hope of anything better

Speaker: NA
Text: during the last ten or fifteen years of

Speaker: NA
Text: life? Yet we hear this Government boastthe

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of the national income at the present

Speaker: NA
Text: time and what it is going to be in the

Speaker: NA
Text: future. It does nothing whatever for

Speaker: NA
Text: people who pioneered this country. Instead

Speaker: NA
Text: of financing the Snowy Mountains scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: from revenue, the Government should do

Speaker: NA
Text: what would be done by a Labour governtwo

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, pay for it out of loan moneys.

Speaker: NA
Text: would then have enough money to find

Speaker: NA
Text: work for these old people and to find

Speaker: NA
Text: homes for the people of our community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Being a rational sort of a bloke, I

Speaker: NA
Text: hopes that something good would come

Speaker: NA
Text: out of the Budget. About this time of

Speaker: NA
Text: the year every one in the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: is looking to the Budget. The taxpayer

Speaker: NA
Text: is looking for reduced taxation rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioner is looking for a rise in pensions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Every one has his eye on the Budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: after reading the Budget papers and

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the speeches made by honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: - bers opposite, I cannot be convinced that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is anything good in this Budget for

Speaker: NA
Text: anybody.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me turn now to the subject of immi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gration. In 1949, when this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: came to office, there was an immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: programme in operation. The Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter ( Mr Menzies) promised at that time

Speaker: NA
Text: that immigrants coming to Australia would

Speaker: NA
Text: be provided with homes, but his promise

Speaker: NA
Text: turned out to be nothing but hypocrisy

Speaker: NA
Text: and sham. He brought out a few hundred

Speaker: NA
Text: homes from Denmark or some other

Speaker: NA
Text: country and scattered them around

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland and other places. Then it

Speaker: NA
Text: became the responsibility of the States to

Speaker: NA
Text: find homes for these people who were

Speaker: NA
Text: When dumped here, 120,000 of them each year.

Speaker: NA
Text: These immigrants arrive in Australia, are

Speaker: NA
Text: placed in hostels and have a terrible time

Speaker: NA
Text: of it when they first come to the country.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the use of bringing them here if

Speaker: NA
Text: there are no homes for them and no work?

Speaker: NA
Text: They eat their heads off in hostels and

Speaker: NA
Text: nobody is happy about it. They have to

Speaker: NA
Text: leave their families in the hostels until they

Speaker: NA
Text: are able to find some work. This Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has done nothing to house those

Speaker: NA
Text: has immigrants or to house our native

Speaker: NA
Text: No one looking for a home in this coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try can expect any help from this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: his ment. Look at the raw deal it is giving

Speaker: NA
Text: returned servicemen. These men come

Speaker: NA
Text: to me at my office in Sydney seeking details

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Â£2.750 that they are entitled to get

Speaker: NA
Text: the from the War Service Homes Division.

Speaker: NA
Text: They want to know how long it will be

Speaker: NA
Text: before they will get a loan, but all I can

Speaker: NA
Text: say is that it will be eighteen months or

Speaker: NA
Text: years. Young men and women who

Speaker: NA
Text: It are eager to get married and settle down

Speaker: NA
Text: find that it is very easy for them to get

Speaker: NA
Text: the money from some other sources while

Speaker: NA
Text: they are waiting on a war service homes

Speaker: NA
Text: loan. The Commonwealth guarantees that

Speaker: NA
Text: had the advance will eventually be made, so

Speaker: NA
Text: the money lender, solicitor, or whoever

Speaker: NA
Text: lends the money, knows that he has only

Speaker: NA
Text: to wait for eighteen months or two years

Speaker: NA
Text: for repayment. But what does the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: The serviceman pay for this temporary finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial accommodation? He must pay nearly

Speaker: NA
Text: But, 20 per cent, on the Â£2,750 for eighteen

Speaker: NA
Text: hearmonths or two years; there is no other

Speaker: NA
Text: way out. It would be far better for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to stop accepting applications

Speaker: NA
Text: until those who have been promised an

Speaker: NA
Text: advance receive it. These young people

Speaker: NA
Text: then would not be tied to a money lender

Speaker: NA
Text: for the mortgage that they need to buy a

Speaker: NA
Text: house. They pay as much in eighteen

Speaker: NA
Text: months or two years to the money lender

Speaker: NA
Text: as they would pay to the Government if

Speaker: NA
Text: they had the advance for the term of their

Speaker: NA
Text: natural life. It is not right that men who

Speaker: NA
Text: have served their country so well should

Speaker: NA
Text: be treated in this way by the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: But another matter that is even worse

Speaker: NA
Text: than this is the availability of hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment for ex-servicemen. In New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales, this is handled in a most disgrace-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful way. One case I had was that of a

Speaker: NA
Text: blind man. Although he was 99 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: blind, he had to wait until he was com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely blind before he was given a pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion. During the war, a mortar bomb ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ploded near him and immediately deprived

Speaker: NA
Text: him of the sight of his right eye. But he

Speaker: NA
Text: had to get three or four men who were

Speaker: NA
Text: near him at the time to prove his case

Speaker: NA
Text: when he asked for a pension. Then the

Speaker: NA
Text: sight of his other eye started to go and he

Speaker: NA
Text: could not work. His wife did the best she

Speaker: NA
Text: could to look after him. All these details

Speaker: NA
Text: can be checked; I have brought this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: before honorable members on other occa-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions. Four Macquarie-street specialists

Speaker: NA
Text: said that the loss of sight in the second

Speaker: NA
Text: eye could be caused by the explosion of

Speaker: NA
Text: the mortar bomb; yet the medical referee

Speaker: NA
Text: ruled him out and would not give him a

Speaker: NA
Text: pension.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Anderson - I do not believe it!

Speaker: Mr MINOGUE
Text: Yo u would not

Speaker: NA
Text: believe it. But you will come to believe

Speaker: NA
Text: it one day.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Anderson -Wha t about

Speaker: NA
Text: country

Speaker: Mr MINOGUE
Text: I will deal with you

Speaker: NA
Text: later.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Order ! The honoranother

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for West Sydney will address

Speaker: NA
Text: the Chair. I ask honorable members to

Speaker: NA
Text: cease interjecting.

Speaker: Mr MINOGUE
Text: I shall mention a case

Speaker: NA
Text: now that I have mentioned in this chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: before. It concerns a returned soldier, now

Speaker: NA
Text: living in Sydney, who was shot at Gallipoli.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that that is going back a long way,

Speaker: NA
Text: but nevertheless this man was shot in the

Speaker: NA
Text: leg and lost the use of his ankle. Twelve

Speaker: NA
Text: operations were performed on him in

Speaker: NA
Text: Gallipoli, one in England, one on the way

Speaker: NA
Text: back to Australia, and several in Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although he was suffering from this dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ability, he continued to work for a tobacco

Speaker: NA
Text: company at Kensington. He had a stick

Speaker: NA
Text: and used to drag his leg along behind him.

Speaker: NA
Text: He received a pension of something like

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£2. Later in life he married. During the

Speaker: NA
Text: Austraha Day holiday in January of this

Speaker: NA
Text: year, he became very ill and I was called

Speaker: NA
Text: in to see him. I could not get him into

Speaker: NA
Text: any hospital in Sydney. I rang the Yaralla

Speaker: NA
Text: Repatriation Hospital and the Randwick

Speaker: NA
Text: Hospital. I rang every hospital in Sydney.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable members will believe me on this

Speaker: NA
Text: case, as well as on the other one, because

Speaker: NA
Text: I have substantial proof of both cases.

Speaker: NA
Text: There was not a hospital in Sydney that I

Speaker: NA
Text: did not ring about this man. He had some

Speaker: NA
Text: heart trouble, but it was ruled that this

Speaker: NA
Text: had nothing to do with the war or with

Speaker: NA
Text: his injuries. Surely he had the heart of a

Speaker: NA
Text: lion, to live at all and to work for the years

Speaker: NA
Text: that he did; but this Government ignored

Speaker: NA
Text: him all the time. If his ankle was bad,

Speaker: NA
Text: Yaralla willingly gave him treatment, but

Speaker: NA
Text: if he suffered any other physical disability,

Speaker: NA
Text: he had to fend for himself.

Speaker: NA
Text: Following a heart attack, his wife was

Speaker: NA
Text: lucky enough to get him into a hospital at

Speaker: NA
Text: Glebe at Â£20 a week. However, after three

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks the hospital authorities said that he

Speaker: NA
Text: was not likely to get better and asked his

Speaker: NA
Text: wife to take him away. Arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: were made for him to go to a hospi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal at Balmain. His wife arranged for an

Speaker: NA
Text: ambulance to take him to Balmain, but he

Speaker: NA
Text: was there for only two and a half hours

Speaker: NA
Text: the before the authorities at this hospital tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: phoned her at her home and asked her to

Speaker: NA
Text: take him away because he would not get

Speaker: NA
Text: better and they could not keep him.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another ambulance was engaged, and

Speaker: NA
Text: fee paid. The man was taken from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Balmain hospital to his home and he

Speaker: NA
Text: was lying on the floor of this little two-

Speaker: NA
Text: storey house when I was called in. During

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole of the Australia Day holiday I

Speaker: NA
Text: tried to get him into a hospital, but without

Speaker: NA
Text: success. At last I got him into the Sacred

Speaker: NA
Text: Heart Hospice for the Dying at Darling-

Speaker: NA
Text: hurst. That man lived for only five more

Speaker: NA
Text: days.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many honorable members on the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment side of the House claim that

Speaker: NA
Text: they are ex-servicemen. I put to them

Speaker: NA
Text: that' it is only fair for this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to do the right thing by these men who

Speaker: NA
Text: gave the best years of their lives in the

Speaker: NA
Text: defence of their country. There cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: be many of them left now. Although four

Speaker: NA
Text: or five specialists may say that a condition

Speaker: NA
Text: is due to war service, a medical referee

Speaker: NA
Text: will rule, on behalf of the Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the ex-serviceman is not entitled to a

Speaker: NA
Text: pension. The ex-servicemen are not given

Speaker: NA
Text: any consideration at all. I hope that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Repatriation (Senator Sir

Speaker: NA
Text: Walter Cooper) will do something in the

Speaker: NA
Text: cases that I have mentioned. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment does not see fit to look after these

Speaker: NA
Text: men, but they were good enough to fight

Speaker: NA
Text: in the war. The irony of it all is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the widow of the ex-serviceman to whom

Speaker: NA
Text: I have just referred is only 59 years of

Speaker: NA
Text: age and cannot get the age pension. She

Speaker: NA
Text: is in receipt of the widow's pension, the

Speaker: NA
Text: lowest pension available. Her two brothers

Speaker: NA
Text: were killed instantly at Gallipoli at the

Speaker: NA
Text: same time as her husband was injured.

Speaker: NA
Text: For all those years, he dragged along trying

Speaker: NA
Text: to earn a living; yet this Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: which says that it tries to help the people,

Speaker: NA
Text: closes its eyes and imposes a means test

Speaker: NA
Text: on those who seek hospital attention. I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that something will be done to change

Speaker: NA
Text: this position.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn now to social service payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable members on the opposite side

Speaker: NA
Text: admit that the pension increase of 7s. 6d.

Speaker: NA
Text: is not very good. But the Treasurer ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Harold Holt) has announced that in future,

Speaker: NA
Text: under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme,

Speaker: NA
Text: a charge of 5s. will be made for every

Speaker: NA
Text: doctor's prescription that is presented to

Speaker: NA
Text: a chemist. There mav be same excep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions which I will mention later. But is

Speaker: NA
Text: it proper for the Treasurer to bring down

Speaker: NA
Text: a Budget which leaves the pensioners in

Speaker: NA
Text: fear of having to pay 5s. for every pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: scription they have made up? Child

Speaker: NA
Text: endowment, maternity allowances and all

Speaker: NA
Text: other social service benefits have been

Speaker: NA
Text: ignored by the Government. Possibly when

Speaker: NA
Text: the next election year comes round

Speaker: NA
Text: increases in these payments will be offered

Speaker: NA
Text: to the people as a sop. Supporters of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government often condemn the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Government of New South Wales, but

Speaker: NA
Text: were it not for that Government it would

Speaker: NA
Text: be impossible for pensioners in that State

Speaker: NA
Text: to carry on.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some people suggest that I speak for the

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners only because I want their vote.

Speaker: NA
Text: My reply is that at the last election my

Speaker: NA
Text: majority was the unlucky number of

Speaker: NA
Text: 13,000. There is no need for me to speak

Speaker: NA
Text: on behalf of the pensioners to gain their

Speaker: NA
Text: votes, but any man who does not speak

Speaker: NA
Text: on their behalf is not worthy of a seat

Speaker: NA
Text: in this Parliament. They are the people

Speaker: NA
Text: who pioneered this country. During this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate Ministers have referred to people

Speaker: NA
Text: who have been thrifty and those who have

Speaker: NA
Text: not. I remind those Ministers that until a

Speaker: NA
Text: few years ago the basic wage was only

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£3 10s. or Â£4 a week. Many workers

Speaker: NA
Text: reared families on that income. Were they

Speaker: NA
Text: not thrifty? Many of the men and their

Speaker: NA
Text: sons went to the war and fought for their

Speaker: NA
Text: countrv. But now many of them are

Speaker: NA
Text: subject to the means test in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: qualify for a pension. The best deal these

Speaker: NA
Text: people ever received was given to them by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labour Party. The means test should

Speaker: NA
Text: be abolished. It is a disgrace to think that

Speaker: NA
Text: inspectors, receiving Â£20 or Â£30 a week,

Speaker: NA
Text: visit the back doors of homes where pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioners live and ask all sorts of questions.

Speaker: NA
Text: They want to know who lives in the front

Speaker: NA
Text: room, whether the woman in the house

Speaker: NA
Text: is the pensioner's wife or his de facto wife,

Speaker: NA
Text: or whether a pensioner's wife has left him.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is totally wrong that these people should

Speaker: NA
Text: be subject to such inquiries in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlement to a pension. Even then, the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount they are given is far below what

Speaker: NA
Text: they need to live in any degree of comfort.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Labour Government in New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales helps the pensioners in a big way.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth Government is seeking

Speaker: NA
Text: to take credit for increasing pensions by

Speaker: NA
Text: 7s. 6d. a week to Â£4 15s., but that is

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing compared with what the New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales Government is doing. Its

Speaker: NA
Text: social welfare organization provides cloth-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and blankets for pensioners, and if they

Speaker: NA
Text: are in need of spectacles, hearing aids or

Speaker: NA
Text: dentures, they can obtain them without

Speaker: NA
Text: cost. This Government provides a

Speaker: NA
Text: funeral allowance of only Â£10. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: far from enough to give any person a

Speaker: NA
Text: decent burial. On several occasions mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers from this side have asked the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Social Services to increase this

Speaker: NA
Text: amount, but he has refused to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: The New South Wales Government pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vides free milk for pensioners, and also

Speaker: NA
Text: helps them to meet ambulance service

Speaker: NA
Text: charges. The widow I spoke about earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: received bills from the local ambulance

Speaker: NA
Text: for Â£14 or Â£15. It was impossible for her

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay this amount, but the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: of New South Wales came to her aid and

Speaker: NA
Text: met the cost in full.

Speaker: NA
Text: Each year, the Sydney City Council gives

Speaker: NA
Text: a week's employment to the pensioners.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last year, this cost Â£60,000. It also remits

Speaker: NA
Text: the rates of any widow who lives in her

Speaker: NA
Text: own home and is solely dependent on her

Speaker: NA
Text: pension. The State Government reim-

Speaker: NA
Text: burses the Sydney City Council to half

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost involved in giving this assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: to pensioners. Were it not for the State

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and the Sydney City Council,

Speaker: NA
Text: these people would not be able to live.

Speaker: NA
Text: That would certainly be the case if they

Speaker: NA
Text: had to depend upon the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Menzies) or the Minister for Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Services for help. The meals-on-wheels

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme renders wonderful help to pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioners in New South Wales. Once a day,

Speaker: NA
Text: a hot meal is supplied to them for the low

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of 2s. But for this, their prospect of

Speaker: NA
Text: getting sufficient food would be very poor

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed.

Speaker: NA
Text: On previous occasions I have referred

Speaker: NA
Text: the Pioneers Ball which is held each year right to live.

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Sydney Town Hall. Strange to say,

Speaker: NA
Text: some people have told me that I should not

Speaker: NA
Text: mention such a thing over the air. Surely,

Speaker: NA
Text: the trash and nonsense I hear over the air

Speaker: NA
Text: should not take preference over what

Speaker: NA
Text: being done for the pensioners. On 16th

Speaker: NA
Text: October next, this ball will be held again

Speaker: NA
Text: from 8 o'clock at night until 2 o'clock next

Speaker: NA
Text: morning. Sir Edward Halstrom, the

Speaker: NA
Text: great animal lover, has never failed

Speaker: NA
Text: donate a refrigerator to help this good

Speaker: NA
Text: cause. Also, Halvic Industries, whose

Speaker: NA
Text: factory is in the electorate of the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bradfield ( Mr Turner), who

Speaker: NA
Text: yesterday condemned the Government, could

Speaker: NA
Text: takes a practical interest in doing something

Speaker: NA
Text: on behalf of these poor people. The

Speaker: NA
Text: manager of that company provides a but

Speaker: NA
Text: valuable prize each year.

Speaker: NA
Text: But that is not enough. Indeed, it should

Speaker: NA
Text: not be necessary for organizations of this

Speaker: NA
Text: kind to have to do such things to help the

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners. The Treasurer has brought

Speaker: NA
Text: down a budget dealing with a total sum of

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£1,600,000,000. Is not the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: ashamed that out of that vast amount it is

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide a paltry 7s. 6d. a week for the

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners, of which it will take back 5s.

Speaker: NA
Text: for medical prescriptions? If a pensioner,

Speaker: NA
Text: who receives only Â£4 15s. a week, earns

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£2 or more a week he loses his medical

Speaker: NA
Text: card. I know of pensioners who go to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney city markets and in return for mind-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a cab they are given a few apples or a

Speaker: NA
Text: cabbage. But every day, social service

Speaker: NA
Text: inspectors are there also watching to see

Speaker: NA
Text: how much the pensioners get for doing

Speaker: NA
Text: such odd jobs. That is a disgraceful state

Speaker: NA
Text: of affairs.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are many more matters I should

Speaker: NA
Text: like to speak about, but time will not permit

Speaker: NA
Text: me to do so. I visited South America last

Speaker: NA
Text: year and I saw there some conditions which

Speaker: NA
Text: resemble those in Australia. I attended a

Speaker: NA
Text: conference of the Inter-Parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: Union at Rio de Janeiro. Some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: newspapers have complained that they were

Speaker: NA
Text: not told what happened at that conference.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can tell them that as a result of it, there

Speaker: NA
Text: is no need to be afraid of the possibility

Speaker: NA
Text: that nuclear weapons or atomic bombs will

Speaker: NA
Text: be used in warfare at least in the imme-

Speaker: NA
Text: diate future. At that conference which was

Speaker: NA
Text: representative of all nations many matters

Speaker: NA
Text: were discussed, and it declared that people

Speaker: NA
Text: to in every part of the world should have the

Speaker: NA
Text: But in the countries which I visited I

Speaker: NA
Text: was deeply distressed by the extreme wealth

Speaker: NA
Text: and extreme poverty which existed side by

Speaker: NA
Text: is side. In Brazil we were taken to many

Speaker: NA
Text: beautiful palaces-almos t every important

Speaker: NA
Text: building seemed to be a palace-an d the

Speaker: NA
Text: day before we left we were taken 500 miles

Speaker: NA
Text: inland to the new capital city of that

Speaker: NA
Text: to country. We saw many workers as we

Speaker: NA
Text: drove along and they seemed to be poverty

Speaker: NA
Text: stricken. As we passed a mountain which

Speaker: NA
Text: was pointed out to me I was informed that

Speaker: NA
Text: every night workers climbed it as best they

Speaker: NA
Text: because there were no roads and slept

Speaker: NA
Text: in the open. In the day time no sign of a

Speaker: NA
Text: house could be seen on the mountain side,

Speaker: NA
Text: at night the lights from the camp fires

Speaker: NA
Text: seemed to be as numerous as the stars.

Speaker: NA
Text: The highest wage paid for manual labour

Speaker: NA
Text: in Rio de Janeiro is about Â£15 a month.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the sum earned by drivers of buses

Speaker: NA
Text: or tramcars. That is an example of ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: treme wealth side by side with extreme

Speaker: NA
Text: poverty. A similar state of affairs exists

Speaker: NA
Text: in New York, and in nearly every other

Speaker: NA
Text: great city that we visited.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is, perhaps, one of the best

Speaker: NA
Text: countries in the world. It would be the

Speaker: NA
Text: best country in the world if it were not

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Liberal and Australian Country

Speaker: NA
Text: Party Administration which is in charge of

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs. The Government has provided a

Speaker: NA
Text: terrific amount of money for defence, and

Speaker: NA
Text: it has arranged substantial increases in the

Speaker: NA
Text: salaries and allowances of members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament, but it has not done the right

Speaker: NA
Text: thing by the pensioners. The Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter has said that there is no sign of war

Speaker: NA
Text: at present and that the possibility of war

Speaker: NA
Text: within the next few years is very remote.

Speaker: NA
Text: In that case why does the Government in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tend to spend nearly Â£200,000.000 on

Speaker: NA
Text: defence? The Minister for the Army ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Cramer) last night told us about the peace-

Speaker: NA
Text: loving people whom he had met during his

Speaker: NA
Text: travels. He has no regard tor the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mon people. When he was chairman of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Sydney County Council, there was a

Speaker: NA
Text: black-out every time a by-election was con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducted in the metropolitan area. He has

Speaker: NA
Text: not improved since that time. He and I

Speaker: NA
Text: were aldermen on the Sydney City Coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: cil, and we were also members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney County Council. On one occasion

Speaker: NA
Text: during an inspection of a mine we lost our

Speaker: NA
Text: lamps, and we prayed that we might get

Speaker: NA
Text: out of the mine safely. We did, and when

Speaker: NA
Text: we reached the surface he said, " No one

Speaker: NA
Text: will ever hear me say another word about

Speaker: NA
Text: miners". But he has now changed his

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Grayndler

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Daly) said last night that the Governcomplaint

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, by its Budget, would waste am

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£50,000,000. One can imagine the benesector

Speaker: NA
Text: fits that would flow to the pensioners,

Speaker: NA
Text: people who need assistance most, if pride

Speaker: NA
Text: were devoted to their cause.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Order ! The honortwo

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's time has expired.

Speaker: Mr IAN ALLAN
Text: Gwydir) [3.27] -

Speaker: NA
Text: The debate on the Budget, which has conmary

Speaker: NA
Text: tinued for the past fortnight, has been

Speaker: NA
Text: dull. I am grateful to the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for West Sydney ( Mr Minogue) for the

Speaker: NA
Text: way in which he has livened up pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceedings.

Speaker: NA
Text: I congratulate the Treasurer ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Harold Holt) on the presentation of his

Speaker: NA
Text: first Budget. Although the effect of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget provisions will not be inconsequen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial, the Budget is more superficial than

Speaker: NA
Text: we have been accustomed to expect in

Speaker: NA
Text: recent years. I do not think that it will

Speaker: NA
Text: have any profound overall effect on the

Speaker: NA
Text: country. The proposed increases in post-

Speaker: NA
Text: age charges, and the fact that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has budgeted for a large deficit, are

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed weighty matters. Of course, honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members must realize that this is the

Speaker: NA
Text: first Budget introduced by the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: very shortly after he assumed office, and

Speaker: NA
Text: it is difficult to introduce radical changes

Speaker: NA
Text: and bold innovations at a first attempt. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is also difficult to introduce anything novel

Speaker: NA
Text: at a time when the country is moving

Speaker: NA
Text: along so buoyantly, expanding so rapidly

Speaker: NA
Text: and holding so firmly the confidence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: business community. I am sure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer did not wish to make any great

Speaker: NA
Text: changes because his predecessor in office,

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir Arthur Fadden, in the long years that

Speaker: NA
Text: he held the portfolio, did much to bring

Speaker: NA
Text: about the prosperity that we now enjoy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope that in future budgets the Trea-

Speaker: NA
Text: surer will be in a position to make some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the changes that are necessary to keep

Speaker: NA
Text: our financial machinery abreast of the times

Speaker: NA
Text: so that the expansion and development now

Speaker: NA
Text: taking place in Australia may continue.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Budget has a shght bias in favour

Speaker: NA
Text: of the manufacturing sector of the eco-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomy. Speaking as a representative of one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the greatest pastoral and agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: regions in the Commonwealth, I have no

Speaker: NA
Text: to make about that. In fact, I

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to see that the manufacturing

Speaker: NA
Text: is receiving attention, because we

Speaker: NA
Text: the in the country share the manufacturers'

Speaker: NA
Text: in the way in which Australian indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try has expanded in the last few years under

Speaker: NA
Text: the guidance of this Government. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: conscious also of the fact that in the next

Speaker: NA
Text: or three years we must provide more

Speaker: NA
Text: job opportunities. To do this we must

Speaker: NA
Text: have expanding secondary industries. Pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: producers rely upon manufacturers to

Speaker: NA
Text: very provide them with the best possible home

Speaker: NA
Text: market for their commodities. We in the

Speaker: NA
Text: country welcome any encouragement given

Speaker: NA
Text: to manufacturers which will lead to expand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing and more efficient secondary industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some idea of the effect of this bias on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Budget may be obtained from the

Speaker: NA
Text: editorial in the August, 1959, issue of

Speaker: NA
Text: " Industry To-day", which is the official

Speaker: NA
Text: publication of the Victorian Chamber of

Speaker: NA
Text: Manufactures. The editorial made certain

Speaker: NA
Text: claims for concessions on behalf of private

Speaker: NA
Text: companies-th e Budget granted those con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessions. It sought a reduction in income

Speaker: NA
Text: tax-th e Budget granted that reduction. It

Speaker: NA
Text: asked that the Government cease the

Speaker: NA
Text: practice of using current Government

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue for capital works and services-

Speaker: NA
Text: the Budget met that request by the changes

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed in the accounting procedure in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Post Office. Various other requests

Speaker: NA
Text: were made in the editorial to which I have

Speaker: NA
Text: referred, all of which have been met in one

Speaker: NA
Text: way or another. A bias does exist towards

Speaker: NA
Text: the manufacturing sector but, so long as

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary industries are encouraged to be-

Speaker: NA
Text: come more efficient we, who represent the

Speaker: NA
Text: great primary industries which produce the

Speaker: NA
Text: goods that give us the overseas funds that

Speaker: NA
Text: we need, have no criticism to offer.

Speaker: NA
Text: It must be remembered, however, that

Speaker: NA
Text: large proportion of fhe manufacturers

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia are not interested in maintaining

Speaker: NA
Text: or achieving efficiency, 'high productivity

Speaker: NA
Text: or a high rate of turnover at low prices.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have been cushioned for so long that

Speaker: NA
Text: they find it a good deal easier and more

Speaker: NA
Text: advantageous to kick along the inflationary

Speaker: NA
Text: spiral. That section o'f industry, which

Speaker: NA
Text: damage our economy, is not worthy of

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tbe meat that is missing from this

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget sandwich is the encouragement to

Speaker: NA
Text: industry to raise the productivity of Ausof

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia by the implementation by the

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment of a definite plan designed to

Speaker: NA
Text: raise the country's total wealth. That meat

Speaker: NA
Text: -should be sandwiched between the careful

Speaker: NA
Text: balancing that has taken place between

Speaker: NA
Text: -capital goods and consumer goods, on

Speaker: NA
Text: one hand, and between loan expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: .and revenue expenditure, on the other.

Speaker: NA
Text: I submit three proposals for the

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration of the Government during the

Speaker: NA
Text: inext year or two. I believe that these pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posals would supply what is now lacking

Speaker: NA
Text: from the current Budget. They are pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posals designed to put the missing meat into

Speaker: NA
Text: the sandwich and increase the wealth of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for West

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney spoke about the pensioners.

Speaker: NA
Text: They and every one else have a direct

Speaker: NA
Text: interest in increasing the total wealth of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. We must not become obsessed

Speaker: NA
Text: with the idea of cutting up the cake into

Speaker: NA
Text: even smaller fragments. We must not

Speaker: NA
Text: forget that our real aim is to bake a bigger

Speaker: NA
Text: cake. Therefore, I suggest to the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, first, that it should do something

Speaker: NA
Text: about our wage-costs treadmill. This exists

Speaker: NA
Text: in all Western countries, including the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States of America and the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom. We have done less about it than

Speaker: NA
Text: any of the other countries. It is possible

Speaker: NA
Text: that we require to do less because, to a

Speaker: NA
Text: very large extent, the Tariff Board, which

Speaker: NA
Text: is very much alive to its responsibilities, is

Speaker: NA
Text: helping to keep costs down in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, we have to realize that price

Speaker: NA
Text: fixation is just as important in checking the

Speaker: NA
Text: spiral of costs as is the fixation of wage

Speaker: NA
Text: levels. For very long, now, the arbitration

Speaker: NA
Text: system has been bumping up wage levels.

Speaker: NA
Text: The increased wage rates have been

Speaker: NA
Text: a followed immediately by increased prices

Speaker: NA
Text: of which have robbed fhe wage earner of all

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefits that he has been granted by

Speaker: NA
Text: the court. But that is not the worst of it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The whole process of wages chasing prices

Speaker: NA
Text: has encouraged the inefficient manufacturer,

Speaker: NA
Text: the inefficient supplier of services, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: inefficient producer, and it has loaded the

Speaker: NA
Text: can country with a burden that has put us out

Speaker: NA
Text: any of step with the rest of the world. The

Speaker: NA
Text: wages-prices spiral has resulted in

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing inflationary pressures in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. We are out of step with the rest

Speaker: NA
Text: the world -because other countries are

Speaker: NA
Text: Goundertaking deflation and correction of

Speaker: NA
Text: those evils that we are allowing to persist.

Speaker: NA
Text: I invite the Governnaent's attention to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Cohen report which was published in the

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Kingdom about three weeks ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is the report of three wise men in that

Speaker: NA
Text: country who were given the task, a year or

Speaker: NA
Text: so ago, of studying wages, .prices and pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: conductivity. The proposals of the Cohen

Speaker: NA
Text: committee, to our way .of thinking, are quite

Speaker: NA
Text: -revolutionary. There is no need for us to

Speaker: NA
Text: apply the rigorous price control recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mended by the Cohen committee because

Speaker: NA
Text: we have a different set of conditions here.

Speaker: NA
Text: But at least we have a very powerful argu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for the introduction of a restrictive

Speaker: NA
Text: practices court such as has been operating

Speaker: NA
Text: in the United Kingdom and the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is one way in which we could check

Speaker: NA
Text: price fixation by industry without inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: fering with the efficient manufacturer. All

Speaker: NA
Text: the honest conscientious manufacturers, of

Speaker: NA
Text: whom there are quite a few in the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity, look to the Government for a

Speaker: NA
Text: lead. They try their utmost to absorb

Speaker: NA
Text: wage increases and the Government has a

Speaker: NA
Text: duty to help them. One way in which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government can help them is by instituting

Speaker: NA
Text: either a monopolies commission or a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: strictive practices court, or both, and so

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing the light of day to bear on some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the price-fixing arrangements that

Speaker: NA
Text: operate in this country and which lead to

Speaker: NA
Text: gross inefficiency and place a burden not

Speaker: NA
Text: merely on exporters but on the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: NA
Text: The next proposal that I make to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is that it should do something

Speaker: NA
Text: positive to foster import-saving industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have in mind particularly the agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: industries of cotton, tobacco and oil seeds

Speaker: NA
Text: -crop s which can be grown abundantly,

Speaker: NA
Text: widely and easily in Australia. All that is

Speaker: NA
Text: needed is a positive lead from this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment through the Australian Agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: Council. So far, the tide for the Agricul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tural Council has run from the States to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth. It is about time that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth took the initiative and

Speaker: NA
Text: organized a national plan such as I have

Speaker: NA
Text: suggested for developing these industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: This would save us a large amount in over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas funds paid for imports. It would also

Speaker: NA
Text: have another effect of which I shall speak

Speaker: NA
Text: in a moment and which I believe is of vast

Speaker: NA
Text: importance.

Speaker: NA
Text: The argument against doing anything is

Speaker: NA
Text: that we might as well receive cotton from

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States of America where it is

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidized to the extent of 8d. per lb.

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States Government, and that

Speaker: NA
Text: might as well go on receiving vegetable

Speaker: NA
Text: oils which, through the operation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: P.L.480 scheme in the United States,

Speaker: NA
Text: cheap and in abundance throughout the

Speaker: NA
Text: world. The aid schemes that are operated

Speaker: NA
Text: by the United States are flooding

Speaker: NA
Text: world market with vegetable oils and this

Speaker: NA
Text: is having its effect on price levels. The

Speaker: NA
Text: argument is that it would be wise for us

Speaker: NA
Text: to go on buying cheap oil from abroad

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than produce it ourselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: The same argument is applied to tobacco.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is asked, " Why not buy cheap tobacco

Speaker: NA
Text: from abroad rather than grow it our-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves? " I shall counter that with a pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal which I believe is of tremendous im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portance and which, to my mind, con-

Speaker: NA
Text: clusively overshadows that argument. Any

Speaker: NA
Text: one who knows the countryside is aware

Speaker: NA
Text: that sharp fluctuations occur in the income

Speaker: NA
Text: of different regions because of sharp fluc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tuations in climate or in overseas prices.

Speaker: NA
Text: One region may go ahead in prosperity for

Speaker: NA
Text: four years, then strike a lean year or a

Speaker: NA
Text: lean two or three years when there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: great return and the whole region stagnates.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is occurring in some part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth all the time. It is the

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of thing that does not show up in

Speaker: NA
Text: statistics yet this wild fluctuation of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: comes in the different country regions holds

Speaker: NA
Text: back, more than does inflation, the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision of funds for investment and the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision of proper amenities in the country-

Speaker: NA
Text: side.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we could have some stability of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come throughout the countryside we would

Speaker: NA
Text: have the right climate for the continued

Speaker: NA
Text: flow of investment money. There would

Speaker: NA
Text: be a continual unchecked development of

Speaker: NA
Text: our rural industries and the countryside

Speaker: NA
Text: would be provided with amenities that it

Speaker: NA
Text: does not have at the present time. With

Speaker: NA
Text: a plan to develop our import saving in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustries throughout the nation we would

Speaker: NA
Text: help to diversify production over the length

Speaker: NA
Text: and breadth of the countryside and we

Speaker: NA
Text: would help to stabilize the level of incomes

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the countryside. That would

Speaker: NA
Text: have rapid and profound effects on the

Speaker: NA
Text: future welfare and continuing progress

Speaker: NA
Text: of our country towns and country regions.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the argument advanced against

Speaker: NA
Text: those who believe that we should rely upon

Speaker: NA
Text: by receiving this kind of assistance from the

Speaker: NA
Text: we United States of America. We owe it to

Speaker: NA
Text: the primary producers and people in coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try towns to do something positive to help

Speaker: NA
Text: are them stabilize their incomes and obtain

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the comforts and amenities that

Speaker: NA
Text: people in the cities enjoy. That could be

Speaker: NA
Text: the done in the way I have suggested.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, I propose that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: should pay attention to the financial rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions between the Commonwealth and the

Speaker: NA
Text: States. Only recently, the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiated an agreement to regulate Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth and State relations for the next

Speaker: NA
Text: six years. I deplore that agreement. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think it is the worst thing that has been

Speaker: NA
Text: done for many years. Nothing could

Speaker: NA
Text: damage the cause of federalism more than

Speaker: NA
Text: avoiding the search for a solution to the

Speaker: NA
Text: present problem of financial relations be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the Commonwealth and the States,

Speaker: NA
Text: yet that is just what this agreement does.

Speaker: NA
Text: It avoids finding a remedy. The possibility

Speaker: NA
Text: of finding a solution has been postponed

Speaker: NA
Text: for six years. Why not admit that the States

Speaker: NA
Text: will not get back their taxing powers, that

Speaker: NA
Text: uniform taxation is here to stay? It is

Speaker: NA
Text: impossible and impracticable to return the

Speaker: NA
Text: powers to levy income tax formerly enjoyed

Speaker: NA
Text: by the States. Let us admit that. We

Speaker: NA
Text: should then admit that a very large volume

Speaker: NA
Text: of the taxpayers' funds is being passed

Speaker: NA
Text: over by the Commonwealth to the States

Speaker: NA
Text: to be controlled and spent by them. The

Speaker: NA
Text: States do not have to account to the tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: payers for that money. Such an arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is conducive to bad administration.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has already had the effect of leading to

Speaker: NA
Text: irresponsibility and maladministration

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the States of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth. By delaying the possibility of

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a solution to this problem for six years,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Government is not

Speaker: NA
Text: living up to its obligations or its ideals.

Speaker: NA
Text: know that this Government believes in

Speaker: NA
Text: federalism, but it is not living up to this

Speaker: NA
Text: ideal or to its obligations to the taxpayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: We owe it to the taxpayers to ensure that

Speaker: NA
Text: every Â£1 of their money that we receive is

Speaker: NA
Text: spent as wisely and fruitfully as possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: We cannot do that under the present

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangement.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, I suggest to the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: that it should do what it can to take over

Speaker: NA
Text: the functions of the States within the limits

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Constitution. If we set out to

Speaker: NA
Text: explore those limits in this connexion, I

Speaker: NA
Text: sure we would find a number of different

Speaker: NA
Text: points of entry. There are a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: different functions we could take over from

Speaker: NA
Text: the States one way or another, not with

Speaker: NA
Text: view to destroying the States but with

Speaker: NA
Text: cisely opposite objectives. We would

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthen the States and make them more

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible if we limited their functions

Speaker: NA
Text: and powers to their own taxing capacity

Speaker: NA
Text: so that they would be strong, viable units

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Commonwealth. In that way, we

Speaker: NA
Text: would ensure that Australian administra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion generally was made as efficient as pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible. For example, we could take over

Speaker: NA
Text: the transport field to a large extent. We

Speaker: NA
Text: do not know quite how far we could go

Speaker: NA
Text: as the Commissioner of Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Railways has already suggested that there

Speaker: NA
Text: are provisions in the Constitution for the

Speaker: NA
Text: formation of an interstate commission

Speaker: NA
Text: which would allow the Commonwealth to

Speaker: NA
Text: enter the interstate transport field. Once

Speaker: NA
Text: that was done, the Commonwealth would

Speaker: NA
Text: have a controlling influence throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: the transport sector of the economy. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Government must show

Speaker: NA
Text: initiative, drive and determination in that

Speaker: NA
Text: direction to live up to its obligations to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir, I repeat that our objective in

Speaker: NA
Text: financial matters should be to help the

Speaker: NA
Text: country to bake a larger cake. It is true

Speaker: NA
Text: that that cannot be done entirely by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer. It is not altogether a budgetary

Speaker: NA
Text: matter, but the Budget provides a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: venient time to indicate the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: determination to act along this line. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: a convenient time for the Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: find- indicate its policy and its plans.

Speaker: NA
Text: During the course of this debate, honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members have referred to the number

Speaker: NA
Text: I of jobs which must be provided this year

Speaker: NA
Text: and in the years to come. I warn the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government that in five years' time a very

Speaker: NA
Text: large number of youngsters will be enter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the employment market looking for

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities and for careers not only in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia but in every western country.

Speaker: NA
Text: In five years' time, therefore, we will have

Speaker: NA
Text: a very intensive trade war on our hands.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unless we make this country efficient and

Speaker: NA
Text: strong now, not simply by annual account-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, but by long-range planning and deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mination, we will be in a very difficult posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion when that time arrives in 1965 or

Speaker: NA
Text: am thereabouts. We are a great trading nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: We must plan forward and act aggressively

Speaker: NA
Text: and vigorously to implement those plans.

Speaker: Mr GRIFFITHS
Text: Shortland) [3.53] - I

Speaker: NA
Text: a agree with the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: preGwydir ( Mr Ian Allan) that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment should bake a bigger cake; but I

Speaker: NA
Text: also suggest that the Government should

Speaker: NA
Text: cut it up more evenly and distribute it

Speaker: NA
Text: among the people to better advantage. The

Speaker: NA
Text: statement of the Prime Minister ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Menzies) last week that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: intended to review its proposed increases

Speaker: NA
Text: in postal charges must have been like a

Speaker: NA
Text: breath of fresh air to those organizations

Speaker: NA
Text: which were likely to go out of business

Speaker: NA
Text: when the higher charges became operative.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt that the numerous pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: tests against these imposts and the wielding

Speaker: NA
Text: of the big stick by the Australian Country

Speaker: NA
Text: Party have had their effect. However, I

Speaker: NA
Text: want to record my protest against the

Speaker: NA
Text: charges, especially as they affect private

Speaker: NA
Text: operative organizations such as the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Roads and Motorists Association. The

Speaker: NA
Text: N.R.M.A. distributes about 400,000 copies

Speaker: NA
Text: of its journal to its members each month.

Speaker: NA
Text: This journal is of very great value to

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the N.R.M.A. It appears to

Speaker: NA
Text: me that once again the motoring public are

Speaker: NA
Text: to be the victims of this rapacious Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in its drive for more revenue, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I ask ths Government to consider reviewing

Speaker: NA
Text: the increases with a view to withdrawing

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposals.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, I think the Government should

Speaker: NA
Text: completely recast the Budget, and spread

Speaker: NA
Text: more evenly among the people the benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: that it contains. The Budget is somewhat

Speaker: NA
Text: disappointing. I think that it is more

Speaker: NA
Text: dishonest than any of the other nine

Speaker: NA
Text: budgets for which the Menzies Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has been responsible. It is a rich

Speaker: NA
Text: man's Budget. It strikes at the meagre

Speaker: NA
Text: resources of every worker while at the

Speaker: NA
Text: same time it hands out fabulous conces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions to the wealthy. I feel that the basic

Speaker: NA
Text: problems confronting the community to-day

Speaker: NA
Text: are the cost structure and its impact on the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. Its effect is closely linked with

Speaker: NA
Text: the steeply-mounting national debt and its

Speaker: NA
Text: terrific burden of interest payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: I should have liked to see the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment tackle the problem of the national

Speaker: NA
Text: debt, because in my view the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: will never get control of the inflation that

Speaker: NA
Text: is strangling the economy, nor will it check

Speaker: NA
Text: rising costs, so long as it follows its present

Speaker: NA
Text: fiscal policy. The whole question of the

Speaker: NA
Text: improvement of living standards, produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, expansion, employment, increased

Speaker: NA
Text: social services, imports and exports, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the general welfare of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people, is bound up with the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: fiscal and monetary policies. Even the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Bank, which can hardly be

Speaker: NA
Text: described as a friend of Labour or of the

Speaker: NA
Text: working class, in its monthly economic

Speaker: NA
Text: survey, expressed disappointment with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget. It said-

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, the concessions will not impose any

Speaker: NA
Text: real costs on Commonwealth finances, as it is

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated that increasing incomes and population

Speaker: NA
Text: will raise tax receipts by no less than Â£80,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: It will be seen by that statement, Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Temporary Chairman, that even private

Speaker: NA
Text: sources indicate that the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: co- income this year will be much greater than

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government concedes. Last year, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government budgeted for the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£110,000,000 of central bank funds to

Speaker: NA
Text: balance its budget, rather than cut depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental votes or restrict imports. For-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunately, it did not need most of that sum,

Speaker: NA
Text: as it was able to use income from trust

Speaker: NA
Text: funds which, to my mind, is an action also

Speaker: NA
Text: subject to criticism. This year, the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will seek to use Â£61,000,000 from

Speaker: NA
Text: the same source. I should like to know

Speaker: NA
Text: why there is all this humbug and hypocrisy

Speaker: NA
Text: on the part of the Government about

Speaker: NA
Text: central bank funds, when the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister knows full well that any

Speaker: NA
Text: government will use them to suit its

Speaker: NA
Text: own requirements. Perhaps the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Harold Holt) might tell us why those

Speaker: NA
Text: funds are being used in the defence vote

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than in the vote for some other

Speaker: NA
Text: department. Why are such funds not

Speaker: NA
Text: included in the Post Office appropriation

Speaker: NA
Text: or in the vote for the Snowy Mountains

Speaker: NA
Text: Hydro-electric scheme? Can their use in

Speaker: NA
Text: the defence vote be more easily covered

Speaker: NA
Text: up? Or what is the reason?

Speaker: NA
Text: For my part, I suggest that the defence

Speaker: NA
Text: vote of Â£192,000,000 is one of the greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: rackets on earth. It is certainly the most

Speaker: NA
Text: inflationary item of our expenditure.

Speaker: NA
Text: National service training is the greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: rort that I know of. Apart from its physical

Speaker: NA
Text: aspect, in that the training helps to develop

Speaker: NA
Text: many of our young folk, the money spent

Speaker: NA
Text: on it is just wasted. Naturally, the top

Speaker: NA
Text: brass and the instructors from the regular

Speaker: NA
Text: Army want to keep it going, as it is a good

Speaker: NA
Text: cop for them. Week-end camps are simply

Speaker: NA
Text: a farce, and the quicker they are dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: continued the better for everybody.

Speaker: NA
Text: Will the Treasurer tell the Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: and the people what the Â£37,000,000 approachieving.

Speaker: NA
Text: priated last year from loan funds for

Speaker: NA
Text: defence was used for? Was it used

Speaker: NA
Text: purchase equipment or food or was it used

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay wages? What will the Â£37,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: provided in this Budget be used for

Speaker: NA
Text: same department? I suggest that the

Speaker: NA
Text: formation could be of enormous value,

Speaker: NA
Text: because it would illustrate to some degree

Speaker: NA
Text: whether or not central bank funds could

Speaker: NA
Text: used as extensively by a Labour governmotor

Speaker: NA
Text: ment as they are apparently being used

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government. I make no apology for

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that I believe that central bank

Speaker: NA
Text: will have to be used far more extensively

Speaker: NA
Text: than is now the case, if the nation

Speaker: NA
Text: develop in keeping with the development

Speaker: NA
Text: taking place in Communist countries.

Speaker: NA
Text: The action of the Government in its

Speaker: NA
Text: savage imposition of increased postal rates

Speaker: NA
Text: reeks of dishonesty, and reminds me of

Speaker: NA
Text: imposition of sales tax on ice cream in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1952-53 horror budget. In that year,

Speaker: NA
Text: Arthur Fadden found that a tax on ice

Speaker: NA
Text: cream would return the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: handsome profit, because ice cream

Speaker: NA
Text: then being used by every family as a food.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was no longer a child's delicacy.

Speaker: NA
Text: tax still remains. The Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: failed to remove it because it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: money spinner. The ice cream tax, Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Temporary Chairman, and now the inthe

Speaker: NA
Text: creased postal charges, remind me of

Speaker: NA
Text: centuries-old salt tax of China. Many

Speaker: NA
Text: hundreds of years ago, the Chinese rulers

Speaker: NA
Text: found that every Chinese used salt, so

Speaker: NA
Text: imposed a salt tax on the population.

Speaker: NA
Text: salt tax still remains in China, even though

Speaker: NA
Text: the Chinese people pay no direct personal

Speaker: NA
Text: exertion tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is my view that the crippling postal

Speaker: NA
Text: charges and the ice cream tax will always

Speaker: NA
Text: remain in this country so long as this

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment is allowed to remain in office. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is, therefore, up to the electors to get rid

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Government as quickly as possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: In effect, every one, rich or poor, the

Speaker: NA
Text: the age and invalid pensioners, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: children, all have to subscribe to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's vicious money grab.

Speaker: NA
Text: The theme used by the Treasurer in

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget speech, and repeated by the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, was expansion, progress and

Speaker: NA
Text: stability, which both speakers claimed

Speaker: NA
Text: Government had been responsible for

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasurer repeatedly

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed to the achievements of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: to ment, of industry, and of commercial and

Speaker: NA
Text: financial institutions during the past year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The right honorable gendeman endeavoured

Speaker: NA
Text: by the to show how the Government's immigra-

Speaker: NA
Text: intion programme was assisting in the expan-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of both primary and secondary indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries. He spoke of the high rate of home-

Speaker: NA
Text: be building and of the great number of new

Speaker: NA
Text: vehicles that had been registered

Speaker: NA
Text: by during 1958-59. Mention was made of the

Speaker: NA
Text: remarkable progress in industrial produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: funds tion. The Treasurer said that earlier there

Speaker: NA
Text: were to be seen crippling shortages of

Speaker: NA
Text: is to materials, equipment, fuel and power,

Speaker: NA
Text: which had hampered progress, but that we

Speaker: NA
Text: now seemed to have achieved a remarkable

Speaker: NA
Text: basis of stability-economic , political, social

Speaker: NA
Text: and industrial. The Treasurer, I believe,

Speaker: NA
Text: the then blotted his copybook, because he had

Speaker: NA
Text: the been handing out bouquets to the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir ment, and taking all the kudos for the

Speaker: NA
Text: remarkable achievements of this country

Speaker: NA
Text: a during the past fifteen to twenty years.

Speaker: NA
Text: was The right honorable gentleman had con-

Speaker: NA
Text: veniently forgotten the part that the Curtin

Speaker: NA
Text: That and Chifley Governments had played in

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation's development. He had forgotten

Speaker: NA
Text: good that the immigration scheme about which

Speaker: NA
Text: he talked so much was the brain child of

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Melbourne ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: the Calwell). The right honorable gendeman

Speaker: NA
Text: also forgot that when this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: came to office there was an acute shortage

Speaker: NA
Text: they of man-power throughout the length and

Speaker: NA
Text: The breadth of Australia. Tens of thousands

Speaker: NA
Text: of positions were vacant, thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: people had two jobs each, and employers

Speaker: NA
Text: were glad to take on any kind of labour.

Speaker: NA
Text: In those days it did not matter whether

Speaker: NA
Text: or not a man had an affliction, whether he

Speaker: NA
Text: had a wooden leg or a bad heart; so long

Speaker: NA
Text: Goas he was willing to work he was employed.

Speaker: NA
Text: To-day the position is different. In

Speaker: NA
Text: sick, many industries doctors examine appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cants for employment to see whether they

Speaker: NA
Text: are in good health. If there is any sign of

Speaker: NA
Text: physical disability the applicant is rejected

Speaker: NA
Text: and remains on the dole. Married women

Speaker: NA
Text: the are continually being retrenched and in

Speaker: NA
Text: many instances are not being replaced in

Speaker: NA
Text: industry because mechanized plant is

Speaker: NA
Text: the taking over. To-day there are more than

Speaker: NA
Text: 63,000 registered unemployed. In addition,

Speaker: NA
Text: thousands of women need work and cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: procure it. Literally thousands of people

Speaker: NA
Text: who are out of work refuse to register for

Speaker: NA
Text: employment because of the way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: they are treated at the employment office.

Speaker: NA
Text: Time and again unemployed men aind

Speaker: NA
Text: women have complained that they have

Speaker: NA
Text: been refused payment of the unemploy-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment benefit because departmental officers

Speaker: NA
Text: were not satisfied that they had been

Speaker: NA
Text: genuinely seeking employment. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer could at least have given

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labour government a little credit for

Speaker: NA
Text: its war-time and post-war achievements.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasurer's reference to the Korean

Speaker: NA
Text: war pin-points the thinking of most Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: Party and Australian Country Party

Speaker: NA
Text: members so far as the economic expan-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of this country is concerned. Big

Speaker: NA
Text: business thrives on war whilst millions of

Speaker: NA
Text: people perish. The Budget is a good illus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration of that. If the Treasurer's state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that we have found stability-

Speaker: NA
Text: economic, political, social and industrial-

Speaker: NA
Text: is authentic, why the need for the increase

Speaker: NA
Text: in postal and telephone charges and the

Speaker: NA
Text: imposition of a charge for prescriptions

Speaker: NA
Text: issued under the pharmaceutical benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme? If the nation has found economic

Speaker: NA
Text: stability, what will the Government do

Speaker: NA
Text: with the hundreds of millions of pounds

Speaker: NA
Text: that it has filched from the taxpayers

Speaker: NA
Text: during the last ten years on the pretext that

Speaker: NA
Text: it was putting the surplus spending powei

Speaker: NA
Text: of the people into a safe place in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: curtail inflation? I ask the Treasurer why

Speaker: NA
Text: he is continuing to take out of the Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: solidated Revenue Fund millions of pounds

Speaker: NA
Text: each year to put it into the Loan Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: solidation and Investment Reserve. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Auditor-General's report shows that this

Speaker: NA
Text: fund had a balance of Â£237,372,520 at

Speaker: NA
Text: 30th June last, having re-purchased

Speaker: NA
Text: securities totalling Â£100,046,099. What

Speaker: NA
Text: were the securities re-purchased for more

Speaker: NA
Text: than Â£100,000,000, and from whom were

Speaker: NA
Text: they re-purchased? Will the Treasurer tell

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members how a loss of Â£529.190

Speaker: NA
Text: was incurred in the realization of invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments last year? I feel that some interesting

Speaker: NA
Text: revelations might flow from the details. 1

Speaker: NA
Text: do not suggest for one moment that there

Speaker: NA
Text: is anything sinister in the transaction, but

Speaker: NA
Text: I do think that the disclosures that would

Speaker: NA
Text: flow from the information would be very

Speaker: NA
Text: interesting. For instance, I think the

Speaker: NA
Text: statement made last year by Sir Arthur

Speaker: NA
Text: Fadden, when presenting his 1958-59

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget, showed quite clearly 'that this

Speaker: NA
Text: country had become so hopelessly in debt

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Australian people will forever he

Speaker: NA
Text: held in the vice-like grip of the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions and money lenders. Last yeai

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£363,000,000 of maturing loans had to be

Speaker: NA
Text: met, and this year a similar amount will

Speaker: NA
Text: have to be met.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasurer said that he did not yet

Speaker: NA
Text: know the exact amount that bonds maturing

Speaker: NA
Text: this year would represent, but he said that

Speaker: NA
Text: it would be a substantial amount. I under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand that the amount will b.e in the vicinity

Speaker: NA
Text: of Â£300,000,000. If that is so, you can

Speaker: NA
Text: bet any amount that again this year the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government will have to find a substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: sum for bond redemption purposes. Last

Speaker: NA
Text: year, the Government found Â£72,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: for that purpose and it may have to find

Speaker: NA
Text: a similar amount this year. I should like

Speaker: NA
Text: to know why the Government cannot use.

Speaker: NA
