Text: loan funds for bond redemption just as it

Speaker: NA
Text: is using loan funds to balance its budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is common knowledge that numerous

Speaker: NA
Text: investors in Commonwealth bonds are not

Speaker: NA
Text: renewing them with government or semi-

Speaker: NA
Text: government stock. As the bonds mature

Speaker: NA
Text: they are withdrawn and transferred to hire-

Speaker: NA
Text: purchase companies, which offer up to

Speaker: NA
Text: five times as much interest. The hire-

Speaker: NA
Text: purchase racket operating in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: to-day is a positive disgrace to any

Speaker: NA
Text: civilized community. This Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: being aware of what is happening with re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gard to hire-purchase finance investment in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to-day, is guilty of encouraging

Speaker: NA
Text: the worst form of usury by those people.

Speaker: NA
Text: More than Â£400,000,000 is now tied up in

Speaker: NA
Text: various hire-purchase companies. Week

Speaker: NA
Text: after week advertisements appear in the

Speaker: NA
Text: daily newspapers offering investors up to

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 per cent, interest on their investments.

Speaker: NA
Text: The bonafidesof those companies should b?

Speaker: NA
Text: examined. I submit that an investor can

Speaker: NA
Text: double his capital every five years only by

Speaker: NA
Text: exploitation or at the expense of the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: suming public. Nearly every private bank

Speaker: NA
Text: in the country is operating in the hire-

Speaker: NA
Text: purchase field in some form.

Speaker: NA
Text: Properly conducted, hire purchase is good

Speaker: NA
Text: and essential to family life in times of high

Speaker: NA
Text: costs brought about by inflation, but never

Speaker: NA
Text: was it more necessary than now for govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to police hire-purchase transactions

Speaker: NA
Text: properly and to put a stop to inflation. In

Speaker: NA
Text: my view many people investing in hire

Speaker: NA
Text: purchase to-day are like cannibals. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: living off the misfortunes and needs of their

Speaker: NA
Text: fellows who seek finance to purchase the

Speaker: NA
Text: essential requirements of life.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Temporary Chairman, earlier I was

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with maturing loans and I indicated

Speaker: NA
Text: that possibly Â£70,000,000 would be needed

Speaker: NA
Text: this year to pay bond-holders who wanted

Speaker: NA
Text: their money. In view of the fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government used Â£37.000.000 last year

Speaker: NA
Text: from' bank credit, or, as the Treasurer called

Speaker: NA
Text: it, the loan fund, to help finance the defence

Speaker: NA
Text: vote, why could not similar money be used

Speaker: NA
Text: to repay those investors who seek the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: turn of their money to invest it in hire

Speaker: NA
Text: chase? The national debt now stands at

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£4,040,000,000. Interest payments on that

Speaker: NA
Text: money total Â£147,800,406 this year. Since

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government came to office-i n ten

Speaker: NA
Text: years of Liberal-Australian Country Party

Speaker: NA
Text: Government-th e interest bill has practically

Speaker: NA
Text: doubled, and within a year or two it will

Speaker: NA
Text: have doubled. Since 1949 the debt has

Speaker: NA
Text: increased by Â£1,215,000,000. Are our

Speaker: NA
Text: people to be forever subjected to a rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation so high that many of them will be

Speaker: NA
Text: crippled economically for as long as they

Speaker: NA
Text: live? Each year increased amounts are to

Speaker: NA
Text: be provided in the Budget to meet interest

Speaker: NA
Text: payments. I feel that eventually something

Speaker: NA
Text: must happen to compel governments to do

Speaker: NA
Text: something about this appalling position.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like the Treasurer to say what

Speaker: NA
Text: has happened to the debt incurred in the

Speaker: NA
Text: building of the old Newcastle tramway

Speaker: NA
Text: system or the tramway systems recently

Speaker: NA
Text: taken up in Castlereagh and George streets,

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney, or to the debt incurred in building

Speaker: NA
Text: many ships of the Royal Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: which have long since been sunk or broken

Speaker: NA
Text: up. What happens to the money owing on

Speaker: NA
Text: many of the old post office buildings

Speaker: NA
Text: the exchange equipment, which are

Speaker: NA
Text: obsolete and out of use? I think it is time

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government looked at the posilevel

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and used its loan funds provided from

Speaker: NA
Text: bank credit to repay loans now being

Speaker: NA
Text: deemed, and thus reduce the burden of

Speaker: NA
Text: interest payments which the community cities.

Speaker: NA
Text: meets and which is becoming heavier year

Speaker: NA
Text: by year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us consider the subject of exports,

Speaker: NA
Text: which worries the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Richmond ( Mr Anthony). I agree with him

Speaker: NA
Text: that a high export market does provide

Speaker: NA
Text: prosperity not only to rural communities

Speaker: NA
Text: but to the nation as a whole. But he and

Speaker: NA
Text: his colleagues disregard completely the

Speaker: NA
Text: ability of the home market to do likewise,

Speaker: NA
Text: provided the people are allowed to work and

Speaker: NA
Text: obtain a decent standard of living. A high

Speaker: NA
Text: standard of living can only be obtained by

Speaker: NA
Text: full employment. Increased rural consump-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion can be obtained by increased social ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice benefits, better education, better hous-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, increased water and sewerage facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: and better roads. High costs can be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced by a reduction of the national debt

Speaker: NA
Text: and the excessively high interest bill that the

Speaker: NA
Text: people are called upon to meet every year.

Speaker: NA
Text: This year the interest bill on the national

Speaker: NA
Text: pur- debt, which stands at approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£4,000,000,000, will be approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£147,000,000. If those two items could be

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced we would be well on the way to

Speaker: NA
Text: stabilizing and reducing the cost structure,

Speaker: NA
Text: about which the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Richmond was so concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is my view that in future Australia will

Speaker: NA
Text: need to concentrate on consuming more of

Speaker: NA
Text: its primary production at home, while at

Speaker: NA
Text: the same time increasing exports to Asia of

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary products, such as electronic

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment and the like. I consider that,

Speaker: NA
Text: within the next few years, China will offer

Speaker: NA
Text: an excellent market for the export of elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: trical goods, because she is extremely short

Speaker: NA
Text: of that kind of equipment. I believe, also,

Speaker: NA
Text: that as that country develops industrially

Speaker: NA
Text: it could become an exporter of oil, and,

Speaker: NA
Text: China being within the sterling bloc, that

Speaker: NA
Text: could mean a great deal to Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The need to increase the standard of

Speaker: NA
Text: living of those pensioners who receive the

Speaker: NA
Text: Navy basic pension and those persons who

Speaker: NA
Text: depend on other social service benefits can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not be too strongly emphasized. Nor can

Speaker: NA
Text: and we overlook the need to re-employ the

Speaker: NA
Text: now 63,000 persons who are out of work.

Speaker: NA
Text: These matters should be coupled with the

Speaker: NA
Text: of the consumption of primary pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducts and the need to undertake reproduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: retive works such as water and sewerage

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes in big country centres and the

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a positive and everlasting dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: grace that areas within 10 miles or less of

Speaker: NA
Text: the general post offices in Brisbane, Sydney,

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne and other capital cities are not

Speaker: NA
Text: sewered. I should like to hear the views

Speaker: NA
Text: of members of the Australian Country

Speaker: NA
Text: Party on this subject. Here we have a

Speaker: NA
Text: class of work that is urgently required in

Speaker: NA
Text: almost every large centre. All the material

Speaker: NA
Text: required is in abundant supply in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country, and all the necessary machinery

Speaker: NA
Text: can be manufactured here. Why do we

Speaker: NA
Text: allow 63,000 men and women to be out

Speaker: NA
Text: of work when work on such projects is

Speaker: NA
Text: waiting for them? Last year, a total of

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£8,652,000 was paid out in unemployment

Speaker: NA
Text: and sickness benents. Why could the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government not provide the additional

Speaker: NA
Text: funds to pay wages and provide the equip-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment needed to carry out the work that

Speaker: NA
Text: I have mentioned?

Speaker: NA
Text: The employment of workers on these

Speaker: NA
Text: projects would not entail the expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: of overseas funds, and the workers involved

Speaker: NA
Text: would spend their earnings on the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption of products from our own fac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tories and farms. In Australia to-day,

Speaker: NA
Text: there are 600,000 age and invalid pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioners, and to that number can be added

Speaker: NA
Text: many thousands of widows and special

Speaker: NA
Text: rate war pensioners. Were the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to pay each pensioner another 10s.

Speaker: NA
Text: a week, anything up to another Â£25,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: would go into circulation each year. Most

Speaker: NA
Text: of it would ultimately find its way into the

Speaker: NA
Text: pockets of the farming community, and

Speaker: NA
Text: thus lift the living standards of that sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the community considerably. I see

Speaker: NA
Text: no reason why anybody in this country

Speaker: NA
Text: should be unemployed. Nor do I see any

Speaker: NA
Text: reason why pensioners should go hungry

Speaker: NA
Text: while the farmers can produce a surplus

Speaker: NA
Text: of primary products.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's failure to assist the

Speaker: NA
Text: wives of invalid pensioners or the wives of

Speaker: NA
Text: age pensioners who are not certified as

Speaker: NA
Text: being permanendy incapacitated is beyond

Speaker: NA
Text: all reason. It appears to me that the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Social Services ( Mr Roberton) is

Speaker: NA
Text: quite oblivious to the hardships suffered

Speaker: NA
Text: by the dependants of many of our pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioners. Mr Temporary Chairman, does

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government expect a woman of 55 or

Speaker: NA
Text: 60 who has never worked in industry to

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to obtain employment? Thousands

Speaker: NA
Text: of women have been refused either a wife's

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance or a pension. Many of those

Speaker: NA
Text: who have been refused a wife's allowance

Speaker: NA
Text: have husbands between 65 and 70 years of

Speaker: NA
Text: age who are certified by doctors as being

Speaker: NA
Text: not permanently incapacitated for work

Speaker: NA
Text: although they have been retrenched from

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. Relief for the wife, therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: is refused, and both the man and his wife

Speaker: NA
Text: have to live on a miserable Â£4 7s. 6d. a

Speaker: NA
Text: week. The Government's refusal, in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget, to increase the wife's allowance is

Speaker: NA
Text: despicable, to say the least of it. Numerous

Speaker: NA
Text: women who are compelled to stay at home

Speaker: NA
Text: in order to care for invalid husbands are

Speaker: NA
Text: literally slaves and are half-starved. Often,

Speaker: NA
Text: the invalid requires special food, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: wife then has to go without, because the

Speaker: NA
Text: total income of Â£6 2s. 6d. a week will not

Speaker: NA
Text: go round. If there are children, the posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is much worse.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is my view that the Government should

Speaker: NA
Text: reduce the degree of incapacity necessary in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to qualify for an invalid pension from

Speaker: NA
Text: 85 to 75 per cent, and allow the pensioner

Speaker: NA
Text: to earn as much as other pensioners are

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed to earn. I know that the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: will say that this cannot be done, but I sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: mit, Mr Temporary Chairman, that it can

Speaker: NA
Text: be done. If a pensioner who receives a pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion because he has a heart condition under-

Speaker: NA
Text: takes employment of a kind that further

Speaker: NA
Text: jeopardizes his health, the responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: rests with the pensioner. But I feel that

Speaker: NA
Text: denying invalid pensioners the right to sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: plement their pension by more than a few

Speaker: NA
Text: shillings often condemns the pensioner and

Speaker: NA
Text: his wife to slow death.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Temporary Chairman, I now want to

Speaker: NA
Text: turn for a moment to the reference to

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced taxation made last week by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister, who claimed that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition (Dr Evatt) had

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberately misstated the benefits that will

Speaker: NA
Text: be obtained by all wage-earners as a result

Speaker: NA
Text: of the 5 per cent, reduction in income tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: I suggest that the boot is on the other foot

Speaker: NA
Text: and that it was the Prime Minister who

Speaker: NA
Text: endeavoured to mislead the public about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's taxation proposals. The

Speaker: NA
Text: general public should be told that when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government compares its proposals for this

Speaker: NA
Text: financial year with the proposals contained

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Budget for the financial year 1950-51

Speaker: NA
Text: it should not use average wages as a guide

Speaker: NA
Text: to the benefits that wage-earners are likely

Speaker: NA
Text: to receive as a result of the present tax

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions. The ruse of quoting average

Speaker: NA
Text: wages is deliberately misleading, and its

Speaker: NA
Text: use by people like the Treasurer and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister is not to their credit.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Forbes -O n a point of order, Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Temporary Chairman. I ask for your

Speaker: NA
Text: ruling on whether persons in the press

Speaker: NA
Text: gallery are permitted to read the

Speaker: NA
Text: " Tribune ".

Speaker: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN
Text: ( Mr that

Speaker: NA
Text: Wight) -Order ! The honorable member the ground.

Speaker: NA
Text: for Shortland may continue.

Speaker: Mr GRIFFITHS
Text: Th e Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: took Â£575 as the annual equivalent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: average wage in 1950 and Â£1,040 as the

Speaker: NA
Text: average in 1959. Neither figure is correct,

Speaker: NA
Text: because, in 1950, the majority of tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: payers received a wage much less than

Speaker: NA
Text: the average figure quoted by the right

Speaker: NA
Text: orable gentleman; and the position to-day

Speaker: NA
Text: is similar. According to the statistics

Speaker: NA
Text: tained in the Budget papers, in 1956-57,

Speaker: NA
Text: the number of taxpayers totalled

Speaker: NA
Text: 3,896,074, and 2,559,310 of them received

Speaker: NA
Text: an income of less than Â£999 for the year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cope - I rise to order, Mr Tem-

Speaker: NA
Text: porary Chairman. Is it a fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: person who is reading the "Tribune" is

Speaker: NA

Speaker: Mr GRIFFITHS
Text: I n 1950, the basic

Speaker: NA
Text: wage was approximately Â£6 2s. a week, or

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£317 a year. So a wage or salary earner

Speaker: NA
Text: who received Â£575 in that year earned

Speaker: NA
Text: really good money. However, let us deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with taxation alone, so that we all shall

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour Administration, a married man night

Speaker: NA
Text: with one child to keep paid no tax at all

Speaker: NA
Text: if he earned only the basic wage, and, in

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: were provided at minimum cost. The

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: for expenditure with a chemist, and Â£20

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Malcolm Fraser -O n a point of

Speaker: NA
Text: order, Mr Temporary Chairman: Is it

Speaker: NA
Text: in order for the " Tribune " or any other

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper to be read in the press gallery?

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! There is no point of order in-

Speaker: NA
Text: honvolved. I may say that the Chair is paying

Speaker: NA
Text: attention to what is going on in the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: conmittee. The honorable member for Short-

Speaker: NA
Text: land has been interrupted on a number of

Speaker: Mr CHANEY
Text: Perth) [4.23] -A t this

Speaker: NA
Text: time of the year we indulge in a fortnight's

Speaker: NA
Text: with debate on the Budget. On this occasion

Speaker: NA
Text: it was most interesting to hear the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Broadcasting Commission's

Speaker: NA
Text: news service, on the morning after the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer ( Mr Harold Holt) presented his

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget, summarize it in four minutes. I

Speaker: NA
Text: suppose in that four minutes the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia learned all they wanted to know

Speaker: NA
Text: about the 1959-60 Budget, because the

Speaker: NA
Text: news service picked out the highlights of

Speaker: NA
Text: it, pointing out what you will get and what

Speaker: NA
Text: will be taken from you. Then for a fort-

Speaker: NA
Text: various speakers on both sides of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House express their views on the Budget,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I venture to suggest that not one of us

Speaker: NA
Text: is naive enough to beUeve that what he says

Speaker: NA
Text: will have any direct bearing on the Budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: I predict that the debate will proceed

Speaker: NA
Text: according to plan, the vote being taken

Speaker: NA
Text: But I think we have reason to expect

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£20 that the comments made by various

Speaker: NA
Text: speakers will have some influence on the

Speaker: NA
Text: way in which the next Budget is framed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore I wish later to devote myself to

Speaker: NA
Text: a a few matters to which I think the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment could well give consideration.

Speaker: NA
Text: in Before doing so, however, I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: benecomment on the speeches of a couple of

Speaker: NA
Text: members, one from each side of

Speaker: NA
Text: The first speech to which I refer is that

Speaker: NA
Text: which was made by my colleague, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Bowman ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: MCColm), who spoke last night on the

Speaker: NA
Text: situation in New Guinea. I think he said,

Speaker: NA
Text: with a great deal of truth, that he has

Speaker: NA
Text: given much thought to the position in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory of Papua and New Guinea, and

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 am sure that after his visits there, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the time that has elapsed since he returned

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Territory, he has intensified his

Speaker: NA
Text: study of the situation. Finally he has

Speaker: NA
Text: presented his views to this committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: With those views I have little quarrel, but

Speaker: NA
Text: I do quarrel with that part of his views

Speaker: NA
Text: that the newspapers saw fit to headline this

Speaker: NA
Text: morning. I refer to the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber's remark that he felt the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Territories ( Mr Hasluck) had outlived his

Speaker: NA
Text: usefulness. But, in my opinion, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member broke down his own

Speaker: NA
Text: argument when he said that he believed

Speaker: NA
Text: completely in the sincerity of purpose of

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, and that few men in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: have been as sincere or have worked as

Speaker: NA
Text: hard in the interests of the natives of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory and of our own aborigines as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. If one passes that kind of judg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment on the work of the Minister, one

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot then proceed to a statement that

Speaker: NA
Text: he has outlived his usefulness as Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Territories.

Speaker: NA
Text: If some people in New Guinea, or some

Speaker: NA
Text: people in Australia, believe that actions

Speaker: NA
Text: taken by a Government-no t by a Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: but by a Government-ar e not in their

Speaker: NA
Text: interests, or are not in the interests of

Speaker: NA
Text: the natives, it is quite consistent with our

Speaker: NA
Text: political set-up for them to say so; but

Speaker: NA
Text: surely, if unpopular moves were the reason

Speaker: NA
Text: for removing Ministers from their posts,

Speaker: NA
Text: this country would have been without suc-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessive Federal Treasurers since federation.

Speaker: NA
Text: An unpopular move is, therefore, little

Speaker: NA
Text: excuse for advocating a Minister's removal,

Speaker: NA
Text: f do think, on the other hand, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: facts given us by the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Bowman-th e sincerity of the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, and his interest in the welfare of the

Speaker: NA
Text: native people-ar e fundamental reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: why he should remain in office.

Speaker: NA
Text: This New Guinea question is not one

Speaker: NA
Text: that is confined to the people of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, New Guinea is in the spotlight for

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole of the peoples of the Afro-Asian

Speaker: NA
Text: area, and what Australia does in New

Speaker: NA
Text: Guinea is of vital interest to those peoples

Speaker: NA
Text: in determining their attitude towards us.

Speaker: NA
Text: Their attitude towards us will largely deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mine whether we will be able to proceed

Speaker: NA
Text: to do what we want to do in New Guinea

Speaker: NA
Text: in the best interests of the indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: people of that country. For these reasons,

Speaker: NA
Text: although the Minister may lose the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: in fidence of members of this Parliament and

Speaker: NA
Text: of some residents of New Guinea, if the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and the Government retain the

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence of the people to whom New

Speaker: NA
Text: Guinea rightly belongs, then I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: we can go forward in the assumption that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are treading the right path.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now I wish to comment on something

Speaker: NA
Text: that was said during the debate this morn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning by the honorable member for Braddon

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Davies). He made a statement, per-

Speaker: NA
Text: haps by mischance, to the effect that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tariff Board, in its report on the timber

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry, had recommended subsidies on

Speaker: NA
Text: freights for Australian timber. That is not

Speaker: NA
Text: quite true.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Duthie -I t is pretty nearly right.

Speaker: Mr CHANEY
Text: I t is not quite true at

Speaker: NA
Text: all. It is entirely at variance with the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation that the board did make.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Tariff Board said-

Speaker: NA
Text: Because of the importance which the Board

Speaker: NA
Text: attaches to stability in the timber industry and

Speaker: NA
Text: the importance which freight disadvantages can

Speaker: NA
Text: have upon the return to timber producers in

Speaker: NA
Text: States which have to rely upon sea transport

Speaker: NA
Text: within the Australian market, the Board feels that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's attention should be directed

Speaker: NA
Text: to finding some solution to the problem of freight

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantage between domestic and imported

Speaker: NA
Text: timbers. Indeed, the Board believes that one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the major problems of the timber industry in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmama and Western Australia is, in fact, not

Speaker: NA
Text: a problem directly related to this industry so

Speaker: NA
Text: much as to the interstate shipping industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government, upon receipt of this

Speaker: NA
Text: report, did pay attention to this problem

Speaker: NA
Text: and appointed an inter-governmental com-

Speaker: NA
Text: very mittee to investigate it. From memory, I

Speaker: NA
Text: tthink that the committee did not recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mend that a subsidy be paid on interstate

Speaker: NA
Text: freights, because that is not a solution to

Speaker: NA
Text: the problem. At the time there was ship-

Speaker: NA
Text: ping lying idle in overseas ports, and it was

Speaker: NA
Text: safe to assume that there would be a further

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction in overseas freights, while Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian freight rates would continue to rise.

Speaker: NA
Text: So a subsidy, although it might have offered

Speaker: NA
Text: immediate relief, would not have provided

Speaker: NA
Text: much in the way of any long-term relief,

Speaker: NA
Text: and there was a necessity for the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: itself to look for ways and means to cut

Speaker: NA
Text: its costs, to improve handling conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: and to solve some of its other problems-

Speaker: NA
Text: which it has done.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do believe, however, that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment can give assistance to the timber

Speaker: NA
Text: industry in South Austraha, in Tasmania

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly, and in Western Australia. I

Speaker: NA
Text: feel that the Government is obliged to do

Speaker: NA
Text: so because of the dimculty the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: faces continually in the timber areas that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have in Australia. As your centres of

Speaker: NA
Text: production move further from your sea

Speaker: NA
Text: ports, when new cutting areas are opened

Speaker: NA
Text: up, you get an increase in costs. In placing

Speaker: NA
Text: timber on markets throughout Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry is constantly facing this

Speaker: NA
Text: problem of an increasing cost structure.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the present time Western Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: can produce far more timber than it can

Speaker: NA
Text: sell, either in the State itself or in the

Speaker: NA
Text: eastern States. Although the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has said that it does not use import conlished

Speaker: NA
Text: trols to bolster up any Australian industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that this is one instance in which

Speaker: NA
Text: it would well do so. Souih Australia is

Speaker: NA
Text: importing vast quantities of oregon timber

Speaker: NA
Text: from America. This, of course, costs us

Speaker: NA
Text: dollars. Several honorable members from

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia have spoken on this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter in this chamber on previous occawho

Speaker: NA
Text: sions. At the same time as South

Speaker: NA
Text: is importing timber from America, there

Speaker: NA
Text: are available in Western Australia ample

Speaker: NA
Text: supplies of timber for the South Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: building industry, which has been found

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfactory by the South Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: builders. As a matter of fact, some of

Speaker: NA
Text: them, such as the State housing authority,

Speaker: NA
Text: specify that Western Australian timber

Speaker: NA
Text: should be used in their buildings.

Speaker: NA
Text: If one turns to the section of the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: speech concerned with mining industries,

Speaker: NA
Text: one finds this-

Speaker: NA
Text: Proposals will be brought forward to liberalize

Speaker: NA
Text: under certain circumstances the depreciation

Speaker: NA
Text: visions relating to various categories of expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture by mining concerns on housing and certain

Speaker: NA
Text: other amenities. The annual cost to revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated at Â£250,000 including 1959-60.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because the Government recognizes the

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of mining in the earning of

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas funds, it is taking certain steps

Speaker: NA
Text: develop mining undertakings throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. It is also legislating to give

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance in the search for oil, because of

Speaker: NA
Text: the importance of this commodity with

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to our overseas balances. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has a duty also, not only

Speaker: NA
Text: to those industries that it wants to start up

Speaker: NA
Text: and induce to grow, but also to the older-

Speaker: NA
Text: established industries such as the timber

Speaker: NA
Text: industry. If we can apply these deprecia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion concessions to the mining industry in

Speaker: NA
Text: an endeavour to help it solve its problems,

Speaker: NA
Text: then surely we can meet the requests of

Speaker: NA
Text: the timber industry to have the same con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessions applied in that case.

Speaker: NA
Text: For years past the timber industry has

Speaker: NA
Text: been urging the Government to take into

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration expenditure on mill buildings,

Speaker: NA
Text: housing, &c, with regard to this matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: depreciation. When you move your mill

Speaker: NA
Text: centre to a new area of production you

Speaker: NA
Text: have this problem of building, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe the Government could well con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider applying to the timber industry also

Speaker: NA
Text: the depreciation system that it has estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: for the benefit of the mining industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: By doing so, it would help to lower the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost structure to a certain extent. This

Speaker: NA
Text: would enable the timber industry to survive

Speaker: NA
Text: and to continue to provide employment for

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers of Australians who, in many cases,

Speaker: NA
Text: have been brought up in the timber indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try, who know no other occupation and

Speaker: NA
Text: would be lost souls if they lost their

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia employment in that industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other point that I want to touch on

Speaker: NA
Text: concerns social services. I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition supporters have raised strong

Speaker: NA
Text: objections to the static position of child

Speaker: NA
Text: endowment payments. I agree with them

Speaker: NA
Text: to the extent that I think the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: should give serious consideration to some

Speaker: NA
Text: action in connexion with child endowment

Speaker: NA
Text: payments. If it cannot grant a flat rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: increase applying to every child, then it

Speaker: NA
Text: should adopt some method of easing the

Speaker: NA
Text: burden on the middle income group parti-

Speaker: NA
Text: procularly, and on those with large families.

Speaker: NA
Text: I notice that the Minister for Supply ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: is Hulme), in his Budget speech the other

Speaker: NA
Text: night, in reply to the Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition (Dr Evatt), stated that this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment had done many things which could be

Speaker: NA
Text: to considered as alternative to an increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: the child endowment payments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr KilleD -Ho w many children have

Speaker: NA
Text: you?

Speaker: Mr CHANEY
Text: O n the last count, Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Acting Chairman, seven. I was speaking

Speaker: NA
Text: about the middle income group. Having

Speaker: NA
Text: read the newspaper statements following the

Speaker: NA
Text: Richardson report, I can hardly believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: I am in the middle income group; after

Speaker: NA
Text: reading those newspapers 1 believe that I

Speaker: NA
Text: am in the millionaire group, so what I am

Speaker: NA
Text: saying to the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Moreton does not apply in my case.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Supply said that this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government had introduced a medical

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits scheme, a pharmaceutical benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme, free milk for school children,

Speaker: NA
Text: poliomyelitis vaccine free of charge, tax

Speaker: NA
Text: concessions for educational expenses, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth scholarships scheme, about

Speaker: NA
Text: which 1 shall comment later, and increased

Speaker: NA
Text: tax concessions in respect of dependants.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is very true, and I suppose that the

Speaker: NA
Text: average family has benefited considerably.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it still does not get away from the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that when a child who is still attending

Speaker: NA
Text: a school or a university reaches sixteen

Speaker: NA
Text: years of age, the family suffers because

Speaker: NA
Text: child endowment for that child ceases. It

Speaker: NA
Text: also suffers in another way. The amount

Speaker: NA
Text: lost is not 5s., which is die payment for

Speaker: NA
Text: the first child, but 10s., which is the pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for the second child, because the

Speaker: NA
Text: second child then becomes the first child

Speaker: NA
Text: for the purposes of endowment. The Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment could well give consideration to

Speaker: NA
Text: the payment of child endowment up to

Speaker: NA
Text: a later age for the child who remains at

Speaker: NA
Text: school or proceeds to university, because

Speaker: NA
Text: that is fhe period when the family feels the

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty of financing schooling for their

Speaker: NA
Text: children.

Speaker: NA
Text: I disagree with the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Macquarie ( Mr Luchetti) who stated

Speaker: NA
Text: that all over the country brilliant children

Speaker: NA
Text: were leaving school at an early age to

Speaker: NA
Text: supplement the family income. That to

Speaker: NA
Text: me is a rather derogatory statement to

Speaker: NA
Text: make about parents in the middle and

Speaker: NA
Text: lower income groups, many of whom keep

Speaker: NA
Text: their children at school and at university

Speaker: NA
Text: at great sacrifice to themselves. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: very few instances where a brilliant child

Speaker: NA
Text: leaves school to supplement the family in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come and if we look back over the history

Speaker: NA
Text: of brilliant children who have left school

Speaker: NA
Text: at fourteen or fifteen years of age, we

Speaker: NA
Text: find them in commerce or industry or

Speaker: NA
Text: somewhere else holding leading positions in

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever field they have chosen; their

Speaker: NA
Text: ability has shown itself and they have come

Speaker: NA
Text: to the top.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: have been if they had had the additional

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity, though!

Speaker: Mr CHANEY
Text: Sometime s when I

Speaker: NA
Text: look around this chamber I doubt whether

Speaker: NA
Text: the opportunities that have been given to

Speaker: NA
Text: some have been properly grasped and used

Speaker: NA
Text: to advantage.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Minister for Supply mentioned,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government introduced a Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth scholarship scheme. However good

Speaker: NA
Text: it may be, I believe that it can be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderably improved. First, the interpreta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the living allowance is quite wrong.

Speaker: NA
Text: A living allowance should be paid on the

Speaker: NA
Text: net income and not on the gross income,

Speaker: NA
Text: because very few people qualify for it

Speaker: NA
Text: after the means test has been applied.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further, if a child is brilliant enough to

Speaker: NA
Text: win a scholarship, the value of the scholar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship becomes part of the father's taxable

Speaker: NA
Text: income. It puts the father into a higher

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax group. Any one who wins a

Speaker: NA
Text: motor car on a quiz show, a lottery or a

Speaker: NA
Text: prize as a beauty contestant is not required

Speaker: NA
Text: to add the value of the prize to the taxable

Speaker: NA
Text: income. What we are doing, in effect, is

Speaker: NA
Text: taxing the brain power of our citizens at a

Speaker: NA
Text: time when this brain power should be used

Speaker: NA
Text: to the greatest advantage. I suggest that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government give serious consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: to this problem, because, in all instances,

Speaker: NA
Text: regardless of the income of the parents,

Speaker: NA
Text: education to university level these days is a

Speaker: NA
Text: severe drain on whatever resources they

Speaker: NA
Text: have.

Speaker: NA
Text: The third matter in the field of social

Speaker: NA
Text: services that I would advocate is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government institute, along the lines of

Speaker: NA
Text: the medical health scheme, a dental care

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. Dentists' bills to-day are the

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest bugbear of Australian families.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many children now visit a dentist not to

Speaker: NA
Text: get their teeth put in a sound state, but

Speaker: NA
Text: to have dental treatment to the amount

Speaker: NA
Text: that the parents can afford to pay. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme should be introduced so that the

Speaker: NA
Text: parents of children up to a certain age,

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps seven or eight years or a litde

Speaker: NA
Text: older, could receive some assistance to

Speaker: NA
Text: will ensure that their children enjoy sound

Speaker: NA
Text: dental health. To-day, dentists themselves

Speaker: NA
Text: admit that the simplest treatment is being

Speaker: NA
Text: priced beyond the means of the average

Speaker: NA
Text: parent.

Speaker: NA
Text: The last matter on which I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: comment is a matter that has received a

Speaker: NA
Text: great deal of attention during the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: debate. There is some dangerous talk, par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly from Opposition members, about

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas investments in this country. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for MCPherson ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Barnes) yesterday gave a very clear

Speaker: NA
Text: account of the activities of General

Speaker: NA
Text: Motors-Holden's Limited in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: He mentioned what Australia owed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the company and what the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany had ploughed back into the nation's

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. Therefore, I do not want to

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with that point. However, I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that honorable members should be

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely careful lest they do the very

Speaker: NA
Text: thing that can sound the death knell of

Speaker: NA
Text: development in Australia, by frightening

Speaker: NA
Text: people away from investment within this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. I shall illustrate how simply this

Speaker: NA
Text: can be done. Some two or three years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago, the Western Australian Government

Speaker: NA
Text: passed a simple act on unfair trading. I

Speaker: NA
Text: know as an absolute fact that firms that

Speaker: NA
Text: had decided to go to Western Australia to

Speaker: NA
Text: establish businesses did not do so because

Speaker: NA
Text: of the operation of this legislation.

Text: placing a curb on the progress of their

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable members opposite would do

Speaker: NA
Text: well to get a copy of a speech made by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable William Sebald, the American

Speaker: NA
Text: Ambassador to Australia, to the Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: Rotary Club on 9th June, at a time when investment of British capital.

Speaker: NA
Text: there was much criticism in the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: press from would-be influential people about

Speaker: NA
Text: the success of General Motors-Holden's

Speaker: NA
Text: Limited. That particular aspect was not

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned in the speech, but I think the

Speaker: NA
Text: aim was to stop some of this nonsensical

Speaker: NA
Text: thinking about profits. When we are hear-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing so many tales of gloom about the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian economy, it is refreshing to hear a

Speaker: NA
Text: man like the American Ambassador praise

Speaker: NA
Text: the state of the Australian economy in the

Speaker: NA
Text: way that he did in this speech. I shall

Speaker: NA
Text: quote at some length from it, although if

Speaker: NA
Text: this were the American House of Repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sentatives I could now request that the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: of the speech be incorporated in " Hansard "

Speaker: NA
Text: and I would be saved the necessity of read-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing it. I cannot read it in full but I shall try

Speaker: NA
Text: to string the pieces together. He said-

Speaker: NA
Text: During the past year and a half we have had

Speaker: NA
Text: an extraordinary demonstration of the strength

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian economy in the face of a

Speaker: NA
Text: world-wide recession and of a continuation, for

Speaker: NA
Text: the second consecutive year, of the lowest level

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian farm incomes for a decade. In-

Speaker: NA
Text: come from wool exports have been down by over

Speaker: NA
Text: 40 per cent. Yet, in spite of this, national income

Speaker: NA
Text: has not declined significantly. The period has

Speaker: NA
Text: thus shown that Australia has become less depen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent on primary industry, and particularly on

Speaker: NA
Text: wool, for its short-run prosperity.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the benefit of those who may think that

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Sebald was decrying the development

Speaker: NA
Text: of the wool industry in Australia, I point

Speaker: NA
Text: out that he went on to clarify the statement.

Speaker: NA
Text: Later in the speech he said-

Speaker: NA
Text: The investors of the world, I think, are now

Speaker: NA
Text: becoming aware of Australia's rich resources and

Speaker: NA
Text: of the stability of its institutions and strength of

Speaker: NA
Text: its economy. This being so, Australia has, through

Speaker: NA
Text: its own efforts, reached a most enviable position-

Speaker: NA
Text: which many other less fortunate nations

Speaker: NA
Text: be would go to great lengths to achieve.

Speaker: NA
Text: So the speech proceeded, praising the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian economy which was so attractive to

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas investors and proving that, regard-

Speaker: NA
Text: less of what was taken out after these in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestments had been made, they added to the

Speaker: NA
Text: general wealth of the country because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: attraction of other investments. He said-

Speaker: NA
Text: It is for this reason that I was somewhat

Speaker: NA
Text: by recent comments which suggested that

Speaker: NA
Text: the price paid for foreign investment was too

Speaker: NA
Text: It was interesting to be told that the develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of America in the early days of its

Speaker: NA
Text: history was achieved entirely by the invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of overseas capital. The American

Speaker: NA
Text: railroad system was built in the main by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queen

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria was the largest shareholder in one

Speaker: NA
Text: particular American railroad. From that

Speaker: NA
Text: example, the Americans point to the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian scene and say that since Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: has reached a stage of development com-

Speaker: NA
Text: parable with that in America at that time,

Speaker: NA
Text: the attraction of overseas capital can help

Speaker: NA
Text: us to develop at much the same rate as

Speaker: NA
Text: America did in those early years. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: interesting to note the amount of non-

Speaker: NA
Text: American capital-no t necessarily British-

Speaker: NA
Text: invested in the United States at that period.

Speaker: NA
Text: From 1843 to 1919 America was a net

Speaker: NA
Text: debtor. In 1919 she became a net credi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tor because during World War I . most of

Speaker: NA
Text: the British investments in America had to

Speaker: NA
Text: be sold so that Great Britain could buy

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment needed to fight the war. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 1843 the amount of foreign capital invested

Speaker: NA
Text: in the United States amounted to

Speaker: NA
Text: 200,000,000 dollars. By 1869 the amount

Speaker: NA
Text: had risen to 1,460,000,000 dollars; in 1897

Speaker: NA
Text: it was 2,710,000,000, and in 1908, it was

Speaker: NA
Text: 3,900,000,000 dollars. To show what was

Speaker: NA
Text: happening in the country, American

Speaker: NA
Text: national wealth in 1843 stood at

Speaker: NA
Text: 88,500,000,000 dollars and in 1912 at

Speaker: NA
Text: 186,300,000,000 dollars. America has

Speaker: NA
Text: progressed at an amazing rate over the last

Speaker: NA
Text: two centuries and its example clearly shows

Speaker: NA
Text: that overseas investment in Australia can

Speaker: NA
Text: only serve the best interests of our nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: When dividends from overseas invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments are paid to shareholders outside Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, some people think that Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: resources are being drained away. But, in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, investments of that kind are opening

Speaker: NA
Text: up further channels of investment and in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creasing the reservoir of our national

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth. Critics of undertakings like General

Speaker: NA
Text: Motors-Holden's Limited should bear in

Speaker: NA
Text: mind the fact that all American investments

Speaker: NA
Text: in this country have not met with such

Speaker: NA
Text: success. For example millions of pounds

Speaker: NA
Text: have been invested in oil search in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: with absolutely no return to the investors

Speaker: NA
Text: and the possibility is that there never will

Speaker: NA
Text: be a return.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Jones -Wha t about the profit from

Speaker: NA
Text: oil sales?

Speaker: NA
Text: Lastly, I shall refer briefly to the state

Text: of Western Australia's economy. The

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Hill Proprietary Company Limited. My

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: economy of our State and provide employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for the thousands we want to see

Speaker: NA
Text: employed in Western Australia.

Speaker: NA

Text: the dent on producers, manufacturers and ex-

Speaker: NA

Text: great capital inflow . . . . lies beyond our

Text: The honorable member for Perth ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Chaney) has referred to the benefits to be

Text: derived from the investment of foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: capital in Australia. Although I do not

Text: oppose the establishment of foreign enter-

Text: prises, or the investment of foreign capital,

Text: in this country, there should be a percentage

Text: of Australian holdings in all companies so

Text: established. Those companies should have

Text: the right to export their production to any

Text: part of the world. However, in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: we have companies wholly owned by over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas organizations which exploit this coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try, obtain huge profits and then take out

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia a great proportion of those

Speaker: NA
Text: profits. The much maligned General

Speaker: NA
Text: Motors-Holden's Limited raised its capital

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia. That company advertises every

Text: day for debenture capital to finance its

Text: operations, offering to pay 6 i per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: interest on a long-term loan although it

Text: is making many hundreds per cent, in

Text: profits. G.M.H. is not an example of

Text: foreign capital investment; it is an example

Text: of foreign interests exploiting Australian

Text: capital. Only by expanding the home

Text: markets for our produce can we obtain a

Speaker: NA
Text: turnover in goods to enable us to build up a

Text: sound export market. If we have a substan-

Text: tial home market which is protected to the

Text: extent that our industries are able to

Text: ducers, because during the ten years it has

Text: been in office the march of inflation has

Speaker: NA
Text: been unchecked, and the cost structure has

Speaker: NA
Text: become a heavier burden on our industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been rather alarmed to learn that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Trade, a member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Country Party, has initiated

Speaker: NA
Text: quiries before the Tariff Board into about

Speaker: NA
Text: 300 items on the most-favoured-nation

Speaker: NA
Text: schedule designed to lower the rate of duty

Speaker: NA
Text: on a comprehensive range of goods imported

Speaker: NA
Text: from foreign countries. I have taken the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to examine all those

Speaker: NA
Text: have found that the proposed reductions

Speaker: NA
Text: of duty will be very substantial in many

Speaker: NA
Text: instances and will be disastrous to the

Speaker: NA
Text: establishment of new industries and to the protection.

Speaker: NA
Text: security and development of those already

Speaker: NA
Text: established. Advertisements have appeared

Speaker: NA
Text: in Sydney newspapers to the effect

Text: Tariff Board inquiries will commence on

Speaker: NA
Text: 20th July into 164 items, and on 6th

Speaker: NA
Text: October into a further 106 items. Unfor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunately, the Tariff Board must complete

Speaker: NA
Text: its inquiries within a specified time so it

Speaker: NA
Text: does not have the opportunity to inquire

Speaker: NA
Text: carefully into all of the 300 items on the

Speaker: NA
Text: schedule. I shall refer to only a few of

Speaker: NA
Text: the items on the schedule. The duty of

Speaker: NA
Text: 47i per cent., plus 10 per cent, primage,

Speaker: NA
Text: on screws, bolts, nuts, rivets and metal

Speaker: NA
Text: washers will be reduced to 17i per cent.;

Speaker: NA
Text: the duty of 22i per cent., plus 10 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: primage, on screw hooks, eyes and rings

Speaker: NA
Text: will be reduced to 7 i per cent.; the duty

Speaker: NA
Text: of 45 per cent, on transmitters will be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced to 30 per cent.; the duty of 45 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, on electrical machines and appliances

Speaker: NA
Text: will be reduced to 30 per cent.; and the

Speaker: NA
Text: duty of 22i per cent., plus 10 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: primage, on certain electrical household

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment will be reduced to 7 i per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Industries producing the goods to which

Speaker: NA
Text: I have referred are already established in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, and I am sure that the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions will make it more difficult for

Text: them to carry on. Instead of trying to

Text: build up home markets for our production,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government seems to be trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: wreck established industries. Unfortunately,

Speaker: NA
Text: many Australian Country Party members

Speaker: NA
Text: are one-eyed, and cannot see what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is doing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me refer now to textiles. The duty of

Speaker: NA
Text: 22i per cent, on blankets, which are manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: factured on a large scale in Australia, will

Speaker: NA
Text: be reduced to 12i per cent. A similar

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction will be made in the case of quilts.

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee indicate the substantial reductions of

Speaker: NA
Text: duty that the Government suggests should

Speaker: NA
Text: be made in order to encourage other coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries to purchase our primary products,

Speaker: NA
Text: inbut it is doing this at the expense of our

Text: secondary industries. Such a policy is

Speaker: NA
Text: disastrous. Indeed, Mr G. R. Bain, the

Speaker: NA
Text: tariff officer for the Associated Chambers

Text: of Manufactures of Australia, made a very

Speaker: NA
Text: strong comment about the attitude of the

Speaker: NA
Text: items, and Government. He said-

Speaker: NA
Text: If Ausbralian industry is to grow and to make

Speaker: NA
Text: a greater contribution to national development,

Speaker: NA
Text: it must have tariff rates which will give real

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour will never agree to substantial tariff

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions. We have always regarded the

Speaker: NA
Text: that home market as a sound one for our

Speaker: NA
Text: primary products, and the establishment

Text: and fostering of secondary industry as

Text: essential to our national well-being.

Speaker: NA
Text: Under the Scullin Government Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: did much to establish industries, and

Speaker: NA
Text: any reduction of tariff rates would be a

Text: backward step. The current Tariff Board

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Country Party pressure within the

Text: the broadcasting world. Labour believes

Speaker: NA
Text: Such men would be in the best position to

Speaker: NA
Text: review the tariff schedules. It would be

Speaker: NA
Text: fallacious to suggest that any lowering of

Speaker: NA
Text: the most-favoured-nation tariff would

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. On the contrary, such action

Speaker: NA
Text: would harm this country. In my 25 years

Speaker: NA
Text: of parliamentary life I cannot recall a

Speaker: NA
Text: previous occasion when the Tariff Board

Speaker: NA
Text: has been directed to inquire whether a

Speaker: NA
Text: wide range of duties could be substantially

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced-obviously , in order to benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign industries and embarrass local

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturers. The proposals are fantas-

Speaker: NA
Text: tic, especially as they are made at a time

Speaker: NA
Text: when, on the one hand, Australia is

Speaker: NA
Text: experiencing unemployment, and, on the

Speaker: NA
Text: other, secondary industry is expected to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide work for thousands of new Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians brought in under our immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme. Recently, certain tariff rates

Speaker: NA
Text: designed for the protection of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: industry have been reduced, though

Speaker: NA
Text: increases in the rates had been sought. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have in mind certain rubber goods, textiles

Speaker: NA
Text: and wheeled tractors. The Government also

Speaker: NA
Text: refused to give protection to woollen piece

Speaker: NA
Text: goods in the way recommended by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tariff Board. All this is indicative of a

Speaker: NA
Text: move to break down tariff protection and,

Speaker: NA
Text: in that way, substantially injure the

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Duthie -Wh o is inspiring it?

Speaker: Mr CLARK
Text: I t is inspired by the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Country Party. Recent events in

Speaker: NA
Text: connexion with Tariff Board recommenda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions leave no doubt in our minds that

Speaker: NA
Text: that party is prepared to sacrifice our

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary industries, and remain blind to

Speaker: NA
Text: Austhe advantages of the secure home market

Speaker: NA
Text: that they provide.

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall not labour the point further

Speaker: NA
Text: except to emphasize that our tariff system

Speaker: NA
Text: is in great danger as a result of the inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: which is now taking place. I hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: the board will not be stampeded by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government into reducing tariffs in the

Speaker: NA
Text: way I have described. That would sound

Speaker: NA
Text: the death knell for many great Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: industries, and would add to the ranks of

Speaker: NA
Text: the unemployed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Perth ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Chaney) referred to the inflow of capital

Speaker: NA
Text: from overseas. I believe that we should

Speaker: NA
Text: borrow in order to finance the business of

Speaker: NA
Text: this country, but that loans should be raised

Speaker: NA
Text: within Australia. It is fallacious to borrow

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£20,000,000 abroad in order to implement

Speaker: NA
Text: the Mount Isa to Townsville railway

Speaker: NA
Text: assist scheme when the whole of the labour,

Speaker: NA
Text: material and resources required for the

Speaker: NA
Text: project are obtainable in Australia. We

Speaker: NA
Text: can only be excused for borrowing over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas when we are short of dollars or sterl-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing with which to purchase essentia] re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quirements. We have substantial sterling

Speaker: NA
Text: balances and should be able to buy what

Speaker: NA
Text: we need from Britain. If we do that, the

Speaker: NA
Text: resultant production will swell our export

Speaker: NA
Text: income and help our trade balance. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: humiliating for Australia that her Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister ( Mr Menzies) should be a party

Speaker: NA
Text: to bowing and scraping before the Ameri-

Speaker: NA
Text: can people so that Australia can obtain a

Speaker: NA
Text: miserable Â£20,000,000. To-day, when

Speaker: NA
Text: hundreds of millions are spent annually

Speaker: NA
Text: by governments, Â£20,000,000 is a small

Speaker: NA
Text: sum indeed. It could be advanced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank under the guarantee

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Government. That is a simple

Speaker: NA
Text: banking process which we see put into

Speaker: NA
Text: effect frequently. If an individual wants

Speaker: NA
Text: an overdraft to help him carry out some

Speaker: NA
Text: business enterprise he obtains the help of

Speaker: NA
Text: a guarantor of more substantial means and

Speaker: NA
Text: is then entitled to write cheques up to a

Speaker: NA
Text: specified limit. If the banks-an d particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly the Commonwealth Bank-ca n do

Speaker: NA
Text: this for an individual, how much more can

Speaker: NA
Text: be done for a State, which is backed

Speaker: NA
Text: by all the security which the nation can

Speaker: NA
Text: provide? As long as the nation is sound

Speaker: NA
Text: the security will hold good, and if the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation fails all else is lost. I was rather

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased that the loan for the Mount Isa

Speaker: NA
Text: railway project was turned down. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: hopeful that better counsels will prevail,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the money will be advanced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank and that this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will guarantee its repayment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our essential industries should be

Speaker: NA
Text: developed with local capital. People should

Speaker: NA
Text: be encouraged to invest the substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: savings at present lying in the savings

Speaker: NA
Text: banks. The return to the individual would

Speaker: NA
Text: be much greater if the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: were to use its own resources to finance its

Speaker: NA
Text: works, and public savings were invested in

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary industry. We should be a more

Speaker: NA
Text: prosperous country and every one would

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another matter with which I should like

Speaker: NA
Text: to deal in the few minutes at my disposal

Speaker: NA
Text: is the intention of the Government to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease the charges for telephone calls and

Speaker: NA
Text: the postage of letters, periodicals and so

Speaker: NA
Text: on. This proposal must have been very

Speaker: NA
Text: little understood by Government suppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters, lt is rather significant that an Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Country Party member is respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible for that proposal. I have been re-

Speaker: NA
Text: liably informed that the officers of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Postal Department were entirely opposed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the suggested increases and that the new

Speaker: NA
Text: rates were adopted without their approval

Speaker: NA
Text: or recommendation. Who else could have

Speaker: NA
Text: done it but the Minister in charge of the

Speaker: NA
Text: department, in collaboration with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer? And to-day he is trying to get

Speaker: NA
Text: out from under by introducing a charge

Speaker: NA
Text: which is opposed by the omcers of his

Speaker: NA
Text: own department as being most unjust and

Speaker: NA
Text: inequitable! The Country Party must bear

Speaker: NA
Text: the full brunt of responsibility for these

Speaker: NA
Text: creased charges which will bear so heavily

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the country people, because they make

Speaker: NA
Text: great use of post and telephone facilities.

Speaker: NA
Text: The cost of newspapers, periodicals and

Speaker: NA
Text: so on must increase as the result of these

Speaker: NA
Text: higher rates and all this will add to the

Speaker: NA
Text: already high costs being borne by the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity. Costs have gone up in many ways,

Speaker: NA
Text: yet the Government proposes to double cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain postal charges.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister admits that he knows

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing about the matter. This is not the

Speaker: NA
Text: first occasion on which I have found that

Speaker: NA
Text: he does not know what is going on. He

Speaker: NA
Text: travels around the world so much that he

Speaker: NA
Text: gets out of touch with things here, and

Speaker: NA
Text: knows very little about what is going on

Speaker: NA
Text: at home. The price of wool has been down

Speaker: NA
Text: for over twelve months now, and the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment takes great credit to itself for the

Speaker: NA
Text: recent increase, but I point out that twelve

Speaker: NA
Text: months ago I asked the Prime Minister why

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rates had been increased for money

Speaker: NA
Text: for the purchase of wool. I pointed out

Speaker: NA
Text: that this increase would be responsible for

Speaker: NA
Text: reducing the price of wool. The Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister informed me that he had no

Speaker: NA
Text: knowledge of the matter other than what

Speaker: NA
Text: I had said to him. On the next sitting day

Speaker: NA
Text: I brought to the chamber the actual docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment furnished by the woolbuyers' banks

Speaker: NA
Text: in which it was stated that the interest

Speaker: NA
Text: rates would be increased as from, I think

Speaker: NA
Text: it was, 4th October. I asked the same

Speaker: NA
Text: question again, having the document in my

Speaker: NA
Text: hand at the time, and the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: still said he had no knowledge of the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: I state emphatically that the'restriction of

Speaker: NA
Text: credit then for the purchase of wool made

Speaker: NA
Text: it more difficult for people to buy. It re-

Speaker: NA
Text: stricted the number of purchasers because

Speaker: NA
Text: many of the small buyers were unable to

Speaker: NA
Text: operate owing to inability to obtain credit.

Speaker: NA
Text: This had the effect of reducing the price

Speaker: NA
Text: of wool. Those buyers were not asking

Speaker: NA
Text: for long term credit; they wanted only short

Speaker: NA
Text: term loans to cover the wool during transit

Speaker: NA
Text: and until the signing of the documents on

Speaker: NA
Text: fhe other side of the world. After all,

Speaker: NA
Text: that is only the usual practice on the London

Speaker: NA
Text: market. These operators earn millions of

Speaker: NA
Text: pounds in profit out of financing the sale

Speaker: NA
Text: of wool in Australia whereas if Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Bank provided the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance Austraha would receive millions

Speaker: NA
Text: of pounds in extra returns from the sales

Speaker: NA
Text: in- and would also enjoy the benefit of a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderable reduction in adverse overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: balances. Such charges as freight and in-

Speaker: NA
Text: surance cost Australia about Â£100,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: a year, and I suggest that with the estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lishment of our own shipping line, the

Speaker: NA
Text: carrying of our own insurance and the

Speaker: NA
Text: financing of the sale of our primary pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducts from Australian sources, similar to

Speaker: NA
Text: the way in which wheat sales are financed-

Speaker: NA
Text: by making advance payments to producers-

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia could effect a tremendous saving.

Speaker: NA
Text: My time has nearly expired, and I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that some of the points that I have made

Speaker: NA
Text: will be noted by the Government. The

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation proposals put forward in the Bud-

Speaker: NA
Text: get are very illuminating indeed, and, after

Speaker: NA
Text: perusing a short summary of the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: I find that increased social services and

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits to be granted to the people this

Speaker: NA
Text: year will cost a little more than Â£20,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: whereas increased taxes will return to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government an extra Â£78,500,000. This,

Speaker: NA
Text: together with other increased charges, will

Speaker: NA
Text: return an additional Â£97,300,000 to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government this year. It will be seen,

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore, that although the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: takes credit for granting considerable con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessions to the community by way of tax

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions, more will be taken from the

Speaker: NA
Text: people this year.

Speaker: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN
Text: ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Luchetti) -Order ! The honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber's time has expired.

Speaker: Mr FAIRHALL
Text: Paterson) [5.20] -A s

Speaker: NA
Text: we are considering the state of the national

Speaker: NA
Text: economy in the context of the Budget pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posals, it is not inappropriate to do as I

Speaker: NA
Text: propose-spen d a few minutes looking at

Speaker: NA
Text: the wool industry. It is a happy circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stance that the opening sales of the new

Speaker: NA
Text: season should have shown an increase of

Speaker: NA
Text: from 10 per cent, to 15 per cent, in wool

Speaker: NA
Text: returns, but I believe that would turn into

Speaker: NA
Text: an unhappy circumstance if we allowed

Speaker: NA
Text: ourselves to be bemused by the short-term

Speaker: NA
Text: advantages of this increased price because

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that in the long term the picture

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead of the wool industry is not nearly

Speaker: NA
Text: so bright.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am encouraged in that belief by the

Speaker: NA
Text: statement made by two informed contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: butors to the wool seminar organized by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian National University who

Speaker: NA
Text: said of the demand for wool that " only

Speaker: NA
Text: a narrow line separates prosperity from

Speaker: NA
Text: disaster." With that view I am inclined to

Speaker: NA
Text: agree. Indeed, I believe that the time has

Speaker: NA
Text: come for a searching inquiry into the wool

Speaker: NA
Text: industry and the likely influence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry's future on the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a general feeling of disquiet

Speaker: NA
Text: about the industry's prospects; but there is

Speaker: NA
Text: a general hope that whatever is wrong with

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry will somehow cure itself if

Speaker: NA
Text: we leave it alone. I do not believe that.

Speaker: NA
Text: If there is trouble ahead for the wool in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry, there is equally trouble ahead for

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole economy, and we ought to know

Speaker: NA
Text: it. Therefore, I suggest that nothing short

Speaker: NA
Text: of a royal commission would be adequate

Speaker: NA
Text: to examine thoroughly all aspects of the

Speaker: NA
Text: wool industry and to present to the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian people an integrated picture of the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry which, more than all others, sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports Australia's economy. The wool in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry and its effects on Austraha and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian people must be got into the

Speaker: NA
Text: headlines, and I believe that an inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: by a royal commission would do just that.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that such a commission should

Speaker: NA
Text: be empowered to look into all aspects of

Speaker: NA
Text: the wool industry-productio n and selling,

Speaker: NA
Text: the processing and marketing of the

Speaker: NA
Text: finished product, and the need for and

Speaker: NA
Text: the adequacy of all phases of wool research

Speaker: NA
Text: and wool use promotion. There should be

Speaker: NA
Text: a study of the dependence of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: economy on the wool industry, and, at the

Speaker: NA
Text: same time we ought to attempt to assess

Speaker: NA
Text: the proportions, present and future, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: mounting competition presented to wool

Speaker: NA
Text: by synthetic fibres.

Speaker: NA
Text: The inquiry should lead to a well

Speaker: NA
Text: reasoned programme of what ought to be

Speaker: NA
Text: done to safeguard Australia's economy by

Speaker: NA
Text: preserving the health of the wool industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: When, within one generation, the growth

Speaker: NA
Text: of synthetic fibres has become a menace to-

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's biggest export income earner,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is little room for believing that the

Speaker: NA
Text: wool industry is not threatened.

Speaker: NA
Text: In recent times, there has been a great

Speaker: NA
Text: deal of wool promotion and wool advertis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing under the slogan "There is no substi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tute for wool." Many people will stoutly

Speaker: NA
Text: declare that there is no possibility that

Speaker: NA
Text: synthetics will ever really oust wool, but I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that is a question which only the

Speaker: NA
Text: future, and the laboratories in which tens

Speaker: NA
Text: of millions of pounds are being spent on

Speaker: NA
Text: research into synthetics can possibly

Speaker: NA
Text: answer. In the meantime, the fact remains

Speaker: NA
Text: that in the United States of America which

Speaker: NA
Text: is generally taken as an indicator in matters-

Speaker: NA
Text: of this kind wool use has declined by 40

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent, in the last eighteen years, and

Speaker: NA
Text: in that period there has been an enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: growth in the use of synthetic fibres.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are some who believe that if we,

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia, keep telling ourselves that wool

Speaker: NA
Text: is best, somehow, the future of wool will

Speaker: NA
Text: be secured. But, again, we consume only

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 per cent, of our own production in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, and the task is therefore to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: vince the rest of the world that wool is best,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we must do this in the absence of any

Speaker: NA
Text: motive of natural loyalty.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nor is the threat to wool only from the

Speaker: NA
Text: synthetics. In a recently published volume

Speaker: NA
Text: called " People of Plenty-Economi c

Speaker: NA
Text: Abundance and the American Character ",

Speaker: NA
Text: the author, David M. Potter, said-

Speaker: NA
Text: Not only is the nourishment and housing

Speaker: NA
Text: also the clothing controlled by American

Speaker: NA
Text: dance. One of the most sweeping consequences

Speaker: NA
Text: of our abundance is that in contrast to other

Speaker: NA
Text: people who keep their bodies warm by wearing

Speaker: NA
Text: clothing, we keep our bodies warm primarily

Speaker: NA
Text: the far more expensive and wasteful method

Speaker: NA
Text: heating the buildings in which they are sheltered.

Speaker: NA
Text: The oil furnace has not only displaced the open

Speaker: NA
Text: fire-place. It has also displaced the woollen

Speaker: NA
Text: undergarment and the vest.

Speaker: NA
Text: In commercial language, Potter said that

Speaker: NA
Text: wool has now to compete, not only with

Speaker: NA
Text: dacron, orlon and nylon and the rest of the

Speaker: NA
Text: synthetics, but also with more implacable

Speaker: NA
Text: antagonists-centra l heating and air

Speaker: NA
Text: ditioning. It seems likely that, as Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: homes and other buildings yield to the march

Speaker: NA
Text: of central heating and air conditioning,

Speaker: NA
Text: pattern of dressing will follow that of

Speaker: NA
Text: America. It is not without significance

Speaker: NA
Text: in all five major construction projects

Speaker: NA
Text: before the Commonwealth's own Public a

Speaker: NA
Text: Works Committee, air-conditioning is

Speaker: NA
Text: posed. The pattern is beginning to estabyears.

Speaker: NA
Text: lish itself here in Australia. Certainly,

Speaker: NA
Text: long woollen undergarment is

Speaker: NA
Text: out if it has not already gone. The waist-

Speaker: NA
Text: coat is dying away. The heavy all-woollen

Speaker: NA
Text: suit that used to be worn all the year round

Speaker: NA
Text: is being replaced, for a large part of

Text: year at least, by lighter suits made from

Speaker: NA
Text: wool and synthetics. The light top-coat

Speaker: NA
Text: the synthetic rain-coat have dealt a mortal

Speaker: NA
Text: blow at the all-wool great-coat and

Speaker: NA
Text: electric blanket is no longer a novelty.

Speaker: NA
Text: these things are biting into the wool market.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the meantime, the wool-grower is

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the pinch. It is not as if increased wool

Speaker: NA
Text: production would help wool sales. An inlb.

Speaker: NA
Text: crease may only push down the price of wool

Speaker: NA
Text: to a level at which the producer who is tied

Speaker: NA
Text: to fixed wages, fixed prices' of farm

Speaker: NA
Text: machinery and services, and fixed interest

Speaker: NA
Text: on overdraft, may not be able to stay in the

Speaker: NA
Text: wool business. Fluctuations in the price of

Speaker: NA
Text: wool, as we have seen in recent years

Speaker: NA
Text: present great difficulties to the textile in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustries, a difficulty which manufacturers

Text: of synthetics have been quick to exploit by

Text: fixing the price of their product for long

Speaker: NA
Text: periods even though, under prevailing con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions in the market, they could have re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived increased prices. Therefore, the

Speaker: NA
Text: fluctuation of wool prices may lead to

Speaker: NA
Text: further depression in the price of wool.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the last few years, I think it is true

Speaker: NA
Text: to say, particularly jn regard to marginal

Speaker: NA
Text: but producers, that much of the Australian wool

Speaker: NA
Text: abunclip has not returned the cost of produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. The grower, therefore, has had the

Speaker: NA
Text: choice of receiving a salary for his work

Speaker: NA
Text: by or a return on his investment, but not both.

Speaker: NA
Text: of Since he could invest his money with com-

Speaker: NA
Text: parative safety at from 5 per cent, to 8

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent., his decision to stay in the wool

Speaker: NA
Text: business is a gesture of unbridled optimism

Speaker: NA
Text: or indicates his inability to free himself

Speaker: NA
Text: from the land under existing conditions.

Speaker: NA
Text: A few years ago it might have been fanci-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful to suggest that the characteristics of

Speaker: NA
Text: conwool could be duplicated synthetically.

Speaker: NA
Text: But now, with the accumulated knowledge

Speaker: NA
Text: and experience, and the advances in tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: our nology and techniques, we cannot be so

Speaker: NA
Text: sure. Professor M. Chaiken, Professor of

Speaker: NA
Text: that Textile Technology at the University of

Speaker: NA
Text: now New South Wales, has stated that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: danger that man-made fibres will supplant

Speaker: NA
Text: prowool completely in from ten to twenty

Speaker: NA
Text: Certainly, this danger will increase

Speaker: NA
Text: the unless something quite adventurous is done

Speaker: NA
Text: on its way to keep wool in demand.

Speaker: NA
Text: Economic developments occur earliest in

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States of America. There, the

Text: the consumption of fibres since 1940 shows a

Text: disturbing trend. Since that year rayon con-

Speaker: NA
Text: and sumption has more than doubled, increas-

Text: the lb. a year. Nylon consumption has in-
