Speaker: NA
Text: feelreasonably well. Even the consumption of

Text: fibres.

Speaker: NA
Text: of America dropped from 434,000,000 lb.

Speaker: NA
Text: those years, the population climbed from

Speaker: NA
Text: that people in the United States have not,

Speaker: NA
Text: by any means, stopped buying textiles; but

Speaker: NA
Text: they are buying less wool. Between 1954

Text: and 1957, world production of synthetic

Text: fibres rose by about 30 per cent, per

Text: annum. The influences that work in

Text: America are not less active elsewhere in

Text: major markets, nor even here in Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: It is true that no single textile-n o man-

Speaker: NA
Text: made fibre-has all the qualities of wool.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it is likewise true that wool is

Speaker: NA
Text: markedly deficient of'some of the" wanted

Speaker: NA
Text: qualities in textiles. The Commonwealth

Text: Scientific and Industrial Research Organ-

Text: ization recently published a research

Text: bulletin which included an article under

Text: the title "The Challenge to Wool". In

Speaker: NA
Text: this article the qualities of wool were com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared with those of man-made fibres. It

Speaker: NA
Text: showed that in the wanted qualities of

Speaker: NA
Text: dyeing, heat resistance, moisture absorp-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and draping, wool left the synthetics

Speaker: NA
Text: far behind. But it also showed that in the

Speaker: NA
Text: equally wanted qualities of strength and

Speaker: NA
Text: resistance to insects, wrinkling and shrink-

Speaker: NA
Text: age, the synthetics held a handsome

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is worth mentioning, in passing, that

Speaker: NA
Text: this gives point to the value of blends of

Speaker: NA
Text: wool and synthetics, because the buyer of

Speaker: NA
Text: textiles is concerned only with the finished

Speaker: NA
Text: fabric of superior quality and is little

Speaker: NA
Text: interested in the composition except in so

Speaker: NA
Text: far as it indicates the qualities that he is

Speaker: NA
Text: looking for. This statement also puts a

Speaker: NA
Text: heavy question mark against the views of

Speaker: NA
Text: those, including some members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Wool Bureau, who believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's wool publicity should not men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion synthetics or blends. The fear that,

Speaker: NA
Text: in selling blends, we would be promoting

Speaker: NA
Text: the sale of synthetics, is of doubtful

Speaker: NA
Text: validity at this time. In any case, it is a

Speaker: NA
Text: question that ought to be settled by com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petent market research.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is more than a little evidence that

Speaker: NA
Text: major wool processors, particularly in the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States of America, are heavily

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged in the production of blends. Under

Speaker: NA
Text: these conditions, wool promotion which

Speaker: NA
Text: ignores blends would be unrealistic. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that, in the short term, man-made

Speaker: NA
Text: fibres and wool are complementary. But

Speaker: NA
Text: it is true that, in the Jong run, synthetic

Speaker: NA
Text: research will work towards the complete

Speaker: NA
Text: replacement of wool. It is simple common

Speaker: NA
Text: sense that wool research must aim at pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducing in wooi all the advantages which

Speaker: NA
Text: are now possessed exclusively by the

Speaker: NA
Text: synthetics. It may very easily be that the

Speaker: NA
Text: way to sell more wool, until research is

Speaker: NA
Text: further advanced-an d I have chosen

Speaker: NA
Text: those words carefully-i s to promote the

Speaker: NA
Text: marriage of wool and synthetics in the

Speaker: NA
Text: world's best textiles.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not put forward that view as a

Speaker: NA
Text: conclusion. I merely say that "we should

Speaker: NA
Text: not dismiss the possibility but should seek

Speaker: NA
Text: to establish its truth or falsity. People

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout history have been saying that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no substitute for a particular

Speaker: NA
Text: product. But substitutes have come and

Speaker: NA
Text: have replaced the product entirely or have

Speaker: NA
Text: eaten heavily into its market. What can

Speaker: NA
Text: happen is plainly written in the story of

Speaker: NA
Text: indigo for the production of which Indian

Speaker: NA
Text: farmers once cultivated 1,500,000 acres-

Speaker: NA
Text: until European chemists learnt to produce

Speaker: NA
Text: analine dyes. Indian farmers then went out

Speaker: NA
Text: of the indigo business entirely and were

Speaker: NA
Text: obliged to find new products and new

Speaker: NA
Text: markets in a process which could only have

Speaker: NA
Text: been long and costly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Closer to us in time is the fate of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Siberian hog which, as you know, pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided most of the bristles for the world's

Speaker: NA
Text: brushes. Although natural bristles are said

Speaker: NA
Text: to have some great advantages, the fact

Speaker: NA
Text: is that they went down before the synthetic,

Speaker: NA
Text: nylon. Silk met and succumbed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: same competition. It is true that silk is

Speaker: NA
Text: still manufactured, but I doubt whether

Speaker: NA
Text: it would be were it not for the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: workers in silk are among the most under-

Speaker: NA
Text: paid workers in the world. Nevertheless,

Speaker: NA
Text: in a few short years, nylon has cut the

Speaker: NA
Text: silk market in half. It has been reduced

Speaker: NA
Text: the last fifteen or eighteen years.

Speaker: NA
Text: With these bits of history in mind, we

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to turn to an examination of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's dependence on the wool industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unhappily, there are many who fail to

Speaker: NA
Text: understand the extent to which wool under-

Speaker: NA
Text: pins our economy, but if the wool industry

Speaker: NA
Text: goes into a decline, the Australian economy,

Speaker: NA
Text: our wages, our salaries, and our standards

Speaker: NA
Text: of living will, I believe, smartly follow it

Speaker: NA
Text: into the same sort of decline. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended exercise that we should think

Speaker: NA
Text: for a moment of the shape of an Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian economy without a wool industry of

Speaker: NA
Text: any great consequence. As the position is

Speaker: NA
Text: now, and has been for years past, Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia has been warding off a very difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: balance-of-payments problem only by the

Speaker: NA
Text: imposition of the harshest import restric-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions. The apparent permanence of import

Speaker: NA
Text: restrictions is a by-product of our failure

Speaker: NA
Text: to match our appetite for imports with an

Speaker: NA
Text: ability to find abroad markets for our pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducts. But, happily or unhappily, depend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing on how one looks at it, this position

Speaker: NA
Text: has been masked or obscured in recent

Speaker: NA
Text: years by the inflow of capital, which

Speaker: NA
Text: reached the total of Â£712,000,000 between

Speaker: NA
Text: 1947 and 1956. But capital investment

Speaker: NA
Text: could dry up overnight and, indeed, it

Speaker: NA
Text: would most certainly do so if anything

Speaker: NA
Text: happened in the wool industry to force a

Speaker: NA
Text: halt or even a recession in the general

Speaker: NA
Text: tempo of the Australian economy. Then

Speaker: NA
Text: we would be left with the problem, often

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to, of meeting dividend service

Speaker: NA
Text: on foreign investment from vastly reduced

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas earnings.

Speaker: NA
Text: Industrially, we are a high-cost country,

Speaker: NA
Text: yet we are in competition with more

Speaker: NA
Text: experienced, more populous, lower-cost pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers in the United States of America,

Speaker: NA
Text: Europe, and, increasingly, in Asia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: prospect of making up in secondary pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducts what we lose in wool is a rather

Speaker: NA
Text: bleak one, unless we are to accept a heavy

Speaker: NA
Text: fall in wages or salaries. Apart from wool,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the field of primary produce our major

Speaker: NA
Text: export items, wheat, dairy products, barley,

Speaker: NA
Text: and so on, are meeting world surplus pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction, much of which is subsidized by

Speaker: NA
Text: governments, as in the case of American

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat. The one product in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: which we enjoy a great natural advantage,

Speaker: NA
Text: and upon which we depend, is fine wool.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is clear that if our standards of living

Speaker: NA
Text: are to be maintained in the future, we shall

Speaker: NA
Text: depend on wool in two ways. First, it

Speaker: NA
Text: must earn our basic overseas income.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, it must service overseas invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in this country, which supports any

Speaker: NA
Text: hope we have of competing in the field

Speaker: NA
Text: of secondary industrial production.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first great task is to see that wool

Speaker: NA
Text: can foot the bill. We must know whether

Speaker: NA
Text: or not it is likely that wool can be replaced

Speaker: NA
Text: in the foreseeable future and, if so, what

Speaker: NA
Text: we are going to do about it. This much is:

Speaker: NA
Text: certain: Australia will fall back to being a:

Speaker: NA
Text: very second-class nation indeed if wool goes

Speaker: NA
Text: the way of those scores of products which

Speaker: NA
Text: have been replaced by more useful or

Speaker: NA
Text: cheaper items. It ought to be kept in mind

Speaker: NA
Text: that wool provides in foreign exchange

Speaker: NA
Text: three times as much as do all of our manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: factured products combined. A permanent

Speaker: NA
Text: drop in wool exports would offer poor pros-

Speaker: NA
Text: pects for continued industrialization. It

Speaker: NA
Text: would cripple Australia's burgeoning indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries as much as it would cripple rural

Speaker: NA
Text: production.

Speaker: NA
Text: I repeat that it is hard to imagine Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia without a wool industry of some

Speaker: NA
Text: magnitude. We prefer not to think about

Speaker: NA
Text: it, but for the sake of the future of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country's economy we ought to think about

Speaker: NA
Text: it in the most serious and close-up terms.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we are to appreciate the problem, we

Speaker: NA
Text: ought first to get some idea of how big

Speaker: NA
Text: wool is in national or international stature.

Speaker: NA
Text: If our wool production were in the hands

Speaker: NA
Text: of one company, it would rate only 57th

Speaker: NA
Text: place in the list of major productive enter-

Speaker: NA
Text: prises in the United States, as published

Speaker: NA
Text: by " Fortune " magazine. It is interesting

Speaker: NA
Text: to note that it would be considerably below

Speaker: NA
Text: Kodak in size and about one-third of the

Speaker: NA
Text: size, in terms of turnover, of that enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: competitor with wool, the Du Pont industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is the producer of nylon, dacron,

Speaker: NA
Text: orlon and a large number of other syn-

Speaker: NA
Text: thetics, and I am sure it will be the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducer of more in the future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Research into wool can be a long and

Speaker: NA
Text: costly business, even involving the sheep-

Speaker: NA
Text: breeding programme, but the chemist in

Speaker: NA
Text: the synthetics laboratory is under no such

Speaker: NA
Text: handicap. He can try out new formula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions and new techniques with small-batch

Speaker: NA
Text: production, always with the likelihood of

Speaker: NA
Text: coming up with something new. With

Speaker: NA
Text: greater resources at his command

Speaker: NA
Text: he might allot 50 scientists to a

Speaker: NA
Text: particular project and waste some of

Speaker: NA
Text: money, but, as I say, one never

Speaker: NA
Text: what will be uncovered. This fact alone

Speaker: NA
Text: gives the synthetic fibre industry an

Speaker: NA
Text: mous advantage in its publicity, because

Speaker: NA
Text: always has at hand some new, exciting

Speaker: NA
Text: synthetic which it can publicize. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: left with wool, and it is a more difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: job to prove that wool is improving in

Speaker: NA
Text: quality. The chemist, of course, is beating

Speaker: NA
Text: us hands down in the amount of money

Speaker: NA
Text: he has to spend on the development and

Speaker: NA
Text: promotion of his industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: We in Australia will have this year

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£2,000,000 to spend on the wool industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: By comparison, it is interesting to note

Speaker: NA
Text: the Celanese Corporation of America will

Speaker: NA
Text: spend Â£2,500,000 on an industry which

Speaker: NA
Text: has a turnover less than one-third that

Speaker: NA
Text: wool. The Du Pont organization, our to

Speaker: NA
Text: most formidable competitor, with an

Speaker: NA
Text: advertising budget of about Â£20,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: year, a research budget of. the same

Speaker: NA
Text: portions, and an advertising public

Speaker: NA
Text: tions staff that runs into hundreds, will

Speaker: NA
Text: be sparing the expense account. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Pont organization has pilot plants in which

Speaker: NA
Text: every known spinning and weaving device

Speaker: NA
Text: is installed. It has textile experts,

Speaker: NA
Text: work with any manufacturer who seeks Producers Federation.

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance. It employs designers to help

Speaker: NA
Text: produce more suitable textiles. Its adverdisagreement

Speaker: NA
Text: tising agents are constantly engaged Jn

Speaker: NA
Text: market research, testing the acceptability

Speaker: NA
Text: of its products. I refer honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: to a recent bulletin of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Scientific and Industrial Research Organizapromotion,

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, containing photographs of a laborations,

Speaker: NA
Text: tory of this kind. Du Pont's task is

Speaker: NA
Text: get a bigger percentage of its products

Speaker: NA
Text: wool. Ours is the task of countering its

Speaker: NA
Text: efforts, which will not be done by putting

Speaker: NA
Text: our heads in the sand. The market

Speaker: NA
Text: for us will be pretty cold and unfriendly

Speaker: NA
Text: and there is no room and less time for us

Speaker: NA
Text: to feel sorry for ourselves as we con-

Speaker: NA
Text: template bigger, more powerful, better

Speaker: NA
Text: financed and very formidable competition.

Speaker: NA
Text: The thing for us to do is assess the facts,

Speaker: NA
Text: to count the cost of failure and then

Speaker: NA
Text: decide what we must do to be saved. The

Speaker: NA
Text: provision we are at present making, and

Speaker: NA
Text: reliance on prejudiced opinion rather

Speaker: NA
Text: on scientific knowledge, will not help

Speaker: NA
Text: to get through, and Australia's comindustry

Speaker: NA
Text: petitors in the world's textile market will

Speaker: NA
Text: his not sit by and wait for us to make up our

Speaker: NA
Text: knows minds. There is no doubt in my mind

Speaker: NA
Text: that the amount of money available for

Speaker: NA
Text: enorresearch and promotion will have to be

Speaker: NA
Text: it vastly increased. It may be that the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers' own contribution will need to be

Speaker: NA
Text: expanded, but I believe the cost structure

Speaker: NA
Text: of the industry will still put a limit to that.

Speaker: NA
Text: its Therefore, I think there will be a call on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government to expand its support of

Speaker: NA
Text: what is in fact Australia's basic industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: After all, we have subsidized butter. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have not hesitated to support, by advertis-

Speaker: NA
Text: about ing and promotion, the sale abroad of

Speaker: NA
Text: other primary products. We are to-day

Speaker: NA
Text: that offering great concessions in the field of

Speaker: NA
Text: oil search. These are very wise and proper

Speaker: NA
Text: things to do, but if there is any validity

Speaker: NA
Text: of in the points I have put forward, refusal

Speaker: NA
Text: further aid the wool industry will savour

Speaker: NA
Text: very much of giving away the substance

Speaker: NA
Text: a while we grasp at the shadow. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: pror that it wpuld be timely and proper to

Speaker: NA
Text: relareconstruct the Australian Wool Bureau.

Speaker: NA
Text: not It consists, as honorable members know,

Speaker: NA
Text: Du of seven members. One is a Government

Speaker: NA
Text: nominee, and the other six are split evenly

Speaker: NA
Text: between the Australian Woolgrowers

Speaker: NA
Text: who Council and the Australian Wool and Meat

Speaker: NA
Text: It is noted,

Speaker: NA
Text: unhappily, that there is some evidence of

Speaker: NA
Text: between these two sections of

Speaker: NA
Text: the producing industry. I question whether

Speaker: NA
Text: the safeguarding of Australia's greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, whose problem is less one of

Speaker: NA
Text: production than of market research, sales

Speaker: NA
Text: advertising and public rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: can be left in the hands of graziers,

Speaker: NA
Text: to who may be the best men in the world at

Speaker: NA
Text: into their own jobs but who do not show any

Speaker: NA
Text: great capacity in the field of promotion or

Speaker: NA
Text: in the ability to control those who are

Speaker: NA
Text: place responsible for promotion.

Speaker: NA
Text: There appears to be a deep-rooted objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to expanding the bureau to include

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing and marketing experts, on

Speaker: NA
Text: the ground, as I understand it, that it wou d

Speaker: NA
Text: open the way to outside interference with

Speaker: NA
Text: the wool-growers in the handling of their

Speaker: NA
Text: to own production which is understood to be

Speaker: NA
Text: the property of the wool producers them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves. Of course, we must have some re-

Speaker: NA
Text: than gard to that point of view. But, as I

Speaker: NA
Text: us believe an inquiry would show, the wool

Speaker: NA
Text: is so vital a part of Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: economy, future security and prosperity that

Speaker: NA
Text: the public interest in the handling of the

Speaker: NA
Text: wool clip may be greater than that of the

Speaker: NA
Text: producer. The grower has nothing to lose

Speaker: NA
Text: and everything to gain by an expanded

Speaker: NA
Text: effort to preserve the industry which under-

Speaker: NA
Text: lies his personal fortunes. In fact, if the

Speaker: NA
Text: job is done properly-a s it must be-th e

Speaker: NA
Text: best interests of the wool-grower and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian people will be shown to be

Speaker: NA
Text: synonymous. That fact is already widely

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciated by wool producers, many of

Speaker: NA
Text: whom are disturbed at the apparent lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: direction of present efforts in wool

Speaker: NA
Text: promotion.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am well aware of the difficulty of

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfying vocal opinion in the wool in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry. Again, I beheve the findings of a

Speaker: NA
Text: royal commission would do much to bring

Speaker: NA
Text: unified and positive thinking to the industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: to say nothing of support for a really worth-

Speaker: NA
Text: while plan of research and sales promotion.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hit or miss methods of research and sales

Speaker: NA
Text: promotion will not-save the wool industry,

Speaker: NA
Text: and surely any bureau dealing with such an

Speaker: NA
Text: industry ought to include in its member-

Speaker: NA
Text: ship men experienced in textile research

Speaker: NA
Text: and production as well as advertising and

Speaker: NA
Text: marketing. To bring home to the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian people the extent of their dependence

Speaker: NA
Text: on wool and to assemble the facts about

Speaker: NA
Text: every phase of so important an industry, 1

Speaker: NA
Text: believe there should be a searching inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: by a royal commission. If it is true that

Speaker: NA
Text: the tide has set permanently against wool,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is necessary to recognize the fact at the

Speaker: NA
Text: earliest possible moment. We ought to

Speaker: NA
Text: know what we can do to replace declining

Speaker: NA
Text: wool income if such a position is inescap-

Speaker: NA
Text: able. Certainly, progress will go on at an

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing rate in the synthetic fibre field.

Speaker: NA
Text: We must know as clearly as we can know

Speaker: NA
Text: what the end effect of this progress on our

Speaker: NA
Text: own economic affairs will be.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the face of the wonderful achievements

Speaker: NA
Text: of t.:c chemical mdustry, I cannot believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that ever-increasing research will not pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce enormous progress towards the syn-

Speaker: NA
Text: thetic industry's goal of ousting wool.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nothing but good could come from concen-

Speaker: NA
Text: trating on the wool industry the undoubted

Speaker: NA
Text: talents and experience we have in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country in wool growing and selling, wool

Speaker: NA
Text: and textile research, market research,

Speaker: NA
Text: advertising and sales promotion for the

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit of the industry and the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. Hence the need for a royal

Speaker: NA
Text: commission-an d soon. We may elect to

Speaker: NA
Text: wait and see, but Du Pont certainly will not

Speaker: NA
Text: do so, nor will Imperial Chemical

Speaker: NA
Text: Industries, Union Carbide, Celanese,

Speaker: NA
Text: Courtaulds, Montecatini and the rest of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people who are engaged in the world's

Speaker: NA
Text: growing synthetic fibre industry. The

Speaker: NA
Text: longer we wait, the easier it wili be for

Speaker: NA
Text: them.

Speaker: Mr CLAY
Text: St. George) [5.48] -I t was

Speaker: NA
Text: right and proper that the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Paterson ( Mr Fairhall) should de-

Speaker: NA
Text: vote so much of his time-i n fact, all his

Speaker: NA
Text: time-t o a discussion and examination of

Speaker: NA
Text: the subject of wool. There is no more

Speaker: NA
Text: important factor in the economy of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. I myself speak with the benefit of

Speaker: NA
Text: 30 years practical experience in the textile

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, and I think there would be few

Speaker: NA
Text: who would realize as fully as I do the

Speaker: NA
Text: importance of this industry to Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and also, so far as I am concerned, to the

Speaker: NA
Text: field of employment, because" this industrj'

Speaker: NA
Text: is one of the few in which profitable em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment can be found for large numbers

Speaker: NA
Text: of women. In that regard, it is almost

Speaker: NA
Text: unique.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Paterson

Speaker: NA
Text: spoke of the substitutes which are being

Speaker: NA
Text: developed and which threaten the

Speaker: NA
Text: sovereignty of wool in the textile field. He

Speaker: NA
Text: spoke very well and very learnedly on that

Speaker: NA
Text: subject. I reflect upon what happened to

Speaker: NA
Text: another textile fibre in the natural field. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have heard far too many people say that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no substitute for wool. I remem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber tbe time when people were saying with

Speaker: NA
Text: similar confidence that there was no sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stitute for silk. I well remember the enor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mous export market which Japan possessed

Speaker: NA
Text: in that natural fibre that we call silk. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was largely used in clothing and hosiery,

Speaker: NA
Text: and Japan placed great reliance on silk to

Speaker: NA
Text: obtain overseas currency. Almost within

Speaker: NA
Text: a few months, the silk industry of Japan

Speaker: NA
Text: collapsed and disappeared. I would not

Speaker: NA
Text: like to see the same fate overtake the

Speaker: NA
Text: natural fibre upon which we place, I think,

Speaker: NA
Text: far too much reliance.

Speaker: NA
Text: With regard to the commodity we call

Speaker: NA
Text: wool, I think it would be of great value if

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Government were to give

Speaker: NA
Text: even greater encouragement to the scientists

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Commonwealth Scientific and Indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial Research Organization who could then

Speaker: NA
Text: devote their remarkable talents towards im-

Speaker: NA
Text: proving this fibre. I remain unconvinced

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is difficult to improve this natural

Speaker: NA
Text: fibre. We might even reach the stage where

Speaker: NA
Text: wool, taken from the sheep's back, will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be spun, scoured and treated for the

Speaker: NA
Text: mills but taken to a plant where it will be

Speaker: NA
Text: subjected to solvents and extruded. But it

Speaker: NA
Text: remains for the scientists of the C.S.I.R.O.

Speaker: NA
Text: with the requisite staff and money, to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: duct their investigations and examine what

Speaker: NA
Text: can be done with our most important

Speaker: NA
Text: primary product.

Speaker: NA
Text: Everybody is fully aware of the enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: financial value of wool to Australia. With-

Speaker: NA
Text: out it, the standard of living in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: would be much lower than it is. If its

Speaker: NA
Text: value were to drop catastrophically, the

Speaker: NA
Text: effect would be widespread. At the wool

Speaker: NA
Text: sales immediately preceding the recent

Speaker: NA
Text: sales, prices were much lower, and many

Speaker: NA
Text: wool-growers, especially the smaller men,

Speaker: NA
Text: were in grave doubts about their financial

Speaker: NA
Text: stability. So it does not take a great drop

Speaker: NA
Text: in the price of wool to cause alarm to the

Speaker: NA
Text: wool-growers. When some possible calamity

Speaker: NA
Text: appears on the horizon, I always wonder

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Government is doing about it.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has been said by the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Paterson that a relatively small sum

Speaker: NA
Text: of money is being spent on wool research.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe-an d I am sure the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member will agree with me-tha t in view

Speaker: NA
Text: of the enormous value of wool to Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: if the expenditure on research into wool

Speaker: NA
Text: were trebled or quadrupled, it would still

Speaker: NA
Text: not be too much. I have great confidence

Speaker: NA
Text: in the scientists of the C.S.I.R.O. When

Speaker: NA
Text: they brought a remedy to the wool indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try they produced that diabolical disease,

Speaker: NA
Text: myxomatosis, but horrible as it was, they

Speaker: NA
Text: probably saved the Australian economy at

Speaker: NA
Text: the time. The price of wool was then

Speaker: NA
Text: dropping and had the rabbit population

Speaker: NA
Text: remained at the level it had reached, there

Speaker: NA
Text: is no doubt there would have been a great

Speaker: NA
Text: drop in the production of wool as well as

Speaker: NA
Text: in its value.

Speaker: NA
Text: The scientists of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Scientific and Industrial Research Organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: zation came up with a remedy. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: they could come up with some remedy

Speaker: NA
Text: whereby we can make this natural fibre

Speaker: NA
Text: superior to the synthetics which threaten

Speaker: NA
Text: it. Let me say this: It used to be a part

Speaker: NA
Text: of my business to go into the mills of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country and see the work being done. I

Speaker: NA
Text: refer particularly to the knitting of wool.

Speaker: NA
Text: I did not know-an d I still do not know-

Speaker: NA
Text: one manufacturer who would use wool if

Speaker: NA
Text: he could get the people to accept a sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stitute- I am referring particularly to

Speaker: NA
Text: orlon-no t because the manufacturer is un-

Speaker: NA
Text: patriotic or disloyal to Australia, but be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause wool has been unstable in its price

Speaker: NA
Text: level.

Speaker: NA
Text: The manufacturers of this country have

Speaker: NA
Text: been grievously concerned about ordering

Speaker: NA
Text: commodities for which they have to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: three months in advance. If a change

Speaker: NA
Text: takes place in the price during the three

Speaker: NA
Text: months after they have made payment they

Speaker: NA
Text: can be put to great financial trouble. I

Speaker: NA
Text: myself have known manufacturers to be-

Speaker: NA
Text: come bankrupt because there was a change

Speaker: NA
Text: in the price of wool to their disadvantage.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we do not find some way to stabilize it

Speaker: NA
Text: -th e price of wool-manufacturer s will

Speaker: NA
Text: be less and less inclined to use our own

Speaker: NA
Text: most valuable product-wool . So I

Speaker: NA
Text: come back to this question: What is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government doing about it?

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: Mr CLAY
Text: Tha t is the answer. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is doing nothing about it. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not say that it sits idly by, but it sits

Speaker: NA
Text: by, adopting a Micawber-like attitude,

Speaker: NA
Text: hoping that something will turn up. I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that something does turn up, because I

Speaker: NA
Text: have a strong feeling that the time is not

Speaker: NA
Text: far distant when we will need something to

Speaker: NA
Text: turn up. I speak those words with great

Speaker: NA
Text: feeling, because I think that the textile in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry of Australia is probably the most

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient industry in this country. I can

Speaker: NA
Text: point to one mill in Newcastle-certainly ,

Speaker: NA
Text: it processes cotton, but others process wool

Speaker: NA
Text: -whic h achieves a higher efficiency rating

Speaker: NA
Text: than any other mill in the world. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: thinking in terms of the United States of

Speaker: NA
Text: America and Japan. As honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers know, the textile industry of Japan is

Speaker: NA
Text: greatly assisted by the United States. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would hate to see an industry such as this,

Speaker: NA
Text: which provides such a large amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: employment for the families of Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: threatened in any way by a catastrophe

Speaker: NA
Text: such as a fall in the price level of wool.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Temporary Chairman, I have indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated to you that I think the remarks of

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Paterson very

Speaker: NA
Text: timely. It is my earnest hope that the

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Government- I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber did pay very close attention to

Speaker: NA
Text: what he had to say-wil l heed what he said.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unless great notice is taken of the warning

Speaker: NA
Text: that has been issued by the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Paterson, dire calamity can fall

Speaker: NA
Text: upon this country. I believe it is true to

Speaker: NA
Text: say that if there is a fall of only ld. per

Speaker: NA
Text: in the price of wool, between Â£4,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: and Â£5,000,000 is lost in overseas earnings

Speaker: NA
Text: to the people of Australia, or to the economy

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia. In consequence, I think that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have to do all that lies in our power-

Speaker: NA
Text: of course, we on this side of the chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: can do very little except to exhort-t o in-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce the Government to spend the neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary money upon the encouragement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: scientists employed by the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Scientific and Industrial Research Organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: zation and, if necessary, bring scientists

Speaker: NA
Text: from other parts of the world to set their

Speaker: NA
Text: brains to work in order that the answer

Speaker: NA
Text: might be found to what looks like being

Speaker: NA
Text: a most difficult problem in the not very

Speaker: NA
Text: distant future.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has been revealed by the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Paterson that several millions

Speaker: NA
Text: of pounds are being spent by the Celanesc

Speaker: NA
Text: Corporation alone. It deals in an artificial

Speaker: NA
Text: fibre in the rayon field. When rayon was

Speaker: NA
Text: first produced, there was great competition

Speaker: NA
Text: between rayon and cotton, and the rayon

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturers got the better of the battle

Speaker: NA
Text: until such time as the cotton manufacturers

Speaker: NA
Text: of the world set to and, by research, im-

Speaker: NA
Text: proved the fibre we call cotton, and

Speaker: NA
Text: gradually gained supremacy. In this com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petition the advantage frequency passes

Speaker: NA
Text: from one fibre to another, and it is our job

Speaker: NA
Text: to see that the natural fibre that is so valu-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to us retains its supremacy over fibres

Speaker: NA
Text: such as nylon, orlon and dacron.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

Speaker: Mr CLAY
Text: Australi a places too much

Speaker: NA
Text: reliance on wool, especially for the earning

Speaker: NA
Text: of overseas funds. We depend upon it

Speaker: NA
Text: more than is good for our own security in

Speaker: NA
Text: these times when the synthetics industry is

Speaker: NA
Text: developing as a field of danger for our wool

Speaker: NA
Text: industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is with some regret that I leave the

Speaker: NA
Text: subject of wool and return to the rather

Speaker: NA
Text: dreary subject of the Budget. Many words

Speaker: NA
Text: and many phrases have been applied in

Speaker: NA
Text: description of this Budget. Supporters of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government have prated about the

Speaker: NA
Text: stability and expansion which are to flow

Speaker: NA
Text: from this year'sfinancialplanning. The use

Speaker: NA
Text: of the words " stability " and " expansion "

Speaker: NA
Text: in descriptions of the Budget intrigue me.

Speaker: NA
Text: " Stability " is defined in Nuttall's Diction-

Speaker: NA
Text: lb. ary as " the dynamic condition by which a

Speaker: NA
Text: body retains its condition, shape or

Speaker: NA
Text: motion ". Expansion is, of course, the act

Speaker: NA
Text: of expanding, or the state of being ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: panded. So we have this contradiction-

Speaker: NA
Text: a condition in which the economy will not

Speaker: NA
Text: alter its position, shape or motion, although

Speaker: NA
Text: at the same time it will expand!

Speaker: NA
Text: The people will surely be dazed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer's profound pronouncements.

Speaker: NA
Text: They will be dazed even further by the

Speaker: NA
Text: gifts contained in the Budget, which remind

Speaker: NA
Text: me strongly of the gift of the Trojan horse

Speaker: NA
Text: which led to the fall of Troy. Those who

Speaker: NA
Text: know the ancient Greek story will recollect

Speaker: NA
Text: that for a long time the besieging Greeks

Speaker: NA
Text: had failed to breach the walls of Troy. So

Speaker: NA
Text: they left a gift for the Trojans outside the

Speaker: NA
Text: walls, and the Trojans foolishly accepted it

Speaker: NA
Text: and brought it within their gates. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: a wooden horse filled with armed men, and

Speaker: NA
Text: so Troy fell. Apparently justice is done

Speaker: NA
Text: in this Budget in a Trojan horse fashion,

Speaker: NA
Text: by giving equally to the rich and to the

Speaker: NA
Text: poor. The 5 per cent, reduction in income

Speaker: NA
Text: tax applies to all. I find it just a little

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult to comprehend this Liberal justice,

Speaker: NA
Text: which gives 6d. to the poor and Â£1 to the

Speaker: NA
Text: rich. But then, of course, we people on

Speaker: NA
Text: this side of the chamber are biased. We

Speaker: NA
Text: persist in thinking that the man with the

Speaker: NA
Text: 6d. is entitled to even more consideration.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Calwell) has described the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: as " Robin Hood in reverse", as a man

Speaker: NA
Text: who has robbed the poor to help the rich.

Speaker: NA
Text: He could have gone even further and

Speaker: NA
Text: described the Treasurer as a " Robin Hood-

Speaker: NA
Text: wink ", the modern magician from the

Speaker: NA
Text: party which has modified Abraham

Speaker: NA
Text: Lincoln's famous dictum by showing that

Speaker: NA
Text: you can fool enough of the people for

Speaker: NA
Text: enough of the time. This is done by means

Speaker: NA
Text: of financial legerdemain in the first and

Speaker: NA
Text: second years of a three-year term, and

Speaker: NA
Text: removing the pressure in the third year, in

Speaker: NA
Text: which year the electors have a say. This

Speaker: NA
Text: policy has characterized the actions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government since December, 1949, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: have sufficient faith in the intelligence of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian people to believe that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government cannot fool enough of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people for very much longer. The Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: is a vivid illustration of the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: contempt for public opinion in the first

Speaker: NA
Text: year of a three-year term.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to make some reference during

Speaker: NA
Text: the course of this speech to the allied

Speaker: NA
Text: lems of housing and immigration, because

Speaker: NA
Text: to me they seem to be inseparable. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: most curious thing that at this particular

Speaker: NA
Text: time there is, as there has been for

Speaker: NA
Text: years past, no shortage of bricks, timber,

Speaker: NA
Text: glass, tiles, iron, or any one

Speaker: NA
Text: which are so necessary for the building of

Speaker: NA
Text: a home; yet Australians and immigrants

Speaker: NA
Text: alike are finding the housing situation

Speaker: NA
Text: perate. Only a few days ago, in this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber, we were debating the Matrimonial

Speaker: NA
Text: Causes Bill. A considerable part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion on that bill showed that it

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed on both sides that the absence of

Speaker: NA
Text: housing for a very large number of people,

Speaker: NA
Text: or the availability to them of unsatisfactory

Speaker: NA
Text: housing only, contributed materially to

Speaker: NA
Text: divorce rate in Australia. Housing plays

Speaker: NA
Text: very important part in several of the

Speaker: NA
Text: lems which trouble the minds of honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members. I suggest to the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: that since we desire more and more,

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia needs more and more,

Speaker: NA
Text: best type of immigrant, there is no better

Speaker: NA
Text: way to go about getting them than to be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to tell intending migrants in Europe

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States that they can be sure

Speaker: NA
Text: that when they reach these shores they

Speaker: NA
Text: will have no difficulty in getting themeighteen

Speaker: NA
Text: selves established in a home where they

Speaker: NA
Text: can live in comfort and raise their families.

Speaker: NA
Text: It might be said, and it has been

Speaker: NA
Text: that on this side of the chamber we are

Speaker: NA
Text: completely destructive in our approach

Speaker: NA
Text: the Budget. I wish to deny that the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Party's attitude to this Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: destructive. Certainly there are many

Speaker: NA
Text: features of it about which we feel highly

Speaker: NA
Text: critical. I want to suggest to the Governphone

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, for what it is worth, that if it wants

Speaker: NA
Text: to assist in solving the housing problem

Speaker: NA
Text: should not leave the matter entirely in

Speaker: NA
Text: hands of the States, but should go to the

Speaker: NA
Text: rescue of the States. One way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: it could do so would be to facilitate the

Speaker: NA
Text: construction of large blocks of flats in or

Speaker: NA
Text: near the cities and towns of this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Young married couples in the first few years

Speaker: NA
Text: of their married lives might be much better

Speaker: NA
Text: housed in flats than in homes. This would

Speaker: NA
Text: relieve them of the need to find the enor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mous amount of money required for a

Speaker: NA
Text: deposit on a home early in their married

Speaker: NA
Text: life, and would save them the enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure associated with the first few

Speaker: NA
Text: years of buying a home. If married couples

Speaker: NA
Text: probcould rent flats for a few years they would

Speaker: NA
Text: have a chance to establish their finances

Speaker: NA
Text: a so that later they could build or acquire

Speaker: NA
Text: homes in which to establish families.

Speaker: NA
Text: some Honorable members on both sides of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House agree that there are no better people

Speaker: NA
Text: of the materials than family people.

Speaker: NA
Text: As an indication of how badly people

Speaker: NA
Text: desneed homes I remind honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: very of the very large number of what are

Speaker: NA
Text: called " home units " being erected in our

Speaker: NA
Text: cities. I know that many such units have

Speaker: NA
Text: was been built in or around Sydney, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: presume that that is also the case in other

Speaker: NA
Text: cities. That indicates to me quite plainly

Speaker: NA
Text: the desire of many people to acquire a

Speaker: NA
Text: the home at any cost If such people could

Speaker: NA
Text: a rent flats I am sure that there would be

Speaker: NA
Text: proba desirable diminution of the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: home units being built, and there would

Speaker: NA
Text: also be a greater number of places avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: and able for young people to occupy in the

Speaker: NA
Text: of the early years of their marriage.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before I leave the subject of housing

Speaker: NA
Text: or I wish to make brief reference to the quite

Speaker: NA
Text: large number of people who come to my

Speaker: NA
Text: office with complaints about the delay of

Speaker: NA
Text: months between the approval of

Speaker: NA
Text: a war service housing loan and the actual

Speaker: NA
Text: paying over of the money. I think it is

Speaker: NA
Text: deplorable that the heroes of the last war

Speaker: NA
Text: should have to wait eighteen months for a

Speaker: NA
Text: said, loan. During that period of eighteen

Speaker: NA
Text: months many of these people make private

Speaker: NA
Text: to arrangements with finance companies for

Speaker: NA
Text: temporary loans; so the finance companies

Speaker: NA
Text: is entirely profit by this delay.

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall make a brief reference to tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: and bulk postal charges. I remind

Speaker: NA
Text: all people who have a private telephone, if

Speaker: NA
Text: it they need reminding, that a local call will

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost them a penny extra from now on and

Speaker: NA
Text: that the rental of the telephone will be

Speaker: NA
Text: increased by Â£2. I presume that the

Speaker: NA
Text: increase of Â£2 applies to a six-monthly

Speaker: NA
Text: period, which will mean an increase of Â£4

Speaker: NA
Text: a year. Telephones are rapidly becoming

Speaker: NA
Text: a luxury. There are in my electorate many

Speaker: NA
Text: old people who rely on a telephone as their

Speaker: NA
Text: only means of calling help, to send an SOS

Speaker: NA
Text: should something happen to them. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government makes it hard for them to

Speaker: NA
Text: own a telephone, I know that their diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: culties are going to be greatly increased.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know what will happen to the printing

Speaker: NA
Text: trade as a result of the bulk postage charges,

Speaker: NA
Text: and so does everybody else, so I shall not

Speaker: NA
Text: labour the proposed increase. I deplore

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that this Budget contains nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: to help blind people to get a telephone.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that blind people ought to be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to obtain telephones free of charge, and

Speaker: NA
Text: I think most other people will agree with

Speaker: NA
Text: me.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to make a brief reference

Speaker: NA
Text: defence. First, let me congratulate the older.

Speaker: NA
Text: scientists who developed the Malkara and

Speaker: NA
Text: thereby helped to make Australia safe from

Speaker: NA
Text: the invasion which one day may threaten.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think we all are conscious of the

Speaker: NA
Text: that one day invasion may be threatened,

Speaker: NA
Text: and we know from where the threat may

Speaker: NA
Text: come. I have taken some interest in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Army. I went to Mackay at the invitation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Minister for the Army ( Mr Cramer).

Speaker: NA
Text: I am very .glad that he invited me, because

Speaker: NA
Text: I came into contact there with omcers

Speaker: NA
Text: men of the Citizen Military Forces,

Speaker: NA
Text: whom I cannot speak too highly. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: it is a wonderful thing that there are

Speaker: NA
Text: many thousands of young men and middle300

Speaker: NA
Text: aged men who devote their time, and

Speaker: NA
Text: a little of their own money, to training

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves to defend this country in

Speaker: NA
Text: hour of need.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish now to refer to local government

Speaker: NA
Text: and to say that this Government should

Speaker: NA
Text: relieve local government authorities of

Speaker: NA
Text: necessity to pay" pay-roll tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: ties provide so many facilities for the

Speaker: NA
Text: people that it is time they received some

Speaker: NA
Text: help from this Government. They cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: get the loan funds they cry out for-and

Speaker: NA
Text: Lord knows, they cry loud enough for

Speaker: NA
Text: If the Government wants to help them

Speaker: NA
Text: some way it should relieve them of the need

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay pay-roll tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it is time that somebody on

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the chamber made a kindly remark

Speaker: NA
Text: about General Motors-Holden's Limited,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I propose to do that. General Motors-

Speaker: NA
Text: Holden's is the only big company, that I

Speaker: NA
Text: know of which makes no attempt to water

Speaker: NA
Text: its capital or to conceal its profits. For that,

Speaker: NA
Text: I congratulate its directors. Sometimes I

Speaker: NA
Text: wonder what would have happened had the

Speaker: NA
Text: directors of General Motors-Holden's been

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: I also want to refer briefly to the Boeing

Speaker: NA
Text: 707 aircraft which plague the suburbs sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rounding Kingsford-Smith aerodrome.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are the noisiest planes ever built. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have heard them pass overhead, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: noise is like the approach of a typhoon. It

Speaker: NA
Text: grows to a crescendo, so that conversation

Speaker: NA
Text: becomes impossible until it gradually dies

Speaker: NA
Text: away. There is no nuisance so great to the

Speaker: NA
Text: people living in the suburbs around the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingsford-Smith airport as the Boeing 707,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the people of Melbourne will know all

Speaker: NA
Text: to about it too, before they are many months

Speaker: NA
Text: I suggest that the Government give close

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration to what has been done at

Speaker: NA
Text: fact Kowloon Bay, Hong Kong, where a

Speaker: NA
Text: promontory has been built to take a run-

Speaker: NA
Text: way. A promontory could be built into

Speaker: NA
Text: Botany Bay, as far as the Heads, if neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary. If that were done, all aircraft could

Speaker: NA
Text: land or take off along the promontory

Speaker: NA
Text: extending out into the bay. I am told that

Speaker: NA
Text: and they could do this. The roadway known

Speaker: NA
Text: of as General Holmes Drive could be dropped

Speaker: NA
Text: a few feet, and there would be no need to

Speaker: NA
Text: so hold up traffic. There would no longer be

Speaker: NA
Text: or 400 motor cars held up, waiting for

Speaker: NA
Text: not a Boeing to pass overhead. The lights

Speaker: NA
Text: could be taken away. The noise nuisance

Speaker: NA
Text: an would almost cease to exist. In addition,

Speaker: NA
Text: planes could take off with much greater

Speaker: NA
Text: safety if they were taking off along a run-

Speaker: NA
Text: way that extended over the water. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, this Government gives no sign of

Speaker: NA
Text: the doing anything about constructing such a

Speaker: NA
Text: Such authoripromontory into Botany Bay.

Speaker: NA
Text: Perhaps the safety factor is the most im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant factor of all in this connexion. 1

Speaker: NA
Text: , warn this Government that one of these

Speaker: NA
Text: them. days an accident will happen. If one of

Speaker: NA
Text: in these metal monsters crashes on a school

Speaker: NA
Text: or a hospital in the St. George district, woe

Speaker: NA
Text: betide this Government. Thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: this gallons of inflammable liquid might drop

Speaker: NA
Text: on a three-story school or hospital, and a

Speaker: NA
Text: thousand lives could be lost in the holocaust

Speaker: NA
Text: -or inferno that would follow. Let no one

Speaker: NA
Text: -say that that could not happen. Such things

Speaker: NA
Text: -can always happen. We should not be run-

Speaker: NA
Text: ning the risk of their happening.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to congratulate the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: -on its social services and on the very prodi-

Speaker: NA
Text: .gal generosity that it has displayed towards

Speaker: NA
Text: the old, the ill and the widowed. The Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment proposes to give them an addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional 7s. 6d. a week, as if that were the

Speaker: NA
Text: last drop of its heart's blood. These old

Speaker: NA
Text: people made Australia what it is to-day. If

Speaker: NA
Text: we are enjoying life, it is because the old

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Australia made it possible for us.

Speaker: NA
Text: Well might they say-

Speaker: NA
Text: How sharper than a serpent's tooth it is

Speaker: NA
Text: To have a thankless child!

Speaker: NA
Text: This Government proposes to reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation for all by 5 per cent., which, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, will give great benefits to the rich

Speaker: NA
Text: and little or next to nothing to the people

Speaker: NA
Text: on lower incomes. What decent person

Speaker: NA
Text: would not have preferred taxes to stay as

Speaker: NA
Text: they were in order that those on whom the

Speaker: NA
Text: burdens of age and the hammer blows of

Speaker: NA
Text: misfortune have fallen might have a little

Speaker: NA
Text: more? Were it not for the fact that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have a number of service clubs to help

Speaker: NA
Text: out, the situation would be a great deal

Speaker: NA
Text: worse for those in our midst who are

Speaker: NA
Text: fortunate than we are.

Speaker: NA
Text: Has this Government no heart? Has it

Speaker: NA
Text: no shame? Has it no conception of

Speaker: NA
Text: wounds dealt by death when it takes the

Speaker: NA
Text: breadwinner? Do we, too, have to join

Speaker: NA
Text: with death in deepening the wounds inprovide

Speaker: NA
Text: flicted on a widow in the loneliness which

Speaker: NA
Text: comes from separation by death? We give

Speaker: NA
Text: her 7s. 6d. a week extra and say, " Be

Speaker: NA
Text: happy ". No one has a greater call on

Speaker: NA
Text: greatest virtue of all-charity-tha n

Speaker: NA
Text: the widow. But this Government allows proceed.

Speaker: NA
Text: her tears to pass unnoticed. Her cries

Speaker: NA
Text: remain unheard.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to say a few words about the

Speaker: NA
Text: means test, in the few minutes that remain

Speaker: NA
Text: to me. I call the means test a penalty

Speaker: NA
Text: for thrift and self-denial. We preached

Speaker: NA
Text: the people during many of the years that

Speaker: NA
Text: have passed and we told them they should

Speaker: NA
Text: save and prepare for their old age. We

Speaker: NA
Text: said to them, " I f you do those things

Speaker: NA
Text: will be much better off towards the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: your days". What is their reward?

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Mr Bowden) -

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The honorable member's time has

Speaker: NA
Text: expired.

Speaker: Mr HAROLD HOLT
Text: Higgins-Trea -

Speaker: NA
Text: surer) [8.18].^rLess than three weeks ago

Speaker: NA
Text: I presented, on behalf of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Government, the financial pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gramme for the year 1959-60. The Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition has taken the course of moving the

Speaker: NA
Text: traditional amendment to the Budget by

Speaker: NA
Text: way of a vote of censure on this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Honorable members on this side of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House, Sir, have not been greatly im-

Speaker: NA
Text: pressed-nor , 1 feel, has the country-b y

Speaker: NA
Text: the efforts so far of honorable gentlemen

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite to attack the Government, but at

Speaker: NA
Text: least from my point of view they have

Speaker: NA
Text: served a useful purpose in giving me a

Speaker: NA
Text: chance to come back into the debate and

Speaker: NA
Text: answer criticisms, not only those which

Speaker: NA
Text: have come from across the chamber and,

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed, a few from my own side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: committee, but also some which have come

Speaker: NA
Text: from outside.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I turn to those criticisms, Sir, it

Speaker: NA
Text: might be as well, in order to get the dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussion back into perspective, if I were to

Speaker: NA
Text: us restate quite briefly what the Budget sets

Speaker: NA
Text: out to do; indeed, what every financial

Speaker: NA
Text: less statement on behalf of this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: at Budget time has sought to do during

Speaker: NA
Text: our ten years of office. We aim to develop

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australia. We aim to continue a high

Speaker: NA
Text: level of employment with jobs for all who

Speaker: NA
Text: are able and willing to work. We aim to

Speaker: NA
Text: for our national security and to

Speaker: NA
Text: apply a spirit of social justice to the policies

Speaker: NA
Text: that we hope to implement. At the same

Speaker: NA
Text: time we aim to hold costs and prices stable

Speaker: NA
Text: the so that there shall be a sound economic

Speaker: NA
Text: ' has base upon which our development can

Speaker: NA
Text: I stressed in my Budget speech that our

Speaker: NA
Text: twin objectives for Australia are stability

Speaker: NA
Text: and expansion. A welter of criticism has

Speaker: NA
Text: been directed to the Budget since that time,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I submit that none of it has really

Speaker: NA
Text: to shaken those elements that I announced to

Speaker: NA
Text: the committee. Honorable members have

Speaker: NA
Text: questioned some of the elements, but no

Speaker: NA
Text: onehas really shaken what we consider to

Speaker: NA
Text: you be the foundations of Australian develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and prosperity at this time, nor indeed

Speaker: NA
Text: the principles upon which we have acted.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is signincant that in this debate on a

Speaker: NA
Text: budget which relates to the financial cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances not only for the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Government but also of six State govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments, which covers the expenditures of

Speaker: NA
Text: 22 departments of state, which touches the

Speaker: NA
Text: financial circumstances of every citizen of

Speaker: NA
Text: this Commonwealth and which involves a

Speaker: NA
Text: total expenditure of Â£1,682,000,000 and a

Speaker: NA
Text: host of items, the argument now seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: be narrowing down to the Â£4,000,000 or

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£5,000,000 that is concerned mainly with

Speaker: NA
Text: bulk commercial postage. The mass of

Speaker: NA
Text: people outside are left unmoved by the

Speaker: NA
Text: criticisms of honorable gentlemen opposite.

Speaker: NA
Text: They .recognize that Australia is moving

Speaker: NA
Text: steadily forward. In my Budget speech I

Speaker: NA
Text: forecast that Australia and all sections of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians could be assured of a favorable

Speaker: NA
Text: year. Such pointers as have developed

Speaker: NA
Text: since that time all are confirming the assessmuch

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that I was then able to make.

Speaker: NA
Text: There should be no surprise that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget evoked criticisms from many

Speaker: NA
Text: quarters. We have become accustomed in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to a certain pattern of criticism

Speaker: NA
Text: which develops after each budget is pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented. First, there is the immediate

Speaker: NA
Text: criticism that comes from the press, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: say in no unkindly spirit that the commer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial press of this country has long realized

Speaker: NA
Text: that circulation is built more by criticism,

Speaker: NA
Text: and particularly sensational criticism, than

Speaker: NA
Text: it is by commendation. That lesson has not

Speaker: NA
Text: been lost on others who have observed the

Speaker: NA
Text: press techniques.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then, of course, there are the criticisms

Speaker: NA
Text: that come from the spokesmen for sectional

Speaker: NA
Text: interests, and there are hordes of them in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, Their numbers grow each year

Speaker: NA
Text: and they come to governments with their

Speaker: NA
Text: requests. They overstate those requests

Speaker: NA
Text: before the Budget is presented. Human

Speaker: NA
Text: nature being what it is, they tend to pitch

Speaker: NA
Text: their requests rather high, perhaps thinking

Speaker: NA
Text: that if they get one-half or one-third of

Speaker: NA
Text: what they ask for, they will not have

Speaker: NA
Text: badly. Then after the Budget has given

Speaker: NA
Text: them the one-half or one-third of what they

Speaker: NA
Text: requested, they cannot afford to commend

Speaker: NA
Text: it because they had asked for something

Speaker: NA
Text: more. So, every budget is a disappointing

Speaker: NA
Text: budget to the spokesmen for our sectional

Speaker: NA
Text: interests.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then we come to the political opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, it would be expecting too much,

Speaker: NA
Text: and displaying optimism far beyond even my

Speaker: NA
Text: buoyant temperament, to ask for commen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dation from an Opposition of a budget intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced from this side of the chamber. Indeed,

Speaker: NA
Text: if we got commendation we would begin to

Speaker: NA
Text: wonder where we were going wrong,

Speaker: NA
Text: because quite certainly I never intended at

Speaker: NA
Text: any stage to produce a budget that would

Speaker: NA
Text: appeal to the Leader of the Opposition (Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Evatt) and his socialist colleagues nor, I

Speaker: NA
Text: gather, have I done so, judging by what they

Speaker: NA
Text: have been saying.

Speaker: NA
Text: There have been some criticisms from my

Speaker: NA
Text: own side of the chamber, and I shall deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with all of them brieffy, if I can. But if

Speaker: NA
Text: anybody has taken the trouble, as naturally

Speaker: NA
Text: I have, to follow closely what the critics

Speaker: NA
Text: have said, he will have discovered that

Speaker: NA
Text: of the criticism tends to cancel out.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the one hand, for example, there was a

Speaker: NA
Text: fairly general press criticism that the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: was too timid, too conservative, that it

Speaker: NA
Text: reflected cautionary Treasury thinking, that

Speaker: NA
Text: we should have been bolder, and that we

Speaker: NA
Text: should have gone for bigger expenditures in

Speaker: NA
Text: certain directions. If that is one's point of

Speaker: NA
Text: view it is a valid criticism, but it cancels

Speaker: NA
Text: out-o r tends to-th e criticism voiced by

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the more thoughtful members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Parliament, that far from being too

Speaker: NA
Text: timid and too conservative, this is a budget

Speaker: NA
Text: that threatens inflation in this country

Speaker: NA
Text: because we are budgeting for a deficit of

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£61.000,000. Both sets of critics cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: right, and I prefer to believe that the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment has adopted a reasonable balance

Speaker: NA
Text: in this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is true that we have budgeted for a

Speaker: NA
Text: quite substantial deficit and that there is the

Speaker: NA
Text: normal desire to balance one's accounts.

Speaker: NA
Text: But let me just mention three factors

Speaker: NA
Text: which I believe justified-an d indeed made

Speaker: NA
Text: desirable-som e deficit financing on this

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion. One is that we expect to have

Speaker: NA
Text: about 80,000 additional people available for

Speaker: NA
Text: the work force in the course of the current

Speaker: NA
Text: done year. We must provide opportunities for

Speaker: NA
Text: them. There must be an expansion of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry and of the employment that industry

Speaker: NA
Text: can provide. Another factor is that in the

Speaker: NA
Text: course of the year we will be importing an

Speaker: NA
Text: additional Â£50,000,000 worth of goods com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared with last year. This itself is a counter-

Speaker: NA
Text: inflationary matter. The third factor is that

Speaker: NA
Text: inside the Budget, on the revenue account,

Speaker: NA
Text: about Â£150,000,000 is to be provided lor

Speaker: NA
Text: the capital works of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. Normally, we would have

Speaker: NA
Text: hoped to raise that money by loan, but for

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons with which honorable gentlemen are

Speaker: NA
Text: familiar, we now have to take it from

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue. In addition to that Â£150,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: there is another Â£37,000,000, of which

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£30,000,000 is to bridge the gap between

Speaker: NA
Text: our estimated loan raisings of Â£190,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Â£220,000,000 which the States have

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed upon as a loan programme for this

Speaker: NA
Text: year and the remaining Â£7,000,000 of which

Speaker: NA
Text: is for land settlement. So, although on the

Speaker: NA
Text: face of it there is a deficit and the cash is

Speaker: NA
Text: short to that extent, it is not as irrespon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible as deficit financing sometimes proves

Speaker: NA
Text: to be, because I repeat that we have this

Speaker: NA
Text: very substantial volume of what is in effect

Speaker: NA
Text: capital provision being made out of our

Speaker: NA
Text: revenues this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other criticisms also tend to cancel out.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition is the only

Speaker: NA
Text: one of the critics who has managed to have

Speaker: NA
Text: it both ways. He attacked us, first, because

Speaker: NA
Text: in his view we were not providing enough

Speaker: NA
Text: by way of taxation relief-an d I will come

Speaker: NA
Text: to that in a little more detail later. Then

Speaker: NA
Text: he said that we were too niggardly with our

Speaker: NA
Text: provision for social services. In other

Speaker: NA
Text: words, he recommended an expansion of

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure in this and other directions.

Speaker: NA
Text: But at the same time he attacked every

Speaker: NA
Text: provision that we had made for getting in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased revenue. He was against what we

Speaker: NA
Text: were doing in the field of postal charges.

Speaker: NA
Text: He was against what we were doing in

Speaker: NA
Text: niaking a charge for pharmaceutical bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: fits. Whilst attacking the charges that we

Speaker: NA
Text: were imposing and, at the same time

Speaker: NA
Text: recommending increased expenditures, the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable gentleman was saying that

Speaker: NA
Text: our policy was one of creeping inflation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Well, what would his policy be in the cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances? He made it quite clear that

Speaker: NA
Text: he was also critical because we proposed to

Speaker: NA
Text: raise by way of loan money which he said

Speaker: NA
Text: could be provided by treasury-bills. In

Speaker: NA
Text: those three criticisms, taken together, the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable gentleman has made it

Speaker: NA
Text: abundantly clear that the policy of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Labour Party would produce

Speaker: NA
Text: not creeping inflation, but galloping

Speaker: NA
Text: inflation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Crean -Yo n are the last one who

Speaker: NA
Text: should talk about inflation.

Speaker: Mr HAROLD HOLT
Text: Well , I have

Speaker: NA
Text: been talking about it for some little time.

Speaker: NA
Text: When he came to the item of taxation, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition had his criticisms

Speaker: NA
Text: to make, and they were in these terms-

Speaker: NA
Text: Apart from its miserable halfpenny reduction

Speaker: NA
Text: in customs duty on petrol, the Government failed

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Budget to reduce customs duty, excise duty,

Speaker: NA
Text: pay-roll tax or sales tax, particularly on household

Speaker: NA
Text: goods.

Speaker: NA
Text: All of us in this place know that, when you

Speaker: NA
Text: look at a particular budget, to be reason-

Speaker: NA
Text: able and fair you do not treat it in isolation

Speaker: NA
Text: from other budgets which have preceded it,

Speaker: NA
Text: nor do you treat it in isolation from other

Speaker: NA
Text: important economic events that have

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred during the year. Let us look at

Speaker: NA
Text: some of these earlier matters and link them

Speaker: NA
Text: up with what we have done in this Budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, all taxes cannot be reduced in

Speaker: NA
Text: all budgets, unless a government is prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: to budget for enormous inflationary deficits

Speaker: NA
Text: far beyond anything that we would be will-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to contemplate. Although tax con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessions in the present Budget are confined

Speaker: NA
Text: almost wholly to income tax, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: granted concessions in taxes of every kind

Speaker: NA
Text: in our previous budgets when economic and

Speaker: NA
Text: financial circumstances have permitted us

Speaker: NA
Text: to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me remind the committee that since

Speaker: NA
Text: we took office complete exemption from

Speaker: NA
Text: sales tax has been granted on well over 100

Speaker: NA
Text: items, many of which were foodstuffs and

Speaker: NA
Text: household goods subject to sales tax while

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour was in office. Honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite talk about our not doing anything

Speaker: NA
Text: on pay-roll tax. Well, at least we have im-

Speaker: NA
Text: proved things in this direction since we

Speaker: NA
Text: assumed office. The pay-roll tax exemption

Speaker: NA
Text: was increased from Â£1,040 per annum, that

Speaker: NA
Text: being the exemption in force when we took

Speaker: NA
Text: office, to Â£4,160. It was subsequently in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased to Â£6,240, and in 1957 to Â£10,400.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a result, the number of employers paying

Speaker: NA
Text: pay-roll tax has been reduced by approxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately 70,000 since this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: assumed office. As is well known, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: abolished land tax and entertainment tax,

Speaker: NA
Text: which previously were levied by the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: government.

Speaker: NA
Text: One point of the Opposition's criticism

Speaker: NA
Text: was that, although we had made some taxa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion concessions, this was a rich man's

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget-i n other words, that those con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessions had been made in favour of the

Speaker: NA
Text: wealthy against the poor. I repeat that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: utterly unfair to treat a budget item as being

Speaker: NA
Text: unrelated to anything else that has occurred.

Speaker: NA
Text: When we were making our Budget decisions,

Speaker: NA
Text: we found that the great mass of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: wage-earners had already benefited this year

Speaker: NA
Text: by what was a quite substantial increase of

Speaker: NA
Text: the basic wage, that a margins case was in

Speaker: NA
Text: the course of being heard, that pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: would be receiving additional benefits under

Speaker: NA
Text: the Budget, and that most sections of the

Speaker: NA
Text: community had shared in one way or another

Speaker: NA
Text: in the benefits of a reasonably prosperous

Speaker: NA
Text: year.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not often that one can touch the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come tax structure. You obviously do not

Speaker: NA
Text: want to be chopping and changing your tax

Speaker: NA
Text: rates from year to year. As I pointed out

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier, in recent years a vast sum has been

Speaker: NA
Text: raised annually from revenue for capital

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes. This year, having regard to that

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstance in itself and to the benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: which others had received, we felt that the

Speaker: NA
Text: small degree, the modest degree, of tax re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction on the direct income scale was

Speaker: NA
Text: justified.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is said, Mr Chairman, that the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: favours the rich against the poor. The fact

Speaker: NA
Text: of the matter is that the man who at present

Speaker: NA
Text: is paying 60 dmes as much tax as another

Speaker: NA
Text: man will continue to pay 60 times as

Speaker: NA
Text: much tax as that man on the smaller in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come. The Prime Minister ( Mr Menzies)

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrated very effectively that the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: portion of tax levied by us on the higher

Speaker: NA
Text: incomes is in excess of that which was

Speaker: NA
Text: levied by Labour when it was in office. He

Speaker: NA
Text: might have added that, so far as company

Speaker: NA
Text: tax is concerned, this Government could

Speaker: NA
Text: hardly be accused of being more tender

Speaker: NA
Text: towards the companies than was the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: government. When we assumed office,

Speaker: NA
Text: the general rate of company tax was 7s. in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Â£1. During our term of office it has

Speaker: NA
Text: fluctuated at different times and has risen

Speaker: NA
Text: to as high as 9s. in the Â£1. At the moment

Speaker: NA
Text: it stands at 7s. 6d. I find it a little ironical

Speaker: NA
Text: that, while on the one hand I as Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: am attacked by honorable gentlemen oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: site who say it is a rich man's budget, on

Speaker: NA
Text: the other hand I have been strongly criti-

Speaker: NA
Text: cized by the Taxpayers' Association, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Chamber of Manufactures and the Cham-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber of Commerce for being far too nig-

Speaker: NA
Text: gardly in the tax provision that I have been

Speaker: NA
Text: able to make by way of benefit to their

Speaker: NA
Text: members. I think most fair-minded people

Speaker: NA
Text: will agree that we have done what was-

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable in the circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: I deplore the attempt by honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentlemen opposite to create in the minds

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Australian public a picture of a

Speaker: NA
Text: government legislating along class lines.

Speaker: NA
Text: Theirs is a shabby and mischievious charge-

Speaker: NA
Text: -on e which this Government, by its per-

Speaker: NA
Text: formance during its ten years of office, has.

Speaker: NA
Text: shown should not be levelled against it.

Speaker: NA
Text: We would not be here in this chamber

Speaker: NA
Text: to-day with a record majority unless the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Australia had come to the well-

Speaker: NA
Text: founded conclusion that this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: was prepared to deal fairly by all sections

Speaker: NA
Text: of the community. One of the reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: why honorable gentlemen opposite are sit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting where they are and in reduced num-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers is that they have not been able to

Speaker: NA
Text: absorb the spirit of the modern Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and realize that Australians generally are

Speaker: NA
Text: sharing fairly in the national prosperity

Speaker: NA
Text: which our policies have at least been able

Speaker: NA
Text: to encourage.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have mentioned the criticism that has

Speaker: NA
Text: come from the spokesmen for industry to

Speaker: NA
Text: the effect that we have not done enough

Speaker: NA
Text: for them. It is true that in this Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: there is no substantial direct tax concession

Speaker: NA
Text: for industry. But there have been tax

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions for industry in earlier budgets.

Speaker: NA
Text: I refer, for example, to the matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: depreciation allowances. I point out that

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, as a whole, probably has never

Speaker: NA
Text: fared better than it has during this recent

Speaker: NA
Text: period, largely because of a financial and

Speaker: NA
Text: economic environment which our policies

Speaker: NA
Text: have been able to foster. One point of

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence should suffice for me to make

Speaker: NA
Text: my point. At the moment, I have an

Speaker: NA
Text: analysis for only the first nine months of

Speaker: NA
Text: the last financial year, but I point out that

Speaker: NA
Text: public support for Australian industry by

Speaker: NA
Text: way of investment in one form or another

Speaker: NA
Text: was 72 per cent, greater than for the pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vious year. That certainly reflects not only

Speaker: NA
Text: prosperity in industry, but faith in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinued prosperity on the part of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian investing public.

Speaker: NA
Text: So, when all these criticisms are boiled

Speaker: NA
Text: down, it is not surprising that the finance

Speaker: NA
Text: editor of the Melbourne "Herald", of

Speaker: NA
Text: Wednesday, 12th August, in an article

Speaker: NA
Text: which included some criticism of his own,

Speaker: NA
Text: should say-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Budget leaves the Federal Treasury in the

Speaker: NA
Text: soundest financial position of any government

Speaker: NA
Text: treasury in the world, and brands us inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: nationally as one of the soundest countries in

Speaker: NA
Text: the world financially.

Speaker: NA
Text: My only complaint is that the newspaper

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned tucked that comment away in

Speaker: NA
Text: relatively small print towards the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Eddy's article. However, favorable

Speaker: NA
Text: comment in the United Kingdom press was

Speaker: NA
Text: given quite wide publicity, and I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: need to refer to it. It may be of interest

Speaker: NA
Text: to honorable members to hear a comment

Speaker: NA
Text: from New Zealand, our neighbour just

Speaker: NA
Text: across the water. The New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: " Evening Post", commenting on our

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget, said this-

Speaker: NA
Text: A spirit of enterprise and expansion is abroad

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia, and it is reflected in the federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget and the comments which followed its

Speaker: NA
Text: presentation. It gives the distinct impression

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australia is forging ahead economically at

Speaker: NA
Text: a tremendous rate. It is a brave Budget, too,

Speaker: NA
Text: not in the sense of being unpopular, but because

Speaker: NA
Text: it recognizes frankly that the whole Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: economy these days is based upon the assumption

Speaker: NA
Text: of strong, continuous growth.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even if Dr Evatt and Australian businessmen
