Speaker: NA
Text: do not agree with Mr Holt, there is much in his

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget about which we in New Zealand are

Speaker: NA
Text: entitled to feel some twinges of envy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Reynolds - I can give the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: some other comments about it.

Speaker: Mr HAROLD HOLT
Text: Th e honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member may have an opportunity at some

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me turn for a few minutes, Sir, to

Speaker: NA
Text: some particular criticisms that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: made. The honorable member for St.

Speaker: NA
Text: George ( Mr Clay), who preceded me, re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred to pensions. No party, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: has a monopoly of warm-heartedness in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to what can be done or should be

Speaker: NA
Text: done for the aged and the infirm in our

Speaker: NA
Text: community, and we, for our part, Sir, have

Speaker: NA
Text: a record in these matters which is un-

Speaker: NA
Text: matched in the history of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: federation. Honorable gentlemen opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: have given us all sorts of criticisms, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: facts speak for themselves. When we took

Speaker: NA
Text: office late in 1949, the Budget which had

Speaker: NA
Text: just been presented by the Labour Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment provided a total of just on

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£80,000,000 for social services and health

Speaker: NA
Text: services. Our Budget this year provides

Speaker: NA
Text: just over Â£300,000,000 for national wel-

Speaker: NA
Text: fare and for health services. I admit

Speaker: NA
Text: quite frankly that there has been some

Speaker: NA
Text: movement in prices since 1949, but it cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly has not been of anything like the

Speaker: NA
Text: dimensions that the difference in propor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions may suggest- a growth from

Speaker: NA
Text: under this Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: only half as much as the same number of

Speaker: NA
Text: pounds would have bought in 1948.

Speaker: Mr HAROLD HOLT
Text: Th e honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member may halve it, if he likes, but there

Speaker: NA
Text: is now just on four times the volume of

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure that was provided in Labour's

Speaker: NA
Text: last Budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that what we have proposed does

Speaker: NA
Text: not satisfy the pensioner organizations. It

Speaker: NA
Text: would be surprising if it did. But in every

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget, we have tried to do a little more,

Speaker: NA
Text: and there has been this progressive increase

Speaker: NA
Text: in expenditure which I have mentioned.

Speaker: NA
Text: The pensioner organizations said that they

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted a pension equivalent to half the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic wage, but it does not take very much

Speaker: NA
Text: thought to realize that if that principle

Speaker: NA
Text: were adopted many pensioner couples who

Speaker: NA
Text: were eligible also for income and property

Speaker: NA
Text: concessions under the provisions of our

Speaker: NA
Text: social services would be rather better off

Speaker: NA
Text: than were taxpayers who paid for the

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners' benefits, and I do not think that

Speaker: NA
Text: the request was very seriously pressed.

Speaker: NA
Text: There have been others, Sir, who have said

Speaker: NA
Text: that pension rates should move in accord-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance with movements in the C series index

Speaker: NA
Text: of retail prices. If we apply that test, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has nothing to be ashamed of.

Speaker: NA
Text: After the provision made in this Budget,

Speaker: NA
Text: the general rate will be 15s. 5d. a week

Speaker: NA
Text: higher than the present-day equivalent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1949 rate obtained by applying the C

Speaker: NA
Text: series index. For pensioners eligible for

Speaker: NA
Text: supplementary assistance-an d those are

Speaker: NA
Text: the cases of greater hardship-th e total

Speaker: NA
Text: combined payment of pension and assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance will be Â£1 5s. 4d. a week more than

Speaker: NA
Text: the present-day equivalent of the 1949 rate

Speaker: NA
Text: -th e rate when Labour was in office-

Speaker: NA
Text: adjusted according to movements in the C

Speaker: NA
Text: series index of retail prices.

Speaker: NA
Text: But that is by no means the end of the

Speaker: NA
Text: story. There was no pensioner medical

Speaker: NA
Text: service in 1949. The pensioner had to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: for medical treatment and medicine. Since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1951, a .general practitioner service and a

Speaker: NA
Text: wide range of medicines have been pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided free of charge for the majority of

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners. Further, invalid and widow

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners with children now receive an

Speaker: NA
Text: additional pension of 10s. a week for each

Speaker: NA
Text: child under 16 years, except the first. No

Speaker: NA
Text: such supplement was paid in 1949. The

Speaker: NA
Text: means test has been liberalized in that the

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed income has been raised from

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£1 10s. to Â£3 10s. a week and the property

Speaker: NA
Text: limit from Â£750 to Â£2,250 for a single pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner and from Â£1,500 to Â£4,500 for a

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioner married couple. A pension free

Speaker: NA
Text: of the means test was introduced for the

Speaker: NA
Text: blind in October, 1952. Income from

Speaker: NA
Text: property has been disregarded since

Speaker: NA
Text: October, 1954, in applying the income

Speaker: NA
Text: means test. These all are concessions and

Speaker: NA
Text: liberalizations which have occurred during

Speaker: NA
Text: the term of office of this Government and

Speaker: NA
Text: which did not apply while Labour was in

Speaker: NA
Text: office.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have never felt, Sir, that although

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth has a substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility for our aged and infirm the

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility should end there. It will be

Speaker: NA
Text: a bad day for Australia when there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: recognition that there is also a State respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility, which is exercised through the wel-

Speaker: NA
Text: fare organizations which each State

Speaker: NA
Text: government has established, when there is

Speaker: NA
Text: no sense of community responsibility and,

Speaker: NA
Text: finally, when there is no sense of family

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility. What we, as a Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Government, provide is a base for

Speaker: NA
Text: the pensioner to which the discharge of

Speaker: NA
Text: these other responsibilities can add its

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then there was the attack that this Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: failed to provide for increased child endow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. That has been answered by many

Speaker: NA
Text: previous speakers. After all, we introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: child endowment. In the teeth of Labour's

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition, we extended it to the first child.

Speaker: NA
Text: But it was supporters of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour Party who, after the child endow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment scheme had been put into operation

Speaker: NA
Text: and was beingfinancedby the pay-roll tax,

Speaker: NA
Text: decided to alter the principle applied in

Speaker: NA
Text: the fixing of the basic wage. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: gone along to the industrial tribunals since

Speaker: NA
Text: the pay-roll tax was introduced to finance

Speaker: NA
Text: child endowment, and have pressed the

Speaker: NA
Text: tribunals not to make provision for family

Speaker: NA
Text: needs- I believe that, in the long run, that

Speaker: NA
Text: would have been a sounder approach-bu t

Speaker: NA
Text: to fix the highest basic wage that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: within the capacity of industry to pay.

Speaker: NA
Text: Quite clearly, you cannot have it both ways.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having the pay-roll tax, at a certain rate,

Speaker: NA
Text: levied on industry in order to finance child

Speaker: NA
Text: endowment, you cannot ask the arbitra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion tribunals to fix the highest basic wage

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is within the capacity of industry to

Speaker: NA
Text: pay, and, at the same time, chide the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government because it is not able to get

Speaker: NA
Text: more from industry for the purpose of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creasing child endowment. So I say that

Speaker: NA
Text: the critics of the present scheme would do

Speaker: NA
Text: well to look at their own policies and see

Speaker: NA
Text: whether they could usefully be overhauled.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not think it is necessary, Sir, to

Speaker: NA
Text: answer criticisms of the pharmaceutical

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits scheme that have been made. The

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed changes in the scheme have been

Speaker: NA
Text: well received by the public. I think that

Speaker: NA
Text: when we presented thefigureswhich showed

Speaker: NA
Text: how the number of prescriptions had grown

Speaker: NA
Text: from 3,000,000 to more than 16,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: a year and how the cost had increased

Speaker: NA
Text: there was a general realization that the

Speaker: NA
Text: position had to be stabilized. And the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is setting about doing just that.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another major criticism, in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: which I do not want to take up the time

Speaker: NA
Text: of the committee unnecessarily, is related

Speaker: NA
Text: to postal charges. Fortunately, it is not so

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary for me to deal with this, because

Speaker: NA
Text: my colleague, the Postmaster-General ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Davidson), will elaborate this matter in his

Speaker: NA
Text: second-reading speech on the legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: which will provide for the revised rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: I just want to make two or three points

Speaker: NA
Text: for the consideration of honorable gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: men opposite. Since World War IL, just

Speaker: NA
Text: on Â£400,000,000 has been spent on capital

Speaker: NA
Text: items for the Post Office. The return from

Speaker: NA
Text: postal services has not represented anything

Speaker: NA
Text: like a normal interest return on that capital

Speaker: NA
Text: investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: In one particular area, that of com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mercial bulk postage, quite apart from any

Speaker: NA
Text: notional interest being introduced into the

Speaker: NA
Text: calculations, the Post Office was losing

Speaker: NA
Text: millions of pounds a year. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£5,000,000 would have been the total over

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole area in the year just concluded.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the field in which there has been some

Speaker: NA
Text: public controversy in recent days, had

Speaker: NA
Text: matters stood where they were there would

Speaker: NA
Text: have been an operating loss of Â£3,000,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, it costs about 6d. to deliver,

Speaker: NA
Text: under the bulk postage scheme, a periodical

Speaker: NA
Text: or a newspaper, for which a charge of l i d .

Speaker: NA
Text: is made. The Government, through the

Speaker: NA
Text: Post Office, has virtually been subsidizing,

Speaker: NA
Text: to the tune of about 5d. an article, the

Speaker: NA
Text: delivery _of commercial articles delivered

Speaker: NA
Text: as part of commercial services. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: think anybody would regard that as reason-

Speaker: NA
Text: able, or that the general taxpayer should

Speaker: NA
Text: carry such a burden, when the consumer

Speaker: NA
Text: and the commercial operative might very

Speaker: NA
Text: well do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: I saw some rather flamboyant criticism

Speaker: NA
Text: in one of the newspapers under the heading,

Speaker: NA
Text: " Dial M for Murder." Incidentally, I

Speaker: NA
Text: have discovered since taking over the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasury that criticism can assume some

Speaker: NA
Text: rather flamboyant forms. For instance,

Speaker: NA
Text: some character hung a red flag in a tree

Speaker: NA
Text: neaimy home in the dark of night some

Speaker: NA
Text: little time ago. I do not know whether

Speaker: NA
Text: that was a sign that I had produced a rich

Speaker: NA
Text: man's Budget or the reverse. Again, a

Speaker: NA
Text: package marked " Fragile " which was de-

Speaker: NA
Text: livered to my wife over the week-end,

Speaker: NA
Text: contained a very old set of false teeth. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not know what that was supposed to

Speaker: NA
Text: signify. In any event, this newspaper

Speaker: NA
Text: article, " Dial M for Murder", suggested

Speaker: NA
Text: that it costs the department only Â£9 for a

Speaker: NA
Text: telephone, yet it charges this exorbitant

Speaker: NA
Text: annual rental. As my colleague knows-

Speaker: NA
Text: and the figures will be produced by him

Speaker: NA
Text: - i f you take into account the elements

Speaker: NA
Text: which a commercial organization would

Speaker: NA
Text: very properly take into account in the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stallation of a telephone, such as the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: change equipment, the underground cables,

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost of installation in the home as well

Speaker: NA
Text: as the mechanism itself, you get a figure

Speaker: NA
Text: of not Â£9 for that telephone, but Â£290.

Speaker: NA
Text: So when the facts can be presented-an d

Speaker: NA
Text: we have produced a few of them to-night-

Speaker: NA
Text: these things take on a very different aspect

Speaker: NA
Text: from that which our critics would present

Speaker: NA
Text: to the public.

Speaker: NA
Text: Finally, let me say this: I indicated that

Speaker: NA
Text: we had achieved in this country a remark-

Speaker: NA
Text: able degree of stability, unparalleled in

Speaker: NA
Text: our history, economic, social, political and

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial, which has left us most favorably

Speaker: NA
Text: placed to deal with the economic circum-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances of the future. Nothing which has

Speaker: NA
Text: been said in the course of this Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: debate has challenged that proposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nobody can deny that these circumstances,

Speaker: NA
Text: unrivalled in our own history and, I be-

Speaker: NA
Text: live, unsurpassed anywhere else, exist in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to-day. So I say that the Budget-

Speaker: NA
Text: which has been produced will enable those

Speaker: NA
Text: favorable circumstances to continue. The

Speaker: NA
Text: judgment that should be applied to it is

Speaker: NA
Text: not a judgment made on the day after

Speaker: NA
Text: the Budget is announced. The real

Speaker: NA
Text: test should be applied on the eve of the

Speaker: NA
Text: next budget which will be introduced into

Speaker: NA
Text: this Parliament. I feel every confidence

Speaker: NA
Text: that when that time arrives I shall be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to say quite faithfully to this House that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Budget for 1959-60 assured Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: a prosperous year of expansion and de-

Speaker: NA
Text: velopment, and gave to its people better

Speaker: NA
Text: living standards than they had known

Speaker: NA
Text: before.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer ( Mr Harold Holt) has to-night

Speaker: NA
Text: defended himself against the critics of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget which was recently introduced into

Speaker: NA
Text: this Parliament. He told the Parliament

Speaker: NA
Text: that the key-note, in effect, of the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: was an attempt to hold costs and prices

Speaker: NA
Text: stable. But we are informed by one critic

Speaker: NA
Text: in this Parliament that between 1948-on e

Speaker: NA
Text: year before Labour left office-an d 1957

Speaker: NA
Text: the official retail price indices covering food,

Speaker: NA
Text: rent, clothing and miscellaneous household

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure, rose in Australia by 98 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent., representing an all-time record. This

Speaker: NA
Text: critic indicated that prices rose in that

Speaker: NA
Text: period by only 50 per cent, in the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom, where the economic position is

Speaker: NA
Text: and has been much more difficult to manage

Speaker: NA
Text: than ours. The relevant figure for Canada

Speaker: NA
Text: was 26 per cent., for New Zealand 52 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent., for South Africa 43 per cent., and for

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States of America 18 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are told by the present Treasurer, as

Speaker: NA
Text: is always the case when a Treasurer of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government brings his Budget into the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament, that the aim and objective of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has been to hold prices

Speaker: NA
Text: stable and prevent inflation, but, as has

Speaker: NA
Text: been the case throughout the last ten

Speaker: NA
Text: years, inflation has proceeded apace, and

Speaker: NA
Text: the position of the average citizens of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country, particularly those receiving the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic wage or a little more, has become

Speaker: NA
Text: worse and worse. After all, as everybody

Speaker: NA
Text: knows, inflation means ever-increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: prices for commodities that must neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sarily be purchased by the people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Confirmation of my claim can be found

Speaker: NA
Text: in the report of an address delivered by

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Coombs, the Governor of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Bank, and reported in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne " Age " of to-day. To be quite

Speaker: NA
Text: fair, let me say that the report came

Speaker: NA
Text: Perth, and I realize that it is possibly

Speaker: NA
Text: condensation of Dr Coombs's address.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, he is reported to have said this-

Speaker: NA
Text: Inflation is a serious and growing threat

Speaker: NA
Text: health of our economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Well, who has managed the economy of

Speaker: NA
Text: this country, untrammelled, for the past

Speaker: NA
Text: ten years? This Government took office

Speaker: NA
Text: with a fanfare of trumpets, saying, " We

Speaker: NA
Text: will not only put value back into the Â£1,

Speaker: NA
Text: but we will even ensure that the Â£1

Speaker: NA
Text: have a higher purchasing power for the

Speaker: NA
Text: people receiving social service benefits".

Speaker: NA
Text: Nobodv can suggest that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: is governing fairly and justly when con6

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration is given to the figures

Speaker: NA
Text: will cite, and for which I am indebted to

Speaker: NA
Text: the speech of the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Yarra ( Mr Cairns).

Speaker: NA
Text: We find that in this current finanwe

Speaker: NA
Text: cial year the Government requires engage

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£1,682,300,000 in cash- a lot of money

Speaker: NA
Text: -an d it expects to get by way of revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: not enough to meet that requirement. In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact,, it expects to get Â£1,385,300,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is short of its requirements by

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£297,000;000. The Government says lo

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of Australia, " We will borrow

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£190,000,000 from the trading banks, and,

Speaker: NA
Text: of course, we will pay them the prevailing

Speaker: NA
Text: bank rates". The Government will not

Speaker: NA
Text: say to the trading banks, " We will use our

Speaker: NA
Text: powers under the Banking Act to deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mine a rate of interest that is reasonable,

Speaker: NA
Text: considering the fact that this money

Speaker: NA
Text: required to finance the activities of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Government". The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government tells the people, " In addition,

Speaker: NA
Text: we will issue Â£46,000,000, plus the amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of our deficit, Â£61,000,000, to finance

Speaker: NA
Text: activities, per medium of treasury-bills".

Speaker: NA
Text: It gets the treasury-bills for about f per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, from its own Commonwealth Bank,

Speaker: NA
Text: and there is no reason why it should not

Speaker: NA
Text: be compelled to get its Â£190,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: the same rate instead of the higher preagain

Speaker: NA
Text: vailing bank rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is not the first time that we have

Speaker: NA
Text: had this deficit budgeting. It happened

Speaker: NA
Text: last year, when the deficit was estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: be Â£110,000,000. That sounds serious

Speaker: NA
Text: and is serious, but does any one who reads

Speaker: NA
Text: in the daily press of the gigantic mergers

Speaker: NA
Text: of big businesses really beheve that there

Speaker: NA
Text: is any shortage of money or capacity to

Speaker: NA
Text: from pay increased taxes by those who have

Speaker: NA
Text: a waxed exceedingly rich and affluent during

Speaker: NA
Text: the ten years of mis-government by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Menzies-Fadden Administration? Look at

Speaker: NA
Text: to the the powerful commercial concerns that are

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to swallow each other. Do they

Speaker: NA
Text: want to swallow each other so that they

Speaker: NA
Text: can disgorge something to help the people

Speaker: NA
Text: or do they want to swallow each other so

Speaker: NA
Text: that they can strengthen their grip on Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's economy and amass wealth for the

Speaker: NA
Text: will few people who direct them? The daily

Speaker: NA
Text: newspapers carry advertisements inserted

Speaker: NA
Text: by hire-purchase companies and others,

Speaker: NA
Text: offering rates of interest that range from

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent., 8 per cent, and 10 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: that 1 to even 15 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have a Treasurer who was one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Heaven-sent geniuses of the Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: Party. But this year, as with last year,

Speaker: NA
Text: are told that the Government must

Speaker: NA
Text: in deficit financing. This deficit

Speaker: NA
Text: financing excuse is used to deprive people

Speaker: NA
Text: of the substantially higher social services

Speaker: NA
Text: payments that they are entitled to receive.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasurer comes into this chamber and

Speaker: NA
Text: brags of the reduction in taxation, but

Speaker: NA
Text: these reductions mean that the man on the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic wage will get 18d. and I will get

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£25. Is that social justice? I get Â£25 a

Speaker: NA
Text: year out of this Budget on my taxable in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come and the less fortunate man on the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic wage gets about 18d. a week out of

Speaker: NA
Text: it. Is that not a pointer to the methods

Speaker: NA
Text: is used by this Government to finance its

Speaker: NA
Text: activities? But far worse than this is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's complete failure in the last

Speaker: NA
Text: three years to take the bit in its teeth and

Speaker: NA
Text: to do something about one aspect that

Speaker: NA
Text: our more than anything else is responsible for

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the difficulties that must be faced.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Paterson

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Fairhall) made a speech to-day, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: congratulate him. I do not often congratu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ai late my opponents and I will cut him down

Speaker: NA
Text: very shortly. I congratulate him for

Speaker: NA
Text: pointing out to this Government, as I had

Speaker: NA
Text: planned to do on somewhat different lines,

Speaker: NA
Text: that if this or any other government is

Speaker: NA
Text: to going to manage the affairs of the country

Speaker: NA
Text: and control inflation effectively, it must

Speaker: NA
Text: control the marketing of Australia's annual

Speaker: NA
Text: wool clip, if possible with the consent of

Speaker: NA
Text: -the growers. What are we confronted with

Speaker: NA
Text: here? We are confronted with this fact:

Speaker: NA
Text: The 90,000 wool-growers in Australia-

Speaker: NA
Text: that is all there are-sen d their wool to

Speaker: NA
Text: the markets for sale. Every year in these

Speaker: NA
Text: markets they are the victims of the most

Speaker: NA
Text: capable and most highly organized set of

Speaker: NA

Text: anywhere in the world. We have only

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: situation in this country was so serious

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: ing 1,700,000 bales of wool in the sea

Text: because, they believed, it would never

Speaker: NA
Text: sold. An organization was created to

Speaker: NA
Text: the surplus wool and, concurrently with

Text: the incoming clips. As a result of its

Speaker: NA
Text: operations, protected from the price rigger,

Speaker: NA
Text: the growers reaped a profit of Â£35,000,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Subsequently, the propaganda of the banks,

Speaker: NA
Text: brokers and profiteers, who wanted

Speaker: NA
Text: the wool-growers at their mercy again,

Speaker: NA
Text: convinced the growers that they should

Speaker: NA
Text: vote out their own organization, and they

Speaker: NA
Text: the price of wool would never again gp

Speaker: NA
Text: down to the disastrous level' that had

Speaker: NA
Text: ruling after the war, but within three

Text: months it went down by 30 per cent, and

Speaker: NA
Text: within six months it went down by 60 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. All these periodic flutters in the

Speaker: NA
Text: market do not mean very much.

Text: I advise my honorable friend to read the

Text: copy of " Muster", published on 25th

Speaker: NA

Text: sales but only one of us bid, and we can

Text: been split up thelots afterwards". That is

Text: thing that when there is a surplus which

Text: as wei! as the brokers and the conserva-

Text: being -'lone about it. But when the moun-

Text: tain of wool disappears and the immediate

Text: danger passes, they want to open the way

Text: I will not traverse the history of

Speaker: NA
Text: B.A.W.R.A.. because it is long, but it was

Speaker: NA
Text: a successful organization, and sold for the

Speaker: NA
Text: growers of this country Â£35,000,000-worth

Text: of wool when other people said, "Dump

Text: it, because you will not be able to get

Text: rid of it". At the end of World War II . ,

Text: Kingdom and Australia. The Labour go-

Text: vernment of the day agreed to buy a 50

Text: per cent, interest in the Australian portion

Text: of the surplus, amounting to 7,000,000-odd

Speaker: NA
Text: bales. It agreed to form an approved

Text: organization to be known as "J.O.". It

Text: was believed that to sell those 10,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus bales of wool would take from ten

Text: to fourteen years. But the market proved

Speaker: NA
Text: buoyant and that wool was sold, together

Text: years.

Speaker: NA
Text: That scheme was backed by the Coming

Text: monwealth Labour Government under the

Text: The end result was that because a reserve

Text: price was fixed by agreement between

Text: South Africa, New Zealand, Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Kingdom, a profit of more

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£99,000,000 was made out of that transappoint

Text: action. Of that sum, Â£40,000.000 or

Text: Â£50,000,000, for which the Commonwealth

Text: taxpayers were committed and which could

Text: have been lost, was paid out. It was really

Text: only a sum to be drawn on, but it was safe

Speaker: NA
Text: the proceeds from the sale of that surplus

Speaker: NA
Text: wool which he had already been paid for.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us trace the subsequent history of

Speaker: NA
Text: wool. There was a movement among the

Speaker: NA
Text: growers to get a similar organization to

Text: protect future wool clips, but it was de-

Text: stroyed. I make that charge with a full

Text: destroyed? It was agreed among the

Text: growers' organizations that a poll be taken

Text: regarding the new set-up which was to bs

Text: ended its work. The Menzies Government

Text: had just obtained an agreement with South

Speaker: NA
Text: Africa, New Zealand and the United King-

Speaker: NA
Text: dom for a similar scheme to proceed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then, in the 1950-51 Budget it imposed a

Speaker: NA
Text: tax of l i per cent, on the gross sales of all

Speaker: NA
Text: wool sold in Australia in order to raise the

Speaker: NA
Text: finance necessary to work the new scheme.

Text: about that, but the Government imposed

Speaker: NA
Text: a further 20 per cent, deduction from the

Speaker: NA
Text: gross wool cheques of every wool-grower

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia, and the brokers, the buyers,

Speaker: NA
Text: the banks, commercial interests in this

Text: country and a whole lot of people who had

Text: more interest in commercial transactions

Text: than in wool and not much interest in the

Text: welfare of their country, launched propa-

Speaker: NA
Text: ganda for a " No " vote, and unfortunately

Text: the growers voted out that scheme. They

Speaker: NA
Text: believed that if they voted it in, they would

Speaker: NA
Text: lose 2 H per cent, of their wool cheque each

Speaker: NA
Text: year.

Speaker: NA
Text: But time marches on. That was in 1951.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: five serious. In 1957-58, during one period

Speaker: NA
Text: of twelve months the return from wool in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia dropped by Â£100,000,000. Dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: this last twelve months it dropped

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: indulging in the same sort of talk that

Speaker: NA
Text: try in an effort to divert the minds of

Speaker: NA

Text: enough to take steps to have an effective

Speaker: NA
Text: say in the price paid for it.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: for the last ten years. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: the earned the admiration of the whole world

Text: method, or in some other way of dealing

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to add a few words about postal

Speaker: NA
Text: charges. I have not time to say very

Text: much, but I do say that it is a well-known

Text: property can be ascertained. The Post

Text: revenue to meet losses incurred by the

Text: that have been given to people in isolated

Speaker: Mr BRIMBLECOMBE
Text: Maranoa)

Speaker: NA
Text: [9.24] -A t this late stage, when the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: debate is drawing to a conclusion, I want,

Speaker: NA
Text: first of all, to offer my congratulations to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer ( Mr Harold Holt) on the

Speaker: NA
Text: presentation of his first Budget in this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber. I intend, however, despite the

Speaker: NA
Text: second speech he has delivered, to offer

Speaker: NA
Text: some criticisms of certain matters con-

Speaker: NA
Text: out tained in that Budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think this is an appropriate occasion

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay a tribute to Sir Arthur Fadden, who

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer of this country for so

Speaker: NA
Text: many years, and who played a very big part

Speaker: NA
Text: in bringing about the sound economic con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions which this country enjoys to-day. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think it should be put on record that he

Speaker: NA
Text: played a major part in placing the economy

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia on a very sound basis. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: it is worth recalling to the minds of some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the younger people in the community that

Speaker: NA
Text: the when he introduced some of his early

Speaker: NA
Text: it is Budgets, which I well remember, he was

Speaker: NA
Text: criticized by all sections of the people from

Speaker: NA
Text: Post one side of the country to the other, so

Speaker: NA
Text: much so that at one period he said that he

Speaker: NA
Text: could entertain the only friends he had left

Speaker: NA
Text: in a telephone box! However, as time went

Speaker: NA
Text: on, he was proved to be right, and I think

Speaker: NA
Text: telethe great majority of the people of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: and tralia now are prepared to say that what

Speaker: NA
Text: Sir Arthur Fadden did was in the interests

Speaker: NA
Text: that, of his country and that he is a great

Speaker: NA
Text: to think of the dire circumstances

Speaker: NA
Text: would arise if the wool industry were

Speaker: NA
Text: to go to the wall.

Speaker: NA
Text: I recall that, not many years ago, when

Speaker: NA
Text: woolgrowers were enjoying high prices for

Speaker: NA
Text: their wool, they did not receive any sym-

Speaker: NA
Text: pathy from a number of Labour members

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Parliament. I can remember speak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, on this subject in the House. I spoke

Speaker: NA
Text: as the representative of one of the biggest

Speaker: NA
Text: fine woolgrowing electorates in the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth. As a matter of fact, over half

Speaker: NA
Text: of the sheep in Queensland-11,000,00 0

Speaker: NA
Text: of them-ar e in my electorate. When I

Speaker: NA
Text: spoke on behalf of the woolgrowers, I was

Speaker: NA
Text: chided for being parochial, and I was told

Speaker: NA
Text: that I was always looking after the great

Speaker: NA
Text: wool and beef barons. I was chided with

Speaker: NA
Text: that, and the record can be seen in

Speaker: NA
Text: " Hansard ". To-day we find that honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members opposite are talking in a diff-

Speaker: NA
Text: erent strain. I do not include the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for St. George in what I am

Speaker: NA
Text: going to say, because he has already

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrated that he can see the dangers

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead if any further calamity happens to

Speaker: NA
Text: the wool industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members of the Opposition are now dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: playing great sympathy and telling this Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment, quite rightly, that it should do

Speaker: NA
Text: something to rectify the position. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: their duty to do that sort of thing if they

Speaker: NA
Text: think it is in the interests of the nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: But they should be consistent. The pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of the wool industry is subject to

Speaker: NA
Text: the vagaries of the seasons to a very great

Speaker: NA
Text: extent. The industry also relies on the

Speaker: NA
Text: auction system, which the growers them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves have decided they want. The Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment adopts the attitude that if the

Speaker: NA
Text: growers want a free auction system, they

Speaker: NA
Text: shall have it. It is their product and they

Speaker: NA
Text: should decide the best method for its dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal. The honorable member for Lalor

Speaker: NA
Text: has claimed that some of the buyers rig

Speaker: NA
Text: the sales and that a free auction system

Speaker: NA
Text: does not exist. He has said that the buyers

Speaker: NA
Text: go to the sales and make one bid. My

Speaker: NA
Text: colleague, the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Mallee ( Mr Turnbull), has reminded me

Speaker: NA
Text: that the infamous Newmarket one^bid

Speaker: NA
Text: auction was introduced by the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Party. What reply can the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Lalor make to that assertion?

Speaker: NA
Text: During his speech he did not say one word

Speaker: NA
Text: about what that system has cost the primary

Speaker: NA
Text: producers.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said that the Labour Party would

Speaker: NA
Text: trade with any country irrespective of the

Speaker: NA
Text: religious beliefs and political views of. its

Speaker: NA
Text: people. I remind him of the attitude

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted by the Labour Party when this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government announced its intention to

Speaker: NA
Text: enter into a trade agreement with Japan.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Labour Party opposed the move very

Speaker: NA
Text: vigorously and voted against it in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House. How can the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: reconcile that fact with his statement to-

Speaker: NA
Text: night that the Labour Party is prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: to trade with all and sundry, whether it is

Speaker: NA
Text: red China, Russia or any other ountry?

Speaker: NA
Text: The Labour Party should be consistent in

Speaker: NA
Text: its attitude.

Speaker: NA
Text: I should like to comment on the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal to reduce income tax by 5 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: I join with the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Canning ( Mr Hamilton) in saying that the

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction will be of advantage to only a

Speaker: NA
Text: very small minority of the people. The

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal will benefit those who have assets

Speaker: NA
Text: and will give nothing to those whose income

Speaker: NA
Text: is so low that they are not liable to be

Speaker: NA
Text: taxed. I refer in particular to the great

Speaker: NA
Text: majority of the people whom I represent.

Speaker: NA
Text: One has only to look at the figures to see

Speaker: NA
Text: how income from primary industries has

Speaker: NA
Text: been falling and how costs have been

Speaker: NA
Text: rising. Although the total income from

Speaker: NA
Text: 1956-57 to 1958-59 has remained fairly

Speaker: NA
Text: static, costs in the form of wages, depre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciation and other charges have risen con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderably. I venture to say that the great

Speaker: NA
Text: free majority of primary producers will not be

Speaker: NA
Text: liable for income tax in any case, so they

Speaker: NA
Text: will not receive any benefit from the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed reduction of 5 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: I should like to refer now to postal

Speaker: NA
Text: charges. Of all the Ministers who have

Speaker: NA
Text: participated in this debate, only the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister ( Mr Menzies), the Treasurer and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Supply ( Mr Hulme) have

Speaker: NA
Text: made any reference to this very conten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tious matter. The Prime Minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: announced that some alteration will be

Speaker: NA
Text: made in the bulk postage rates. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Supply, in a very brief refer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence to the subject, made a poor defence

Speaker: NA
Text: of the proposal to increase the postal rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government would be wise to recon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider its proposal. I make that statement

Speaker: NA
Text: after having given some thought to the

Speaker: NA
Text: subject. During the last few years I have

Speaker: NA
Text: made it my business to study the operations

Speaker: NA
Text: of the various sections of the Post Office.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have found that senior officers have been

Speaker: NA
Text: able to effect many economies in all

Speaker: NA
Text: branches. During his Budget speech the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer, referring to the efficiency of the

Speaker: NA
Text: organization, said-

Speaker: NA
Text: We all know it to be a highly competent

Speaker: NA
Text: organization-efficientl y managed, devoted to the

Speaker: NA
Text: service of the public, progressive iu its outlook,

Speaker: NA
Text: eager to meet the ever-increasing demands upon

Speaker: NA
Text: it for wider and better facilities, lt has had

Speaker: NA
Text: success in this; it has made really great headway

Speaker: NA
Text: in providing Australia with an adequate and up-

Speaker: NA
Text: to-date communications system.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that statement to be true because 1

Speaker: NA
Text: have investigated the operations of the Post

Speaker: NA
Text: Office. I have visited practically all the

Speaker: NA
Text: large post offices in Australia as well as

Speaker: NA
Text: many of the smaller establishments, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: have talked with the employees in those

Speaker: NA
Text: places. A committee wiil investigate the

Speaker: NA
Text: capitalization of the Post Office and express

Speaker: NA
Text: it in proper accounting terms. If that com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee reports that there is no justification

Speaker: NA
Text: for the increased charges, I wonder wheth :r

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government will reduce thern. I sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose that, in this instance, any reduction

Speaker: NA
Text: could not be made retrospective.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has been suggested that losses have been

Speaker: NA
Text: sustained by various sections of the Post-

Speaker: NA
Text: master-General's Department. [ agree that

Speaker: NA
Text: there may have been losses in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: pounds, shillings and pence, but how can

Speaker: NA
Text: one place a monetary value on the service

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Post Office has given to the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia, particularly those in the

Speaker: NA
Text: country areas? The Government has a

Speaker: NA
Text: duty to provide services for the people who

Speaker: NA
Text: are prepared to pioneer the outback. Un-

Speaker: NA
Text: less they are given some of the amenities of

Speaker: NA
Text: city life-an d postal and telephone ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices are what may be called an essential

Speaker: NA
Text: amenity in the country areas-ho w can the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government expect them to go into the wide

Speaker: NA
Text: open spaces?

Speaker: NA
Text: Every day we read and we hear that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: essential that we produce more and reduce

Speaker: NA
Text: costs. Industries, particularly primary in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustries, in the electorate which I repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sent are very conscious of the fact that costs

Speaker: NA
Text: must be reduced if vve are to compete in

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas markets. But the manufacturers

Speaker: NA
Text: and the primary producers have no control

Speaker: NA
Text: over the majority of the costs that they must

Speaker: NA
Text: bear, and this Budget has not given them

Speaker: NA
Text: a lead as to the way in which the question

Speaker: NA
Text: should be approached.

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall state briefly my view on how

Speaker: NA
Text: duction costs may be reduced. First and

Speaker: NA
Text: foremost, transport costs should be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: viewed. Jf there were some co-ordination

Speaker: NA
Text: between the transport services of the

Speaker: NA
Text: various States, these costs could be reduced

Speaker: NA
Text: materially. Transport represents between

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 per cent, and 30 per cent, of the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of primary production. Another way to

Speaker: NA
Text: notable reduce production costs is to assist people

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged in primary industry to obtain up-

Speaker: NA
Text: to-date equipment and thus produce more

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiently. I have in mind especially those

Speaker: NA
Text: who have commenced operations within

Speaker: NA
Text: the last eight or nine years. In my own

Speaker: NA
Text: area those people are well and truly up

Speaker: NA
Text: against it in obtaining finance for modern

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment and taking advantage of the

Speaker: NA
Text: new techniques made available by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: Research Organization. Of course, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: living in hope that the proposed Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Development Bank of Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: which will commence operations next year,

Speaker: NA
Text: will be able to provide the necessary credit

Speaker: NA
Text: for this purpose nnd for other essential

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes. At present it is difficult to obtain

Speaker: NA
Text: finance from the trading banks, which

Speaker: NA
Text: prefer to invest in avenues offering quicker

Speaker: NA
Text: returns.

Speaker: NA
Text: Until recent years it was the practice

Speaker: NA
Text: for the country storekeeper, and the stock

Speaker: NA
Text: and station agent, to act as a sort of

Speaker: NA
Text: banker for the farmer to carry him over

Speaker: NA
Text: the seasonal period. They could obtain

Speaker: NA
Text: short term credit with which to buy the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole of the sacks or fertilizer needed in a

Speaker: NA
Text: district and could extend similar credit to

Speaker: NA
Text: the primary producers using them. Such

Speaker: NA
Text: short-term credits are no longer available.

Speaker: NA
Text: Their withdrawal is retarding production

Speaker: NA
Text: and is imposing a great handicap on pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: mary producers.

Speaker: NA
Text: At present a convention of scientists is

Speaker: NA
Text: being held in Perth. Once again we have

Speaker: NA
Text: been told that there is a dearth of able

Speaker: NA
Text: scientists in Australia. I shall mention

Speaker: NA
Text: only one group, for whose services pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: mary industry is crying out. I refer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: aericultural scientists. Why are they not

Speaker: NA
Text: available in greater numbers? Facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: for training young people are provided at

Speaker: NA
Text: the universities, but pupils are not coming

Speaker: NA
Text: forward for training. When the agricul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tural scientist has taken his degree and

Speaker: NA
Text: progoes out on probation he is paid less than

Speaker: NA
Text: is a plumber. He is the lowest paid of all

Speaker: NA
Text: scientists, yet this country depends upon

Speaker: NA
Text: the sale of primary produce for the over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas credit that it needs if it is to buy the

Speaker: NA
Text: material which keeps secondary industry

Speaker: NA
Text: going.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Clyde Cameron -Whos e fault is

Speaker: NA
Text: that?

Speaker: Mr BRIMBLECOMBE
Text: I t is our fault,

Speaker: NA
Text: and doubtless when Labour was in office

Speaker: NA
Text: it made the same mistake. I ask the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment to grant more scholarships for

Speaker: NA
Text: work in this faculty; to make the associated

Speaker: NA
Text: grant more liberal; and to ensure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: probationer is given adequate remuneration.

Speaker: NA
Text: It may be said that I have an axe to grind

Speaker: NA
Text: in bringing forward this matter. Indeed I

Speaker: NA
Text: have. Almost all the members of my

Speaker: NA
Text: family are agricultural scientists. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are leaving their government employment

Speaker: NA
Text: because they do not receive sufficient

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration to make it worth their while

Speaker: NA
Text: to remain. They could make more outside

Speaker: NA
Text: with private enterprise, or by simply going

Speaker: NA
Text: on the land. Australia cannot afford to

Speaker: NA
Text: lose agricultural scientists, who are the

Speaker: NA
Text: link between the producers and the sales

Speaker: NA
Text: end. We must encourage them in every

Speaker: NA
Text: way possible. I plead with the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to look at this matter and ensure that these

Speaker: NA
Text: people are given a decent position in the

Speaker: NA
Text: list of scientists, which is a very long

Speaker: NA
Text: At present they are at the bottom and there

Speaker: NA
Text: are available very few to fill the positions

Speaker: NA
Text: that are vacant.

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade is the life blood of this country,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Minister for Trade ( Mr MCEwen)

Speaker: NA
Text: has done a mighty job in promoting

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas. I recall that, some years ago, he

Speaker: NA
Text: warned Australia that we must encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: our secondary industries because we could

Speaker: NA
Text: not live for ever on our earnings from

Speaker: NA
Text: mary industry. He has done everything in

Speaker: NA
Text: his power to attain that end. We of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Country Party believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: proper balance should be maintained now

Speaker: NA
Text: between the primary and secondary indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries. We believe that the home market

Speaker: NA
Text: the best market, but we have not forgotten

Speaker: NA
Text: that the export market is the most important

Speaker: NA
Text: for the maintenance of this country's

Speaker: NA
Text: economic stability.

Speaker: Mr CLYDE CAMERON
Text: Hindmarsh) made

Speaker: NA
Text: [9.49] - I think that I ought to tell any

Speaker: NA
Text: who may have been listening to the honorcountry.

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Maranoa ( Mr Brimble-

Speaker: NA
Text: combe) that he is normally a supporter of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government. He is an Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Country Party representative and his party

Speaker: NA
Text: alone is responsible for keeping in office

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government-whic h he has criticized

Speaker: NA
Text: so correctly, and with such justification.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, it is his party alone that makes it

Speaker: NA
Text: possible for the Government to increase

Speaker: NA
Text: postal charges in the way that he has

Speaker: NA
Text: criticized. It is the Australian Country

Speaker: NA
Text: Party alone which is responsible for this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government being able to make tremendous

Speaker: NA
Text: reductions in tax on high incomes-givin g

Speaker: NA
Text: practically no benefit to the smaller income-

Speaker: NA
Text: earners whom he mentioned when referring

Speaker: NA
Text: to the primary producers. It is perfectly

Speaker: NA
Text: correct, as the honorable member said,

Speaker: NA
Text: that there are very few primary producers

Speaker: NA
Text: to-day who will get any benefit at all from

Speaker: NA
Text: the reduction in income tax that is pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed in this Government's Budget. On

Speaker: NA
Text: the other hand, people living in the capital

Speaker: NA
Text: cities who own large parcels of shares in

Speaker: NA
Text: the big concerns which manufacture the

Speaker: NA
Text: things that the primary producer has to

Speaker: NA
Text: buy at a price fixed arbitrarily by the manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facturing combines themselves, will have the

Speaker: NA
Text: lion's share of the reduction.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the members on the Government side

Speaker: NA
Text: list. of the chamber who have criticized this

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget in the same way as the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: has criticized it vote, in a few minutes'

Speaker: NA
Text: time, in accordance with the way in which

Speaker: NA
Text: they have spoken, the Budget will be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: jected and this Government will have to

Speaker: NA
Text: face another general election. Of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: it although some honorable members oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: site often speak against things that the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment does, they can always be relied

Speaker: NA
Text: upon to vote for the Government when ita

Speaker: NA
Text: prifate is likely to be in the balance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst it is pleasing to know that some

Speaker: NA
Text: a members of both Government parties are

Speaker: NA
Text: agreeing with the criticisms which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition has levelled against this rich

Speaker: NA
Text: man's Budget, it would be very much more

Speaker: NA
Text: is pleasing if we could see them match their

Speaker: NA
Text: words with deeds and vote against the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government when the division bells cease

Speaker: NA
Text: ringing and the count of heads takes place.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Maranoa

Speaker: NA
Text: yet another important point when he

Speaker: NA
Text: one said that trade is the life blood of this

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no doubt that trade

Speaker: NA
Text: is the life blood of a country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Any government that knows its respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility to its people ought to do every-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing possible to expand trade.

Speaker: NA
Text: agree that a country should not, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: send to countries that may become

Speaker: NA
Text: enemies, strategic raw materials or materials

Speaker: NA
Text: that could be turned into war goods. On

Speaker: NA
Text: the other hand, I cannot understand the

Speaker: NA
Text: double talk of members of the Liberal Party

Speaker: NA
Text: and Australian Country Party when they

Speaker: NA
Text: pretend on the one hand, that they are op-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed to trade with China, but, on the other

Speaker: NA
Text: hand, do not oppose trade with red Russia.

Speaker: NA
Text: They are opposed to recognizing red China,

Speaker: NA
Text: yet they are quite prepared to recognize

Speaker: NA
Text: red Russia!

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Hume ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Anderson) who is interjecting knows that

Speaker: NA
Text: he sold his wool to red Russia at a time

Speaker: NA
Text: when it seemed that wool would be a very

Speaker: NA
Text: important factor in a war which the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment had told us was only three years

Speaker: NA
Text: away. This honorable member who always

Speaker: NA
Text: has so much to say about not recognizing

Speaker: NA
Text: red China, sold his wool to red Russia for

Speaker: NA
Text: no better reason than that red Russia was

Speaker: NA
Text: able to pay him a few pence per pound

Speaker: NA
Text: more for it than anybody else was willing

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay. The primary factor in the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's mind was not any " hi-

Speaker: NA
Text: falutin " principle about recognizing Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munist countries, but the question of how

Speaker: NA
Text: much more money he could get by selling

Speaker: NA
Text: to red Russia- a country which his own

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister had told him, in 1951,

Speaker: NA
Text: would be at war with us within three years.

Speaker: NA
Text: That illustrates the kind of split principle

Speaker: NA
Text: that seems to be applied in this question of

Speaker: NA
Text: the recognition of red China.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although the Government talks a lot

Speaker: NA
Text: about refusing to recognize red China, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Trade ( Mr MCEwen) has told

Speaker: NA
Text: us that it is now quite in order to sell not

Speaker: NA
Text: only wool and foodstuffs but also steel to

Speaker: NA
Text: red China. This indicates how strong are the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's moral objections to trade

Speaker: NA
Text: with Communist countries. Its excuse for

Speaker: NA
Text: permitting our potential enemies in the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munist world to be supplied with vital war

Speaker: NA
Text: materials is in effect, " If we do not give

Speaker: NA
Text: the Communists steel, some other country

Speaker: NA
Text: will, so we might as well join in the bean-

Speaker: NA
Text: feast and get our cut of the profit".. The

Speaker: NA
Text: prime consideration of these people, all the

Speaker: NA
Text: time, is not some high principle but the

Speaker: NA
Text: question, " How much money can we get

Speaker: NA
Text: in our own pockets from the transaction we

Speaker: NA
Text: now contemplate? "

Speaker: NA
Text: I The difference between the policy of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and that of the Labour Party

Speaker: NA
Text: is that we are honest. We agree with the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Maranoa when he

Speaker: NA
Text: says that trade is the life blood of the

Speaker: NA
Text: country. We believe it is proper to trade

Speaker: NA
Text: with the countries of the world irrespective

Speaker: NA
Text: of their kind of government. I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: criticize the honorable member for Hume

Speaker: NA
Text: for having sold his wool to red Russia at a

Speaker: NA
Text: time when war seemed to be inevitable; but

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not like to hear the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber criticizing the Opposition simply be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause it is honest enough to say that we

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to trade with any country irrespective

Speaker: NA
Text: of its politics. At the same time as he

Speaker: NA
Text: criticizes us for advocating trade with these

Speaker: NA
Text: countries, he trades with them himself, sell-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing his wool to red Russia simply because he

Speaker: NA
Text: can get an extra penny per lb. for it.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition simply says, " Let us face

Speaker: NA
Text: the issue ". If we decided to trade only

Speaker: NA
Text: with those countries whose politics are tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: same as our own, we would not be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: trade, I presume, with New Zealand be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause it has a Labour government and we

Speaker: NA
Text: have a Tory government. We would be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to trade with, the United Kingdom

Speaker: NA
Text: only so long as it elected Tory governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: If a Labour government were elected, pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumably we would stop trading because we

Speaker: NA
Text: disagreed with that Government's politics.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a magnificent form of reasoning-

Speaker: NA
Text: that once a government's politics are

Speaker: NA
Text: different from ours we should refuse to

Speaker: NA
Text: trade with the people of that country. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is the kind of addled thinking which

Speaker: NA
Text: typifies the attitude on the Goverament side

Speaker: NA
Text: of the chamber to this question of trade with

Speaker: NA
Text: China. I believe, as I have always said, that

Speaker: NA
Text: we ought to trade with any country. The

Speaker: NA
Text: more we extend the avenues of trade, the

Speaker: NA
Text: better the chance we will have of selling our

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus commodities, and the better the

Speaker: NA
Text: chance we will have of getting higher prices

Speaker: NA
Text: for our existing exports such as wool.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us look at the situation which has

Speaker: NA
Text: been gradually developing in this country

Speaker: NA
Text: since this Government has been responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: for its finances. In 1958-59 our overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: reserves were Â£16,000,000 more than in the

Speaker: NA
Text: previous year. That sounds quite good.

Speaker: NA
Text: But against the increase of Â£16,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: must be offset Â£203,000,000 worth of

Speaker: NA
Text: invisibles including freight charges, insur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance payments and interest on overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: borrowing. Consequently, instead of having

Speaker: NA
Text: a surplus of Â£16,000,000 we had a deficit of

Speaker: NA
Text: It may be said that there is nothing we

Speaker: NA
Text: can do about the invisibles. I disagree en-

Speaker: NA
Text: tirely with that statement. A substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the Â£203,000,000 consists of ship-

Speaker: NA
Text: ping charges which are arbitrarily fixed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the shipping cartels in the United Kingdom

Speaker: NA
Text: and other parts of the world. These charges

Speaker: NA
Text: are fixed at the maximum rate that the car-

Speaker: NA
Text: tels are able to extract from the primary

Speaker: NA
Text: producers, especially those in this country

Speaker: NA
Text: who have to iely on shipping to get their

Speaker: NA
Text: goods to the world markets. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment should expand the Commonwealth-

Speaker: NA
Text: owned shipping line so that the people's own

Speaker: NA
Text: ships may be used to carry the produce of

Speaker: NA
Text: this country for the actual cost of working

Speaker: NA
Text: the vessel.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Forbes -Pu t Lascars on.

Speaker: Mr CLYDE CAMERON
Text: I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: know which honorable member opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: interjected but one of them looks like a

Speaker: NA
Text: Lascar himself. I do not agree with putting

Speaker: NA
Text: Lascars on the ships. The mentality on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government side of the chamber is indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cated by this suggestion that Lascars should

Speaker: NA
Text: be employed on Commonwealth-owned

Speaker: NA
Text: ships at cut rates of wages. We could and

Speaker: NA
Text: should employ good Australian seamen on

Speaker: NA
Text: our own Australian ships, pay them decent

Speaker: NA
Text: wages and save the exorbitant profit that

Speaker: NA
Text: goes to the shipping cartels in England. A

Speaker: NA
Text: tremendous reduction would then be made

Speaker: NA
Text: in the invisible charges that have to be paid

Speaker: NA
Text: by the primary producers. The poor old

Speaker: NA
Text: primary producer is the one who fattens

Speaker: NA
Text: the shareholders of the P. & O. line.

Speaker: NA
Text: And has anybody in this House ever heard

Speaker: NA
Text: one word of protest from members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: -Country Party against that form of

Speaker: NA
Text: exploitation? Of course not!

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Daly -Ther e is only one of them

Speaker: NA
Text: awake.

Speaker: Mr CLYDE CAMERON
Text: A s the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member says, there is only one

Speaker: NA
Text: of them awake at the moment, which in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dicates the interest the members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Country Party have in the affairs of the

Speaker: NA
Text: people they pretend to represent. The

Speaker: NA
Text: point I wanted to make was that, in addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to the drain that has occurred already

Speaker: NA
Text: in our overseas balances, this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has now decided to increase by another

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£50,000,000 the value of imports it will

Speaker: NA
Text: permit to come into the country. Therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: we have to find a further Â£50,000,000 worth

Speaker: NA
Text: of exports to meet the extra Â£50,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: worth of imports the Government has now

Speaker: NA
Text: decided to allow into the country. It is true

Speaker: NA
Text: that there has been an increase in the price

Speaker: NA
Text: of wool and that this increase will to a

Speaker: NA
Text: large extent meet the extra Â£50,000,000

Speaker: NA
Text: worth of imports the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: decided to admit to the country, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: important point is that the whole of the

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in the price of wool which we

Speaker: NA
Text: expect to flow to us as a consequence of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Russian entry into the wool market

Speaker: NA
Text: is now going to be absorbed by the increased

Speaker: NA
Text: import quotas this Government has decided

Speaker: NA
Text: to allow.

Speaker: NA
Text: Still talking about invisibles, I emphasize

Speaker: NA
Text: that when we send dividends out of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country as a consequence of foreign invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment here we are sending away something

Speaker: NA
Text: for which we will get no return whatever.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is something like the tribute which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Romans extracted many centuries ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: When the conquering Roman armies

Speaker: NA
Text: marched into foreign lands and subjugated

Speaker: NA
Text: the peoples, governors were appointed to

Speaker: NA
Text: rule them and to collect tribute from them

Speaker: NA
Text: to be sent to Rome. To-day, overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: capitalists are doing much the same thing.

Speaker: NA
Text: The only difference is that they are invited

Speaker: NA
Text: here. They are being feted and given great

Speaker: NA
Text: treatment by the Australian Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: not so that they will bring armies to extract

Speaker: NA
Text: tribute from us but in order that they will

Speaker: NA
Text: bring in capital which is just as effective

Speaker: NA
Text: a means of extracting tribute not only this

Speaker: NA
Text: year and next year but for centuries to

Speaker: NA
Text: come, unless some other government steps

Speaker: NA
Text: in and puts an end to it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us now examine the position of

Speaker: NA
Text: General Motors-Holden's Limited. Last

Speaker: NA
Text: year, the company made a net profit of

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£15,000,000; that is after paying taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: and after setting aside a very liberal amount

Speaker: NA
Text: for depreciation, and a large amount for

Speaker: NA
Text: reserves. The actual profit was Â£30,000,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: and 425 per cent, of the original net capital

Speaker: NA
Text: of the company was sent abroad last year

Speaker: NA
Text: in the form of dividends. In other words,

Speaker: NA
Text: General Motors-Holden's Limited sent

Speaker: NA
Text: away Â£7,500,000, an amount equal to 425

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent, of the original capital investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, if one looks at the total net profit

Speaker: NA
Text: that General Motors-Holden's Limited made

Speaker: NA
Text: one finds that it represents 800 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: profit in one year on the original capital

Speaker: NA
Text: investment.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been a good deal of miscon-

Speaker: NA
Text: ception about the original capital of

Speaker: NA
Text: General Motors-Holden's Limited. No

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt many people know that the original

Speaker: NA
Text: capital invested in this company was about

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£2,225,000. But there was not one

Speaker: NA
Text: American dollar in that amount! That

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£2,225,000 was lent to General Motors-

Speaker: NA
Text: Holden's Limited by the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Bank!

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Anderson -Unde r what govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment?

Speaker: Mr CLYDE CAMERON
Text: Unde r the

Speaker: NA
Text: Chifley Government. So every time the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member praises General Motors-

Speaker: NA
Text: Holden's Limited, as he did in his

Speaker: NA
Text: speech

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Anderson - I did not praise the

Speaker: NA
Text: company.

Speaker: Mr CLYDE CAMERON
Text: Th e honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member did! I read the report of his

Speaker: NA
Text: speech, and it did not surprise me that he

Speaker: NA
Text: said that it was a marvellous thing to see

Speaker: NA
Text: General Motors-Holden's Limited making

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£30,000,000 profit while the primary pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers did not know which way to turn to

Speaker: NA
Text: pay their debts.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Anderson - I said that I did not

Speaker: NA
Text: praise the company.

Speaker: Mr CLYDE CAMERON
Text: On e minute

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member praises the idea of

Speaker: NA
Text: General Motors-Holden's Limited making

Speaker: NA
Text: a profit of Â£30,000,000, and now he speaks

Speaker: NA
Text: as though it is a terrible thing because the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour Government introduced the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal in 1947 for the establishment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: company.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Anderson -Wha t nonsense!

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Mr Bowden) -

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The honorable member for Hume

Speaker: NA
Text: will remain silent, as will all other honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members.

Speaker: Mr CLYDE CAMERON
Text: Som e might fits

Speaker: NA
Text: ask, "Why does not General Motorsour

Speaker: NA
Text: Holden's Limited increase the capital base

Speaker: NA
Text: of its undertaking here? Why does it still

Speaker: NA
Text: leave the base at Â£2,225,000? Why does

Speaker: NA
Text: it not issue bonus shares as other com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies do? " There is a very good reason.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the company did increase the capital

Speaker: NA
Text: base of its assets, then, for a start, it would

Speaker: NA
Text: have to pay a capitalization tax of 15 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent., and it is not prepared to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: Indeed, General Motors-Holden's Limited

Speaker: NA
Text: is determined to pay as little by way of

Speaker: NA
Text: tax as it can to the Australian people, and,

Speaker: NA
Text: while it is determined to pay as little by

Speaker: NA
Text: way of tax as it can, having got the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment- I think it was in 1953-t o agree

Speaker: NA
Text: to the abolition of double taxation, so that

Speaker: NA
Text: it now pays no tax at all on certain earn-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings on which it previously paid tax, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: charging the Australian users of its pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duct as much as it can extract from them

Speaker: NA
Text: while paying its employees only what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Vehicle Builders Union forces it to pay.

Speaker: NA
Text: If it were not for the efforts of this union,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is constantly pressing the company

Speaker: NA
Text: for increased wages and decent conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: of employment, General Motors-Holden's

Speaker: NA
Text: Limited would be in a very much better

Speaker: NA
Text: position than it is to-day, and the employees

Speaker: NA
Text: would be in a very much worse position.

Speaker: NA
Text: Profit can be made in one of two ways-

Speaker: NA
Text: either by under-paying the employees or

Speaker: NA
Text: by overcharging consumers for the goods

Speaker: NA
Text: produced. I believe that General Motors-

Speaker: NA
Text: Holden's Limited is doing a little bit of

Speaker: NA
Text: each. It is certainly true that it is over-

Speaker: NA
Text: charging when one looks at the profits it

Speaker: NA
Text: makes on the goods it sells and, having

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to the profits, I believe the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany is grossly underpaying the men it

Speaker: NA
Text: employs.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have referred to the tribute that is

Speaker: NA
Text: being extracted from this country. Let me

Speaker: NA
Text: explain what I mean. In 1948-49, 4 i per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, of the total national income of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia went abroad in the form of dividends

Speaker: NA
Text: on capital invested in this country from

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas. Let me now give the figure for

Speaker: NA
Text: 1956-57, which is only two years ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amount has been increased sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantially since then, as every one will

Speaker: NA
Text: agree, but the year 1956-57 is the last

Speaker: NA
Text: year for which I have been able to obtain

Speaker: NA
Text: figures. The tribute taken out of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country by foreign investors in the form

Speaker: NA
Text: of dividends from which we get no bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever amounted to 8 i per cent, of

Speaker: NA
Text: national income in 1956-57. How

Speaker: NA
Text: much longer will this drift be allowed to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue? If the percentage gets higher

Speaker: NA
Text: and higher, the time will come when 50

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent, of our total national income will

Speaker: NA
Text: be sent to overseas investors, while the

Speaker: NA
Text: people who produce it, and the country

Speaker: NA
Text: which is responsible for its production, will

Speaker: NA
Text: get no benefit whatever from it.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that we are now faced with a

Speaker: NA
Text: very serious situation. This Government

Speaker: NA
Text: is allowing an inflationary situation to

Speaker: NA
Text: develop. Even its own supporters are now

Speaker: NA
Text: beginning to criticize it and ask very perti-

Speaker: NA
Text: nent questions about it. I refer the House

Speaker: NA
Text: to the speech delivered by the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bradfield ( Mr Turner), who

Speaker: NA
Text: is a member of the Liberal Party in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament. This is what he said only the

Speaker: NA
Text: day before yesterday-

Speaker: NA
Text: Fear and anxiety are gripping at the hearts of

Speaker: NA
Text: tens of thousands of thrifty people in this com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity as they watch the erosion of their savings

Speaker: NA
Text: and wonder how they can provide for their declining

Speaker: NA
Text: years. I make a plea for these forgotten people,

Speaker: NA
Text: who are a numerous and not negligible section

Speaker: NA
Text: of the community.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader of the Opposition (Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Evatt) was perfectly correct when he

Speaker: NA
Text: described this as a rich man's budget. I t

Speaker: NA
Text: is a rich man's budget, as Country Party

Speaker: NA
Text: member after Country Party member and

Speaker: NA
Text: some Liberal Party members i n Country

Speaker: NA
Text: Party seats have indicated. It is a budget

Speaker: NA
Text: which seeks to give enormous reductions in

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax to the very wealthy and the

Speaker: NA
Text: paltry sum of 9d. a week to the ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: family man with two or three children.

Speaker: NA
Text: To illustrate this point, I mention the case

Speaker: NA
Text: of the man who is earning Â£1,000 a year

Speaker: NA
Text: and who has three children. He is now

Speaker: NA
Text: paying Â£54 a year in income tax. He is to

Speaker: NA
Text: receive a magnificent reduction of ls. in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Â£1 or 54s., not a week, not a day as

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the rich will receive under

Speaker: NA
Text: this Budget, but a year. He is to get

Speaker: NA
Text: the wonderful payout of ls. a week!

Speaker: NA
Text: That is completely illusory, because he has

Speaker: NA
Text: not yet looked at the effect of the basic

Speaker: NA
Text: wage increase. When he adds the 15s. in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease in the basic wage-equivalen t to

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£39 a year-t o his income of Â£1,000, he

Speaker: NA
Text: will find that instead of enjoying a reduc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of Â£2 14s. a year, as the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: pretended, he will pay an extra Â£6 a year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead of paying Â£54, as he did last year,

Speaker: NA
Text: he will pay Â£60 a year because of the effect

Speaker: NA
Text: of the basic wage increase upon his salary.

Speaker: NA
Text: It must not be forgotten, either, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in the basic wage does not improve

Speaker: NA
Text: his standard of living. It merely seeks,

Speaker: NA
Text: belatedly, to maintain his present standard.

Speaker: NA
Text: Therefore, he is forced to pay Â£6 a year

Speaker: NA
Text: more in tax than he paid last year, instead

Speaker: NA
Text: of paying less, as the Government claims.

Speaker: NA
Text: Turning to the other side of the picture,

Speaker: NA
Text: the wealthy men who live in the mansions

Speaker: NA
Text: of Vaucluse, Springfield, Toorak and all

Speaker: NA
Text: the other flash suburbs in the various

Speaker: NA
Text: capital cities-th e stock exchange investors

Speaker: NA
Text: and bankers, men whose incomes are about

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£20,000 or Â£30,000 a year-ar e not

Speaker: NA
Text: affected by the 15s. increase in the basic

Speaker: NA
Text: wage. Let honorable members not laugh

Speaker: NA
Text: when I mention incomes of Â£20,000 and

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£30,000, because there are in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: men who receive such incomes. The re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction in their income tax will be of the

Speaker: NA
Text: order of Â£10 a week, while the man on

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£1,000 a year, with three children to main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain, will have to pay an extra Â£6 a year.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Government talks about a deficit

Speaker: NA
Text: of some Â£61,000,000. What is a deficit?

Speaker: NA
Text: When a government has commitments

Speaker: NA
Text: which it cannot meet from taxation and

Speaker: NA
Text: from borrowings, it has to make up the

Speaker: NA
Text: difference in some manner. This Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment proposes to bridge the gap with trea-

Speaker: NA
Text: sury-bills. What will happen will be that

Speaker: NA
Text: the private banks will buy from the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment, with credit created by the pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate banks, these treasury-bills issued by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government to bridge the gap between

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments on the one hand and revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: and loan raisings on the other hand. No

Speaker: NA
Text: real money, no new money in the true

Speaker: NA
Text: sense of the word, will be made available.

Speaker: NA
Text: Credit created by the private banks is to

Speaker: NA
Text: be used by them to pay for the treasury-

Speaker: NA
Text: bills, on which the Government will then

Speaker: NA
Text: pay interest to the private banks so that

Speaker: NA
Text: they may be reimbursed for the trouble

Speaker: NA
Text: of issuing this imaginary credit. A l l that

Speaker: NA
Text: the private banks will do in this trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: action will be to expand their own credit

Speaker: NA
Text: in order to buy government securities. They

Speaker: NA
Text: will then use those very securities, which

Speaker: NA
Text: they have bought as a consequence of ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: panding their own credit, in order to build

Speaker: NA
Text: up their liquid assets, on which they can

Speaker: NA
Text: make additional credit available to their

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinary borrowers.

Speaker: NA
Text: Who are their ordinary borrowers? As

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Maranoa has

Speaker: NA
Text: said, the ordinary borrowers from private

Speaker: NA
Text: banks to-day are not the farmers, who are

Speaker: NA
Text: living in hope that they might get money

Speaker: NA
Text: from the new Development Bank. The

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinary borrowers from private banks to-

Speaker: NA
Text: day are the hire-purchase companies. What

Speaker: NA
Text: is their position? The honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Hume ( Mr Anderson) is shaking his

Speaker: NA
Text: head. Of course, he would not know any-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing about hire-purchase transactions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having sold his wool to the Russians at

Speaker: NA
Text: such a high price, he does not know any-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing about buying goods on hire purchase.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can tell the honorable gentleman that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian community has increased its

Speaker: NA
Text: indebtedness to hire-purchase companies

Speaker: NA
