Text: from about Â£58,000,000 ten years, ago to

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£351,000,000, which is the amount now

Speaker: NA
Text: owing to the various hire-purchase com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies. These companies in turn are get-

Speaker: NA
Text: ting their money from people who normally

Speaker: NA
Text: would be making money available in go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment loans for government undertak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings and public works.

Speaker: NA
Text: If bank credit is to be extended, why can

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Bank not extend the

Speaker: NA
Text: credit which is now allowed to be handled

Speaker: NA
Text: by the private banks? If the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Bank did so, the interest would be

Speaker: NA
Text: payable to the Government itself, and no

Speaker: NA
Text: interest would be payable, as it is now

Speaker: NA
Text: payable, to the private banks. There would

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore be no secondary innation, such as

Speaker: NA
Text: is the case when money is borrowed from

Speaker: NA
Text: the private banks, or when private banks

Speaker: NA
Text: are allowed to buy treasury-bills on artifi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cially or privately created bank credit. The

Speaker: NA
Text: interest rate in this country has reached an

Speaker: NA
Text: alarming level. The total interest bill is

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£83,000,000 a year ten years ago. We

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot go on forever building up this

Speaker: NA
Text: enormous indebtedness in interest rates to

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas lenders of money and to internal

Speaker: NA
Text: lenders of money to the Australian Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment. We cannot go on forever meet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing this enormous interest bill of

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£148,000,000 a year. There has to be an

Speaker: NA
Text: end to it sooner or later, and the sooner

Speaker: NA
Text: the better.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to deal quickly with the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: as it affects various groups. I remind

Speaker: NA
Text: the Committee that the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: decided to reduce income tax by

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£20,000,000, the major portion of which

Speaker: NA
Text: will go into the pockets of the very rich

Speaker: NA
Text: people, company investors and banking

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions of the country. Government

Speaker: NA
Text: supporters say that high taxes are an im-

Speaker: NA
Text: pediment to earning capacity, but I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: believe it. I do not believe that you can

Speaker: NA
Text: stop people from wanting to earn more

Speaker: NA
Text: money simply by increasing their taxes.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is a myth that ought to be exploded.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Government is wrong in paying out

Speaker: NA
Text: every year more and more handouts to

Speaker: NA
Text: the rich who do not need them, leaving the

Speaker: NA
Text: poor who need relief so badly to flounder

Speaker: NA
Text: along as best they can. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has given a handout to the wealthy by

Speaker: NA
Text: deciding that those who can afford to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£8 a week in insurance premiums will be

Speaker: NA
Text: able to deduct the whole Â£8 from their

Speaker: NA
Text: taxable income. What working man can

Speaker: NA
Text: afford to pay Â£8 a week in insurance pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: miums? Obviously, this is another hand-

Speaker: NA
Text: out to the very wealthy. Private com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies will receive taxation concessions

Speaker: NA
Text: amounting to Â£2,250,000. Foreign oil

Speaker: NA
Text: companies, which have taken up all the

Speaker: NA
Text: oil prospecting leases with the exception

Speaker: NA
Text: of two or three, will get a handout of

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£1,250,000. When they find oil, they will

Speaker: NA
Text: decide whether we get the oil and, if so,

Speaker: NA
Text: at what price.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the sort of thing done by this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, which claims to represent

Speaker: NA
Text: the people. It has announced a reduction

Speaker: NA
Text: of i d . a gallon in excise duty on petrol,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it has no guarantee from the oil

Speaker: NA
Text: companies that the i d . reduction in excise

Speaker: NA
Text: will be passed on to the motorist. I shall

Speaker: NA
Text: be very surprised indeed if it is in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: passed on. The Government has announced

Speaker: NA
Text: its intention to increase the age pension by

Speaker: NA
Text: against 7s. 6d. a week, that is, to 34.5 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: of to-day's basic wage, whereas the pension

Speaker: NA
Text: fixed by the Chifley Government was 37

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent, of the basic wage in 1948. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government maintained the relationship

Speaker: NA
Text: between the pension and the basic wage

Speaker: NA
Text: established by the Chifley Government

Speaker: NA
Text: eleven years ago-everybod y else has had

Speaker: NA
Text: an increase except the ordinary worker-

Speaker: NA
Text: the pension would be not Â£4 15s. but

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£5 3s. Yet this Government has the

Speaker: NA
Text: cheek to boast about what it is doing for

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners.

Speaker: NA
Text: An amazing position exists in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed increases in postal charges

Speaker: NA
Text: amounting to about Â£17,800,000 a year.

Speaker: NA
Text: The ordinary letter rate, which is applic-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to letters written by the average man,

Speaker: NA
Text: wili be increased from 4d. to 5d., while

Speaker: NA
Text: the air mail rate, which is applicable mostly

Speaker: NA
Text: to letters written by business men and

Speaker: NA
Text: wealthy people who want quick replies

Speaker: NA
Text: and do not worry about a 3d. surcharge,

Speaker: NA
Text: will be reduced from 7d. to 5d. The main

Speaker: NA
Text: beneficiary from the increased charges will

Speaker: NA
Text: be Ansett-A.N.A., because it is proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: that all letters will be sent by air. I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that Ansetts, when carrying out this con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tract, will do it a litde more honestly than

Speaker: NA
Text: was the case six months ago when one of

Speaker: NA
Text: their big motor transports overturned on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hume Highway and its contents, scattered

Speaker: NA
Text: alf along the road for everybody to sec,

Speaker: NA
Text: included thousands and thousands of air

Speaker: NA
Text: mail letters. These letters, on which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government had been paid 7d., were being

Speaker: NA
Text: moved by ordinary surface transport.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Killen -Ca n you prove that?

Speaker: Mr CLYDE CAMERON
Text: Tha t can be

Speaker: NA
Text: proved.

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Text: Order ! The honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentieman's time has expired.

Speaker: Mr OPPERMAN
Text: Corio) [10.19]-I f is

Speaker: NA
Text: always interesting to hear the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Hindmarsh ( Mr Clyde

Speaker: NA
Text: Cameron), who has just concluded his

Speaker: NA
Text: speech. As usual, it makes up in fluency

Speaker: NA
Text: and force what it lacks in sense and logic.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member referred to wool.

Speaker: NA
Text: I remember that when we put a 30 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: tax on wool sales to balance against future

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax as a buttress against inflation,

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member as well as the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition (Dr Evatt) and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Leader ( Mr Calwell) put up a

Speaker: NA
Text: bold fight purely for the sake of being

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunist protagonists for the poor

Speaker: NA
Text: old woolgrowers. It is rather ironical to

Speaker: NA
Text: hear the honorable member speak of the

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of cohesion in the Liberal Party when

Speaker: NA
Text: one thinks of a case now before the court

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning a certain trade union, and when

Speaker: NA
Text: one also thinks of the dissension in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Labour Party to-day which has

Speaker: NA
Text: caused it to lose the confidence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian people. The honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber's economics are sadly off the beam

Speaker: NA
Text: when he talks of nationalized shipping lines

Speaker: NA
Text: because he overlooks conveniently the cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of running a ship on Australian charter

Speaker: NA
Text: rates of pay. Obviously, those rates would

Speaker: NA
Text: have to be paid, buf they are more than

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£200 above the British charter rates. So,

Speaker: NA
Text: the primary producer whom the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member professes to be so solicitous about

Speaker: NA
Text: would be merely subsidizing the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's socialistic ideas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before I speak on the Budget, I would

Speaker: NA
Text: like to congratulate the Treasurer ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Harold Holt) on bringing forward his first

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget. We in this Parliament know the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable gentleman's versatility, his

Speaker: NA
Text: experience and capacity, which have made

Speaker: NA
Text: him a most prominent political figure. Fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowing his representation of Australia over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas in various roles which he filled so

Speaker: NA
Text: capably as Minister for Immigration, Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Labour and National Service and

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman of the Commonwealth Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary Association, he is regarded highly

Speaker: NA
Text: abroad as an outstanding statesman. With

Speaker: NA
Text: such a reputation to sustain and having

Speaker: NA
Text: taken over his portfolio from such a re-

Speaker: NA
Text: nowned personality as Sir Arthur Fadden,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer might have been forgiven if

Speaker: NA
Text: he had yielded to the human temptation at

Speaker: NA
Text: his first attempt to make a spectacular

Speaker: NA
Text: effort to extend concessions to all sections

Speaker: NA
Text: of the community. That would have gained

Speaker: NA
Text: him an immediate and temporary popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larity, but it would have been gambling with

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's future. However, to his credit

Speaker: NA
Text: and to the benefit of Australia, he has

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrated the level-headed judgment

Speaker: NA
Text: which has earned him his present important

Speaker: NA
Text: portfolio. Instead of yielding to any such

Speaker: NA
Text: impulse the right honorable gentleman has

Speaker: NA
Text: reflected in this Budget the restraint, con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol and sense of responsibility which has

Speaker: NA
Text: marked the Administration of the Menzies

Speaker: NA
Text: Government during the past ten years.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition in fairness to its own fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowers who, after all, derive the greatest

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit from stability in employment should

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate some appreciation of the situation

Speaker: NA
Text: instead of endeavouring once more to

Speaker: NA
Text: create the same old atmosphere of gloom

Speaker: NA
Text: and depression. For years, the Opposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion has despairingly tried to paint a gloomy

Speaker: NA
Text: picture of what lies ahead. Honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite know that the position is

Speaker: NA
Text: quite different; and their recognition of the

Speaker: NA
Text: facts slips out occasionally. For instance,

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Grayndler ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Daly) said last night-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Budget appals me, particularly in view of

Speaker: NA
Text: this period of prosperity and progress.

Speaker: NA
Text: That statement came from an honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member opposite. The lack of consistency

Speaker: NA
Text: and intensity in the Opposition's attack

Speaker: NA
Text: reveals just how unsure it is of its ground.

Speaker: NA
Text: During my ten years in this Parliament, I

Speaker: NA
Text: have never heard such a variety of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: flicting opinions as those expressed by

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Opposition in support of

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendment moved by their leader.

Speaker: NA
Text: This, perhaps, is not to be wondered at, for

Speaker: NA
Text: this is the tenth round of their endeavours

Speaker: NA
Text: to dislodge the Menzies Government. As

Speaker: NA
Text: they have delivered every type of budget

Speaker: NA
Text: body blow known to political science and

Speaker: NA
Text: have been punched back on the ropes each

Speaker: NA
Text: time, while they face another desperate

Speaker: NA
Text: defensive for the ensuing twelve months,

Speaker: NA
Text: there is some excuse for their coming into

Speaker: NA
Text: this encounter and wondering, exhausted

Speaker: NA
Text: and battered as they are, just how they can

Speaker: NA
Text: make some sort of a showing which will

Speaker: NA
Text: justify them continuing as one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: contestants.

Speaker: NA
Text: After all, a party which has been preof

Speaker: NA
Text: dicting for ten years terrific financial

Speaker: NA
Text: disasters, great unemployment, the collapse

Speaker: NA
Text: of overseas markets, the winning of the

Speaker: NA
Text: elections and the ill wind of the public

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government, while still having a few

Speaker: NA
Text: internal fights on its own hands, must

Speaker: NA
Text: come to the stage that this Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: undoubtedly has reached. It has the feeling

Speaker: NA
Text: that the public places no reliance on its

Speaker: NA
Text: arguments and has no faith in its alternabeen

Speaker: NA
Text: tive methods and plans for developing along

Speaker: NA
Text: sound lines. How wrong the Labour Party

Speaker: NA
Text: has been year after year. It

Speaker: NA
Text: to reflect on the last Budget as a measuring

Speaker: NA
Text: stick of the reliability of the Opposition in

Speaker: NA
Text: criticizing this Budget. During the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: debate last year, the Deputy Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition ( Mr Calwell), whom we can

Speaker: NA
Text: accept as expressing the typical outlook

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labour Party, said-

Speaker: NA
Text: The mess in which this Government finds itself

Speaker: NA
Text: in regard to loan raising, in regard to loan

Speaker: NA
Text: versions, in regard to cash balances, in regard

Speaker: NA
Text: deficits, in regard to inflation and in regard to

Speaker: NA
Text: everything else is of its own making. Nobody

Speaker: NA
Text: else created its problems. They cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: on to labour troubles because the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: continually boasts of the amount of peace there

Speaker: NA
Text: has been in industry since it has been in office.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those sentences offer the best complipened

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that could be paid to the Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: management of the country, for if we

Speaker: NA
Text: unequivocally blamed in 1958

Speaker: NA
Text: alleged mess, and, by contrast, in 1959

Speaker: NA
Text: the economic position is even sounder, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government must be given the credit.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is the position? Loan raising has

Speaker: NA
Text: been at a record level of Â£206,500,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: Loan conversions have been readily met.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Budget deficit has been decreased from

Speaker: NA
Text: record amount in savings banks, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: average deposit stands at Â£136 a head of

Speaker: NA
Text: population, compared with Â£129 a head in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1958. That does not indicate an infla-

Speaker: NA
Text: tionary spiral.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Hindmarsh

Speaker: NA
Text: referred to hire purchase. The fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: we can have hire-purchase borrowings at

Speaker: NA
Text: the current level and still have an increase

Speaker: NA
Text: in savings bank deposits indicates that the

Speaker: NA
Text: condition of the nation is good. The

Speaker: NA
Text: people have more washing machines and

Speaker: NA
Text: refrigerators. Construction of houses has

Speaker: NA
Text: increased, and the people have all the other

Speaker: NA
Text: things which constitute a higher standard

Speaker: NA
Text: living. The Opposition can talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: statistics and percentages, but every married

Speaker: NA
Text: couple going into a house to-day has it well

Speaker: NA
Text: next furnished, with carpets on the floor. A

Speaker: NA
Text: for few years later they have a motor car,

Speaker: NA
Text: because the Australian motor car industry

Speaker: NA
Text: enables them to start life on a better basis

Speaker: NA
Text: than was possible at any previous stage

Speaker: NA
Text: in our history. All this is indicative of

Speaker: NA
Text: higher standards. The - Labour Party has

Speaker: NA
Text: completely wrong in its forecasts. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has looked into the crystal ball and tried

Speaker: NA
Text: to prophesy the future, but with singular

Speaker: NA
Text: is well perhaps lack of success.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Daly -Wha t about sales of bicycles?

Speaker: Mr OPPERMAN
Text: The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Grayndler asks about bicycle

Speaker: NA
Text: of sales. My reply is that that is one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: measuring sticks of the higher standard of

Speaker: NA
Text: living. Sales of bicycles have fallen off

Speaker: NA
Text: as sales of motor cars, motor scooters and

Speaker: NA
Text: conother forms of transport have risen. During

Speaker: NA
Text: to this Government's ten years of office, we

Speaker: NA
Text: have had violent fluctuations of income.

Speaker: NA
Text: blamed Had the position not been handled with

Speaker: NA
Text: courage and foresight by the Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Opposition predicted could have

Speaker: NA
Text: happened. Assuredly, it would have hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: if the Labour Party had been in

Speaker: NA
Text: office and put into operation its ideas on

Speaker: NA
Text: were economics and finance. The economy

Speaker: NA
Text: for an would have been wrecked.

Speaker: NA
Text: Every time action was taken by the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment to balance these fluctuations and

Speaker: NA
Text: changes in the national income, the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition predicted immediate disaster. Yet

Speaker: NA
Text: this era, as a result of the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: financial restraint and control of imports,

Speaker: NA
Text: has proved to be the most prosperous in

Speaker: NA
Text: the history of this country. If, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: words of the Deputy Leader of the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition, our troubles were of our own

Speaker: NA
Text: making, then surely our present prosperity

Speaker: NA
Text: must be regarded as of our own creation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Topically enough, the quotation that

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared on yesterday's date pad was-

Speaker: NA
Text: Chance never helps those who do not help

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Government has helped this country

Speaker: NA
Text: to its present state. During the period I

Speaker: NA
Text: have mentioned, our population has in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creased from under 8,000,000 to over

Speaker: NA
Text: 10,000,000 people. That has called for a

Speaker: NA
Text: tremendous effort in handling and guidance.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have also in that period of time attracted

Speaker: NA
Text: more than Â£700,000,000 of foreign capital

Speaker: NA
Text: from overseas sources. Everybody knows

Speaker: NA
Text: that money outside a country-mone y which

Speaker: NA
Text: is available for investment-ha s a sensitivity

Speaker: NA
Text: to the state of the country into which it may

Speaker: NA
Text: come. The existing conditions in that

Speaker: NA
Text: country are carefully watched and checked

Speaker: NA
Text: so as to provide a guide to the conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: which might apply in the future. The fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that more than Â£700,000,000 worth of

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas capital has come to this country

Speaker: NA
Text: is quite an objective compliment to the

Speaker: NA
Text: state of affairs in Australia that has

Speaker: NA
Text: during these years.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have retained the goodwill of the

Speaker: NA
Text: International Bank for Reconstruction and

Speaker: NA
Text: Development, and we have raised dollar

Speaker: NA
Text: loans amounting to Â£317,000,000 which

Speaker: NA
Text: are not given lightly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our secondary industries-thi s is impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant to the Labour Party on the other side

Speaker: NA
Text: of the chamber-hav e been developed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Surely if their policy and outlook and plat-

Speaker: NA
Text: form made an appeal to the ordinary work-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing man, honorable members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: would be in offics here to-day. I find that

Speaker: NA
Text: there are at present in existence in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country 53,200 factories producing goods

Speaker: NA
Text: worth Â£4,710,000,000 this year, and we have

Speaker: NA
Text: come to be the world's eighth trading nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: This, I say quite confidently, has been a

Speaker: NA
Text: magnificent decade-on e in which, although

Speaker: NA
Text: almost Â£80,000,000 has been expended on

Speaker: NA
Text: repatriation benefits, Â£236,600,000 on social

Speaker: NA
Text: services, Â£24,100,000 on pharmaceutical

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits, Â£12,000,000 on migration, and

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£192,800,000 on defence, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has also met the demands of water conser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vation by projects such as the Snowy

Speaker: NA
Text: Mountains scheme. Through State instru-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentalities, 50,000 miles of macadamized

Speaker: NA
Text: roads have been constructed, and hospitals

Speaker: NA
Text: and schools have been built. All this, mark

Speaker: NA
Text: you, in spite of the tremendous handicaps

Speaker: NA
Text: consequent on our country being approxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mately the size of the United States and our

Speaker: NA
Text: population being about the same as that of

Speaker: NA
Text: Greater London! No other country in the

Speaker: NA
Text: world with such a small population in rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to its area enjoys such a high standard

Speaker: NA
Text: of living as we enjoy. But we must con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue to face frontiers in the areas that have

Speaker: NA
Text: not been fully developed. In an expanding

Speaker: NA
Text: community, this must always be the case.

Speaker: NA
Text: The last decade has been a period of

Speaker: NA
Text: tremendous financial, industrial and com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mercial activity. There are people who

Speaker: NA
Text: want the benefit of all these things but they

Speaker: NA
Text: do not want to bear, the expense associated

Speaker: NA
Text: with obtaining them. They want the things

Speaker: NA
Text: that cannot be obtained without an infusion

Speaker: NA
Text: of money. Members of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: must realize that a higher standard of living

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot be obtained without work. They

Speaker: NA
Text: have criticized the take-overs and mergers

Speaker: NA
Text: that have occurred during the period that

Speaker: NA
Text: the population of this country has risen

Speaker: NA
Text: from fewer than 8,000,000 people to more

Speaker: NA
Text: existed than 10,000,000 people. The speeches

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been delivered by honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite make it evident that they

Speaker: NA
Text: think that success is something to be

Speaker: NA
Text: deplored. I cannot believe that they really

Speaker: NA
Text: think along those lines. Such developments

Speaker: NA
Text: are merely a reflection of expansion of

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprise and individuality; they do not

Speaker: NA
Text: represent monopolies. Let us look at the

Speaker: NA
Text: history of take-overs. The increased effi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciency that accompanies them enables prices

Speaker: NA
Text: to be reduced. Has there been any less

Speaker: NA
Text: competition because the Myer Emporium

Speaker: NA
Text: Limited, Cox Brothers (Australia) Limited,

Speaker: NA
Text: Waltons-Sears Limited, Patersons Proprie-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary Limited, Reid Murrays Limited, Elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tronic Industries Limited, and Pye Holdings

Speaker: NA
Text: have become involved in such business

Speaker: NA
Text: deals? Of course not! In fact, added

Speaker: NA
Text: capital and larger premises have demanded

Speaker: NA
Text: a higher turnover, with consequent better

Speaker: NA
Text: prices and better services to the public

Speaker: NA
Text: brighter prospects for the employees.

Speaker: NA
Text: The last ten years have been an era such

Speaker: NA
Text: as we have never before known in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. This is the era for big men. It

Speaker: NA
Text: provides a test for executives, and offers

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities for men who are efficient,

Speaker: NA
Text: untiring and diligent. This decade has

Speaker: NA
Text: shown the calibre of Australians and has

Speaker: NA
Text: revealed their status. The Ansetts, Richard-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons, Myers, Warners, Kormans and

Speaker: NA
Text: Beaurepaires deserve our admiration. We

Speaker: NA
Text: might criticize them for various reasons,

Speaker: NA
Text: but they have contributed enormously to

Speaker: NA
Text: our prosperity by their business acumen,

Speaker: NA
Text: courage and enterprise. They are men who

Speaker: NA
Text: commenced on a shoestring, as Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: members could have done, and were once

Speaker: NA
Text: workers on the line. They command our

Speaker: NA
Text: admiration. We know of their early

Speaker: NA
Text: beginnings. They have shown by their

Speaker: NA
Text: results what a land of opportunity this is.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable members opposite, when

Speaker: NA
Text: talking about the big profits that have

Speaker: NA
Text: made by companies and individuals, should

Speaker: NA
Text: study the income tax figures. First, com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies are required to pay tax, and

Speaker: NA
Text: secondly, dividends are taxable in the

Speaker: NA
Text: hands of the shareholders. Our taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: system takes care very effectively of high

Speaker: NA
Text: profits and still leaves room for incentive,

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Melbourne has

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated that he acknowledges this. Did

Speaker: NA
Text: he not recently open an Â£8,000 community

Speaker: NA
Text: centre at Clayton that was donated by a

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bill Viney who, eight years ago, was

Speaker: NA
Text: an unemployed builder's labourer, but has

Speaker: NA
Text: since built 1,000 houses and has orders

Speaker: NA
Text: for another 500 houses? This success story

Speaker: NA
Text: is symbolic of Labour's inability to grasp

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that hundreds of thousands of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian workers who listened avidly ten

Speaker: NA
Text: years ago to stories of capitalism grinding

Speaker: NA
Text: down workers, are to-day employers, exe-

Speaker: NA
Text: cutives and capitalists, and are providing

Speaker: NA
Text: examples which other workers wish to fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: low. The whole application and oudook

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia is shaped in that way, and so

Speaker: NA
Text: long as the old guard of Labour keeps

Speaker: NA
Text: trotting out this socialist bogey and per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sists in its criticism of profits honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite will remain where they

Speaker: NA
Text: are for years to come.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Grayndler

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Daly) dealt very comprehensively

Speaker: NA
Text: and General Motors-Holden's Limited-t o a

Speaker: NA
Text: degree that his colleagues had not done-i n

Speaker: NA
Text: an endeavour to offset the fact that that

Speaker: NA
Text: company was commenced during the regime

Speaker: NA
Text: of a Labour government.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ward -Tha t is right.

Speaker: Mr OPPERMAN
Text: Labou r made the

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ward -No , we did not make them.

Speaker: NA
Text: You are mistaken.

Speaker: Mr OPPERMAN
Text: Th e honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber also mentioned the Ford Motor Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany of Australia Proprietary Limited. If

Speaker: NA
Text: ever there was an example of what a great

Speaker: NA
Text: company can do for a city, it is the example

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Ford Motor Company at Geelong.

Speaker: NA
Text: General Motors have established their

Speaker: NA
Text: premises in Melbourne, and the full effect

Speaker: NA
Text: of that establishment is not readily apparent

Speaker: NA
Text: because its employees live in the many

Speaker: NA
Text: suburbs. But in Geelong the Ford orga-

Speaker: NA
Text: nization has a direct and beneficial effect

Speaker: NA
Text: been upon the economy. At one stage it was

Speaker: NA
Text: thought in Corio that the whole show might

Speaker: NA
Text: be going to Broadmeadows. Let me tell

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members that there was im-

Speaker: NA
Text: mediately a set back to local housing, com-

Speaker: NA
Text: merce and confidence. You cannot im-

Speaker: NA
Text: press the Geelong people with talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: profits going overseas. That is only inci-

Speaker: NA
Text: dental to the amount of work, the amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of spending, the amount of wages and

Speaker: NA
Text: their effect on the local community and the

Speaker: NA
Text: prosperity in and around it. If more over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas firms like General Motors would estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: lish themselves or open branches in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country, it would have a great and bene-

Speaker: NA
Text: ficial effect on Australia, completely out of

Speaker: NA
Text: proportion to any penalties that we might

Speaker: NA
Text: pay by having to send profits overseas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Getting away from that matter, Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman, I should like to say a few words

Speaker: NA
Text: about postal charges. These proposals are

Speaker: NA
Text: among the features of the Budget that have

Speaker: NA
Text: caused some discussion, principally because

Speaker: NA
Text: they have not been properly understood.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am quite sure that as time goes on they

Speaker: NA
Text: will be understood. The subject of postal

Speaker: NA
Text: charges touches a reminiscent chord so

Speaker: NA
Text: far as I am concerned, because any one

Speaker: NA
Text: who has been associated with that tremen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dous undertaking, the Postal Department,

Speaker: NA
Text: realizes that there is something about it

Speaker: NA
Text: with that he can never forget.

Speaker: NA
Text: To-night I heard one honorable niember

Speaker: NA
Text: speak of the profits made by the Post Office

Speaker: NA
Text: prior to 1945. Let me point out that those

Speaker: NA
Text: profits were made, to a great extent, be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause the average wage paid in the postal

Speaker: NA
Text: service was not as great as the average

Speaker: NA
Text: wage paid outside. In return for some

Speaker: NA
Text: security, for three weeks annual leave and

Speaker: NA
Text: for long service leave after twenty years

Speaker: NA
Text: of service, postal employees were prepared

Speaker: NA
Text: to take a lower rate of pay than people

Speaker: NA
Text: working outside. A telegraph messenger

Speaker: NA
Text: pedalled his bicycle around for 15s. a week.

Speaker: NA
Text: He worked for 48 hours a week, with no

Speaker: NA
Text: pay for ordinary overtime, and he worked

Speaker: NA
Text: on Saturday afternoons for a rate of pay

Speaker: NA
Text: which would not have been acceptable by

Speaker: NA
Text: people outside. Do you honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers on the Labour side want a return to

Speaker: NA
Text: these conditions? We could have cheaper

Speaker: NA
Text: rates on that basis. But they are asking

Speaker: NA
Text: for all possible amenities and all modern

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions for postal workers, whilst at

Speaker: NA
Text: the same time they .ask for cheaper rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can remember Percy Cerutty, the great

Speaker: NA
Text: trainer of Australian athletes to-day, pedalIt

Speaker: NA
Text: ling his bicycle as a linesman, with a big

Speaker: NA
Text: bag of tools on the back of the machine.

Speaker: NA
Text: The overhead on the motorized side of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Postal Department's activities has risen

Speaker: NA
Text: from about Â£65,000 a year in those days

Speaker: NA
Text: to Â£4,600,000 a year to-day. A brick

Speaker: NA
Text: building for a post office cost Â£208 a

Speaker: NA
Text: square in those days, but the present cost

Speaker: NA
Text: is Â£548 a square for a prefabricated build-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. So it goes on. These factors have

Speaker: NA
Text: to be considered when we are talking about

Speaker: NA
Text: charges for postal services to-day.

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that it was with great regret

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government found it necessary to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase postal charges, but when one is

Speaker: NA
Text: confronted with the facts that I have out-

Speaker: NA
Text: lined one realizes that something must be

Speaker: NA
Text: done. Heavy losses are currently being

Speaker: NA
Text: incurred on most types of non-letter class

Speaker: NA
Text: mail, including publications, patterns,

Speaker: NA
Text: samples and merchandise, printed matter,

Speaker: NA
Text: registered articles and parcels. Even with

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposed increases, there will still be

Speaker: NA
Text: big losses on the carriage of that class of

Speaker: NA
Text: mail. Confronted with these facts, one can

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehend that in this day and age the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer and the Cabinet reluctantly had

Speaker: NA
Text: to decide to increase charges. I say again

Speaker: NA
Text: that they did so reluctantly. I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: it was with the greatest reluctance that they

Speaker: NA
Text: came to the decision to alter the rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now, Mr Chairman, I should like to

Speaker: NA
Text: say a few words about immigration. The

Speaker: NA
Text: proposal to increase the rate of intake of

Speaker: NA
Text: immigrants to 125,000 a year is something

Speaker: NA
Text: which, on my experience of immigrants in

Speaker: NA
Text: my electorate, appeals to me greatly. I

Speaker: NA
Text: know that there is some opposition to new

Speaker: NA
Text: people coming into this country. Very

Speaker: NA
Text: often they do not become assimilated

Speaker: NA
Text: rapidly. They tend to remain in their own

Speaker: NA
Text: groups, and sometimes they are difficult for

Speaker: NA
Text: us to understand. I have always main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained that the younger generation is the

Speaker: NA
Text: one which will provide more for this

Speaker: NA
Text: country. The older people come here with

Speaker: NA
Text: their trades and their skills, but the new

Speaker: NA
Text: generation of immigrants will be real Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians. In the Corio electorate, where

Speaker: NA
Text: we have some 10,000 new Australians, we

Speaker: NA
Text: find that the dux of the form, the head

Speaker: NA
Text: prefect, the scholarship winner or the

Speaker: NA
Text: winner of an award for distinguished work

Speaker: NA
Text: and outstanding sporting achievements is

Speaker: NA
Text: very often the child of new Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: is recognized that after a few months in

Speaker: NA
Text: school most of these children become so

Speaker: NA
Text: thoroughly Australian that only their

Speaker: NA
Text: names distinguish them from the native

Speaker: NA
Text: born children.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having said that, Mr Chairman, I should

Speaker: NA
Text: like to make a suggestion to the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Immigration. I suggest that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Immigration follow the

Speaker: NA
Text: example of the Repatriation Department,

Speaker: NA
Text: whose officers visit Geelong to give

Speaker: NA
Text: specialized advice to people who have

Speaker: NA
Text: dealings with the department or cases being

Speaker: NA
Text: that dealt with by the department. It was felt

Speaker: NA
Text: originally that this practice would not be

Speaker: NA
Text: found to be justified, but experience

Speaker: NA
Text: showed that it was a valuable aspect of

Speaker: NA
Text: the department's work. Sometimes when

Speaker: NA
Text: I am away from the electorate I am

Speaker: NA
Text: worried because urgent immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: matters have to wait to be cleared with

Speaker: NA
Text: the central offices of the department. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have a letter here concerning the work of

Speaker: NA
Text: the officers from the Repatriation Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. It is said that they work in Geelong

Speaker: NA
Text: long after the time each day when they

Speaker: NA
Text: would normally expect to finish, which

Speaker: NA
Text: must make them very late in returning to

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne. It would be a very good

Speaker: NA
Text: gesture on the .part of the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration if officers of that department

Speaker: NA
Text: could visit areas where there are numbers

Speaker: NA
Text: of immigrants with problems, in the same

Speaker: NA
Text: way as officers of the Repatriation Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment go to places outside Melbourne to

Speaker: NA
Text: help people with their repatriation

Speaker: NA
Text: problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the last speaker in this Budget debate,

Speaker: NA
Text: may I say that I feel that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Treasurer have presented a budget

Speaker: NA
Text: which, despite initial criticism, will be

Speaker: NA
Text: recognized eventually by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people as being in the best interests of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country, just as other budgets of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government have been recognized.

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Harold Holt) put-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the question be now put.

Text: (The Chairman- Mr G. J. Bowden.)

Speaker: NA
Text: FOREIGN AFFAIRS COMMITTEE.

Speaker: NA
Text: Message received from the Senate intiWheeler)

Speaker: NA
Text: mating that it had agreed to the following

Speaker: NA
Text: resolutions:-

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) That Senators Pearson and Vincent be dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: charged from attendance on the Joint Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: on Foreign Affairs.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) That Senators Buttfield, MCCallum and

Speaker: NA
Text: be members of the Joint Committee on Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) That, until such time as the vacancies

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Senate on the committee are filled

Speaker: NA
Text: by members of the Opposition, Senator Mattner

Speaker: NA
Text: be a member of the committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT.

Speaker: NA
Text: Administration of Territories-Repatriatio

Speaker: NA
Text: -Unemploymen t Benents.

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Harold Holt) proposed-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: Mr DALY
Text: Grayndler) [11.4] - Mr usefulness.

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, I wish to speak about a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: that has caused great concern and has been

Speaker: NA
Text: reported in the press at some length. I

Speaker: NA
Text: refer to certain allegations made by a

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment supporter against a senior

Speaker: NA
Text: ter of the Government. I have before me

Speaker: NA
Text: a report in to-day's Melbourne " Sun"

Speaker: NA
Text: under the heading " Relieve Hasluck

Speaker: NA
Text: Office Urges M.H.R.". The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member concerned is the honorable memthe

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Bowman ( Mr MCColm) who yesterParliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: day in this place made certain disturbing

Speaker: NA
Text: allegations against the competence and

Speaker: NA
Text: PAIRS. administration of the Minister for Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tories ( Mr Hasluck). According to the

Speaker: NA
Text: press report the honorable member said-

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . the Minister's period of usefulness as

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Territories has come to an end.

Speaker: NA
Text: An almost complete lack of good public rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions between the department, the Minister and

Speaker: NA
Text: the people has caused this position.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those are very grave and disturbing

Speaker: NA
Text: allegations by a Government supporter

Speaker: NA
Text: against a senior Minister in the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Not only has the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Bowman attacked the Minister, but he

Speaker: NA
Text: has also attacked the Minister's Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary Secretary, the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Calare ( Mr Howse), who has been the

Speaker: NA
Text: public relations consultant on this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition to the statement made by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Bowman, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Mitchell ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: accused the Minister of calling

Speaker: NA
Text: certain people in the Territory of Papua

Speaker: NA
Text: and New Guinea locusts. The Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: exchanges with the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Mitchell during the course of the latter's

Speaker: NA
Text: speech were very disturbing to both the

Speaker: NA
Text: Scott Minister and honorable members generally.

Speaker: NA
Text: I see that the Prime Minister ( Mr Menzies)

Speaker: NA
Text: is in the House. The Minister for Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: for tories evidently does not intend to defend

Speaker: NA
Text: himself, or perhaps he accepts the charges

Speaker: NA
Text: as true. The Prime Minister has made no

Speaker: NA
Text: statement on them, and the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bowman and the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Mitchell have not withdrawn

Speaker: NA
Text: n their allegations. Judging by the sour look

Speaker: NA
Text: on the face of the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bowman as I am speaking, I think that he

Speaker: NA
Text: will rise to his feet when I have finished

Speaker: NA
Text: my speech and confirm the fact that he

Speaker: NA
Text: thinks the Minister has outlived his

Speaker: NA
Text: In fairness to the people of this country,

Speaker: NA
Text: and particularly to the people in the Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: Gotory, something should be done about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minisallegations that have been made. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister should stand aside until such time

Speaker: NA
Text: as an investigation can establish whether

Speaker: NA
Text: of the charges made by the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers can be substantiated. As I have said,

Speaker: NA
Text: allegations also refer to the Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary, the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Calare. He has held the posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: the tion of Parliamentary Secretary to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for many years. We have come to

Speaker: NA
Text: know him in this Parliament as a man of

Speaker: NA
Text: integrity, but nobody is defending him now

Speaker: NA
Text: -h e has not even spoken for himself. If

Speaker: NA
Text: his silence does nothing else it lends sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stance to the charges that have been made,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they require explanation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister is receiving a big salary.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not complain about that; but if he is

Speaker: NA
Text: not a competent Minister, if he has lost the

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence of the people affected by his

Speaker: NA
Text: administration and if he no longer has the

Speaker: NA
Text: confidence of the rank and file of Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment supporters, there can be no excuse

Speaker: NA
Text: for his retention in the Ministry without

Speaker: NA
Text: some, investigation being made.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have not had any personal differences

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Minister as he does not come much

Speaker: NA
Text: within my ambit, but I do feel that in some

Speaker: NA
Text: matters regarding his administration he

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to overstep the mark. One of his

Speaker: NA
Text: most recent actions has been to interfere

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Northern Territory matrimonial

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs of a native girl and a man named

Speaker: NA
Text: Daly. I would have thought that this sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: ject of Daly, Gladys, Arthur and Mr Ward

Speaker: NA
Text: was well outside the scope of the Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Quite frankly I am somewhat disturbed

Speaker: NA
Text: about this matter. I intended to ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister specifically to state that I was not

Speaker: NA
Text: the Daly involved in this matter. I know

Speaker: NA
Text: that my colleague, the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for East Sydney ( Mr Ward) is disturbed

Speaker: NA
Text: because some people may think that he is

Speaker: NA
Text: the Ward in the case.

Speaker: NA
Text: I mention this matter because it shows

Speaker: NA
Text: that somewhere along the line the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: may be going off the beam. After all, it Is

Speaker: NA
Text: taking things too far when, in the middle

Speaker: NA
Text: of a debate on matrimonial legislation de-

Speaker: NA
Text: signed to maintain the family unit, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister is keeping lovers in the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory apart. In other words, the allehad

Speaker: NA
Text: gations concerning the Minister's administravery

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of his department evidently have some

Speaker: NA
Text: substance in them and the Minister should

Speaker: NA
Text: be asked to explain his attitude and to state

Speaker: NA
Text: what foundation there is for the charges

Speaker: NA
Text: that have been made.

Speaker: NA
Text: I mention this matter in passing, probably

Speaker: NA
Text: somewhat humorously, but nonetheless with

Speaker: NA
Text: a certain degree of conviction that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has overstepped the mark in

Speaker: NA
Text: respects in the Northern Territory. He

Speaker: NA
Text: not exactly inspired us with confidence in

Speaker: NA
Text: him by his handling of a matter as technical

Speaker: NA
Text: as a love affair. Surely, the persons con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned have certain human rights. There-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore, I ask the Prime Minister, who is in

Speaker: NA
Text: the chamber, to take some action in rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to the matter and to institute some

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of inquiry.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not wish to speak at greater length

Speaker: NA
Text: on this subject, because I note that other

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members are anxious to discuss

Speaker: NA
Text: it. No doubt my colleague from East

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney would like to discuss it, because

Speaker: NA
Text: he is involved personally. I should like to

Speaker: NA
Text: hear the honorable member for Bowman

Speaker: NA
Text: and the honorable member for Mitchell,

Speaker: NA
Text: who evidently have evidence to offer

Speaker: NA
Text: against the Minister, state their case. When

Speaker: NA
Text: all is said and done, the Minister has been

Speaker: NA
Text: charged by his own colleagues with being

Speaker: NA
Text: incompetent and not fit to carry out the

Speaker: NA
Text: work for which he has been chosen by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister. Surely the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: should be obliged to stand down until his

Speaker: NA
Text: administration is investigated and a full

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry is made into the very grave and

Speaker: NA
Text: disturbing charges which have been levelled

Speaker: NA
Text: against him by very reputable supporters

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Government. I think we are entitled

Speaker: NA
Text: to have an answer to those charges. I ask

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister to note my comments,

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly in relation to matters affecting

Speaker: NA
Text: the Northern Territory, and, above all else,

Speaker: NA
Text: to exonerate me from any association with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister in a matrimonial event that

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred in the Territory. I ask that my

Speaker: NA
Text: remarks be noted, that some evidence be

Speaker: NA
Text: furnished to the Parliament in support of

Speaker: NA
Text: the charges made, and that a full investiga-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion be held into the Minister's adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration so that justice shall be done to all.

Speaker: NA
Text: not intended to say anything about the

Text: I think he said that the Minister for Terri-

Text: fulness. I have yet to see evidence that he

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: They want action. They want greater

Speaker: NA
Text: results from the big businessman's Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that now occupies the treasury bench.

Speaker: NA
Text: When allegations were made against

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Privileges Committee believing that he

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: he had been completely exonerated. I was

Speaker: NA
Text: told by .some honorable members on this

Speaker: NA
Text: that he was getting around with a big

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: " He has undergone a very serious

Speaker: NA
Text: operation. Don't continue your criticism

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: further talk about it, he had a miraculous

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: My real purpose in rising was to refer to

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: that case the ex-serviceman concerned,

Speaker: NA
Text: Repatriation Board and then by the Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: patriation Commission, went before an en-

Text: appeal tribunal. He was the worst

Text: case of shell shock that I have ever seen.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. The application by the Professional Officers

Speaker: NA
Text: Association was filed in June, 1957, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service Arbitrator and was later, at the

Speaker: NA
Text: request of the association, referred to the Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciliation and Arbitration Commission. As I have

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed out previously, the claims not only of

Speaker: NA
Text: this association, but of a number of other asso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciations in the " white collar" and professional

Speaker: NA
Text: fields, are now before the Commission at the

Speaker: NA
Text: instance of the associations themselves and the

Speaker: NA
Text: President has done all in his power to find a

Speaker: NA
Text: means of expediting proceedings. Several attempts

Speaker: NA
Text: he made to cut corners were rejected by the

Speaker: NA
Text: claimant associations. The present position of

Speaker: NA
Text: the applications is that at a hearing before the

Speaker: NA
Text: president of the commission, in mid-July, certain

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals were put forward by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Council of Trade Unions and the " white collar "

Speaker: NA
Text: and professional associations namely that claims

Speaker: NA
Text: affecting the metal trades, aircraft industry and

Speaker: NA
Text: bank officials' awards would be heard and claims

Speaker: NA
Text: of the professional and " white collar" workers

Speaker: NA
Text: would be temporarily set aside. The President

Speaker: NA
Text: has listed the first-mentioned claims for 25th

Speaker: NA
Text: August. It is possible that a separate Bench will

Speaker: NA
Text: be constituted to carry forward the part-heard

Speaker: NA
Text: claims of the professional engineers: some aspects

Speaker: NA
Text: of their case are presently before the High Court.

Speaker: NA
Text: Postal Department.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr E. James Harrison asked the Post-

Speaker: NA
Text: master-General, upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. What facilities in the way of making social

Speaker: NA
Text: service payments, distributing income tax forms,

Speaker: NA
Text: collecting war service home remittances* &c, are

Speaker: NA
Text: provided by the Post Office for other departments?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Can he indicate in respect of each State

Speaker: NA
Text: what is the manhour content per week represented

Speaker: NA
Text: by each of the public facilities provided by his

Speaker: NA
Text: department outside the normal business associated

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Post Office?

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. What amounts are allowed to his department

Speaker: NA
Text: by outside departments for the services rendered?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Davidson -Th e answers to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member's questions are as

Speaker: NA
Text: follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. The Post Office provides the following

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities on behalf of other departments:-(a )

Speaker: NA
Text: Payment, of age and invalid pensions, war pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions, widows' pensions, child endowment, Naval,

Speaker: NA
Text: Military, and Air Force allotments; (b) collection

Speaker: NA
Text: of war service homes and repatriation payments,

Speaker: NA
Text: customs duty on postal articles; (c) sale of Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth taxation stamps, beer duty stamps,

Speaker: NA
Text: State duty stamps; (d) Commonwealth savings

Speaker: NA
Text: bank transactions.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Particulars of the manhour content repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented by each individual facility are not readily

Speaker: NA
Text: available as generally these activities are under-

Speaker: NA
Text: taken by postal counter and other staffs con-

Speaker: NA
Text: currently with their normal postal duties. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, including allowance for the time of non-

Speaker: NA
Text: official Post Office staff, the approximate total

Speaker: NA
Text: manhours spent each week on all work per-

Speaker: NA
Text: formed for all other departments in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: each State is as follows:-Ne w South Wales,

Speaker: NA
Text: 15,086; Victoria, 12,853; Queensland, 7,427; South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, 4,101; Western Australia, 5,670;

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania, 1,985.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. The department receives commission from

Speaker: NA
Text: each' outer department concerned, based iu some

Speaker: NA
Text: instances on the number of transactions and in

Speaker: NA
Text: Nature of Charge. Penalty.

Speaker: NA
Text: No penalty imposed

Speaker: NA
Text: from presenting honest and

Speaker: NA
Text: frank evidence (i.e., despatch of

Speaker: NA
Text: a demand that a witness retract

Speaker: NA
Text: certain evidence given to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Court)

Speaker: NA
Text: Twelve months' imprisonment on

Speaker: NA
Text: article and cartoon in the 13th each charge, sentenced to be

Speaker: NA
Text: January issue of the " Maritime served concurrently

Speaker: NA
Text: Worker "

Speaker: NA
Text: others on the total values handled. For the year

Speaker: NA
Text: 1957-58 the total value of these transactions was

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£253,000,000 and the commission earned

Speaker: NA
Text: amounted to Â£1,150,107.

Speaker: NA
Text: Telephone Services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Costa asked the Postmaster-General,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: How many telephones, for which applications

Speaker: NA
Text: have been made, are awaiting connexion to

Speaker: NA
Text: exchanges at (a) Bankstown, (b) Hurstville, (c)

Speaker: NA
Text: Peakhurst, and (d) Revesby?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Davidson -Th e answer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member's question is as

Speaker: NA
Text: follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: Tariff Board.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ward asked the Minister for Trade,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Has bis attention been drawn to allegauons

Speaker: NA
Text: made on oath by Mr A. Date, a former member

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Tariff Board, that in 1956 and 1957 mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the Tariff Board were guilty of suppress-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing evidence, violating the rule of law, altering

Speaker: NA
Text: the minutes of Tariff Board meetings and other

Speaker: NA
Text: improper practices?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Can he state whether Mr Date has for-

Speaker: NA
Text: warded communications to the Governor-General

Speaker: NA
Text: containing highly critical references to the integrity

Speaker: NA
Text: and capacity of the Mimster fot Trade?

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. If so, and in view of the serious nature of

Speaker: NA
Text: these allegations made by a former highly paid

Speaker: NA
Text: servant of the Government, does he propose to

Speaker: NA
Text: take any action in the matter; if not, will he

Speaker: NA
Text: explain his reasons for not doing so?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCEwen.^-Th e answer to the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's questions are as follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Yes. Since Mr Date was appointed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tariff Board early in 1954 he has addressed more

Speaker: NA
Text: than. 260 letters and telegrams of complaint and

Speaker: NA
Text: protest to His Excellency the Governor-General,

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable the Prime Minister, Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, Ministers, members of Parliament, per-

Speaker: NA
Text: manent heads and officers of various departments.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. I have received through the Official Secretary

Speaker: NA
Text: to His Excellency the Governor-General a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munication addressed to His Excellency by Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Date. I have been informed that Mr Date has

Speaker: NA
Text: also given copies to the Right Honorable H. V.

Speaker: NA
Text: Evatt, Q.C, Leader of the Opposition, the mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Yarra and the press.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. I do not propose any action based on this

Speaker: NA
Text: communication. There has been most careful con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration of Mr Date's complaints and requests

Speaker: NA
Text: and appropriate action has been taken from time

Speaker: NA
Text: to time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cairns asked the Minister f o r Trade,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. When Messrs. Date and Ely retired from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tariff Board did they each receive exactly the

Speaker: NA
Text: same treatment from the Superannuation Board

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of payments made to them?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. If not, in what way did the treatment differ

Speaker: NA
Text: and what was the reason for the difference?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCEwen -Th e answers to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members questions are as

Speaker: NA
Text: follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. No.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. The two cases were quite different. Mr Date

Speaker: NA
Text: was contributing to the Superannuation Fund

Speaker: NA
Text: under the Superannuation Act and sections 25

Speaker: NA
Text: and 40 of that act applied in his case. He has not

Speaker: NA
Text: attained the age of 60 years.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ely was a contributor to the Provident

Speaker: NA
Text: Account under the Superannuation Act and sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion 60Y of the act was applied. Mr Ely had

Speaker: NA
Text: attained the age of 65 years at the time of cessa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of duty.

Speaker: NA
Text: Office Accommodation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ward asked the Attorney-General,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. What was the cost of providing new office

Speaker: NA
Text: space for himself and his staff in Sydney?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. What was the cost of furnishing these offices?

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. What is the (a) area of the space provided

Speaker: NA
Text: and (b) number and designation of the persons

Speaker: NA
Text: occupying these offices?

Speaker: NA
Text: - Sir Garfield Barwick -Th e answer

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member's questions is

Speaker: NA
Text: follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1, 2 and 3. The Commonwealth Bank required

Speaker: NA
Text: the premises in Martin-place previously occupied

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Deputy Crown Solicitor. Consequently,

Speaker: NA
Text: portion of Phillip House, Phillip-street, has been ter

Speaker: NA
Text: remodelled to accommodate the Deputy Crown

Speaker: NA
Text: Solicitor and his staff. The removal of the Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Crown Solicitor to Phillip House made it highly

Speaker: NA
Text: desirable to provide offices for the AttorneyNavigation

Speaker: NA
Text: General and for the Solicitor-General in Phillip

Speaker: NA
Text: House in close proximity to the Library of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Crown Solicitor. Office accommodation

Speaker: NA
Text: has, therefore, been provided in Phillip House

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Law Officers and for three members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the personal staff of the Attorney-General, namely,

Speaker: NA
Text: private secretary, assistant private secretary and

Speaker: NA
Text: a typist. For this purpose a further portion of

Speaker: NA
Text: Phillip House was remodelled. The total space

Speaker: NA
Text: for the purpose of housing the Attorney-General,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Solicitor-General and the three members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Attorney's staff is 1,060 square feet; the total

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of the alterations (including electrical in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stallations, additional ventilation, toilet accommo-

Speaker: NA
Text: dation and passages and renovation of adjoining

Speaker: NA
Text: corridors) is Â£4,642; and the cost of furniture,

Speaker: NA
Text: furnishings and fittings (including shelving) is

Speaker: NA
Text: Colombo Plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Swartz asked the Minister f o r Supply,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Have arrangements been concluded for the

Speaker: NA
Text: supply of 600 diesel-driven centrifugal pumps to

Speaker: NA
Text: Burma?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Are these pumps being provided under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Colombo Plan?

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Has the contract been approved for manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facture of the pumps by the Toowoomba Foundry

Speaker: NA
Text: Proprietary Limited?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hulme -I t is correct that a contract

Speaker: NA
Text: has been let to the Toowoomba Foundry

Speaker: NA
Text: Propiretary Limited for the supply of 600

Speaker: NA
Text: diesel pumps to Burma under the Colombo

Speaker: NA
Text: Plan.

Speaker: NA
Text: "Himalaya" at Captain Cook Dock.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Costa asked the Minister represent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the Minister for Shipping and Trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: port, upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Is the Minister able to state the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: repairing the "Himalaya" at the Captain Cook

Speaker: NA
Text: Dock, Garden Island?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Is he also able to state whether the P. and O.

Speaker: NA
Text: Company will be reimbursed for the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: repairs?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hulme -Th e Minister for Shipping

Speaker: NA
Text: and Transport has advised that he is unable

Speaker: NA
Text: to state the cost of repairing the

Speaker: NA
Text: "Himalaya" at the Captain Cook Dock,

Speaker: NA
Text: to Garden Island, which would be a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: as between the P. and O. Company and

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of the Navy. He is also unable

Speaker: NA
Text: to state whether the P. and O. Company

Speaker: NA
Text: will be reimbursed for the cost of repairs.

Speaker: NA
Text: His department's concern in the mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: is limited to ensuring that

Speaker: NA
Text: the " Himalaya", as a passenger vessel,

Speaker: NA
Text: complies with the safety provisions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Act and for this purpose the

Speaker: NA
Text: repairs will be subject to inspection by

Speaker: NA
Text: departmental surveyors. The arrangement

Speaker: NA
Text: for the use of the Captain Cook Dock is a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter for the representatives of the owners

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Minister for the Navy to whom the

Speaker: NA
Text: question has been referred.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministerial Visits Overseas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ward asked the Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. What Commonwealth Mmisters made over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas visits, and what number of visits was made by

Speaker: NA
Text: each, from and including the year 1949-50?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. What was the cost in each

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure incurred by all persons who were

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the ministerial party or who went

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas on work associated with the ministerial

Speaker: NA
Text: visit?

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. In computing the cost of these tours, is it

Speaker: NA
Text: the practice to include expenditure upon (a) fares,

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) maintenance, (c) travelling or living away

Speaker: NA
Text: from home allowances and (d) cost of entertain-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Menzies -Th e answer to the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's questions is as follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1, 2 and 3. 1 direct the honorable member's

Speaker: NA
Text: attention to my replies to similar questions by

Speaker: NA
Text: him and which he will find in the "Hansards" of

Speaker: NA
Text: 17th February, 1953 and 31st May, 1955. I see

Speaker: NA
Text: no reason to add to what I have already said on

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: Royal Australian Air Force.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Ward asked the Minister for Air,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Has the Commonwealth been requested to

Speaker: NA
Text: consider re-equipping the Royal Australian Air

Speaker: NA
Text: Force with Northrop T.38 all-weather fighter air-

Speaker: NA
Text: craft with a ground speed of 1,520 miles per hour

Speaker: NA
Text: which could be produced in Australia with existing

Speaker: NA
Text: instance, including equipment?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. If so, what decision has been made in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of this proposition?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Osborne -Th e answer to the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's questions is as follows:-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Northrop T.38 aircraft is a supersonic two-

Speaker: NA
Text: seater trainer under trial for the United States

Speaker: NA
Text: Air Force. The manufacturing company has

Speaker: NA
Text: developed a supersonic fighter known as the

Speaker: NA
Text: N.156, from the basic design of the T.38. The

Speaker: NA
Text: prototype of the N.156 made its first flight on

Speaker: NA
Text: 30th July, 1959. It is one of several aircraft the

Speaker: NA
Text: makers of which are seeking orders from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Royal Australian Air Force. A sales team from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Northrop company recently visited Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: for this purpose.
